Test Prep or Perp? I am aghast: The Ethicist writes that an action that is ''unwise, unsafe and illegal'' -- taking unprescribed drugs to try to improve an LSAT score -- ''does not offend ethics.'' Even had he meant to say that were such a drug safe, legal and effective, then using it would be ethical, he would still be wrong. Tests exist (in theory) to measure current, and anticipate future, ability. Unless the test-taker is planning to spend her entire career on the drug, she is falsifying her credentials.

Donald H. Rumsfeld The former defense secretary, forced to resign by President Bush in November 2006, has an office in downtown Washington and is planning to write memoirs to be released in 2009. He is said to be talking to publishers on his own terms. ''Publishers are not interviewing Donald Rumsfeld, Donald Rumsfeld is interviewing publishers,'' said Raymond F. DuBois, a former deputy under secretary of defense.

ROSENZWEIG--Roy, The staff and board members of The American Social History Project (CUNY) mourn the passing of our cherished collaborator, advisor, and friend. A distinguished historian, visionary educator, lifelong radical, and supportive comrade, Roy counseled us in times of need and was our indispensable partner, board member, and co-author for more than a quarter-century. From our ''Who Built America?'' books, documentaries, and CDROMs through our many Web collaborations, Roy was our intellectual anchor and our inspirational and kind taskmaster. He has left his indelible mark on the field of history, democratic education, digital scholarship -and in our hearts. We send our deepest sympathy to Roy's wife Deborah, his family, and to his many colleagues in the History Department and Center for History and New Media at George Mason University.

The Posteverything Generation Nicholas Handler's embrace of the postmodernist academic canon inspired an overwhelming desire in me for the draft to be called up again. Context defines content. I'll see him and his classmates on the street in protest of a draft, voting en masse.
KLAPPER--Norma, passed on September 26. Beloved mother of Mitchell, Barbara and Janet (Ron). Cherished nana of Jesse and Robin. We will miss you forever.

Nearly a quarter of the trees the city plans to plant over the next decade as part of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's Million Trees NYC campaign will be on city streets. Based on a street tree census conducted last year, the city concentrated on neighborhoods that have the fewest trees and a high percentage of residents with asthma and other respiratory conditions. The parks department will plant 380,000 trees on existing parkland, and 400,000 will be planted in partnership with businesses, developers, and nonprofit and community groups.

SCOTESE--Mildred. The trustees, members of the Educational Foundation for the Fashion Industries, administration, faculty, staff and students of the Fashion Institute of Technology acknowledge with sadness the death of Mildred Scotese, wife of Peter Scotese, chairman emeritus of FIT's Board of Trustees and treasurer of the Educational Foundation. The Scotese family has been a great supporter of the College and an inspiration for generations of students. Their nurturing care and dedication to Millie have been yet another example for all of us to emulate. We extend our heartfelt sympathy.
SCOTT--Dagmar Pauline (Salo), on October 2, 2007 age 87, in New York City. Survived by her son Robert. Former employee of Beth Israel Medical Center Library.

10 P.M. (WE) GIRL MEETS COWBOY City women go in search of country loving in this new dating series set in the wilder part of the American West. Tonight, Marisa, Tracey, Halle and the sexy Russian Lina compete for the affection of Chris, an Arizona rough rider, by cooking Southwestern food, playing gunslinger poker, riding horses and completing daily ranching chores (while holding their noses). 8 P.M. (Fox) THE SIMPSONS Standing in line at the bank, Marge starts talking to an oddball (Steve Buscemi) who happens to be a robber. When he gets cornered by the police, Marge promises to visit him in jail if he'll turn himself in. But when he receives a call and the person on the other end (Ted Nugent) isn't Marge, he escapes to try to find her.

WITH nutritionists touting the Mediterranean diet, all sorts of restaurants have been calling their food Mediterranean in recent years. They are often Italian, but in the case of Wild Fig Mediterranean Grill, which opened in Garden City in July, the cuisines are Turkish and Greek. The owners, Ali and Gwen Ugan, are Turkish, as are most of the very personable servers. The Ugans also run Wild Fig Mediterranean Grill in Glen Cove; both restaurants serve the same menu.

ADLER--Richard Alfred, 53, of Leonia, NJ, on October 5, 2007, of lung cancer. Survived by his loving wife Jane (nee Parenti), and daughters Stephanie and Cynthia of Leonia, parents Antony and Claude of Paris, sister Caroll, brother-inlaw Vasco, nieces Samantha and Judith, and sisters-in-law Diane and Lynne. Born and trained as a chef in Paris, Richard was President of RMS-Touch, a hospitality and kiosk software company. An expert skier, he graced the trails of Hunter Mountain, near his Woodland Valley weekend retreat where he loved to entertain. A memorial service and interment will be private. Richard was one of a kind and will be dearly missed.

An art entry in the Week Ahead report on Sept. 30 referred incorrectly to a new program to collect contemporary art. It was announced last month by the Asia Society; it was not announced this month by the Japan Society. (The two are not affiliated.) Also, because of an editing error, the entry misstated the role of Reiko Tomii in the Japan Society's current exhibition, ''Making a Home: Japanese Contemporary Artists in New York.'' She is co-author of the catalog of the exhibition; she did not organize the show with Eric C. Shiner.

AS Congress debates legislation that would help borrowers in high-cost areas find more affordable mortgages, the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development is no longer insuring mortgages for borrowers who receive down-payment help from sellers. A cottage industry has emerged around these so-called ''down-payment assistance programs'' in recent years. When borrowers are considered good risks to be able to handle the monthly payments but lack enough money for a down payment, companies like the Nehemiah Corporation and AmeriDream advance the down-payment money to the buyers. Once the sale closes, the sellers reimburse the companies that amount, plus a fee.

ORLIAN--Alvin E., Herb's cherished friend for 54 wonderful years, and a very special friend to me. A kind, compassionate man who enjoyed life and its many rewards. A man of great integrity. I will miss him dearly. To Bobbi, his loving and caring wife, I extend my deepest sympathy and support. I wish for you to be comforted by the many happy memories we share. May they bring you and your family peace at this very difficult time. Best friends together again. Love, Linda Gallen ORLIAN--Alvin Ernest. We mourn the loss of the senior member of the West Point Jewish Chapel Fund Board of Directors. Al graduated from the United States Military Academy at West Point on June 1, 1943, one month short of his 20th birthday. Commissioned a 2nd Lieutenant in the infantry, he fought in Europe with the 29th Division. He was wounded twice and resigned as a Major in 1947 to enter the family business. Al was always there when we needed him. His significant donations helped build the Jewish Chapel at West Point and support the Jewish cadet programs. His wise, stern counsel will be sorely missed. Louis Gross, Chairman, West Point Jewish Chapel Fund ORLIAN--Alvin E., a beloved brother-in-law and uncle, we will miss you dearly. Bert, Randi and Scott ORLIAN--Alvin. The Officers and Members of the Board of Governors of the Jewish Home at Rockleigh, Russ Berrie Home for Jewish Living, note with profound sorrow the passing of our board member, longtime supporter, and very dear friend Al Orlian. Al was a special person who helped many Jewish in communal causes, and made special commitments to helping the elderly in our community. He will be missed. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Barbara and his entire family. May his name be for a blessing. Ary Freilich, President Charles P. Berkowitz, Executive Vice President ORLIAN--Alvin E. For more than 25 years of working with Alvin Orlian, I came to know him as a friend and as a man who cared genuinely for others. I know his wife and children feel his loss deeply, as do I. Howard M. Krams ORLIAN--Alvin E., a good and gracious man, a valued friend and client. Our condolences to his wife, Barbara and to all of his family. He will be missed. The partners & staff of H.J. Behrman & Co., LLP ORLIAN--Alvin E., of Shaddock Lane in Boca Raton, Florida died peacefully on October 12, 2007 in his home at 11:00am. He is survived by his wife, Barbara Orlian and his four daughters: Joan Hillman, Amy Orlian, Robin Chaplin and Stephanie Lessing and his five grandchildren: Jared Hillman, Chelsea Milkman, Kim Lessing, Zackary Milkman and Jesse Lessing. Alvin battled lung cancer for the past year and fought stoically until the end. He remained optimistic and retained his sense of humor until his final days. His wife and family will remember him as a deeply devoted, loving and courageous man who valued his family and friends above all else. His intelligence, honesty, strength and depth of character will forever remain in our hearts. Alvin graduated in 1943 from the West Point Military Academy. He served in World War II as a major in the United States Army and was one of the founders of the Jewish Chapel at West Point and served on the board of the Rockleigh Jewish Home. Donations would be warmly received by any of the charities dear to his heart including: The West Point Jewish Chapel. The Jewish Home at Rockleigh, the Anti-Defamation League, the United Jewish Federation and the American Cancer Society. The funeral will be held at the Beth Israel Memorial Chapel at Jog Road and Woolbright on Sunday, October 14 at 1:00pm.

GOLD--Elaine, died at home on October 9, 2007. Born October 8, 1924 in the tiny town of Morgan, Utah, she found her way to most corners of the earth in a life rich with adventure. A High School English teacher for many years, Elaine loved teaching, but she loved learning even more. Most especially, she loved her children, Scott and Leslie Cardell, and her late husband, Warren Gold. She will be deeply missed.

WEINSTEIN--Seymour ''Sy'', age 88, died at home September 25, 2007 of natural causes. He was a graduate of Brooklyn College and Teachers College, Columbia University, where he studied to be an art teacher. Those plans were shelved when he was drafted into the military in 1942. He served with the Army Air Force in the European Theater as a photographer, supervising a photo lab for the 485th Bombardment Group and was honorably discharged at the rank of captain. After the war, he married Dorothy Rosenberg and joined her family's hardware manufacturing business, General Hardware, where he designed packaging and tools. He spun off his own firm, MG Tool Company, a distributor of precision measuring tools. In recent years, he was a resident of The Hallmark Battery Park City after owning homes in Scarsdale and Croton-on-Hudson, NY and in Switzerland. He is survived by sons Gerald and Martin and their wives. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later time. Interment is at Mt. Eden Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Memorial donations may be made to the Seymour and Dorothy Weinstein Foundation.
108 West 2nd Street, No. 101 Los Angeles
BIGELOW--Otis on October 6, 2007 at the age of 87. Actor, director, and playwright. Survived by his life partner, Thierry Mahe.

TURER--Helen, on October 10, 2007, died peacefully at her daughter's home in Vermont. Wife of the late Leo. Mother of Robin Twery and the late Ricky. Grandmother of Naomi Twery, Timmy and the late Leo. Retired after 30 years as Purchasing Agent for NYC, she was a frequent participant in the IRP at The New School. We will miss her intellectual curiosity and her lively conversations. Services Sunday, 11:30am at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

THE NEWS Turkey reacted angrily after a House committee voted to condemn as genocide the mass killings of Armenians in Turkey that began during World War I. BEHIND THE NEWS Turkey signaled its displeasure by recalling its ambassador in Washington. The tension between the allies came at a particularly inopportune time, as Turkey mobilized its military for a possible incursion against Kurdish separatists in neighboring Iraq. American officials fear the action could ignite a wider war.

MEYERSFIELD--Judith (nee Lechtman), on October 13, 2007 after a long illness. She was the best pal of Irving, wonderful mother of Gail and Terry and Marc. Loving grandmother of Scott. Dear sister of Duke and Susan and Sandy and Pat. Services Sunday, 11am, Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, FL. Burial Monday, 11:15am, Montefiore Cemetery, St. Albans, NY. NEW RITUAL IN ROME To the Editor: Regarding: ''Forget the Vespa: Making Your 2 Wheels a Bike in Rome'' (Sept. 23): It was our last afternoon in Rome and we had one task to do. My husband, David, and I rented bikes from a small shop near the Campo de' Fiori. We rode several miles along the Tiber, on bumpy cobblestones and smooth bike paths, to the Ponte Milvio, the oldest bridge into the city, to take part in Rome's latest ritual.

RICHENTHAL--Arthur. October 11, 2007. Beloved husband of the late Vivian. Adoring father of Donald, David and Susan. Cherished grandfather of Daniel, Matthew, Kate, and Julliette. Loving companion of Joan Easton. Service Sunday October 14, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Vivian Richenthal Pulmonary Institute at Mount Sinai Hospital . RICHENTHAL--Arthur. The Gaisman Division of Pulmonary, Critical Care and Sleep Medicine of the Mount Sinai Medical Center and the Vivian Richenthal Research Institute deeply mourn the death of our extraordinary friend and advisor, Arthur Richenthal. His strong support and wisdom has enabled us to make major contributions in the battle against disabling Lung Disease. Victims of lung cancer, fibrosing lung diseases and the World Trade Center catastrophe have benefited from his commitment to research and patient care. He was a valuable, proud New York City treasure who had a rare blend of intelligence, incisiveness, wisdom, warmth, and humility. Our deepest sympathy to his children and grandchildren. Our staff, patients and all New York join them in grieving the loss of this pillar of our families. Michael C. Iannuzzi, M.D. Alvin S. Teirstein, M.D. RICHENTHAL--Arthur. Articulate, energetic, full of conviction and caring. He will be missed. Barbara & Donald Jonas RICHENTHAL--Arthur. The arts in NYC have lost a true friend. For a decade urban teen dancers of the free citywide Young Dancemakers Company have flourished with Arthur Richenthal's support and encouragement of this artistic opportunity. He will be missed, in our work, in our audience, in our hearts. Alice Teirstein, Director, Young Dancemakers Co. RICHENTHAL--Arthur, on October 12, 2007, with sadness and love. Shirley Leviton and family

NEGLECTED MEMORIAL To the Editor: Regarding: ''Footsteps | U.S. World War I Monuments in France: On Hallowed Ground, a Place of Painful Beauty'' (Sept. 30): Seven years ago, we retraced my father-in-law's ''steps'' in World War II through Normandy and then to Bastogne, Belgium, where he had served in Patton's Third Army. Afterward, my husband and I spent a day and drove from Verdun up to the Meuse-Argonne American Cemetery commemorating World War I.
Art Randy Kennedy

SHERWOOD--Blanche Burger, age 96, mother of Stanley and the late Louis and Paul, grandmother of Jonathan, Jennifer, Hayley, Ari and Daniel, wife of the late Morris and extended family. Donations to Abramson Center, North Wales, PA.

SOME of the best gift shops have a museum attached to them. Those stores offer an appealing array of wedding gifts for people who are tired of shopping in the same old places -- and might enjoy spending a couple hours in a museum as well. Some of the items they sell are reproductions of pieces in the museum's collections. Others are pieces in production that are also represented in the museum's collections. And for design buffs, something that was chosen by a curator might hold special cachet. The museums here all have Web sites, but it is also worth paying a visit to smaller local museum shops. 1.The Guggenheim Museum The stainless steel Crevasse vase, designed by the architect Zaha Hadid, is 16.5 inches tall; $249 at guggenheim.org or (800) 329-6109.

This is the first time in post-Soviet history when only the Kremlin decides who can participate and who can't. The Kremlin decides which party can exist and which party cannot. VLADIMIR A. RYZHKOV, a Russian democracy advocate and member of Parliament whose party has been banned. [20]

ZUCKERMAN--Dr. Herman Charles, beloved husband, father, and grandfather, died at home at age 93. He was a graduate of NYU (B.S. 1934, M.D. 1938) and served in the US Army as Captain, Medical Corps, 1942-1945. A pioneer of mammography, he initiated the use of diagnostic radiology for the breast in NYC in 1954, and was the sole user, teacher, and writer on the subject from 1954-1962. He is author of several publications, lectured worldwide, and continued to practice mammography until age 83. Admired at home and abroad for his charm, humor, and gentle manner, he is survived by his wife Janice of 57 years, his daughter Andrea Zuckerman, MD, son-in-law George Fulop, MD, and grandchildren Douglas and Kate Fulop. Services will be held at on Tuesday October 16, 4pm at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NYC.

We are going with a small group to visit Islamic architectural sites in Andalusia. I would also like to visit some special sites focusing on food, wine or olive oil, particularly between Córdoba and Granada. I haven't found it easy to do research on food in Spain via the Web. Do you have any suggestions for us?

New York Senate Republicans have been busily fanning the last embers of the ''Troopergate'' investigation. Their hearings on this matter are designed to reflect poorly on their most aggressive Democratic opponent, Gov. Eliot Spitzer. But a recent story in the Albany Times Union raised an interesting question: why are the politicians aiming their peashooters only at Mr. Spitzer? It also raised the distinct possibility that Troopergate is designed mainly to distract the public from the seedy behavior of other politicians in Albany. Since early summer, the headline issue has been whether Mr. Spitzer's team forced state troopers to somehow manufacture or ''create'' documents for the media. Those documents, from 2007, involved the lavish use for political purposes of state helicopters and state drivers by Senate Leader Joseph Bruno, New York's top elected Republican.

OLAN--Jamie, on October 3, 2007. Beloved daughter of Teena and Stanley Olan of NYC. We will always remember her kindness and compassion, her beautiful blue eyes and her love of music. She will be deeply missed by her aunts, uncles, cousins and many dear friends and neighbors. She will be forever in our hearts.

Tense Times at Bronxville High My goodness, parents scanning essays, making Halloween costumes at 3 a.m., tracking where other high-school students are applying and typing in their child's PIN number to check admission status (Susan Dominus, Sept. 30). This is truly over the top. When their children leave for college, will these parents be just an e-mail message away, planning their schedules and scanning their papers? And when they graduate, will they be there to help with the job applications, interviews and salary negotiations? Parents are supposed to be protectors, not promoters. Home should be a refuge, not a boot camp for college admissions.
Say Hi to Your Neighbors. Leave the Milfoil Behind. To the Editor:

Brennan Stays in the Race Hawaii's 42-35 overtime victory at San Jose State on Friday night has ramifications for both the Heisman Trophy and the Bowl Championship Series. It will be fascinating to see if the Warriors' comeback from a 14-point deficit in the final four minutes helps or hurts the Heisman chances of Hawaii quarterback Colt Brennan. He might have played his worst game of the season, but the conditions on the sloppy, wet field were not exactly ideal. Brennan completed 44 of 75 passes for 4 touchdowns and 545 yards, along with 4 interceptions. He also ran for a touchdown at the end of regulation to force overtime.

Why Teach for America? Negar Azimi asks if the growing success of Teach for America undermines public education, as alumni leave teaching for other professions or open high-achieving charter schools, perpetuating privatization. If true, this is certainly cause for concern. But Teach for America members are deeply committed to public education. Witness the recent appointment of an alumna, Michelle Rhee, as chancellor of the Washington, D.C., public schools. She has made no secret of her intent to remain in the city for years to come. Rest assured, Rhee's dedication will not stand alone among Teach for America Alumni.

Loving husband of Rhoda (nee Freeman) for 59 years, devoted father of Joanne, Philip and Debra, doting grandfather of Jeremy, David and Evan. Funeral on Monday, October 15, at 10:00am at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

Extra Credit I always enjoy your Style section, but it seemed odd to fit these college freshmen with $1,200 scarves and shirts they would probably never own in reality. I have this image of your fashion staff throwing clothes on these kids, snapping photos, ripping the clothes off and heading back to New York. CUPAIUOLO--Allison R., age 89, in Delhi, New York after a short illness. Survived by daughter and son-in-law, Rose and John Wadsworth. Grandchildren Allison (Tim) Linger, Christine (Denis) Pierro, and Joyce (Brett) Rosely; great-grandchildren Morgan and Robin Linger, Gianna and Alexandra Pierro, and Heidi Rosely; nieces and nephews Frances Wells, Carol Hensch, Kenny Lytle, Robert John Lytle, and Russell Sandberg and their families. Services and interment Friday in Delhi.

STRONG--Robert Livingston, of Westwood, Massachusetts, died on October 5, 2007. Born on June 2, 1914 to Theodore Strong and Cornelia Livingston Van Rensselaer Strong, of New Brunswick, New Jersey, he attended Rutgers Preparatory School and received his A.B. from Rutgers College in 1936. After graduating from Columbia Law School he served in the Judge Advocate General Corps in World War II, and was recalled to that service in the Korean War. For most of his professional career he practiced trust and estate law for the First National City Bank of New York. For a decade after retiring from Citibank he was Executive Director of the Cleveland H. Dodge Foundation, of New York City. His public service was long and dedicated. Mr. Strong served for many years as Treasurer of Lighthouse International, as President of the Charlotte Palmer Phillips Foundation, and as founding President of the Summit (New Jersey) Area Public Foundation. Mr. Strong married Mary Johnston Sutherland, of Atlanta, Georgia, in 1947. Their devoted marriage of 59 years ended only with her death in February, 2006. Mr. Strong is survived by his son, William S. Strong, and grandchildren Mary and Robert, all of Lexington, Massachusetts. A service will be held on Saturday, October 20th, at the Second Reformed Church in New Brunswick, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, gifts in memoriam to Lighthouse International, www.lighthouse.org, would be greatly appreciated.
HAYDN: Symphonies Nos. 88-92;

WALLACE--Shane M., husband of Dana nee McAleer and father of son James, died Tuesday at his home in Greenwich, CT. He was 38. Mr. Wallace succumbed after a valiant fight with brain cancer for more than a year. At the time of his death, Mr. Wallace was the Head of J.P. Morgan Chase's Telecommunications Mer gers & Acquisitions Group. In an era when many investment bankers move from one firm to another, Mr. Wallace spent his entire career at J.P. Morgan. Mr. Wallace was a graduate of Bronxville High School and Dartmouth College. At Dartmouth Mr. Wallace was a member of Psi Upsilon fraternity and writer for The Dartmouth Review newspaper. A lifelong Republican, Mr. Wallace also worked during his undergraduate years as an intern for then Vice President Dan Quayle. Mr. Wallace was an accomplished wing shot, fly fisherman and skier whose passion for the outdoors gave countless hours of joy to him and those who had the privilege of spending time with him in the field, stream and slope. Mr. Wallace is survived by his wife, Dana; son, James; his mother, Sheila Riley of New York City; his father, Ronald and stepmother, Sue of Yellville, Arkansas; and his sister, Amanda and her partner Tamara of New York City. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made in his memory to Accelerate Brain Cancer Cure. Donation information is available by either calling 202-419-3140 or accessing the website at www.abc2.org. Funeral services will be held at 2pm on Monday, October 15, at Christ Church Greenwich, 254 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT.

GIVEN--The Reverend Davis. On October 10, 2007, The Reverend Davis Given died peacefully at the age of 87 with his family at his side. The son of the late Dorothy and William Barns Given, Jr., he is survived by his sister Dorothy Given Kee of Dallas, Texas, his niece Dorothy Davis Kee of Herndon, Virginia, nephew William Given Kee of Charleston, South Carolina, and nephew John and his wife Louise Kee of Dallas, Texas, great-nieces Hilary Davis Kee, Elizabeth Given Kee, Sarah Wright Kee, and great-nephew John Rutherford Kee. A graduate of St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire and Yale University 1942. He served in WWII with the Eighth Air Force in England. He graduated from General Theological Seminary in New York City. Father Given was head of the Navajo Good Shepherd Mission at Fort Defiance, Arizona, assistant priest at Trinity Church in New York City and Chaplian at Morningside House and Amsterdam House. In retirement, he was a priest at St. Luke in the Fields. A memorial service will be held on Tuesday, October 16 at 4pm at St. Luke in the Fields Episcopal Church, 487 Hudson St., New York, NY 10014. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Music or Outreach Programs at St. Luke's.

WOODS--Mary Lou. A widely respected humanitarian and social activist died peacefully in her home in Greenwich, CT on October 9, 2007, comforted by family and friends. She was 76 and had been fighting pancreatic cancer. Mary Lou worked all her life for positive social change. A dedicated Democrat, Mary Lou served for 17 years on the Board of Estimate and Taxation (BET) for the Town of Greenwich. She was Campaign Chairwoman for the winning election of the first female Selectman of Greenwich, Ms. Ruth Sims, the first Democrat to hold that position in 75 years. Mary Lou served on the Boards of the Greenwich NAACP, the WestchesterSouthern Connecticut Oberlin Alumni, the YWCA, and the Greenwich Symphony. For fifty years, she was a very active member of the League of Women Voters, serving many terms on its Board. Even while engaged in her battle against cancer, Mary Lou chaired the League's extensive study of the Greenwich BET, which was a very important project to her: she believed that government must constantly improve to better serve the community. She is survived by her four children (Barbara of New York, NY; Sarah of Baltimore, MD; Richard of Springfield, VA; and Clifford III of the Cayman Islands, BWI), her son-and daughters-in-law, her six grandchildren and her former husband, Clifford Woods, Jr. Mary Lou's supportive friends were a very important part of her life. She will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am, Sunday, December 9, 2007, in the Auditorium of the Greenwich Library, 101 West Putnam Avenue, Greenwich Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to: the Chamber Players of Greenwich Symphony; The Hole in the Wall Gang Camp; or Doctors Without Borders USA.

Re-engineering Engineering I was so engrossed and enthusiastic as I read John Schwartz's article about Franklin W. Olin College of Engineering that when I reached the last two paragraphs, I was dismayed. The concerns of Richard K. Miller, the school's president, about the employability of his students and about their prospects of clicking with the corporate culture of large firms resonated with me. The solution is for Olin to become not just a college but also a semi-independent engineering firm. Graduates could be guaranteed a two- or three-year position at the Olin firm, where they would execute real engineering work for paying clients in an environment that would serve as a bridge between college and their eventual independent careers. When they were ready to strike out on their own, graduates wouldn't be looking for entry-level positions; they'd be established professional engineers with completed commercial projects on their résumés.
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

Near the end of Paris Fashion Week, the city fell under a spell on Oct. 6 as citizens celebrated Nuit Blanche, the annual all-night festival of arts and music. It was warm out, and throngs filled the streets and the Tuileries Gardens, which were illuminated by thousands of fires in flowerpots. A huge candlelit chandelier hung at the Concorde gate, above. The museums were open and free; actors performed plays from the balcony of the Comédie-Française, bottom, second from far right. Outdoor restaurants, open until dawn, were packed. The festivities coincided with the annual invasion of fashion luminaries in the favorite color of Paris, black. Even Anna Piaggi of Italian Vogue (in the Nike T-shirt at far right), known for her audacious hues, wore it -- with a green fox scarf. Carine Roitfeld, the editor of French Vogue, top left, in front of the tricolor, was among the women in square shoulder pads. Shapely jersey dresses were everywhere, and in the cool morning, women broke out their full-skirted coats. And if New York women are into handbags, Parisians are all about shoes, including the Goths, right, shod in their monkey fur and spikes.

AT THE DENVER MEMORIAL DAY TANGO FESTIVAL, CHEESMAN PARK, MAY 27, 2007 Cassandra Kagiyama, 20, a student at Arizona State University, dances with Paul Vladimirsky, a fellow student: ''I started tango my second semester, and it really kept me interested in college: I needed more balance, I needed an outlet, I needed a place to be present and connect with people on a more personal level. In Denver, we took two classes a day, focusing on one concept per class, like the embrace or how to walk. Afterward, we went to two milongas, formal dances. So I'd just been dancing nonstop. My feet hurt so much. But it was a beautiful setting and I was really excited to apply everything I'd learned. As a compromise, we kicked off our shoes and danced in the pool. Without music, you focus more on the sound of your feet, you just engage more of your senses. The splashing of the water kept a certain rhythm that was easy to keep up with.'' As told to Seth Kugel

HARDWICK--Dora Storer, known to friends and family as Dosie, died at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York City on Wednesday, October 10th. She was 83. A former resident of the Oranges, Bay Head and Mantoloking, New Jersey, she is remembered for her warmth, contagious enthusiasm and enduring grace, a quality that did not elude her during a long battle with vascular dementia. A graduate of the Beard School (now Morristown-Beard), and Kean University, from which she received a B.A. summa cum laude at 58, she served as President of the Alumnae Association of the Beard School and was a longtime member of the Junior League of Short Hills and the Oranges, where she served on numerous committees, including Children's Theater. Its mission was to introduce live theater to children who might not otherwise have had the opportunity. She was also a cast member in productions that toured the state. A forty year member of the Garden Club of the Oranges and Short Hills, she served terms as treasurer and vice-president and was a prize-winning floral designer and accredited flower show judge with the Garden Club of America. She is predeceased by her husband, Ambrose H. Hardwick, Jr., and survived by her daughters, Cynthia Duer Hardwick of Manhattan and Mary Robinson Hardwick of Pelham, New York, and a brother, Dr. Robert Winthrop Storer, of Ann Arbor, Michigan. At the request of the deceased, no memorial service is scheduled. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Weill Medical College of Cornell University, 525 E. 68th St. Rm. F610, New York, New York, 10065, Attn: Dr. Norman Relkin for Alzheimer's research.

QI have a problem with the water temperature in the shower of my co-op. Without warning, it shifts from comfortable to scalding. I've learned that a new mixing valve, installed inside the wall, can take care of the problem. The building's managers first told me that since the apartment has its original plumbing, the co-op would be responsible. Then they came back and said it was my responsibility. Who should pay for this? A While most proprietary leases provide that the co-op corporation is responsible for plumbing within the walls of the apartment -- unless the plumbing was installed or modified by the tenant-shareholder -- some make the shareholder responsible for the shower assembly, including the mixing valve, said Alexander Suslensky, a Manhattan lawyer. So, he said, whether the co-op is responsible for installing a new mixing valve will depend on the specific terms of the proprietary lease.

LORE--Martin Maxwell, born June 13, 1914 in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, died peacefully at home on October 8, 2007. An attorney and CPA, he graduated from the University of Wisconsin and the University of Wisconsin Law School before earning a Masters in Taxation from Harvard law School. He was a Lieutenant Commander in the United States Navy and worked at the Treasury Department before making New York his home. He was in private practice in New York City for more than 50 years, authored two books on taxation, and was listed in Who's Who in America. He leaves behind his beloved wife, Doris, his children Cathy Lore and Amy Kovner (nee Lore), his sonin-law, Jeffrey Kovner, as well as his grandchildren, Nicholas and Kristin, and granddaughter-in-law, Georgia. His family meant the world to him and he to them. We will miss the sweet, gentle man with the warm smile.

DONOVAN--Richard P., Essex, CT, Richard Cushman Priddie Donovan, 86, died Sunday, October 7th in Essex, CT, after a brief illness. He moved to Essex in 2003 from Pelham, NY, his home for 50 years. He was an attorney practicing municipal bond law in New York City. In 1953 Dick Donovan joined the law firm of Sullivan, Donovan, Henehan, and Hanrahan, which his father Gerald Donovan co-founded in 1928. Dick practiced there his entire career, retiring as the senior partner in 2003, when he closed the firm. For many years the firm was known simply as Sullivan Donovan. In 1948 he graduated first in his class from Cornell University Law School, where he was a member of the Law Review. Before entering private practice, he served as a staff attorney to the SEC in Washington, DC, and as an Assistant US Attorney in the Southern District of NY. From 1969 to 2003 Dick served on the Board of Directors of NY Society for Prevention of Cruelty to Children and as its Secretary from 1971 to 1991. He served on the Board of Trustees of New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center (now the Sound Shore Medical Center of Westchester) from 1974 to 2003. Dick was born in New York City on August 14, 1921 to Gerald Donovan and the former Louise Wiess Priddie of Beaumont, TX. He grew up in New Rochelle, NY, and graduated from Iona Preparatory Academy. A 1942, Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Brown University, he was also a member of Delta Kappa Epsilon. In WWII he served on the battleships USS Alabama and USS South Dakota in both the Atlantic and Pacific theaters. A Navy Lieutenant at war's end, Dick taught flying at the Naval Air Station in Jacksonville, FL. His great-uncle, Harry Wiess of Beaumont, Texas, was a founder of the Humble Oil Company, later part of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, now ExxonMobil. Dick was a member of the NYC, New Rochelle, and NYS Bar Associations. For many years he belonged to Yale Club of NYC, Wykagyl Country Club in New Rochelle, and The Dunes Club in Narragansett, RI. He was married to the former Edythe Walden Thurber, who died in 2005. He is survived by five children and their spouses/partners: Patrick F. Donovan (and Frances Donovan) of Wakefield, RI; Nena Donovan Levine (and Jeffrey E. Levine, Esq.) of W. Hartford, CT; Caroline Donovan, Esq., (and Deborah Burke Karel) of Goldens Bridge, NY; Margaret Donovan (and Sean Donovan) of N. Dorset, VT; and William D. Donovan, M.D., (and Lisa M. Donovan, M.D.) of Old Lyme, CT; by ten grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. A brother, William A. Donovan, Esq. of White Plains, NY, also survives. He was predeceased by his daughter Edythe W. Donovan, Esq. Services are Saturday, October 13 at 10:30 a.m. at Christ the King Church, 1 McCurdy Rd, Old Lyme, CT. A reception will follow. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Brown University Annual Fund, Box 1893, Providence, RI 02912, 800-662-2266 and/or the Essex Meadows Employee Appreciation Fund, 30 Bokum Rd., Essex, CT 06426. Services by Robinson, Wright & Weymer Funeral Home, Centerbrook.

So I did what I usually do when faced with a new piece of technology I don't understand: I hired a tech-savvy assistant. Together, we studied how authors were using Facebook. I showed her some groups started by authors, and she became my field guide and interpreter, helping me understand the mores and customs of this foreign land.

John Edwards's campaign today trumpeted some good news - it received the endorsement of the S.E.I.U. State Council in Iowa. While the Service Employees International Union represents just 2,000 workers in Iowa, the Edwards campaign sees this endorsement as important because it expects S.E.I.U. locals in other states to announce their endorsement of Mr. Edwards as well - with further endorsements expected later this afternoon, with California seen as the biggest plum.

It was produced by Jesse Thorn (aka The Sound of Young America) and features the voices of, among others, John Hodgman. You can find more info here.

What Tolstoy has done in W&P is somehow to render universal the peculiarity of Russian life and society. The more one knows about the sociability, institutions, and politics of the Russian empire under the tsars, the more one comes away perplexed that such a distinctive milieu, in such a particular time, could become - and could remain - an accessible parable of human existence.

I'm not much of an after-dinner drinks guy, having learned some years ago that for my own body chemistry they can make the difference between delicious after-dinner contentment and a descent into dull torpor, hangover and worse. But I do make the occasional exception for the category of beverages known as digestives.

The Board is a new blog, written by members of the New York Times editorial board. The board's 19 members write the Times editorials, and occasional signed pieces, under the direction of Editorial Page Editor Andrew Rosenthal . The board meets as a group at least three times a week, Monday, Tuesday, and Thursday mornings, to discuss editorial positions. We also invite guests -- world leaders, CEO's, grass-roots activists, writers and musicians -- to talk about a wide range of subjects.

Today we have answers to your questions from Nick Young, the Founding Editor of China Development Brief, a nonprofit newsletter "devoted to strengthening constructive engagement between China and other countries." Two versions of the newsletter, one in English and the other in Chinese, were edited from Beijing until July 2007, when the authorities in China ordered publication to cease.

Goldman Sachs astounded Wall Street last month by reporting a 79 percent increase in net income at a time when most of its peers had to write down billions in losses. In reporting its earnings, the investment bank chalked up its huge gains in part to its bets against mortgage-backed securities.

He blogged and vlogged as he went, and you can see his reports at www.nytimes.com/twofortheroad. Tektronix's board is unanimously recommending that shareholders vote to accept the offer, whose price represented a 34 percent premium to Tektronix's closing share price Thursday.

Discovery Communications, the cable-channel operator, said Monday it would buy HowStuffWorks, a Web site that explains the inner workings of almost anything. Financial terms were not disclosed, but The Wall Street Journal reported the price tag was $250 million.

As the anniversary of the 1987 market crash approaches, The New York Times takes a look at Paul Tudor Jones II, the billionaire hedge fund manager, who returned 200 percent for his investors that year and drew a payday of an estimated $100 million for the year, an almost unheard-of sum at the time.

In September 1999, a fledgling activist investor, Warren Lichtenstein, began a campaign to improve the share value of a small-capitalization company, United Industrial, a maker of unmanned vehicles for defense and training systems. Eight years, two proxy contests and one blocked deal later, the company was sold for $1.1 billion to Textron.

In Nascar, Ryan Newman was leading the Bank of America 500 when he crashed with three laps to go, and Jeff Gordon took over from there, holding off Clint Bowyer to win at Lowe's Motor Speedway. Gordon now leads his teammate, Jimmie Johnson, by 68 points. Only three drivers have a realistic shot at the Cup: Gordon, Johnson, and Bowyer.

Biogen Idec, the biotech company worth more than $20 billion, is up for sale and Carl C. Icahn has the company in his sights.

We are in the midst of a stretch of, frankly, rather dull World Series. The losing team over the last four years has won a total of three games -- two for the Yankees in 2003 and one for the Tigers last year -- and the outcomes never seemed remotely in doubt. The casual fan, or even a fan without an inherent rooting interest, might find this a disappointment. Marlins, Red Sox, White Sox and Cardinals fans have a different opinion.

Citigroup, confirming its previous forecast of a big slide in profits, reported a 57 percent decline in net income for the third quarter on Monday. Before I plunge into the profound questions Professor Tanenhaus has laid before our little seminar  or, more likely, defer to my more literate partners in this venture  may I just say that "War and Peace" is a heckuva book? Somehow I managed to make it through college and into late middle age without having read "War and Peace." Though Tolstoy wrote one of my favorite pieces of fiction ("Anna Karenina") and one of my least favorite (that misogynous chastity pamphlet, "The Kreutzer Sonata"), W&P was always too intimidating in scale, and too show-offy to bring to the beach. The Russian language I studied to work in Moscow was more functional than literary, and while my tutors dosed me with just enough Pushkin to nod appreciatively when Evgeny Onegin came up in conversation  more often than you'd think  the master of Yasnaya Polyana was scarcely mentioned. (Although I was duly warned that Tolstoy, pronounced as we pronounce him in the West, means "thick" or "fat," and could be appropriately used to describe "War and Peace," but in Russian the writer's name is pronounced with the emphasis at the back.) While I'm owning up to my lack of qualifications, I should add that I have not written a literature term paper in 40 years, and that I have never participated in a book club. So I came to this assignment with a mixture of guilt, dread and ignorance.

A front-page article on Saturday about criticism of the war effort in Iraq by Lt. Gen. Ricardo S. Sanchez, a former top commander there who has since retired, misstated the year in some editions that his successor, Gen. George W. Casey Jr., took command there. It was in mid-2004, not mid-2006.

Lorena Ochoa clinched her second straight L.P.G.A. Tour player of the year award with a runaway victory in the Samsung World Championship in Palm Desert, Calif. Successfully defending her title in the elite event, Ochoa shot a closing six-under-par 66. The title was her seventh of the year and 16th over all. She finished at 18-under 270. Michelle Wie finished with by far her best round of the tournament, a 71 for an 18-over total to jump her into 19th place in the 20-player event.
An American Indian tribe awaiting federal recognition wants to build a casino at the Aqueduct Racetrack in Queens.

Bernhard Langer matched the Champions Tour scoring records for a 54-hole event, with an eight-under 64 for an eight-stroke victory in the Administaff Small Business Classic in Spring, Tex. Langer finished at 25-under 191 to match the scoring marks for relation to par and low score. Mark O’Meara (68) was second, and Tom Kite (69) third at 16 under.

Indiana Coach Kelvin Sampson will not receive a $500,000 raise and his team will lose one scholarship for next season after violating N.C.A.A.-imposed sanctions on phone calls. The action announced by the university yesterday was the second time in 17 months he had been penalized for improper telephone calls.

Ernie Els won his seventh HSBC World Match Play Championship title by beating Ángel Cabrera, 6 and 4, in Virginia Water, England. Els took the lead on the first hole and he stayed in front all day to claim his first win of the year.

Alec Kessler, a star at Georgia who played four years for the Miami Heat before becoming an orthopedic surgeon, died after collapsing during a pickup game. He was 40. He appeared to have had a heart attack Saturday in Pensacola, Fla., and was pronounced dead a short time later at the hospital, the university said yesterday. The 6-foot-11 Kessler was the captain of Georgia’s 1990 Southeastern Conference championship team and a first-round N.B.A. draft pick.

Serena Williams was undone by errors and lost the Kremlin Cup final in Moscow, 5-7, 6-1, 6-1, to Elena Dementieva. Top-seeded Nikolay Davydenko gave Russia a sweep of the men’s and women’s titles by beating Paul-Henri Mathieu, 7-5, 7-6 (9).

George McNeill, a 32-year-old rookie, won his first career PGA Tour title, shooting a five-under-par 67 for a 23-under 264 total and a four-stroke victory over D. J. Trahan at the Frys.com Open in Las Vegas. McNeill earned $720,000 for the victory in a tournament that did not feature one top-20 player.

Ivo Karlovic had 27 aces and beat Thomas Johansson, 6-3, 3-6, 6-1, to win the Stockholm Open. The 6-foot-10 Karlovic, the tallest player on the ATP Tour, has a tour-leading 1,135 aces this year. Goran Ivanisevic set the record in 1996 with 1,477 aces.

General Electric Company has promised to spend $25 million to help refurbish several Bridgeport neighborhoods, The Connecticut Post reported yesterday. The newspaper, which obtained three proposals for development plans under the state Freedom of Information Act, reported yesterday that the award of the money is expected to be announced in November or December. The Connecticut Housing Finance Authority is researching several developers and reviewing plans and budgets, the newspaper reported.

A Stamford man surrendered to the police yesterday and was charged with murder in the stabbing death of his ex-girlfriend, the state police said. The man, Juan Botello, 20, also was charged with larceny, the police said. Mr. Botello and his ex-girlfriend, Layla R. Banks, 21, of Greenwich, separately attended a party at the Sheraton Stamford Hotel, Capt. Richard Conklin said at a news conference yesterday. Her body was discovered just after 6 a.m. Saturday in a service hallway near the main lobby, the police said. Ms. Banks broke off the relationship with Mr. Botello a week ago, Captain Conklin said.

A 39-year-old man armed with a gun was found shot to death on a street in Paerdegat Basin on Saturday evening, the police said. The shooting occurred shortly before 8 p.m. on Paerdegat Fourth Street near Canarsie, the police said. The victim was identified as Patrick Gordon, who was visiting his girlfriend and whose last known address was on nearby East 83rd Street, the police said. Mr. Gordon had a gun in his waistband when his body was found, the police said. He had been shot several times and was pronounced dead at the scene. There were no arrests yesterday.

Denouncing the ease with which minors can buy alcohol in New York, State Senator Jeff Klein and City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn called for changes yesterday in rules that govern the sale of identifications that would make the sellers liable for damages caused by their customers under the influence of alcohol. Mr. Klein said investigators working for his office were able to purchase identification cards at stores around the city with little or no verification from the sellers. “A young person walks into one of these stores and fills out an application, and within 15 minutes they receive a very official-looking identification card,” Senator Klein said. He said he would introduce legislation making the identification sellers liable for damages in civil court.

A homeless man who was set on fire as he slept outside an East Harlem church on Oct. 5 has died from his injuries, the police said yesterday. The man, Felix Najera, 49, was taken to NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell Medical Center with burns over 75 percent of his body, and died in the hospital on Oct. 9, the authorities said. A Bronx man, Israel Torres, 29, has been charged with attempted murder, the police said, but now that Mr. Najera has died, a more serious charge is expected. The charges had not been changed as of yesterday. Investigators said Mr. Torres poured flammable liquid on Mr. Najera and ignited it as he slept on cardboard in front of Bethany Christian Church on East 103rd Street, but the motive for the attack remained unclear.

ADLER--Richard Alfred , 53, of Leonia, NJ, on October 5, 2007, of lung cancer. Survived by his loving wife Jane (nee Parenti), and daughters Stephanie and Cynthia of Leonia, parents Antony and Claude of Paris, sister Caroll, brother-inlaw Vasco, nieces Samantha and Judith, and sisters-in-law Diane and Lynne. Born and trained as a chef in Paris, Richard was President of RMS-Touch, a hospitality and kiosk software company. An expert skier, he graced the trails of Hunter Mountain, near his Woodland Valley weekend retreat where he loved to entertain. A memorial service and interment will be private. Richard was one of a kind and will be dearly missed.

KRAMER--Paul . Beloved husband of Helen, father of David and Nina, brother of Bren and Mark, uncle to four nieces and three nephews, died October 13, 2007 after a long illness. A producer and filmmaker, he started at the D'Arcy Advertising Agency in 1961 and then moved into the filmmaking business, crafting commercials, industrials, and educational films. He owned and partnered in a succession of filmmaking enterprises, the most recent being First Light Pictures. He had a lifelong affection for cars and boats, but nothing exceeded his love for family and friends, of which he had a prodigious number. Paul was just a classy guy, extraordinarily and genuinely interested in the lives of all those he encountered. He had a sweetness that pervaded every relationship he had, and a delight in life that made his blue eyes twinkle. When he walked into a room, it would light up with his energy. He was five-foot-six, and people a foot taller looked up to h im. He will be missed terribly, but he leaves this world with the love and good wishes of so many. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday October 17, 2007 at 1pm at The Gutterman Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY 11797. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center-Research.

ZUCKERMAN--Dr. Herman Charles , beloved husband, father, grandfather, and brother, died at home at age 93. He was a graduate of NYU (B.S. 1934, M.D. 1938) and served in the US Army as Captain, Medical Corps, 1942-1945. A pioneer of mammography, he initiated the use of diagnostic radiology for the breast in NYC in 1954, and was the sole user, teacher, and writer on the subject from 1954-1962. He is author of several publications, lectured worldwide, and continued to practice mammography until age 83. Admired at home and abroad for his charm, humor, and gentle manner, he is survived by his wife of 57 years, Janice, daughter Andrea Zuckerman, M.D., son-in-law George Fulop, M.D., grandchildren Douglas and Kate Fulop, and brother Seymour Zuckerman. Services will be held on Tuesday October 16, 4pm at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76th St., NYC.

EHRENFELD--Robert . Pioneer Scientist, Manhattan Project. A chemist on the Manhattan Project and president of Halocarbon Products Corporation, died October 6, 2007 at his home in New York. He was 86. While on the Manhattan Project at Columbia University, he devised a compound that even today has widespread industrial uses. This led to his founding Halocarbon in New Jersey in 1950. Halocarbon led the early production of the first non-ozone depleting refrigerant. The company's products, under Dr. Ehrenfeld's guidance, were used in the Apollo missions. Survivors include Elizabeth, wife of 52 years, three daughters and two grandchildren. EISENSTADT--Barbara Leah, beloved wife of Marvin, loving mother of Jeff, Jill, Debra and Steven. The Jets could not have diagrammed a better slump-busting situation: They were in the shadow of the Philadelphia Eagles' end zone late in the fourth quarter with a chance to tie or win the game, and Laveranues Coles, who seemingly has a telepathic connection with quarterback Chad Pennington, was running a fade pattern into the end zone. Coles was in single coverage on fourth-and-1 from the Eagles' 4. Perfect, Pennington thought. It was a timing play they had completed like clockwork many times before, but on Sunday, as has been the case all season, the magic was missing.

Updated, 6:48 p.m. | Debbie Almontaser, who resigned under fire from her position as principal of the Khalil Gibran International Academy, the city’s Arabic-themed school, spoke out publicly for the first time today since her case attracted headlines and protests from opposing sides. Ms. Almontaser, a Yemeni-American with an extensive record of educational and community work in Brooklyn, stepped down on Aug. 10 amid a controversy that erupted after she was quoted defending the use of the word “intifada” as a T-shirt slogan.Ms. Almontaser released a prepared statement through her lawyer and later read the statement from the steps of City Hall in a news conference that started soon after 5 p.m. In the statement, she said that she was forced to participate in an interview with The New York Post, that the newspaper misrepresented her views and that city officials then threatened to shut down the academy if she did not resign.

Monday's late-night call between President Bush and Prime Minister Manmohan Singh is prompting desperate diagnoses regarding the landmark nuclear agreement they've been working on.

"Ten more days left to punting season," the long-time Oxfordshire resident mulled as he lead a group of us on a nature walk, complete with dogs and muddied Wellington boots, through University Parks. We were blessed with warm, clear weather on Saturday as we tromped past duck ponds, through pastures and over rickety bridges. But, with typical English pessimism, we were also told it would not last.
AT&T could pay up to $29.1 billion, or $65 a share for EchoStar Communications, Citigroup analyst Jason Bazinet wrote in a research report Tuesday.

I'm thinking of going to Sicily and Puglia the latter part of October. I'd love any information about these two places, especially the countryside and small towns, to get a sense of people's daily lives. Any Italian B & B's in these areas?

The Colorado Rockies, the best story in baseball, completed an unlikely second postseason sweep last night. They won the National League pennant by defeating the Arizona Diamondbacks -- the last team to win at Coors Field this season -- in the N.L.C.S.

I just wanted to direct readers attention to Paul Krugman's commentary in the International Herald Tribune and The New York Times, about why conservatives hate Al Gore so. (The Wall Street Journal didn't even mention his name in its editorial about the Nobel Prize!) Yes he is a popularizer, and some people will object to that, for a variety of reasons. But, as Krugman notes, he has also been right on a number of issues -- look at ozone depletion.
A new ad for Mitt Romney makes its debut in New Hampshire today, outlining Mr. Romney's "conservative blueprint to lower taxes."
It has taken on Dutch banking giant ABN Amro. Now The Children's Investment Fund is setting its sights on CSX.

Last night the Giants won their fourth game in a row, 31-10, beating the hapless Falcons in Atlanta (home of long escalators that our friendly commenters at The Fifth Down can't stop talking about). The Times's John Branch explains how the Giants flipped the script by having a strong start. The Giants found a lot of success attacking the Falcons' perceived strength, cornerback DeAngelo Hall. You can see Amani Toomer doing just that in this slideshow from the game. So Giants fans, your team is suddenly the bright shining light in the New York sports scene. How do you like their chances in the N.F.C. East?

Two of the weekend's most riveting games happened well outside the six major conferences, as teams from the Western Athletic Conference showed that respect can be earned through outlandish performances in odd time slots.
If a big gang of masked, heavy-breathing hombres broke into my house one midnight and told me they were stealing all my music but that I could keep 9 CDs, I wouldn't hesitate about what to save.

Things are ugly in Nebraska and they may get uglier before they get better for the Cornhuskers. After yesterday's firing of Steve Pederson as athletic director, the question becomes who will take over and what will they do about Coach Bill Callahan. Dennis Dodd on CBS Sportsline, after he gets done calling Pederson an "arrogant, pompous blowhard," makes the case for Tom Osborne taking over as A.D. Steven M. Sipple of the Lincoln Journal Star writes that Pederson will go down as the A.D. "who stripped Nebraska football of nearly everything that made it unique for four decades." And the Web site CoachesHotSeat.com ranks Callahan as the coach with the second-hottest seat. First is Arkansas's Houston Nutt, whom Pederson had originally tried to hire at Nebraska. But Chris Bahn of the Northwest Arkansas Gazette reports that Nutt isn't worried.
Aired Monday night on CBS: I hope the show goes well tonight. Last week -- did you hear about this? -- retired General Sanchez, he called this show "a nightmare with no end in sight."

Those going to a big-time car show or concours with a family in tow now face much the same dilemma as fans of professional sports -- it costs a bundle. Single admission tickets to a major concours can run up to $250 (not including food and parking). This is something not lost on Mike Yager, owner of Mid America Motorworks and presenter of Corvette Funfest, a three-day Corvette show held annually on the grounds of his Corvette parts and accessories business in Effingham, Ill.
Aired Monday night on NBC: A new season of "Survivor" has started on CBS: "Survivor: China," about a bunch of kids that play with their toys every day.

What does an ordinary person do when the ol' computer just won't start up? Poke the power button until the index finger nears chafing, slap the keyboard like a cantankerous kid on a Casio, thoughtfully jiggle the wires, and finally, start poking again.

A controversial choice, I admit, even a predictable one given my favorable review of his show in September. And why the need to single out one collection? There were many good shows this season. We all know that the list would have to include Balenciaga, Jil Sander, Comme des Garçons, Alexander McQueen, Lanvin, Prada. In all likelihood, Narciso Rodriguez, Yves Saint Laurent, Stella McCartney, and Dries Van Noten will clinch things with consumers. There is Martin Margiela's kinky game with nudity.

Ali Eteraz, a Muslim-American lawyer and blogger, has been writing a series of provocative articles on his vision for reform in the Islamic world. The latest is posted at the Guardian of London site today, and focuses on the creation of branch of the Islamic world centered on Western political liberalism:

The Bushies have used rising tax receipts since 2004 as supposed proof that tax cuts pay for themselves -- carefully ignoring the fact that revenues plunged in the early years of the administration, and that the subsequent rapid growth basically just gets us back to the previous trend. Also, they've pretended not to notice that mainly the revenue comes from an incredible surge in corporate profits, the byproduct of an economy in which economic growth leaves most workers behind.

In an overnight appeal to supporters, Senator Barack Obama seems to be embracing his position as an underdog by conceding that he is lagging behind Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in fund-raising and time is running short to catch up.
An acttivist hedge fund Knight Vinke on Tuesday accelerated its attack on HSBC with a fresh call to "grasp the nettle" and tear up its existing strategy.
Movie Gallery, the money-losing video-rental chain, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, reporting assets of $892 million and debt totaling $1.4 billion.

J.C. Flowers, the private equity firm, is expected to submit a firm proposal for Northern Rock in the next two to three weeks and believes that it is further ahead than the consortium led by Richard Branson in the race for the stricken mortgage bank, The Times of London reported.
The media business is in spin mode.

One of the more sublime and lasting pleasures of following a Major League Baseball franchise is looking forward to your young stars of tomorrow. As much fun as it might be to speculate on your team's offseason free agent signings, nothing can quite match the excitement of watching a rookie grow up from an undisciplined raw talent to a linchpin of decades to come. We Cardinals fans saw this with Albert Pujols; out of nowhere, a man-child was dropped into our laps. He was unexpected, he was revelatory and he was ours, and only ours. One feels honored to be part of the fan base to introduce such a talent to the world.

Cambridge Place Investment Management, the hedge-fund manager that lost its European investment chief last week, is restricting withdrawals and reducing fees after subprime-related declines, Bloomberg News reported citing an unnamed source.
By tonight, at least one piece of the three-D puzzle known as the primary calendar may fall into place.

The debt syndication for the buyout of Energy Future Holdings, formerly TXU, appeared to be moving forward more smoothly Monday than the market had expected just a few weeks ago, according to The Deal.

The House Foreign Affairs Committee ranking member, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, and seven other lawmakers have introduced a bill saying that the buyout shop Bain Capital's Chinese minority partner's participation in an acquisition of the networking equipment maker 3Com "threatens the national security of the United States."

Campaign finance analyses dominate today's headlines, with the major papers including large visual spreads showing that Democratic candidates held their strong lead in donations over their Republican rivals.
A look at two homes in the Palmeraie neighborhood of Marrakesh.
Citigroup acknowledged on Monday that its risk management models did not function properly during this summer's credit crisis, contributing to the company's 57 percent drop in third-quarter profit.

China Citic Bank is in discussions that may lead to it acquiring a stake in Bear Stearns, a senior Chinese regulator said Tuesday. The remark was the first official confirmation of media reports that state-run Citic is considering an investment in the Wall Street firm.

Industry observers seemed to cast a jaundiced eye yesterday over a plan unveiled by Citigroup, Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase, with active encouragement from the Treasury Department, to keep the housing-related debt crisis from worsening.
Wagamama's private equity owners are looking to auction the popular British noodle bar chain rather than continue with a planned initial public offering, The Financial Times reported.

Technology companies have ramped up their M&A spending in the last six weeks, and one survey suggests they are just getting started. The 451 Group polled corporate development professionals at actively acquiring companies, and more than 80 percent of them said they planned to maintain or increase their level of M&A in the next year.

Investors may be betting that BEA Systems will land a higher bid than the one offered by Oracle last week, but several Wall Street analysts have their doubts. Three brokers removed their buy ratings from BEA Systems on Monday, cutting the stock to the equivalent of neutral.

An ad insertion start-up, BlackArrow, snagged $12 million in funding on Monday. The start-up's service, targeted at cable companies, dynamically inserts ads in everything from video-on-demand to DVR playback and broadband.
A new hedge fund founded by two former Merrill Lynchers is boasting a customer list that comes off as a veritable all-star Major League Baseball roster.

Toys "R" Us co-owner Kohlberg Kravis Roberts faced a protest by about two dozen people outside its office here on Monday, urging the private equity giant to get rid of lead-tainted toys, Reuters reported.
The founder of the defunct hedge fund Wood River Capital Management was sentenced to three years in prison on Monday for his role in a scheme that led to about $88 million in investor losses.

The Blackstone Group and the banks involved in the $1.8 billion takeover of mortgage and vehicle fleet company PHH have yet to agree on a way to resolve a financing shortfall, dimming the prospects that the deal will go through, Reuters reported.

Hewlett-Packard has agreed to settle a shareholder lawsuit for $117.5 million in a two-year-old case related to stock options backdating at Mercury Interactive, the business software company Hewlett-Packard acquired last year, a lawyer for the plaintiffs said Monday.

Canada's Yamana Gold declared success in its 3.5 billion Canadian dollar ($3.6 billion) takeover bid for Meridian Gold after 78 percent of Meridian's stock was tendered.

After Matt Leinart went down with a broken collarbone in Week 5, the Cardinals signed Tim Rattay to back up Kurt Warner. Now that Warner is out with a sprained elbow, Arizona needs someone to back up Rattay. That quarterback is expected to be Tim Hasselbeck.

One of the big but little-noticed economic stories of the past few years is the sharp slowdown in US productivity growth. Dean Baker and John Schmitt are on the case; their recent article is definitely worth reading.
I.B.M. quarterly sales and profits matched Wall Street’s expectations with the strong performance of its big services business.
The House Democratic majority leader said today that there is room for negotiations with the White House.
Yahoo said that its revenue grew to $1.8 billion, a 12 percent jump from the same quarter last year, while net profit dropped slightly to $151 million.

Ales Kotalik scored a power-play goal with four seconds left in overtime last night to give the Buffalo Sabres a 5-4 victory against the visiting Toronto Maple Leafs. Kotalik’s slap shot from the left circle was stopped by goalie Andrew Raycroft, but Toronto defenseman Bryan McCabe inadvertently knocked the puck into his own net to give the Sabres the dramatic victory.
After investigators found that six identity theft victims had applied for loans at the same local mortgage office police arrested the branch manager and his sister.
The world’s largest shipping carrier said its chief executive, Michael L. Eskew, would retire after six years in the role and more than 30 years with the company.
Nomura Holdings, Japan’s largest securities firm, has already written off about $620 million related to its American subprime mortgage-related business.
Danaher, which makes environmental and electronic testing technology, anticipates gains from Tektronix’s specialty in communications testing products.

Profit beat expectations, a result of a big gain from the sale of its wealth management division and more revenue from an expanding mix of brokerage firm customers.
Knicks Coach Isiah Thomas views veteran guard Fred Jones as a critical piece to a teamwide personality overhaul, from all offense all the time to defense first.
European Union foreign ministers lifted a travel ban on eight top Uzbek officials while renewing an arms embargo.
A British Airways Boeing 747 and a Sri Lankan Airlines Airbus A340 collided while taxiing on a runway at Heathrow Airport in London, but there were no injuries.
Thirty men suspected of being Islamic terrorists, most of them Moroccans and Algerians, went on trial at the National Court in Madrid, the building they are charged with plotting to blow up.
