A consortium led by Iceland's Baugur is interested in making an offer for Saks, but the luxury retailer won't even consider a sale until after the holiday season, The New York Post reported.

Steven Madden Ltd., a designer and seller of trendy footwear, said Friday it would review its strategic alternatives after receiving "inquiries from third parties with respect to an acquisition of the company."
Japanese brewer Kirin is in talks to buy a majority stake in drug maker Kyowa Hakko Kogyo in a deal that could top 300 billion yen ($2.6 billion), Reuters reported citing an unnamed source.
Does the rescue plan for the credit markets need to be saved?
Nobody, it seems, wants to be caught eyeing Bear Stearns. In one day, two reported suitors of the investment bank denied ever having mulled the idea of taking a stake in Bear.
There is a popular contemporary Christian worship song that goes, "This is the day that the Lord has made; we will rejoice and be glad in it."
Cognizant Technology Solutions, an information technology and outsourcing services provider, said Thursday it will pay $135 million in cash to acquire marketRx.
Suburban bands are making musical waves, without relying on New York City.
The Blackstone Group hired Francisco Rey, formerly a media and telecommunications banker at Merrill Lynch, for its corporate advisory team in Europe.
For lawyers who like rankings, there is more than one way to keep score. But the question remains, Does a high ranking matter, and for whom?

Delta Air Lines chieftain Richard Anderson caught many in the industry off guard with his candid comments on potential dealmaking during the airline's quarterly earnings call this week, setting off a rash of talk as to what the Atlanta-based airline might be considering and who it is talking to.
Third Point chief Daniel S. Loeb spent six months pressing for changes at PDL BioPharma. Now the company has put itself on the block, Mr. Loeb has begun to cash out, The Deal reports.

Samuel Zell's $8.2-billion deal to take Tribune private has become entangled in a newly inflamed debate over media ownership rules at the Federal Communications Commission that could pose problems for the transaction.

Microsoft Chief Executive Steve Ballmer said on Thursday the company aims to pursue an independent path, focusing on up to 20 smaller acquisitions of $50 million to $1 billion each annually rather than mega-deals.

About 94 seconds after his team had staved off elimination by beating the Cleveland Indians 7-1 in front of a suddenly sparse Jacobs Field crowd, Red Sox first baseman Kevin Youkilis, the pride of Jewish Midwesterners everywhere, did his best to quell any tendencies toward mass suicide. This was awfully sweet of him.

Fresh from stealing Madonna from Warner Music Group, concert promoter Live Nation is in advanced talks to acquire the Material Girl's merchandising company, Signatures Network, The New York Post reported.

Paul Eustace, whose firm, Philadelphia Alternative Asset Management Company, was shut down by regulators at 2005, has already admitted that he lied to investors, lost $208 million in his hedge funds and stole about $2 million of client cash. (Part of his loot went to pay for his lover's breast augmentation surgery.)

A man that prosecutors say was paid about $2.6 million to be a professional plaintiff - and helped a prestigious New York law firm get lucrative class-action lawsuits - pleaded guilty Thursday to obstruction of justice and two other charges.

Casino Guichard-Perrachon , the biggest supermarket owner in Paris, plans to sell stores, warehouses and shopping centers worth 650 million euros ($930 million) so managers can focus on food retailing.
French defense and media conglomerate Lagardere may have had enough of the life of a publicly-listed company.

Lending by the Bank of England to stricken mortgage bank Northern Rock was increased to 16 billion pounds ($33 billion) over the last week, raising fears that the British bank is running out of funds at a faster rate than expected.

Netscape co-founder Marc Andreessen, Charles River Ventures and SoftTech VC have bet $3.5 million on SocialMedia Networks, creator of an ad and analytics network for widget makers on social networks like Facebook and MySpace.
Attorneys for Coca-Cola are trying to use the guilty plea of class action king William Lerach to derail a seven-year-old securities fraud case against the soft drink giant.
Shares in England soccer-wear manufacturer Umbro soared nearly 30 percent Thursday following speculation that the firm had received a takeover bid from sportswear giant Nike.
TA Associates, the Boston private equity firm, stands to triple its original investment in Lumber Liquidators when the company goes public.

Strabag, the building company that raised 1.33 billion euros ($1.9 billion) in a share sale to fund expansion in eastern Europe, rose 8.1 percent on its debut trading day in Vienna Friday because of growth prospects in Russia.
NRDC Equity Partners, the private equity shop that owns Lord & Taylor, is aiming to raise $360 million in an initial public offering with an eye toward more retail acquisitions.

A U.S. real estate fund has sued HSBC Holdings alleging the British bank's U.S. mortgage trading operation took advantage of the credit crisis to profit at the expense of the fund, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Media companies are often criticized for not taking enough risks in choosing television shows, authors, movies and musicians. But when it comes to technology start-ups, their appetite for risk appears to be on the rise, says The New York Times.
The volume of cross-border mergers is setting new records, despite the credit crunch that has crimped domestic deal-making in the United States, Reuters reports.

While the Internet has given patients unprecedented access to medical information, it's also given doctors the chance to express themselves beyond the exam room. Here's a sampling of some recent posts on the medical blogs:
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
An unlikely coalition of farmers, ranchers and environmentalists is emerging to oppose new coal-burning power plants, like one proposed in Great Falls, Mont.
Images from the Klimt show at the Neue Galerie.
Images chronicling the life of Percy Casey from his childhood days as a performer on “Sesame Street” to his adult nights as the rapper MF Grimm.
Images from "Warhol's World" at the Museum of the Moving Image.
An article in The Times today discusses some of the best spots to view autumn leaves while avoiding crowds:
“Out of the Blue,” by the writer and director Robert Sarkies, dramatizes the terror of a day of massacre without exploiting it.
“Wristcutters: A Love Story” has an offbeat, absurdist charm that turns a potentially creepy conceit into an odd, touching adventure.
“Things We Lost in the Fire” bends over backward to prove that serious American movies can hold their own with the best films from overseas.
If peace lies in acceptance, then no one told the filmmaker Daniel Sánchez Arévalo, whose first feature portrays repressed longing with been-there, done-that assurance.
The tears and the blame mix uneasily in “Reservation Road,” a grim, mechanistic thriller about death and suffering, life and healing among the civilized.
“Rendition” tries to be thoughtful and respectful of complexity while at the same time honoring the imperatives of commercial entertainment.
“30 Days of Night” is a series of gory set pieces that seems to have been edited with a meat ax.
If nothing else, “Meeting Resistance” should dispel any lingering misconception that the Iraq insurgency is mainly the work of outside agitators.
With “Gone Baby Gone,” Ben Affleck has taken a satisfyingly tough look into conscience, to those dark places where some men also go astray.
James Crump’s documentary is a potent exercise in art-world mythography that might be nicknamed “The Prince and the Punk.”
The new sanctions target eleven additional members of the military-run government responsible for a crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators.
In his first public comments since turning down the offer, Joe Torre said the owners did not seem to want to negotiate with him for more money, or better terms.
Andrew Ruben, who built unusual alliances between the retailer and environmental groups, is leaving the job for a new assignment overseeing merchandise.
A Food and Drug Administration panel’s recommendation, if put into practice, could transform pharmacy shelves and change how parents cope with children’s colds.
The Dow closed down 366.94  today as earnings reports from Wachovia and Caterpillar disappointed investors.
A gas explosion ripped through a working-class neighborhood around 7:45 a.m. today, leveling two houses, killing one person and injuring four others.
Two executives from Village Voice Media were arrested on charges that they published grand jury secrets in a story.
Josh Becket did a lot of nasty pitching and a little trash talking to help make sure the Boston Red Sox would survive to play another game.
City officials removed about 220 residents Thursday from dozens of illegal loft apartments in an industrial building in Queens, citing numerous safety hazards.
Keeping alive its major bowl aspirations, Rutgers served notice that big-time college football was still being played in New Jersey by upsetting No. 2  South Florida.
At last night’s Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria, New York’s political and Roman Catholic elite dined on foie gras, and traded barbs.

Police officials and leaders of the nightclub industry announced an effort yesterday to reduce crime and other problems at clubs. The police and club owners drafted their plan after two cases in which women disappeared after visiting clubs and were found murdered. A club bouncer was charged with one of the deaths; he has pleaded not guilty. The initiative includes more training of guards and bouncers and improved lighting around entrances. The police encouraged the clubs to report problems and seek help when needed. Club owners have been reluctant to call 911, fearing that they would blamed and subjected to tickets, arrests and challenges to their liquor licenses.

A retired New York City police detective from the Albany area is a fugitive from prosecution on charges of possessing and distributing child pornography, federal agents said yesterday. Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents requested the public’s help in finding the suspect, Michael W. Niebling, above. He was indicted on Sept. 27 on charges of distributing the material across the country and internationally, using the Internet. He failed to appear at a hearing in United States District Court here on Tuesday, the agency said. He was seen in Myrtle Beach, S.C., on Oct. 11 and may have been in Las Vegas early on Monday and in Boston later that day or the next, at or near Logan International Airport, the federal agents said. As a former police officer, Mr. Niebling may be armed, they said.

The Broadway stagehands’ union announced yesterday that the Nederlander Organization, which owns nine theaters on Broadway, had contacted the union to say that it would not be joining the League of American Theaters and Producers in imposing new work rules on the stagehands. The producers’ league, in response, said the decision by the Nederlander Organization was based solely on a technical legal matter, since it has a separate contract with the stagehands. Still, Bruce Cohen, a spokesman for Local One, the stagehands’ union, said that if the union called a strike, “a strike against the Nederlanders, who are friendly to Local One, would be highly unlikely.” The Shuberts and the Jujamcyn theater chain, which are being represented by the league in talks and will be imposing the rules on Monday, account for 22 of the 39 Broadway theaters. No representative for the Nederlanders could be reached for comment last night.
The suspended defensive tackle Tank Johnson will be allowed to practice starting Friday, which will be his first team session with the Dallas Cowboys since they signed him last month.
Allan Houston did not dress for Thursday’s preseason game against the Nets, and it seems that his chances of making the team are slim.
The Swiss health care company Galenica said it agreed to buy Aspreva of Canada for $915 million to expand its drug portfolio and distribution.
A man who helped Milberg Weiss, a New York law firm, get lucrative class-action lawsuits pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice and two other charges.

An article on Saturday about criticism of the Bush administration’s conduct of the Iraq war by a former top commander there, Lt. Gen. Ricardo S. Sanchez, misstated the name of the group to which General Sanchez spoke. It is the Military Reporters and Editors — not the Military Reporters and Editors Association.

Because of an editing error, a sports article in some editions on Monday about the late starting times of baseball playoff games misidentified the location of the Rockies-Phillies games on Oct. 3 and Oct. 4. They were in Philadelphia, not Colorado.

An article in The Arts on Oct. 10 about a new show on MTV, “Pageant Place,” which looks at some winners of the three beauty pageants Donald Trump co-owns, misidentified one of those pageants. As the article noted in another reference, they are the Miss Universe, Miss USA and Miss Teen USA pageants — not Miss America. The article at one point also misstated the surname of Miss USA 2006, who appears on the show. She is Tara Conner, not O’Connor.

An article in Business Day yesterday about a decision by the Department of Veterans Affairs to restrict the use of the diabetes drug Avandia misstated the number of prescriptions the agency issued for the drug from September 2006 to August 2007. It was 1,389,497 prescriptions, not 161,000. (The prescriptions were written for 161,096 patients.).

An article in some editions on Oct. 5 about a vote by the New York State Association of County Clerks to condemn Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s policy allowing illegal immigrants to obtain driver’s licenses misstated the policy’s origins. It was established through internal administrative procedures at the State Department of Motor Vehicles, not by executive order.

An article on Oct. 6 about the conviction of a Brooklyn man for manslaughter and attempted robbery as hate crimes, stemming from his role in selecting a gay man as a robbery target and chasing him to his death in traffic, included an incorrect range of sentences from prosecutors for manslaughter as a hate crime. (The error also appeared in an article on Oct. 10 about a call for forgiveness from the victim’s mother.) The crime carries a minimum penalty of 1 to 3 years and a maximum of 8 1/3 to 25; the range is not 5 to 15.

An article on Saturday about criticism of the Bush administration’s conduct of the Iraq war by a former top commander there, Lt. Gen. Ricardo S. Sanchez, misstated the name of the group to which General Sanchez spoke. It is the Military Reporters and Editors — not the Military Reporters and Editors Association.

An article in Science Times on Tuesday about an effort in Libya to create a conservation and sustainable development zone misstated the name of the British architectural firm hired to do the design. It is Foster and Partners, not Foster and Associates.

A sports article in some editions on Wednesday about the Rockies’ long break between the National League Championship Series and the World Series misidentified the Colorado third baseman on the periphery of the final play of the N.L.C.S. He is Jamey Carroll, who entered the game in the eighth inning — not Garrett Atkins, the starter at third.
Two weeks after Hershey’s chairman and chief executive said he would leave, the struggling company cut its 2007 forecast, the third such setback this year.
Southwest Airlines and Continental Airlines posted higher quarterly earnings yesterday as fuller planes and fare increases helped offset soaring fuel costs.
The large maker of business software applications said its third-quarter profit rose 10 percent on an increase in license sales.
The electronics giant plans to sell its operations for making microchips used in its PlayStation game console to Toshiba, pulling back from the heavy investment needed.
A Hamas policeman and three members of a Fatah-affiliated clan were killed in an armed clash in Gaza City, according to medical officials and the independent Palestinian Center for Human Rights.
North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-il, has accepted an invitation to visit Hanoi from the Vietnamese leader, Nong Duc Manh.
A former Congolese general, Germain Katanga, arrived at the prison of the International Criminal Court in The Hague.
Air Force troops seized control of the nation’s busiest international airport, in the eastern city of Santa Cruz, after the airport’s managers detained several planes on the runway.
The former Israeli commander of the West Bank, Brig. Gen. Yair Golan, was reprimanded after an investigation of a “human shield” episode in Nablus, in the West Bank.
The Croucher Brewing Company is offering a “lifetime supply” of beer as a reward for the return of a stolen laptop.
The government announced that it would give the United Nations Population Fund $204 million over the next five years to improve the health of mothers and reduce their odds of dying in childbirth.

H. Dale Hemmerdinger, Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s nominee to be chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, made it clear yesterday at a Senate confirmation hearing that he was no expert on transportation policy.
New York City’s chief medical examiner has concluded that the death of a city police detective who worked at ground zero after the Sept. 11 attacks was not caused by exposure to toxic dust there.
Bill Guerin scored his first three goals with the Islanders Thursday night to lead a 5-2 victory against the host Washington Capitals.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Oct. 18 — The man shot to death this week in his convenience store was a small-time actor with a complicated past, including a conviction for money laundering, nine bullet wounds that he said he got on the streets, and a movie role as a drug runner killed after double-crossing a kingpin.

Patrick Biancone, a prominent thoroughbred trainer accused of medication violations, has reached a settlement with Kentucky racing authorities that will bar him from racing anywhere for six months. In exchange, Biancone will not attempt an appeal. For an additional six months, Biancone will not work as a trainer but may go to races, as long as he stays in public areas, the agreement said.Biancone agreed not to appear at the Breeders’ Cup Championships on Oct. 26-27 at Monmouth Park in New Jersey, although the suspension does not go into effect until Nov. 1. Seven horses are pre-entered in his name for eight races, but Biancone will withdraw as trainer of record. He is not prohibited from receiving prize money from the championships.

A lawyer who represented Kia Vaughn, a junior on the Rutgers women’s team, complained to the university that Coach C. Vivian Stringer pressured Vaughn to drop a lawsuit against Don Imus over his sexist and racist remarks about the team. Vaughn dropped her slander and defamation suit in September against Imus, who called Rutgers’s players “nappy-headed hos” after the team lost in the N.C.A.A. finals.Vaughn had filed the lawsuit against Imus and CBS in August, saying his comments during his radio show damaged her reputation. In a Sept. 4 e-mail message and an Aug. 17 letter sent to university officials before the suit was dropped, Vaughn’s lawyer, Richard B. Ancowitz, said that Stringer and others put pressure on his client and other players not to seek legal action against Imus. Vaughn said Wednesday that no one pressured her and that she wanted to “focus on school and basketball and everything else.”.

The Nippon Ham Fighters, managed by Trey Hillman, are going back to the Japan Series. The former Montreal Expos player Fernando Seguignol hit a three-run homer to help the Fighters to a 6-2 victory against the Chiba Lotte Marines, managed by Bobby Valentine, to win the Pacific League championship series, three games to two. Hillman, formerly a successful manager in the Yankees’ minor league system, has been mentioned as a successor to Joe Torre.

Bryant University accepted an invitation to join the N.C.A.A. Division I Northeast Conference. Bryant currently competes in Division II. It is in the first year of a five-year transition period for full Division I membership. Full membership, including eligibility for Division I championships, will take effect September 2012. The university, located in Smithfield, R.I., said it expected to play a Division I schedule in 2008-9.
The victim, who is black, said he was attacked on Tuesday night in the Mariner’s Harbor section by five white men who yelled racial slurs at him.
An panel on Thursday recommended that the government create a commission to promote the free flow of scientific knowledge and talent from other countries.
The state is a painful symbol of the brutality of politics for John McCain, the place that derailed his 2000 bid.
Turkey’s decision to allow the dispatch of troops over Iraq’s border in pursuit of Kurdish guerrillas throws into relief a troubling quandary for Iraq’s leaders.
New evidence that Neanderthals possessed a critical gene known to underlie speech, stems from analysis of a gene called FOXP2, which is associated with language.
Supporters of the bill were unable to convert a single House Republican who voted against the bill last month.
Just days after America’s three largest banks announced a $75 billion effort to rescue troubled securities, the plan has struggled to get off the ground.

New Jersey officials announced yesterday that they would send almost half the New Jersey Army National Guard’s 6,200 soldiers to Iraq by next summer, in one of the state’s biggest troop deployments since World War II. Speaking at an event at the Fort Dix military base, Gov. Jon S. Corzine and Maj. Gen. Glenn K. Rieth, the state’s adjutant general, said that the state’s 50th Infantry Brigade Combat Team would begin training immediately and that 2,700 soldiers could be ready by next summer for a mobilization expected to last one year. Mr. Corzine said that the soldiers’ deployment could hamper the state’s antiterrorism efforts.

A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday after an accident that killed a bicyclist near the intersection of Fulton Street and Utica Avenue, the police said. The man, Alfred Taylor, 41, of Flushing Avenue, struck the bicyclist about 6:21 a.m., the police said. Mr. Taylor was charged with criminally negligent homicide after it was determined that he had been speeding, the police said. The police did not name the bicyclist.

State Senator John D. Sabini, a Queens Democrat, pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of driving while intoxicated. Senator Sabini was arrested shortly after 1 a.m. on Sept. 27 after the police said he failed to signal a turn and drove down the center of a street in Albany. He refused to take a breath test to measure his blood-alcohol content and failed field sobriety tests, said James Miller, an Albany police detective. Jim Long, Senator Sabini’s lawyer, said he had previously advised the senator not to take breath tests, asserting that they are unreliable.
A state appeals court ruled yesterday that a landlord could evict Bianca Jagger from her rent-stabilized apartment on the Upper East Side.
Admiral Crowe served as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff during the Reagan administration and later as ambassador to Britain.

A Newark man who was a suspect in the 2004 killings of four people in a vacant lot next to a Newark church has pleaded guilty to a separate killing, the Essex County Prosecutor’s Office said yesterday. The man, Michael Melvin, 27, was charged in the 2004 killings more than a year after they occurred, but the charges were dismissed this year. In the separate case, Mr. Melvin pleaded guilty yesterday in State Superior Court to aggravated manslaughter for the killing of Lamar McMillan, 27, of Orange in November 2005. Mr. Melvin faces 16 years in state prison.

The union representing 24,000 New York City police officers is challenging a new departmental policy requiring mandatory sobriety tests of any police officer who shoots someone, wounding or killing him. The union, the Patrolmen’s Benevolent Association, filed papers in federal court yesterday challenging the sobriety tests on constitutional grounds. The union argued that the tests violate an officer’s protection against unreasonable searches, according to a statement from the union president, Patrick J. Lynch. Earlier this week, unions representing detectives, sergeants and lieutenants filed papers in federal court against the sobriety tests. “We believe the sobriety test is a reasonable requirement and anticipate the courts will find it so,” said Paul J. Browne, the Police Department’s chief spokesman. Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly announced the new policy in June when he accepted the recommendations of a panel created after a Queens man, Sean Bell, was fatally shot in November in a volley of 50 bullets fired by officers.

A police captain convicted of assaulting an officer under his command, with whom he was having an extramarital affair, was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to 60 days in jail, 50 hours of community service and three years’ probation. The captain, Alberto Sanchez, 42, had been convicted of third-degree assault for an attack on Sharon Gandarilla, 33, an instructor at the Police Academy, where Captain Sanchez was second in command. Justice Richard Carruthers ordered Captain Sanchez to surrender on Monday, but his defense lawyer received a stay, pending an appeal of the conviction. On Sept. 1, 2006, prosecutors say, Captain Sanchez became angry at Officer Gandarilla while they were at a Greenwich Village restaurant because he thought she was flirting with another officer. Captain Sanchez dragged Officer Gandarilla out to her car, where he beat and kicked her, prosecutors said. Captain Sanchez was on modified duty pending the trial and may still face Police Department disciplinary charges.

A Whitestone man was charged yesterday with injuring six people in a series of shootings with a BB gun over the last three weeks in Flushing and Whitestone, prosecutors said. The man, Paul Roedel, 18, of Willets Point Boulevard, was charged with assault and reckless endangerment, the Queens district attorney’s office said. In a statement, District Attorney Richard A. Brown said the shootings began just after midnight on Sept. 23, when Mr. Roedel shot a 15-year-old girl in the back. Mr. Brown said Mr. Roedel was arrested after he drove past an acquaintance and shot him with a BB gun. The police recovered a BB gun and about 180 BBs from Mr. Roedel’s car, Mr. Brown said.
The time may have come to close the city’s Off-Track Betting operation, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said, as a way of getting the city out of a long-troubled business.
An expert panel said Thursday that it was unclear which treatments could help combat veterans who suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder.

Attempts by American-led reconstruction teams in Iraq to forge political reconciliation, foster economic growth and build an effective police force and court system have failed to show significant progress.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
The search giant’s surging third quarter profits showed that it was growing at twice the speed of the online advertising market, which itself is booming.
Letting Ms. Bhutto back to lead her party’s ticket in the soon-to-be-held parliamentary elections is an important step forward for Pakistan.
The Coast Guard is planning a base to deal with ships that are plying the Arctic’s increasingly ice-free waters.
Colombia and Venezuela are rapidly moving to strike energy deals, resolve a boundary dispute and increase trade.
The Senate Intelligence Committee approved a measure that would  grant immunity to telecom companies for their role in assisting government surveillance programs.
In an effort to counter a string of bad news, CBS’s chief executive delivered a strong message to his programming troops last spring: find us another hit, fast.
Joe Torre rejected a $5 million offer that would have kept him as baseball’s highest-paid manager but also would have been a cut from his present salary.
Terry Francona, the Boston Red Sox manager, said it felt strange to know that someone he had respected and enjoyed competing with was no longer with the Yankees.
Since Poland joined the European Union in 2004, more than a million Poles, mainly young, have come to Britain, but a decline in Polish immigrants could be an even bigger problem.
American Jews are trying to reconcile their support of Israel, a Turkish ally, with their commitment to fighting genocide.
A visit to Najaf lays bare the needs of displaced Iraqis and the rough road ahead for national reconciliation.
J. Dennis Hastert, the former House speaker, will resign before his term ends 15 months from now, closing a 21-year career in Congress, Republican aides said.

Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick of Detroit has asked the City Council to approve an $8.4 million settlement in lawsuits brought by former police officers who say they were discharged for investigating misconduct by the mayor and his security guards.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration canceled one of its two agreements to provide seed money to companies hoping to provide space transport services.
Philadelphia has decided that the local Boy Scouts chapter must pay fair-market rent of $200,000 a year for its city-owned headquarters because it refuses to permit gay boys.
An autistic hiker lost for four days has been found alive, a spokesman for the search effort said.
The Chinese leadership realized the need to “re-balance” growth in 2004. But they have been too timid to push hard toward a new strategy.
A heroin death was the second in less than seven months in which a student at Rider, a small private university of about 6,000 undergraduates, died after abusing drugs or alcohol.
The president’s nominee for attorney general, Michael B. Mukasey, declined to say if he considered harsh interrogation techniques to constitute torture.
An F.D.A. official told a panel of experts that they should consider a ban on multisymptom over-the-counter pediatric cough and cold medicines for children under 6.
Without a requirement for full disclosure of who is giving how much to whom — and a cleaner, alternative flow of cash — bundlers will always win.

The first trial involving charges of torture at a notorious military prison during Argentina’s “dirty war,” when the government seized, tortured and killed thousands of suspected leftists, began Thursday.
J. C. Flowers & Company has told its investors just how much money they may lose in the private equity firm’s battle over the buyout of Sallie Mae.
Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger should have signed a bill that would have permitted the distribution of condoms in California’s prisons.
Dan Patrick will write a weekly column for Sports Illustrated, and write a daily blog and simulcast his new radio show on its Web site.

European Union leaders gathering here late Thursday night agreed on a treaty that they hoped would end the drift plaguing the bloc since the French and the Dutch rejected a European constitution two years ago.
The F.C.C. issued a citation on Thursday against a commentator for promoting the Bush administration’s policies without disclosing that he had been paid to do so.

When a steel bucket tumbled 53 stories off the future Bank of America tower near Bryant Park on Wednesday, raining debris and sending people running for cover, it was hardly a novelty. It was the 74th time this year that something fell from a construction site in New York City, the Buildings Department said yesterday.
Advanced Micro Devices reported a larger-than-expected loss but showed progress in curbing its expenses and capturing a share of strong demand for personal computers.
The Rockies took in Latroy Hawkins and Matt Herges, two journeyman relievers, and the team is awfully glad it did.
School officials around the country have been scrambling this week after several cases of staph infection, some of which have led to the death of students.
Mike Gundy, the coach of the Oklahoma State football team, seems to have benefited on and off the field from a postgame tirade defending a player against a critical newspaper column.
Private security contractors fired into a crowded taxi as it approached their convoy of sport utility vehicles in northern Iraq on Thursday.
Rookie cornerback Aaron Ross, who describes himself as “a high-risk, high-reward player,” leads the Giants with three interceptions.
For the No. 8 Kentucky Wildcats, this has been a season in which winning has bred confidence, and confidence has bred more winning.
Joe Torre’s refusal to accept a contract offer came 47 years to the day after the Yankees dismissed Casey Stengel.
The Dalai Lama, Tibet’s exiled spiritual leader, has come to this city so often in recent years that his visits now fly under the radar of most New Yorkers.
Teachers and other educators began assessing a plan to offer performance bonuses to teachers working in the city’s most impoverished neighborhoods.
The Salander-O’Reilly Galleries and its principal have been the subjects of lawsuits by people who say they consigned artworks to the gallery and were not paid, or even notified, when they were sold.
Senator Sam Brownback is planning to drop out of the presidential race Friday, as social conservatives try to find a candidate behind whom they can unite.
People.
Strong demand for low-cost phones in Africa, the Middle East and Asia lifted the company’s share of the global market to almost 40 percent.
The charts that tally the number of deals law firms have worked on present a glimpse into the tight credit market, which brought deals to a halt this summer in the U.S.
Wall Street finished flat and remained uneasy after Bank of America posted disappointing results, providing further evidence that the credit crisis was hurting the economy.
The United Nations envoy to Myanmar said Thursday that the country’s military rulers could be offered incentives to move toward democratic reforms.
When it comes to technology start-ups, the appetite for risk among media companies appears to be on the rise.
In an action likely to increase trade tensions with China, the Bush administration reaffirmed its policy of imposing duties on certain imports, paving the way for possible tariff increases.

The Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act — known as RICO — was signed into law by President Richard M. Nixon in October 1970. Wielded mainly, though not exclusively, as a sword against the Mafia, it holds in its most basic terms that a person or group of people who commit certain crimes as part of a conspiracy or criminal enterprise can be charged with racketeering.
The matchup of Louisville’s high-powered offense and Connecticut’s stingy defense could put one of the teams in position to challenge for the conference title.
The Department of Agriculture has announced standards that would only allow meat to be labeled as grass fed if it came from animals that ate nothing but grass.
Major media companies agreed to a set of guidelines to protect copyrights online but Google, owner of the Web’s biggest video site, was notably absent from the pact.
A Canadian consumer magazine is reporting that a popular line of children’s blocks sold throughout North America contains high lead levels.
The discontinuation of Exubera, an inhaled insulin, is another black eye for Pfizer, the world’s biggest drug company, which has recently sustained a series of reversals.
The Air Force plans to fire at least five officers for allowing armed missiles to be mistakenly loaded on a B-52 bomber and flown over the U.S.

James D. Watson, who won the Nobel Prize for helping decipher DNA, apologized “unreservedly” Thursday for comments reported this week suggesting that black people, over all, are not as intelligent as whites.

A long-running argument about which painting offers a true likeness of Shakespeare has taken a new turn. Experts have found that ink on a label identifying a portrait said to be of Shakespeare dates back to his time, The Globe and Mail of Toronto reported. The painting, right, was made by John Sanders, a Shakespearean-era actor born in 1576, and has been in the possession of Lloyd Sullivan, a retired Ottawa engineer, since his mother gave it to him in 1972. He has spent 15 years and an estimated $750,000 on tests to buttress his belief that the painting is the only true portrait of Shakespeare. On Wednesday Joseph Barabe, a forensic analyst for McCrone Associates of Chicago, said that “the formula of the ink” on a small handwritten label on the back of the Sanders painting “certainly fits” with manufacturing methods and materials from the first 50 or so years of 17th-century England. He said, “I see all of the evidence kind of falling in the realm of authenticity — and I don’t see any evidence coming forth that brings it into question.” When the painting, dated 1603, was shown last year with five other “Shakespeares” in London, it was said that the sitter appeared far younger than the 39-year-old Shakespeare would have been.

The Fox Business Network, which began broadcasts on Monday, said yesterday that it had hired Liz Claman from CNBC. Along with David Asman, Ms. Claman will be a co-anchor of FBN’s afternoon block of programming. Ms. Claman served mainly as an anchor for the CNBC morning programs “Morning Call” and “Cover to Cover.” She joined CNBC in 1998 and appeared on Fox Business for the first time yesterday, interviewing Warren Buffet.

Lassie (above), Toto, the animated Gromit and Snowy (Tintin’s trusty companion) made the shortlist of six dogs to be chosen by public vote as the first inductees in the Dog Walk of Fame to be established in Battersea, south London, The Associated Press reported. The winners, to be announced on Nov. 5, will receive a plaque in Battersea Park, near the Battersea Dogs Home, Britain’s largest and best-known refuge for abandoned dogs. The walk of fame is sponsored by the Kennel Club and Sky Movies.

One week after stabilizing somewhat in the ratings, NBC’s “Bionic Woman” struggled on Wednesday. That sci-fi show lost almost two million viewers compared with last week, averaging 8.5 million in the 9 p.m. hour, or less than two-thirds the audience for its premiere, Nielsen estimated. Among adults 18 to 49, “Bionic Woman” finished third in its time slot, just ahead of Fox’s “Kitchen Nightmares” (6.9 million) but behind CBS’s “Criminal Minds” (14.9 million) and ABC’s “Private Practice” (11.8 million), which remained No. 1 in the 18 to 49 set despite a 10 percent ratings drop. ABC eked out a victory in that age group, continuing to lead at 8 with “Pushing Daisies” (9.7 million). CBS, meanwhile, was the night’s most-watched network, winning the 10 p.m. hour with “CSI: NY” (13.9 million). NBC finished third, and Fox was fourth.

The Ang Lee spy thriller “Lust, Caution” is no longer Taiwan’s entry for the Academy Award for best foreign-language film, The Associated Press reported. The academy ruled that the movie’s sponsor country did not certify that the film’s personnel, like those involved in cinematography, costumes and music, “exercised artistic control” over the project, a requirement. “An insufficient number of Taiwanese participated in the production of the film,” said Teni Melidonian, a spokeswoman for the academy. “Lust, Caution” (with Wang Leehom, above), was replaced by Chen Huai-en’s “Island Etude,” about a university student’s bicycle tour of Taiwan. Stanley Hung, secretary general of the Motion Picture and Drama Association of Taiwan, has appealed the ruling on “Lust, Caution.” Mr. Lee won the Oscar for best director for “Brokeback Mountain.” ... A director who challenged “Eklavya: The Royal Guard,” India’s foreign-language submission, withdrew her petition yesterday. Court hearings had gone on past the academy’s entry deadline. So Bhavna Talwar, the director of the shortlisted “Dharm,” who had claimed bias in the selection process, said: “Eklavya’ has already gone to the Oscars, and that’s fine. We let that go.” ... A record 63 countries will compete in the foreign-language film category, Agence France-Presse reported. The 63 will be reduced to 5 nominees for the Oscar, to be awarded at the 80th Academy Awards ceremony, in Hollywood on Feb. 24.

Giant screens in Times Square will carry a performance by Lang Lang of the Yellow River Piano Concerto at 7 p.m. on Thursday to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Beijing Music Festival. Intended as a gesture of goodwill between China and the United States, the performance will be simulcast by WQXR-FM (96.3), the classical music radio station of The New York Times. Lang Lang will be accompanied by the China Philharmonic, conducted by Long Yu, the founder and director of the Beijing Music Festival. The concerto, by Yin Chengzong, based on the Yellow River Cantata by Xian Xinghai, was written in 1969 to mark the end of the Cultural Revolution and to praise China’s fighting spirit.

HOYT--Charles Orcutt, died on October 16, 2007 in his home in New York City. He was 78. Born in 1929 to Henry H. Hoyt and Anna O. Hoyt, Charles Hoyt grew up in South Orange, New Jersey. He distinguished himself as a student at Pingry School in the class of 1947 and at Princeton University in the class of 1951, where he graduated with high honors. He received his MBA from Columbia University in 1953, and then he joined the pharmaceutical and consumer products company, CarterWallace, Inc., where he rose to become Chairman of the Executive Committee. He retired in 1996. Charles Hoyt is survived by his wife, Suzanne C. Hoyt, his four children, Scott C. Hoyt, Susan T. Hoyt, Ames H. Hoyt, and Sarah H. Steidel, his stepson, William Nguyen, and his six grandchildren. A service will be held at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York City, at 10:00am on Saturday, October 20th.

PORDENONE SILENT FILM WEEKEND For those unfamiliar with the pleasures of silent film, there is no better introduction to this lost art than the ''Treasures From a Chest'' program, presented each year by the French collector and connoisseur Serge Bromberg as part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's annual Pordenone Silent Film Weekend. An engaging and enthusiastic speaker who provides his own piano accompaniment for his screenings, Mr. Bromberg comes up with unexpected marvels each time he visits Brooklyn, as he will again tonight. Though he keeps his selections secret until show time, there are always a few astonishments for the cognoscenti, as well as copious pleasures for newcomers. Mr. Bromberg is one of the stalwarts of the Pordenone Film Festival, a showcase for rediscovered and restored silent films held in a small town near Venice. The weekend tribute in Brooklyn continues through Sunday evening with several films recently restored by the Danish Film Institute that were originally presented in the 2006 Pordenone festival. The programs include a focus on the work of August Blom, who was making lengthy, psychologically complex features like the 1913 film ''Atlantis'' (tomorrow) at a time when American movies were struggling to escape the one-reel format, and a screening of Holger-Madsen's remarkable ''Sky Ship'' (Sunday), above, a 1918 science-fiction film about an expedition to Mars that anticipates many conventions of ''Star Trek.''

Neanderthals, an archaic human species that dominated Europe until the arrival of modern humans some 45,000 years ago, possessed a critical gene known to underlie speech, according to DNA evidence retrieved from two individuals excavated from El Sidrón, a cave in northern Spain. The new evidence stems from analysis of a gene called FOXP2, which is associated with language. The human version of the gene differs at two critical points from the chimpanzee version, suggesting that these two changes have something to do with the fact that people can speak and chimps cannot.

BENNY CARTER CENTENNIAL Benny Carter -- the alto saxophonist, trumpeter, clarinetist, composer, arranger and bandleader often hailed in jazz circles as the King -- died in 2003, a much beloved and amply decorated hero of American music. This year marks the centennial of his birth, and the occasion has been duly noted: Today is Benny Carter Day by proclamation of the City of New York, and tonight and tomorrow Jazz at Lincoln Center will kick off its 2007-8 season with Benny Carter-themed concerts. (Carter, above, has also just joined the ranks of the organization's Nesuhi Ertegun Jazz Hall of Fame.) The concerts should be a natural fit for the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra and its artistic director, Wynton Marsalis, and not just for the usual reasons. As a repertory subject, Carter offers rich terrain: He had an unmistakable and hugely influential sound on alto; an innovative style as an arranger, both for bandstand purposes and behind the scenes in Hollywood, which he helped integrate; and a career that actively spanned almost every era of jazz. He was also a sophisticated artist with a cool but firm determination, precisely the sort of figure Mr. Marsalis is happiest to venerate.

CRICHTON--Judy. The Times obit was great. The Emil family added some terrific stuff, and we want to add more. With Henry Guettel as producer, she wrote narrations for Philharmonic Hall concerts devoted to George Gershwin, Jerome Kern, Cole Porter, Rodgers and Hart, Harold Arlen, Noel Coward and Vincent Youmans, featuring such stars as Fred Astaire, Ray Bolger, Barbara Cook, Judy Garland, Florence Henderson, Howard Keel, Peggy Lee, Beatrice Lillie, Jerry Orbach and Mel Torme. She produced the acclaimed documentary Company: The Making Of A Cast Album. Most importantly, she was the warm, wise and infinitely caring first cousin, once removed of Tod, Nina and Kim Beaty, and Adam and Alec Guettel, and the deeply beloved first cousin and best friend of Mary. Rodgers-Beaty-Guettel Family CRICHTON--Judy. Loving, caring, and protective -one couldn't ask for a more compassionate sister. Judy was my mentor as well as my proxy parent, and she was a generous aunt to my son, Mark Bruhmuller. She listened carefully, and made us laugh when we least expected it and needed it most. I can't imagine not hearing her voice. We'll miss her terribly. Contributions may be made to Weill Cornell Medical College ''In memory of Judy Crichton'' made payable to ''Weill Medical College'' and mailed to Gustine Altschuler, Office of Development, Weill Medical College of Cornell University, 1300 York Avenue, Box 123, New York, NY 10065. We feel so alone without her. May the earth lie light upon her. Clarence and Mimi Barasch Lionel and Lili Barasch Jonathan and Lisa Barasch

BAMFIELD is on a remote bay off the Pacific coast of Vancouver Island, about 100 miles northwest of Victoria and inaccessible by paved highways. (The logging road from Port Alberni can be dangerous, and logging trucks have the right of way.) Most cargo and passengers arrive by boat. The Lady Rose and the Frances Barkley (250-723-8313; www.ladyrosemarine.com) run several times a week to Bamfield, depending on the season, from Port Alberni, at the head of the 25-mile-long Alberni Inlet. Seaway Express ferries (250-726-5353; www.seawayexpress.net run from Ucluelet, south of the coastal town of Tofino, which is 40 miles north of Bamfield. Once in town, a visitor does not need a car. West Coast Magic, a gallery and bed-and-breakfast (286 Brady's Beach Trail, Bamfield; 250-728-3132; www.westcoastmagic.com) rents rooms for 120 Canadian dollars ($126 at $1.05 to the Canadian dollar). Several other B & Bs and fishing lodges also rent rooms in town. At the Imperial Eagle Lodge (250-728-3430; www.imperialeaglelodge.com), the accommodations, starting at 99 Canadian dollars, were fine if a little rudimentary, but the food was brilliant.

'DISGUISED AS CLARK KENT: JEWS, COMICS AND THE CREATION OF THE SUPERHERO' Look! Up in the sky! It's a bird! It's a plane! Oy, it's Superman? In the seminar ''Disguised as Clark Kent'' on Sunday, the author Danny Fingeroth will examine the origins of the creators behind some of the most famous and enduring comic-book characters. Mr. Fingeroth, who has written a book of the same title and was an editor at Marvel for nearly 20 years, will discuss how the work of Jerry Siegel and Joe Shuster (the team behind Superman), Will Eisner (the Spirit) and Stan Lee and Jack Kirby (the Fantastic Four and the X-Men) and others were influenced by their Jewish heritage. ''I go through specific story lines, especially through the '50s and '60s that had Jewish content seeping through,'' Mr. Fingeroth said. Those themes include attempts by Superman to go back in time to save Krypton from exploding. He said, ''He had survivor's guilt, as did Captain America, who was frozen in that iceberg for all those years and survived his partner, Bucky.'' In another example Thor, a Marvel hero, was once forbidden by his father, the Norse god Odin, to marry a mortal woman. ''This clearly picks up the immigrant and specifically the Jewish concern of intermarriage,'' he said.

SAM KIM In describing her new work, ''dumb dumb bunny,'' now running at the Kitchen, the choreographer Sam Kim brought up the notion of agency and how people cope with obstacles. The piece, she said, is about the people ''negotiating, and finding their way in a particular environment, with their particular problems.'' The title, she added, conjures an image of a creature ''that is pretty soft and mute and pretty helpless'' -- a far cry from the wonderfully resourceful independent choreographers who routinely transform the Kitchen with their outlandishly fertile imaginations. Ms. Kim, for instance, has a 22-foot-high section of scaffolding as her major set piece, which she and the other performers will scale during the dance. She and her set designer, Mimi Lien, are also ''blinging out'' the walls, mounting strips of bare bulbs that she described as ''very functional but really flashy,'' while the choreography itself offers another contrast: formal components set next to jittery, sloppy movements.

This 7,000-square-foot house, called Heathcote, was once the residence of the Cooper family. It was built in 1865 and is on a 4.6 acre lot. The three-story house has 10 working fireplaces, nine bathrooms, a sweeping main staircase and an original wall mural by Agnes Tate. The property has gardens designed by Ellen Biddle Shipman in 1927 and a barn that has been converted to an artist's studio. Broker: Patricia Ashley, Ashley-Connor Realty, (607) 547-4045; www.ashleyconnorrealty.com.

WARHOL'S WORLD In 1963 Andy Warhol bought his first movie camera, a silent 16-millimeter Bolex, and became what he called ''a do-it-yourself-filmmaker.'' Over the next breathtakingly productive five years, with the help of assorted performers, assistants and beautiful and funky freaks (and a new camera), he did it himself brilliantly, shooting hundreds of silent and sound, color and black-and-white films. Among the titles are 472 portraits of about three minutes (Marcel Duchamp, Edie Sedgwick, Allen Ginsberg, Dennis Hopper, Andrew Sarris) that he called ''Screen Tests'' and that had been inspired by New York City Police Department mug shots, and about 160 additional films of variable running times and formalist concerns, including the eight-hour minimalist epic ''Empire'' (1964). Many of these were never released, but others were projected at Warhol's Factory, in movie theaters and even in a discothèque, as part of a multimedia blowout featuring the Velvet Underground. These films were not cult secrets of the avant-garde; they were a cultural phenomenon. Around 1970, two years after almost dying from gunshot wounds from a would-be assassin, however, Warhol withdrew his 1960s films from circulation, having turned his attention elsewhere.

PERKINS--Audrey Walker, died on October 2, 2007 at the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio. Mrs. Perkins was born on June 9, 1921 in New York City. She graduated with honors from Barnard with a degree in international relations, sociology, and psychology. She studied painting at the National Academy and the Art Students League in New York. Her works are in the permanent collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Newark Museum, and the National Art Museum of Sport. The beloved wife of the late Richard Perkins, she is survived by three children: George Newell, Audrey Newell, and Frances Newell; and three grandchildren. Her love of nature, appreciation of life, kindness to her family and friends, and sense of humor will always be treasured. Mrs. Perkins will be buried in the Memorial Garden at Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, Florida. Funeral services will be announced. In lieu of flowers, gifts in Mrs. Perkins memory may be sent to: The World Wildlife Fund, 1250 24 St. NW, Washington, DC 20037.

(DIY) CELEBRITY RIDES: BURT BUILDS A BANDIT Burt Reynolds, left, and the crew at Year One, an automobile restoration company, blast to the past to spruce up a fleet of limited-edition Pontiac Trans Ams in this latest installment in the custom-car series. President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan on Thursday denounced a peace overture from President Hu Jintao of China that has received a cautious welcome here from both candidates for the presidential election next March. ''It is very clear now that if we were to sign such a peace treaty under the framework of the 'one China' principle, then I think this would mean, for the 23 million people of Taiwan, a treaty of surrender,'' Mr. Chen said in a 90-minute interview at the presidential palace here.

'BOO AT THE ZOO' Zoos are filled with things that go bump in the night -- along with those that go hiss in the daytime, swoop at dusk, howl in the moonlight or growl at all hours. Some of these creatures seem scary, which makes them favorites for Halloween celebrations. But quite a few are actually more beneficial than threatening. That's one of the themes of ''Boo at the Zoo,'' tomorrow and Sunday at the Bronx Zoo and on Oct. 27 and 28 at the Central Park, Queens and Prospect Park Zoos, as well as again in the Bronx. The annual festivities include demonstrations with zookeepers, who usually bust a few myths about their charges, like bats. ''People are very afraid of them, but they're nature's cleanup crew,'' said Linda Corcoran, a Bronx Zoo spokeswoman. ''They're actually recyclers because they eat bugs.''

An article in some editions on Thursday about the fatal shooting of a convenience store owner in Irvington, N.J., gave an erroneous spelling from prosecutors for his given name and included incorrect details from witnesses and the mayor about an incident involving an armed man that took place in the store several hours before the shooting. (The misspelled name also appeared in a picture caption.) The victim was Dewight Cousar, not Dwight. The incident, originally reported as a robbery, might in fact have been only an attempted robbery, according to a law enforcement official, citing contradictory reports as to whether anything had been stolen. The man was armed with a knife, not a gun, and Mr. Cousar was not in fact in the store at the time.

An article on Aug. 30 about an 81-year-old woman from Greencastle, Pa., who was killed during a carjacking, misstated the amount of money the man charged in her death told the police he stole from her. It was $6 or $8, not $68. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message yesterday.

An article on Wednesday about a proposal to simplify the military disability system misstated which members of the military would be served by the new system. The plan would cover all service members who apply for disability benefits once the new system is in place, and service members in the existing system who were severely wounded in Afghanistan and Iraq after October 2001. It would not apply “only to veterans who entered the military after October 2001.”.
A sports article yesterday about the Jets’ weekly meetings between six captains and Coach Eric Mangini misidentified the location of the team’s game tomorrow. It is at Cincinnati, not Cleveland.

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about a renewed dispute in the Pacific Northwest over spotted owls misspelled the surname of a woman shown measuring a Douglas fir. She is Chandra LeGue, not LaGue.

A film review on Wednesday about “O Jerusalem” misidentified the genre of the book of that title, by Larry Collins and Dominique Lapierre, on which the film is based. It is a work of nonfiction, not a novel.

An article on Sept. 23 about New York City’s plans to remake seven blocks of Ninth Avenue in Chelsea to make more room for pedestrians and bicyclists misstated the location of a bike lane that runs directly alongside the sidewalk. It is on the east side of the avenue, not the west.

The TV Watch column in Weekend yesterday, about the season finales of “Mad Men” and “Damages,” misstated the day that the FX network will show past episodes of “Damages.” It is today, from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m.; the past episodes were not shown on Friday. (“Mad Men” ended its season on Thursday; “Damages” will have its finale on Tuesday.).

An article in the Square Feet pages of Business Day on Wednesday about a surge of development in an arts district in Philadelphia omitted a prominent site from a list of arts venues that existed before South Broad Street was designated as the Avenue of the Arts. It is the Academy of Music, at Broad and Locust Streets, where the Opera Company of Philadelphia performs. The article at one point also misstated the name of the street that crosses Broad. It is Washington Avenue, not Washington Street.

An article on Wednesday about a proposal to simplify the military disability system misstated which members of the military would be served by the new system. The plan would cover all service members who apply for disability benefits once the new system is in place, and service members in the existing system who were severely wounded in Afghanistan and Iraq after October 2001. It would not apply “only to veterans who entered the military after October 2001.”.

Jeff Gordon won the pole for the Subway 500 Nextel Cup race tomorrow after qualifying yesterday at Martinsville Speedway in Virginia with a speed of 94.974 miles an hour on the 0.526-mile circuit. The pole is the 63rd of Gordon’s career.

Justine Henin advanced to the Zurich Open semifinals by defeating Agnieszka Radwanska, 6-4, 6-2. Henin will play Nicole Vaidisova, who defeated Alona Bondarenko, 6-1, 6-4. Francesca Schiavone and Tatiana Golovin will meet in the other semifinal.

Suzann Pettersen birdied the final two holes for a three-under-par 69 and shared the first-round lead with Meena Lee in the L.P.G.A. Tour’s Hana Bank Kolon Championship in Gyeongju, South Korea. Four players were at 71.

Ryan Moore, the 24-year-old former United States Amateur champion, matched his career low round with a seven-under-par 63 yesterday to take a three-stroke lead halfway through the Fry’s Electronics Open in Scottsdale, Ariz. Moore was at 11-under 129.

Argentina defeated France, 34-10, yesterday at Parc des Princes in Paris to claim third place at the Rugby World Cup and record its sixth victory in seven matches against France. The final between England and South Africa is tonight in Paris.
The Champions Tour rookie Mark O’Meara shot an eight-under-par 63 to take the first-round lead in the AT&T Championship in San Antonio. John Cook and Wayne Levi were two strokes back.

Trey Hillman was hired yesterday as manager of the Kansas City Royals, taking over a team that has not been to the playoffs since winning the 1985 World Series. He replaces Buddy Bell. Hillman, 44, will be introduced at a news conference Monday. He is currently managing the Nippon Ham Fighters in the Japan World Series. He has spent the last five years managing in Japan. LANE--Arlene, died peacefully at her home in Florida at the age of 83. Arlene was the beloved wife of the late Murray Lane, the cherished mother of Jeffrey Lane (Nancy), Geralyn Lichtenstein (David), and Richard Lane and the adored grandmother of nine grandchildren and thirteen great-grandchildren. She had been a buyer for Federated Department Stores and later a caring and gifted teacher. She possessed a wonderful sense of humor and her greatest passion was her family. She will be greatly missed. Private funeral services were held.

WIMER--Dr. Ernest, died on October 14th in Valhalla, NY. He came from Germany with his parents in 1937 and went into business. Drafted into the Army in 1943, he served in the 82nd Airborne Division. Wounded, he was taken POW and MIA for eight months. Discharged in 1945, he went to Columbia and earned an M.D. from Downstate. He was affiliated with Montefiore Hospital for 25 years. He is survived by his wife Daphne, daughter Deborah, son Keith and wife Melissa, two grandsons; brothers Kurt and wife Sarah, Walter and wife Paula, Henry Wimpfheimer; Manfred predeceased sister-in-law Margie. His loving cousins, nieces, nephews and friends will miss him

LYNN--Theodore S. (Ted). Beloved husband of Linda F. Lynn. Devoted father of Jessica Lynn (Tucker Lee) and Douglas (Jamie) Lynn. Loving grandfather of Maggie Lee and Eden Hannah Lynn. Devoted son of Sydelle Lynn and the late Irving Lynn. Funeral at Central Synagogue, 55th and Lexington, Friday, October 19 at 11:30am. Shiva at his late residence Saturday evening, Sunday 3-8pm, Monday and Tuesday evening. Family requests donations to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation. 383 Main Ave., 5th floor, Norwalk, CT 06851.

SCHNEIDER--Jacqueline Barasch, 89, died October 17th surrounded by her loved ones. Loving wife of the late Henry Schneider. Devoted mother to Michael Schneider and Jean Kelley and the late Barbara Schneider Bruckner. Beloved and cherished grandmother to Robert and Jamie Bruckner, and Max and Ethan Schneider. Adored aunt of Nancy and Murphy, Liz and Kirk, Lionel and Lili, Jonathan and Lisa, John and Laurie, Bob and Michael, Madeleine and Gil. Dearly loved great-aunt to her grandnieces and grandnephews. Loving sister to Clarence Barasch and the late Thelma Rudey and Gladys Blum. A magnificent woman with a big heart and a zest for life who touched all who knew her. She will be deeply missed. Funeral services 10:30am, Sunday, October 21, Park Avenue Synagogue, 87th Street and Madison Avenue. SCHNEIDER--Jacqueline I. (nee Barasch). It is with unspeakable sorrow that we have lost our darling ''Jackie''. She exemplified the saying that ''You must live for others, if you want to live for yourself''. Her initial interest in public housing was broadened to many other fields, too numerous to state. They included her active participation in musical education for the under-priviledged, concerns of Barnard and Columbia students, the deanship of the Columbia School of Law and of Columbia College, rehabilitation medicine at Mount Sinai Hospital and neurology at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital, and the National Council of Jewish Women. She was much beloved by her son, Michael, and daughter-in-law, Jean, and by her husband and daughter, both of whom predeceased her, and by her grandsons, by her brother and by his extended family. We feel so alone without her. May the earth lie light upon her. Clarence and Mimi Barasch Lionel and Lili Barasch Jonathan and Lisa Barasch SCHNEIDER--Jacqueline B. Park Avenue Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted congregant Jacqueline B. Schneider. We extend to her brother Clarence S. Barasch, her children and the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May her memory remain for a blessing. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. Bressman, Chairman of the Board Menachem Z. Rosensaft, President SCHNEIDER--Jacqueline I. The Board of Directors of Henry and Lucy Moses Fund, Inc. mourn the loss of their dear colleague. Jackie Schneider had two great passions in her life. First was her family: her beloved deceased husband Henry Schneider, her son Michael and daughter-in-law Jean, her deceased daughter Barbara, her four grandchildren and the extended Barasch family. Following close behind were the New York City organizations which provided services to the needy and disadvantaged and to which she in turn made enormous contributions with her intelligence, her unfailing judgment and her inexhaustible good humor. Jackie's charitable interests were as broad and diverse as the City itself. Raised in Brooklyn across the street from Prospect Park, Jackie was a fervent supporter of the city's parks, especially Prospect Park and Central Park. She was active with the Citizens Advice Bureau, the largest settlement house in the Bronx; the National Council of Jewish Women, where she nurtured her HIPPY program; the Stanley Isaacs Neighborhood Center, where most recently she was instrumental in creating a program that helps prepare young people for college admission; the Elaine Kaufman Cultural Center, whose formation and development had been guided by Henry Schneider; the Kraft Jewish Center at Columbia University, and too many others to list. New York City and many of the organizations that attempt to make a difference in the lives of its citizens have suffered a grievous loss in the passing of Jackie Schneider. SCHNEIDER--Jacqueline, NCJW, NY Section, mourns the loss of Jacqueline Schneider. Dedicated, loved and revered Honorary Board Member, devoted advocate of HIPPY (Home Instruction for Parents of Preschool Youngsters), honored winner of the Hannah G. Solomon Award. Her wit and wisdom will be sadly missed. Sincerest sympathy to her family. Beatrice Kahn, Beth Mitchell, Co-Presidents

FISHBEIN--Myrna. Cherished wife of the late Eli Fishbein, beloved mother of Sarah and Steven Epstein, Elisa and Clint Greenbaum, Kalman and Susie Fishbein, loving ''grandma'' of Jake, Lauren, Kate, Augusta, Craig, Dani, Jodi and Eli. BYRNES--Michael Thomas. 41 years old. Michael died peacefully on October 7, 2007 in San Francisco, CA surrounded by his loved ones. He battled pancreatic cancer for two years. He was a wonderful father, son, brother and uncle. He is survived by his daughter, Glenna and her mother, Julie Roberts, both of San Francisco. In addition, he is survived by his father, Jack, of Brooklyn, NY; his sisters, Maureen Corley, Kathleen Baatz and Ellen Arbeeny and his brother, John. Michael loved life and above all loved his family and friends. He will be forever in our hearts and will be greatly missed by all who knew him. Celebration Services will be held in Brooklyn, NY, San Francisco, CA and Boston, MA.

FRENKL--Tony, age 93. Beloved wife of the late Kurt, devoted mother of Jorene, very special ''OMI'' of granddaughter Hillary and good friend to many. A woman who put the needs of others before her own, she will be greatly missed.

LaVALLEE--Christopher M., 37, died on October 19, 2007 at home in NYC surrounded by his family. Beloved husband of Barbara and loving father of Andrew. Devoted son of Faye and Edward LaVallee and brother of Lisa LaVallee. A graduate of Syracuse University and devout Orangeman. Mr. LaVallee was a Vice President at Goldman Sachs. A wonderful friend and incredible man, he will be dearly missed. Visitation at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76 St., NYC on Sunday 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral mass on Monday at Holy Trinity, 213 West 82nd St., NYC at 11:30am. Donations in his memory may be made to The Brain Tumor Foundation, 1350 Avenue of Americas, Suite 1200, NY, NY 10019, Attn: Ethan Schnur.

(Starz) THE PURSUIT OF HAPPYNESS (2006) Will Smith, above, in an Oscar-nominated performance, and his son Jaden Christopher Syre Smith star in this drama inspired by the true story of Chris Gardner, a down-on-his-luck father who conquers nearly insurmountable obstacles -- including the departure of his wife (Thandie Newton), eviction, and life in shelters and on the streets -- on his way to the American dream. ''How you respond to this man's moving story may depend on whether you find Mr. Smith's and his son's performances so overwhelmingly winning that you buy the idea that poverty is a function of bad luck and bad choices, and success the result of heroic toil and dreams,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. 8 P.M. (WE) HAUNTED The channel brews up an evening of spooky stuff, starting with the tales of a theater haunted by an opera singer who died backstage and a witch who watches over her family after a house burning. At 9, ''Rescue Mediums'' closes one season with an investigation into an island home exhibiting paranormal activity; at 9:30, it opens a new one by venturing into an opera house turned nightclub in Barrie, Ontario. And at 10, ''John Edward Cross Country'' visits the set of ''Ghost Whisperer.''

Cadel Evans captured the Pro Tour title at the Giro di Lombardia, finishing sixth behind the winner Damiano Cunego yesterday in Como, Italy.Cunego, with the Lampre team, covered the 150-mile route from Varese to Como in 5 hours 52 minutes 48 seconds. He beat Riccardo Ricco in a sprint finish. Cunego also won the season-ending classic in 2004, the same year he won the Giro d’Italia.Evans entered the race with 227 points. Alberto Contador (191) did not enter and Alejandro Valverde (190) was out with the flu.Danilo Di Luca, who led Evans by 15 points, was excluded from the race after he was handed a three-month ban this week by the Italian Olympic Committee after a doping investigation.

Five Alabama players, including the starting offensive linemen Antoine Caldwell and Marlon Davis and tailback Glen Coffee, were suspended for yesterday’s game against No. 20 Tennessee for a violation of university policy involving the receipt of textbooks.The university discovered the infractions Thursday but did not elaborate on what happened. Also suspended were the reserve defensive backs Marquis Johnson and Chris Rogers. Coffee is Alabama’s second-leading rusher with 413 yards.

Suzann Pettersen shot an even-par 72 for a one-stroke lead after the second round of the L.P.G.A.’s Hana Bank Kolon Championship in Gyeongju, South Korea.Pettersen, sidelined for eight months in 2005 because of a career-threatening back injury, has had a breakthrough season, winning her first major title in the L.P.G.A. Championship in June. Eun-Hee Ji shot a four-under 68 for the best round of the day to move into second place with a 142. Seon Hwa Lee (71) and Jeong Jang (72) are another stroke back at 143. Lorena Ochoa, who wrapped up her second straight player of the year award last week, shot a 75 and is six strokes off the pace at 147.

Justine Henin rallied to defeat Nicole Vaidisova yesterday, 3-6, 6-3, 7-5, and advanced to the final of the Zurich Open today. The top-ranked Henin will play Tatiana Golovin, who defeated Francesca Schiavone, 6-0, 6-4, in the other semifinal.The 15th-ranked Vaidisova did not succumb easily.Henin dropped a set for only the second time since losing in the semifinals at Wimbledon. She also lost a set against Golovin before defeating her in a final in Germany earlier this month.Henin, a winner of 19 consecutive matches, has captured eight titles in 12 tournaments this season.In the final set, Henin broke to lead, 3-2. She converted the first of two break points by drilling a forehand to the baseline that Vaidisova could not return. Trailing by 5-3, Vaidisova saved two match points to hold serve. She then broke the next game.Henin had saved two break points, but she smashed a lazy lob into the net. The following point, Henin angrily threw her racket to the ground after hitting a backhand shot well wide.Henin finally broke for good the next game, putting Vaidisova on the defensive and ending the match with a forehand winner.

A chart with an article on Sept. 30 about the business model of The St. Petersburg Times in Florida included an incorrect figure from Nielsen/NetRatings for the Web site traffic of a competitor, The Tampa Tribune, in November 2006. The total number of unique visitors was about 870,000, not 637,247, according to Nielsen/NetRatings.

The Bond Yields chart on the DataBank pages from Aug. 12 through last Sunday transposed the four-week yield changes for Treasury notes and municipal bonds. And the Regional Indexes chart in the DataBank on Oct. 7 and last Sunday used an incorrect scale; it should have indicated changes of plus or minus 8 percent, not 4 percent. Today’s charts, on Page 12, show the correct changes for the last four weeks. A reader pointed out the Bond Yields error in an e-mail message last week.

An article last Sunday about the different rights accorded to citizens and noncitizens referred incorrectly in some copies to the 120,000 people of Japanese ancestry interned in the United States during World War II. More than 70,000 of them were citizens born in the United States; they were not all immigrants.

An article last Sunday about the odds of winning in the baseball playoffs misstated the probability that a team with a 40 percent chance of winning an individual game would also win a best-of-five series. The team would win the series nearly one-third of the time, not more than one-third of the time.

An article last Sunday about the fashion industry’s reticence to use black models referred incorrectly to a black woman in a maid’s outfit pictured in the September issue of Italian Vogue. She was, in fact, a maid at the hotel where the pictures were taken, and was included, the Vogue photographer said, because of her attractiveness and her ability to underscore the pictures’ theme of a stereotypical rich white woman who hires ethnic servants; the black woman was not a model dressed as a maid.

Reading Robert Sullivan’s article (Oct. 7) on Todd Haynes’s Dylan movie, I was reminded of Todd Solondz’s film “Palindromes,” released in 2004. In “Palindromes,” a rather more controversial film, Solondz chose eight different actors, varying in gender, age, size and race, to portray Aviva, his young female protagonist. While there are clear differences between the two films, Haynes and Solondz seem to have grasped the same idea, creating character by way of collage in order to better portray the fractured nature of an individual’s existence.

Pumpkin is one of the latest ingredients to hit the spa menu. “It brightens the skin without any harmful chemicals,” says Susan Ciminelli of the Susan Ciminelli Day Spa in New York, where you can indulge in a Pumpkin Plum Renewal Treatment ($200 for a full-body scrub). Packed with fruit enzymes, beta carotene, antioxidants and minerals, it’s the kinder, gentler alternative to glycolic acid. The fruit sloughs off dead skin cells while treating the baby-fresh skin underneath to help prolong the glow. For a homemade treatment, Ciminelli suggests steaming the pumpkin, then peeling it and pulsing in a food processor. (Add yogurt and steamed prunes into the mix for a deeper exfoliation.) I was born with poor judgement, the way others are born color-blind or without a sense of rhythm. I once fell in love with a man because he had no ambition, which I found refreshing. I am no better with things than with people. I’ve purchased worthless exercise equipment advertised on late-night infomercials that take up more closet space than my clothes. I once bought a pair of silver sneakers that would look good only in space. I purchased a Marc Jacobs shirt with no buttons just because I got it for a really good price. I have yet to replace the buttons. I own a pair of Kelly-green corduroys. Need I say more? Although I am aware of my disability, I can’t help but gravitate toward these Christian Dior shoes (above). They call to the Carmen Miranda in me. They are candy-apple red. They match nothing in my wardrobe. With that precarious heel, a tumble in these spine wranglers could lead to a life confined to a wheelchair. And what of the damage they can do to others? I will probably fall while walking down Fifth Avenue and, feet in the air, manage to gouge out the eye of a small child with the knifelike stiletto heel. It is one of Madonna’s kids. Great. Now we will never be best friends.

Not every Ph.D. student blows her fellowship money at Barneys New York. But for the urban planner Elizabeth Currid, her passion for style led to some interesting statistics, which she examines in “The Warhol Economy: How Fashion, Art & Music Drive New York City” (Princeton University Press). “The people who create the music you love, the art you like to look at, the fashion you wear — they aren’t just cool and sexy but innovative and important,” Currid says. The city’s real competitive edge lies not in the tech or finance sectors but in the frothier fields like fashion, design and night life: a drink at Bungalow 8 could be more influential than a Four Seasons power lunch. Testimony from the likes of Ryan McGinness and Clap Your Hands Say Yeah explains how art stars, indie bands and groovy young things keep this town fashionable and flush.

Au naturel is over. This season, the ubiquitous French manicure gets the bold treatment: on the runway, the designer Tracy Reese showed black on ivory to match her spectator pumps; the nails at Paul Smith were decorated with dark red-and-beige stripes; and the maroon at Dior (above) matched the shoes and bags. To create your own double-dip look, apply a white or ivory base color to tapered almond-shaped nails, then paint a vibrant-colored half-moon starting at the middle of the nail plate. Do not, however, expect longevity. As Ji Baek, the owner of Rescue Beauty Lounge, warns, “In the era of the BlackBerry and iPhone, this might not be easy to maintain.”.

KAMO KATSUYA: According to the Japanese hairstylist Kamo Katsuya, whose story “Mountain Do” appears on Page 88, there is no such thing as a bad hair day. “I see my work as having two characters,” he says. “I like to express a conflicting image.” For Kamo (his preferred moniker), this means working with a wide range of oddball materials like exotic bird feathers, paper origami and even latex (examples are at right). “I will use anything that is nearby,” he says. A regular collaborator with style compatriots Junya Watanabe and Jun Takahashi, Kamo follows a routine when it comes to teamwork: “First, I give them my idea, and then we work closely together on it.”.

COOPER--Gladys B. , 76, of Monroe Township, New Jersey, died Tuesday, October 16, 2007. Services were held at Bernheim - Apter - Kreitzman Suburban Funeral Chapel in Livingston, New Jersey (800) 938-6372, on Thursday, October 18, 2007. Surviving are her daughter, Lori B. Cooper, her son, Jeffrey A. Cooper, his wife, Elizabeth Schrero Cooper, and two grandchildren, Arielle and Daniel. She will be missed by all. Ms. Cooper served as an Assistant Prosecutor for the County of Essex from 1969 to 1994. She was a successful trial lawyer and a role model to many. She was the Director of the Domestic Violence Bureau. Ms. Cooper was a world traveler and a voracious reader. Ms. Cooper graduated from Bryn Mawr College and Seton Hall Law School in Newark. Memorial contributions can be made in memory of Gladys B. Cooper to Bryn Mawr College of Bryn Mawr, PA.
