PERKINS--Audrey Walker , died on October 2, 2007 at the Cleveland Clinic in Ohio. Mrs. Perkins was born on June 9, 1921 in New York City. She graduated with honors from Barnard with a degree in international relations, sociology, and psychology. She studied painting at the National Academy and the Art Students League in New York. Her works are in the permanent collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Newark Museum, and the National Art Museum of Sport. The beloved wife of the late Richard Perkins, she is survived by three children: George Newell, Audrey Newell, and Frances Newell; and three grandchildren. Her love of nature, appreciation of life, kindness to her family and friends, and sense of humor will always be treasured. Mrs. Perkins will be buried in the Memorial Garden at Christ Memorial Chapel in Hobe Sound, Florida. Funeral services will be announced. In lieu of flowers, gifts in Mrs. Perkins memory may be sent to: The World Wildlife Fund, 1250 24 St. NW, Washington, DC 20037.

YEARWOOD--Edmundo deLorenzo , 1923-2007. Edmundo deL Yearwood a resident of New York City and Barbados, W.I. died on October 4, 2007. He was 84 years old. Born in New York City, he was raised and educated in Washington, D.C. where he lived until he completed his Masters in Social Work at Howard University. He was employed as a Social Worker for the NYC Board of Education and, later, as the Senior Psychiatric Social Worker for the NY State Dept. of Mental Hygiene, Upper Manhattan After-Care Clinic. In 1971 he served as Chief of Service for the Kings County State School of the NY Dept. of Mental Hygiene until he retired in 1978. He served in the US Army Air Force during WWII. He is survived by a brother, Curtis Lambert, of Washington, D.C.

KAUFMAN--Monroe (''Mike'') , of Roslyn Heights, NY, earlier this month at the age of 77. We have lost our family leader, and our intellectual inspiration. A gifted thinker and insatiable lifelong student with great passion for the languages of mathematics and of words. An accomplished man with Degrees in Math, Mechanical Engineering and an MBA. A business executive and Graduate Business School Professor. In his seventies, a designer of valuable computer software, a trusted business advisor and NASD Arbitrator. A provocative conversationalist with a love of ideas and a charming wit. An avid tennis player, and talented pianist, and undefeated master of The Times Double Crostic. A devoted son, husband, father, uncle, grandpa and friend.

LUCKY SHOPS, the annual super-sale of clothes and accessories to be presented by Lucky Magazine on Friday and Saturday at the Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street (Sixth Avenue), is going national. At luckyshops.com, virtual shoppers can partake in the retail frenzy starting today; more than 50 designers -- including Marc Jacobs, Stella McCartney, Balenciaga and Derek Lam -- are represented, and discounts are up to 70 percent. Actual shoppers (last year, over 5,000 visitors came from 40 states) can browse at a denim bar that offers on-site alterations and at two booths of vintage and new high-end pieces that will give 100 percent of their proceeds to Baby Buggy, a charity that benefits children of families in need. Admission tickets are $40 to $85 at luckyshops.com.

WIMER--Dr. Ernest , died on October 14th in Valhalla, NY. He came from Germany with his parents in 1937 and went into business. Drafted into the Army in 1943, he served in the 82nd Airborne Division. Wounded, he was taken POW and MIA for eight months. Discharged in 1945, he went to Columbia and earned an M.D. from Downstate. He was affiliated with Montefiore Hospital for 25 years. He is survived by his wife Daphne, daughter Deborah,son Keith and wife Melissa, two grandsons; brothers Kurt and wife Sarah, Walter and wife Paula, Henry Wimpfheimer; Manfred predeceased sister-in-law Margie. His loving cousins, nieces, nephews and friends will miss him.

Alber Elbaz once thought about becoming a doctor, and his approach to design is a combination of the analytical and the beautiful. He is fascinated by women -- by their desires, their responsibilities, their various guises -- and in each collection for Lanvin, he has sought to find a way to decode that tangle of moods. Like a physician, Elbaz looks for remedies, a solution to any dressing dilemma. ''In the end,'' he explained recently, as he was designing his spring collection, ''you don't need that much. When I left New York for France, I took only two suitcases. I always construct my collections with that thought in mind.'' When it came to envisioning a wardrobe for Jennifer Jason Leigh, who stars in ''Margot at the Wedding,'' which is to be released on Nov. 16, Elbaz saw infinite possibilities: ''She is so complex, like the women who buy my clothes. When I design, I don't think about a particular body part -- I think about what women want and what they dream.'' With that in mind, Elbaz offered some tenets of his fashion philosophy.

ZISMAN--Maureen Frances Brumond . June 20, 1935-October 14, 2007. ''She walks in beauty, like the night, Of cloudless climes and starry skies; And all that's best of dark and bright, Meet in her aspect and her eyes, And on that cheek, and o'er that brow, So soft, so calm, yet eloquent, The smiles that win, the tints that glow, But tell of days in goodness spent, A mind at peace with all below, A heart whose love is innocent!'' Irreplaceable, brave and beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, stepmother, mother and sister-inlaw, and friend. Born Jersey City, New Jersey to Albert and Margaret Brumond, passed away in Irving, Texas where she had lived a quarter-century before recently moving to Frisco Lakes, Texas. Raised on Long Island and a longtime resident of Rockville Centre, NY, she graduated from St. Agnes High School and received her Associates Degree from Briarcliff Manor College. Survived by Barry Zisman, her husband of almost 28 years, children, Doreen, Tracy and William Waxon, stepchildren Michael Zisman and wife Esi Alzamora, Marlene ZismanClark and husband Jesse Clark, grandchildren Ryan, Connor, Kevin and Jack Waxon, step-grandchildren Zoe and Jackson Clark, daughterin-law Jackie Waxon, brother Albert Brumond, brother and sister-in-laws Myron and Linda Zisman. With dignity and grace, she courageously fought Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) for over a decade. Donations may be made in her name to the American Lung Association. Visitation was held Wednesday from 6-8pm at Sparkman Hillcrest Funeral Home. A funeral mass was held at St. Monica Catholic Church at 2:00pm on Thursday, October 18, 2007 in Dallas, Texas. Temporary entombment at Hillcrest Mausoleum in Dallas followed the service. Permanent interment will take place at a future date in Pinelawn Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island, NY. With all my love, forever and a day. B.Z.

DOUBLE DUTY The ultimate goal for any designer who is committed to sustainability is not just to use less energy, less material and less packaging but also to do away with as many objects as possible. At least that's what Naoto Fukasawa is after. He is hardly a household name in the United States, but Fukasawa is the leading industrial designer in Japan, where his cellphones are coveted. Fukasawa's less-is-more approach involves combining different functions into single products. His Tile Light, for example, is both bathroom tile and light fixture. He is now conducting a research project with the Japanese industrial group Matsushita to develop ''intelligent walls'' -- modular panels, each with a functional purpose of providing, say, lighting, heating or sound. ''It's already happening,'' he says. ''I'm just creating the inevitable.'' BRIGHT IDEA They'll soon be illegal in Australia, and they may be banned in parts of Europe and possibly the United States too. The environmental argument to abolish something as wasteful as the old-fashioned incandescent light bulb is fairly incontestable. But perhaps the only thing keeping consumers from switching on their own accord is the fact that energyefficient bulbs are just not that great-looking. ''The light quality isn't that delicious; it's too cold,'' says the British designer Tom Dixon. ''But the energy savings from using, say, a compact fluorescent bulb is phenomenal. We decided to create a shade to house one in the shape of an enlarged bulb, which allows the cold light to warm up a bit.'' Dixon unveiled the Blow Light in a giant outdoor installation in Trafalgar Square during last month's London Design Festival, culminating in the Great Give Away, when more than 1,500 Londoners packed into the square, hoping to leave with one of the 1,000 free Blow Lights.
Model, muse and wife to both George Harrison and Eric Clapton, the blond-haired, pouty-lipped Pattie Boyd is the ultimate English bird.

OPPOSITE POLES ATTRACT when it comes to Antonio Ben Chimol's magnet wrap bracelets, the new adornment of choice around the wrists -- and the necks and ankles -- of Uptown gossip girls and their mothers. The concept is stylishly simple: A 20-inch leather lace is fitted with gold-plated ultrastrength magnet closures on each end. The leather thong can then be wrapped once around the neck, twice around an ankle, thrice around a wrist or even attached to another bracelet for greater length. When not in use, coil the bracelet around a handbag handle or just stick it on the fridge (in gold, black or magenta leather; $130 at ravinstyle.com).

SCHNEIDER--Jacqueline I . The Board of Directors of Henry and Lucy Moses Fund, Inc. mourn the loss of their dear colleague. Jackie Schneider had two great passions in her life. First was her family: her beloved deceased husband Henry Schneider, her son Michael and daughter-in-law Jean, her deceased daughter Barbara, her four grandchildren and the extended Barasch family. Following close behind were the New York City organizations which provided services to the needy and disadvantaged and to which she in turn made enormous contributions with her intelligence, her unfailing judgment and her inexhaustible good humor. Jackie's charitable interests were as broad and diverse as the City itself. Raised in Brooklyn across the street from Prospect Park, Jackie was a fervent supporter of the city's parks, especially Prospect Park and Central Park. She was active with the Citizens Advice Bureau, the largest settlement house in the Bronx; the National Council of Jewish Women, where she nurtured her HIPPY program; the Stanley Isaacs Neighborhood Center, where most recently she was instrumental in creating a program that helps prepare young people for college admission; the Elaine Kaufman Cultural Center, whose formation and development had been guided by Henry Schneider; the Kraft Jewish Center at Columbia University, and too many others to list. New York City and many of the organizations that attempt to make a difference in the lives of its citizens have suffered a grievous loss in the passing of Jackie Schneider. Gray squirrels may be displacing their more staid British cousins, but your writer might have mentioned a revenge of sorts in America. During the 1730s and '40s -- the so-called golden age of the Chesapeake gentry -- planters in Virginia and Maryland took to fox hunting. Hardly had the first huntsman's horn sounded, however, when they discovered a serious obstacle to this amusement. The gray fox, native to America, reclusive and skittish, refused to play along. The gentry, who already imported their hounds, thoroughbreds and riding clothes from England, added the red fox to the list. Clever and wildly audacious, it was the behavioral opposite of the dull and disinterested gray fox. But the same characteristics that made the red fox more sporting have made it a more effective competitor for habitat and resources in America. The red fox in America, like the gray squirrel in Britain, has gradually crowded out its trans-Atlantic cousin from its own territory.

8:30 P.M. (Nickelodeon) THE UNTOUCHABLE KIDS OF INDIA In the world's largest democracy, the caste system still oppresses a group of more than 150 million people -- the Dalits, or untouchables, considered so far below the rest of the population as to be subhuman, to the point that traditionally their shadows were not allowed to fall on members of the upper castes. Although it has been illegal in India to practice inequality and segregation since 1950, discrimination in living conditions, employment and education still occurs. In this ''Nick News'' special, Linda Ellerbee, above, travels to India to interview Dalit children who are fighting for their rights. ''Can they change their world?'' she asks. ''As Gandhi said, 'You may never know what result may come from your action, but if you do nothing, there will be no result.' '' 8 P.M. SHIRES--G. Tom, M.D. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend and colleague Dr. G. Tom Shires. The former Dean of Weill Cornell Medical College and Provost for Medical Affairs at Cornell University, the Lewis Atterbury Stimson Professor and Chairman of Surgery at Cornell University Medical College (now Weill Cornell Medical College) and Surgeon-in-Chief at The New York Hospital (now NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/ Weill Cornell Medical Center), Dr. Shires was deeply committed to excellence in clinical care, medical education and biomedical research. He helped found Weill Cornell's William Randolph Hearst Burn Center, now one of largest centers of its kind in the world; his research into fluid management for trauma patients changed clinical practice; he played a key role in organizing Emergency Medical Services (EMS) in New York City and launching the state's first helicopter ambulance service; and he led influential professional organizations, including the International Surgical Society, American Board of Surgery, American College of Surgeons and the American Surgical Association. In 1963, he became a part of history, performing successful emergency surgery on Governor John Connally following the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. We remember Dr. Shires as an extraordinary surgeon, scientist, leader and a man of impeccable character who instantly earned the respect and affection of everyone with whom he came into contact. We are grateful for his many achievements and will miss him dearly. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to the family of Dr. Shires, including his wife, Robbie Jo, and his children, Donna Jacquelyn, G. Tom III and Jo Ellen. Sanford I. Weill Chairman Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College John Mack Chairman Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NY-Presbyterian Hospital Fabrizio Michelassi, M.D. Chairman of Surgery NY-Presbyterian Hospital Weill Cornell Medical College

GULBRANDSEN--Natalie Webber , former Moderator of the Unitarian Universalist Association, of Newton, MA, formerly of Wellesley, MA, died at her home on October 17, 2007. Born July 7, 1919 in Beverly, MA, she was the oldest of five children born to Kathryn Mary Doherty and Arthur Hammond Webber. A graduate of Beverly High School, 1937, and Bates College, 1942, she committed boundless energy to the community, her church and the larger world. She was married to Dr. Melvin H. Gulbrandsen, a Wellesley dentist, for 48 years. Mrs. Gulbrandsen served two terms as Moderator of the Unitarian Universalist Association and President of the International Association for Religious Freedom. She received honorary degrees from Meadville Lombard Theological School and Bates College as well as the Unitarian Universalist Distinguished Service Award for lifetime service. She is survived by her five children and their spouses, 11 grandchildren, a brother and extended family. There will be visiting hours at the George F. Doherty & Sons Funeral Home, 477 Washington St., Wellesley, MA, on Friday, November 9, 2007 from 5-8pm and a celebration of her life at 10:30am on November 10, 2007 at the Unitarian Universalist Society of Wellesley Hills, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory can be made to the Natalie Gulbrandsen Ministerial International Scholarship Fund, 25 Beacon St., Boston, MA. AS federal regulators and industry groups debate creating standards for explaining mortgage terms to borrowers, Washington Mutual is pushing ahead with its own initiative, which it says will help borrowers avoid bad loans. The company's new rules apply to its loans marketed through 19,000 independent mortgage brokers, among other outlets, but not through its own branches. Earlier this month, it began requiring brokers to verify that they have disclosed key loan terms, spelled out in simplified language. Washington Mutual will also call borrowers before the mortgage closes to review the terms.

MEADOFF--Alan Samuel , passed away at the age of 64 on October 8, 2007 in his home in Jamestown, NC. Originally from New York, he was the devoted son of Joyce and the late Harold, brother of Gail, Randy and Laurie. Alan lived life passionately, fully and on his own terms. He was a unique individual who was ahead of his time and defied conformity. As The founder of Giorgio, an innovative collection of contemporary home furnishings, Alan's creative marketing ability, intelligence, style and outrageous humor made him a one of a kind success. The gift of his retirement was the commitment to mentoring and fathering a local group of Lost Boys of the Sudan. His passion for these boys was as life changing for Alan as it was for them. The family would like to acknowledge the friends and caretakers who were a source of strength to Alan in the last month's of his life. Contributions can be made to the ''African Service Colaliation'' earmarked for the Alan Meadoff Memorial Fund, 122 North Elm St., Suite 500, Greensboro, NC 27401.

EAST MIDLANDS, BOATING ON THE RIVER SOAR, MAY 10, 2007 Jim Senner, 64, a semiretired State Department Foreign Service officer from Arapahoe, N.C.: ''This photo was taken during a two-week canal-boat trip in England with my wife, daughter and grandson. We were on the river somewhere south of Nottingham. My son-in-law Butch, who is a colonel in the Air Force, had just left us halfway through the trip to go to Iraq for six months. The weather had been pretty rainy most of the time but we were enjoying a few hours of sun. We had just cracked a bottle of wine with lunch and toasted the absent Butch. I was reflecting on how lucky we were to be together, traveling through some of the prettiest parts of England. A day or so later our grandson Max took his first steps in a canal-side pub.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

JODY--Boris A. , 88 years old, December 18, 1918-October 16, 2007. Boris was born in Lithuania in 1918, he left home in 1934 at age 16 to attend Sorbonne University in France, studying textile engineering. He graduated in 1938 but could not return to Lithuania due to impending German invasion. His family's home and extensive business holdings were seized by the Germans in 1940. Boris was in France and wanted to join the war against the Nazis. His father, through business connections, was able to arrange his travel papers to England, and Boris was sponsored by a member of Parliament to join the Royal Air Force. He became a pilot, flew many missions over the English Channel, and served 6 years rising to the rank of Captain. After the war he was granted British citizenship, however after uniting with his parents in a displaced persons camp in Europe, where he also met Lillian Zloto who became his wife, he decided to immigrate to the United States. He arrived at Ellis Island with his parents in 1947, married Lillian and started a new life. Boris worked at Standard Motor Products in Long Island City, NY for 42 years starting as a foreman and retiring as senior Vice President of what was by then a Fortune 500 company. His 17 years of retirement starting in 1990 were spent happily in Boca Raton, FL and Los Angeles, CA. Boris leaves behind his wife of 60 years Lillian, his two children, Gilbert Jody M.D. of Los Angeles, CA and Darlene Jody M.D. of Watchung, NJ, his daughterin-law Diane Jody, his son-inlaw Michael Lampert M.D. and six loving grandchildren, Sean, Joanna, Ryan, Andrew, Taylor, Erika. A memorial service is scheduled in New York City on Saturday October 27th, 4:30pm at New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th St. The family will open their home to friends and relatives on Sunday October 28th at 1pm in Watchung, NJ. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the Jewish National Fund www.jnf.org

CRICHTON--Judy Feiner . Adoring grandmother of Hannah and Gillon Crichton, Andrew and Catherine Emil, and Eliza Martin. We note with love certain omissions in Judy's glowing obituary of October 17, 2007. Judy's life was dedicated to journalistic integrity and support for the unjustly disenfranchised. She was a lifelong supporter of democratic causes including work in the presidential campaign of Adlai Stevenson, vocal and effective opposition to the Vietnam War, and unswerving support of the African National Congress in its years of opposition to apartheid rule in South Africa. In addition to the shows which earned her six Emmy awards, she was the producer of the ill fated and justly forgotten quiz show, ''The Generation Gap'' (ABC 1968-1969). And she never owned a pair of socks. We will sorely miss her and her fascination with all life has to offer. The Emil Family

UNGER--Robert Samuel , 90, of Victoria, British Columbia, beloved husband of Beverly Kerness Unger for 63 years and devoted father of Jane Unger, Martha Rothstein, Tom Unger and Sally Unger on October 12, 2007,of cardiac arrest in Portland, OR. Like a cat with nine lives, his life had many incarnations. Born in South Bend, IN, he grew up in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. He graduated from the U. of Penn School of Dentistry and then served as a Lt. Cmdr for the U.S. Navy in Newfoundland during World War II. He developed a passion for fly fishing there, which he passed onto his children and in-laws,traveling with them to remote corners of the world to pursue this sport. His work as a master dentist led him to a thriving practice in Manhattan, which later moved to Hempstead, to Westbury, NY, and then to Salt Spring Island, B.C., where he lived for 28 years before moving to Victoria. Referred by many of his patients as the ''Michelangelo of dentistry'' he specialized in reconstructive dentistry and did his own crown and bridge work. His artistry as a dentist extended to a mastery of jewelry making. His many other passionate interests included Scrabble, the N.Y. Times crossword puzzle, the theatre, tennis and social reform. He will espec ially be remembered for his love of story-telling, his sense of humor and above all, his love for his wife, four children and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to Amnesty International, the NAACP, or the Robert S. Unger Memorial Scholarship Fund c/o Gulf Islands Educational Trust, Salt Spring Island, B.C.

ROSENMAN--Audrey . The Board of Directors and staff of Citizens' Committee for Children of New York mourn the passing of Audrey Rosenman and extend our condolences to her family, friends and the colleagues who share our deep respect for and awe of her lifelong commitment to New York's children and families. Ms. Rosenman was a decadeslong supporter of CCC and, as a Board Member, was a tireless champion of our YouthAction NYC program, serving New York City high school students. She will be greatly missed. Judith Garson, Chairman Maryann Marston, President Jennifer March-Joly, Acting Executive Director ROSENMAN--Audrey (nee Askin) died October 18, 2007 at the age of 73. Born in New York City to Arnold Askin and Fannie (Halff.) Beloved wife of Mervin Rosenman, deceased. Loving mother of Laurie and Christina Weltz, sister of Edith Ehrlich, devoted grandmother of India Ennenga, Edmond and Oliver Ritter. Audrey graduated from Barnard College and received a Masters in Social Work from Columbia University. She worked for many years as a a therapist both in private practice and as counselor to the Chapin School. She was actively involved with the Henry Street Settlement, joining the Board in 1961 and serving as Chairman from 1987-2003. She also was involved with Citizens' Committee for Children and the President's Council at Barnard. Audrey will be remembered for her tireless energy and unbridled enthusiasm for life. She will be missed by many. Funeral services will be held Thursday, October 25th at 5pm at Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel) Madison Ave. at 81st Street, NY. In lieu of flowers please send donations in Audrey's name to the Henry Street Settlement. ROSENMAN--Audrey. The Board of Directors and staff of Henry Street Settlement mourn the death of Audrey Rosenman, a Board member of 46 years, serving as Chairman and President for 24 years. Audrey guided the Settlement through a period of unprecedented growth, resulting in the creation of innovative programs, financial stability and international visibility, welcoming such visitors as Princess Diana and President Bill Clinton. Audrey will be remembered as a strong but gentle leader and generous benefactor whose dedication to Henry Street will be felt for many years to come. She left an indelible mark not only on Henry Street and the Lower East Side community, but on all New Yorkers whose lives she touched personally and even more who reaped the benefits of the Settlement's services she nurtured. We extend our deepest sympathy to Laurie and Christina and their families.

Paris is enjoying a new belle époque. The fashion shows, above, have replaced the races as the fashionable promenade. Two weeks ago, 3,000 stylish guests gathered in the Grand Palais for the Chanel show. Spectators in the back rows had to use digital cameras to zoom in on the models, as the 1912 ladies, below, used binoculars at Longchamp. The trends-to-be included: autumnal tweed coats; day dresses; gray, black and white; and sweaters with cuff bracelets. Even the novelty penguin sweater echoed sophisticated white bib-front necklines. When critics say there is no high fashion, that's baloney. In my 60 years of covering the Paris shows, I have never seen anything like today.

CAMPBELL--Dr. Francis P. , Prominent Retinal Surgeon, 84. Francis Patrick Campbell peacefully expired at his home in Manhattan on October 1, 2007. The cause was complications of Parkinson's Disease. Born in Drumquin Co., Tyrone, Northern Ireland on October 1, 1923, he received his medical degree from the Royal College of Surgeons, Dublin, Ireland, L.R.C.S.I., L.R.C.P.I., (1946) where he was awarded First Prize Medal, Physiology and MacNaughton - Jones Gold Medal, Obstetrics and Gynecology. He was a resident in surgery at Riverside Hospital, Newport News, Virginia and in Ophthalmology at New York University Medical Center-Bellevue Hospital, New York City; NIH Special Research Fellow 1958-1960; Visiting Fellow, Institute of Ophthalmology, Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, 1961. He was Clinical Professor of Ophthalmology at New York University School of Medicine from 1977; Director of Retinal Surgery at Bellevue Hospital, New York University Medical Center and St. Clare's Hospital; Attending at St. Vincent's Hospital, Cabrini Hospital, Veterans Administration Medical Center, and New York Eye and Ear Infirmary; Fellow and member of several medical societies. He practiced clinical ophthalmology specializing in retinal disorders in Manhattan and taught the art of retinal surgery to ophthalmic residents. He served honorably as Captain, Medical Corp. in the U.S. Army, 1951-1955 and received a Bronze Star in Korea, 1954. He was also a Regimental Surgeon in Germany and Chief, Surgical Service, U.S. Army Hospital, Kyoto, Japan. He became a U.S. Naturalized Citizen in Seoul, Korea (1954). His success in medicine was complemented by a full life as a devoted loving husband, father and grandfather. He was an avid reader with scholarly interests in history, and fulfilled his visionary ideas by developing his farm for which he received an Environmentalist of the Year Award, Soil and Water Conservation District, Sullivan County, New York. He is survived by his wife, Magda of 46 years, daughter, Maria D., son, John F., grandchildren, John F. Jr., James F., Catherine I., daughter-in-law, Marina; sisters, Dorothy and Geraldine Campbell; nephews and niece, Alan, Gavin, Peter, Conor, and Paula Campbell; aunt Pat O'Connor; and sisters-in-law, Margaret Campbell and Marija Kova.

KIMBALL--Dorothy Fisher . A longtime resident of Greenwich Village in NYC and Southold, LI died on Tuesday, October 16 after a long illness. She was 82. Daughter of Harold John Fisher and Florence Lutton Fisher, she was raised in Port Washington, NY, attended the experimental Manhasset Bay School, and graduated from Radcliffe College in 1947. She was a loyal and generous alumna for the rest of her life, serving as director of the Radcliffe Club and as a member, and eventually a chairman, of the Harvard Schools Committee. Her lifelong work as an educator included being a co-founder and director of the West Village Co-operative Nursery School, teaching Latin at St. Luke's School and the Village Community School, serving as the director of the Independent Schools' Chairmen Association, and offering advice and opinions on schools and schooling to all who sought them. She was also the former executive secretary of Huguenot Society of America and, up until her death, the executive secretary of the Waltz Society of New York, an organization that combined her appreciation of music and culture with her tremendous love for New York City. Her other great pleasure was traveling and planning trips with her family. She is survived by her brother, David Fisher; her devoted children, Pamela Kimball Kenney of NYC, William Fisher Kimball of Los Angeles, and Susannah Kimball Rosato of Greenwich, CT; her sons-inlaw, David Kenney and Ernest Rosato Jr.; her daughterin-law, Alexandra Kimball; and her adored grandchildren, Sarah and Alice Kenney, Sophie and Fernanda Kimball, Ernest Rosato III, and William, Colin, Lachlan, and Aengus Rosato. She was predeceased by her former husband and lifelong friend, William Maltby Kimball. All who knew her are invited to a memorial service at the Church of the Ascension at 5th Avenue and 10th Street on Wednesday October 24 at 4pm and to a reception afterwards at the Harvard Club of New York, 27 West 44th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory either to the East Harlem School, 340 East 104th Street, NY, NY 10029 attention: Grace Eagar; to Friends of Alta, PO BOX 8126, Alta, UT 84092; or to St. Michael's Church, Clark's Town, Trelawny, Jamaica, West Indies. Donations to any of these may also be sent to Pamela Kenney, 30 West 70th Street, Apartment 6A, NY, NY 10023, and will be forwarded. Ave atque vale, Babba.

WATTS--James . President Gregory H. Williams and the students, faculty and staff of The City College of New York mourn the death and celebrate the life of James Francis Watts, a member of The City College community for forty years, who died on Tuesday after a long illness, bravely fought. Jim was more than a member of the City College community, however; he embodied its spirit. He was the real City College deal, utterly dedicated to our students and our mission. He was a beloved teacher of history, and he inspired a love of learning and a devotion to the life of the mind in his students and his colleagues. He was a scholar, and he served with distinction as Dean of Humanities and Arts, the largest and most diverse of the Colleges divisions from 2002-2004. Jim never hesitated to fight for what he thought was deserved by our students with eloquence and passion, and he contributed enormously to the renaissance of CCNY. We at CCNY will gather later in the year to celebrate Jim's life. At this time, our hearts go out to Jim's wife Pam and his family, as we hold him in our own. The City College of New York
Hebron, Oct. 14.

Updated, 4:53 p.m. | A transit police officer was treated for minor injuries after he was attacked this afternoon while accompanying Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on a subway platform in Lower Manhattan, according to the authorities.

A new turn in the strange political career of a troublesome word — the racial epithet known as the N-word — finds a state legislator denouncing a rapper who plans to use it as the title for his new CD.

There was no relief in sight today for seven residents of the Windermere — a once grand, now decrepit apartment building in Hell’s Kitchen — who have been locked out of their homes since Sept. 19, when the city’s Department of Housing Preservation and Development cited the landlord for 209 violations, including exposed wiring, an accumulation of trash and a lack of electricity.

Wall Street’s fortunes may be taking a turn for the worse — a development that would have major ramifications for the local economy. Major banks, most recently Bank of America, have announced shrinking profits, job cuts or both. The gloomy reports are dashing hopes that large year-end bonus checks for investment bankers and traders would continue to fuel the local economy, Patrick McGeehan writes in a news analysis. The chief economist for the city comptroller’s office says the chance of a recession is increasing. Wall Street is a critical fulcrum of the local economy, generating one of every five dollars of income in the region. Economists estimate that each new job on Wall Street leads to at least 1.3 other jobs, so for every three investment bankers laid off, four other workers are in jeopardy.

As part of our series on the new taxi logo at right, we invited readers to submit their own designs. Many of you stepped up to try.Scott Schwebel submitted the logo below. “More than ever New York City represents to the world all that is America and the dream of a better life,” Mr. Scwebel wrote. “Why not try and have that message reinforced everyday on the street with one of our highest profile city experiences/icons?” He said the creative challenge should have been framed simply: “Will it look good on a T-shirt?”

Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who has been trying to build support for his unpopular plan to grant driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants, announced today that William J. Bratton, the former New York City police commissioner who is now chief of the Los Angeles Police Department, had endorsed it.

In a highly unusual public health advertisement blitz, the city’s Department of Health and Mental Hygiene is buying every single ad space in three Harlem stations along 125th street in an effort to reduce second-hand smoke that is known to lead to asthma and other health problems in children.East and Central Harlem have some of the highest rates of asthma in the country — if not the single highest documented rates of asthma in the country. Approximately 1 in 4 children in Central Harlem has asthma, or about four times the national average. The neighborhoods have twice the city average for children’s hospitalization for asthma.

The Coney Island sideshow is alive and well. On Fifth Avenue, of all places; the realm of Tiffany & Company, Bergdorf Goodman, the St. Regis, the University Club and the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.This one doesn’t feature two-headed calves or Countess Habeba, the great and celebrated Persian Gypsy. Instead, the Sunday afternoon show at the Abercrombie & Fitch flagship store at 56th Street offered a glimpse of shirtless young men standing just behind the doors in the entry vestibule, their jeans riding not much higher than their … well, not too high. Othercomely — but more fully dressed — fellows ushered the crowds in and out.

Cabdrivers went on strike today for the second time in two months, but the work stoppage had only a minimal effect on the daily commute, according to city officials, commuters and drivers interviewed on the street. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg declared that the work action had “no appreciable impact” on traffic movements in the city.
Tens of thousands of people were ordered to evacuate as wildfires continued to spread across southern California.

Running back Ronnie Brown, one of the few bright spots for 0-7 Miami, will miss the rest of the season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament in his right knee. Brown was fourth in the league in rushing (602 yards) and had four consecutive 100-yard games. The Dolphins also learned that safety Renaldo Hill will miss the rest of the season with the same injury.

Most of us have thought about and feared our own deaths at some time or another, and many have faced it head on. My time in Iraq taught me a lot about the fragility of human life, and it served to remind me just how brittle these bones can be. Perhaps it's a lesson I needed to learn. I remember standing on a rooftop in the dark two years ago, working on a satellite dish, when four mortars exploded in a nearby field, filling the impenetrable night with blazing orange light and furious sound. And now, after sixteen months home, the powers that be have utilized a boulder to deliver a similar message.

Senator Barack Obama is drawing criticism for signing up a gospel singer with controversial views about gay men and lesbians for his campaign in South Carolina. Gospel music is one of many ways the campaign is trying to reach black evangelicals in South Carolina, an early voting state where half the Democratic primary voters are black and where at least one recent survey shows Mr. Obama is losing ground to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

In Formula One, Kimi Raikkonen of Ferrari won the 2007 World Championship in Brazil, an improbable outcome to a crazy year. Going into the race, Raikkonen was seven points behind Lewis Hamilton and four behind Fernando Alonso. And he needed several things to fall into place in order to win the title. When Hamilton suffered a gearbox glitch in the early laps and dropped down the 18th position, it looked like Raikkonen might have a chance. By that time, Felipe Massa and he were pulling away from Alonso.

The House Ways and Means chairman, Charles Rangel, is preparing to introduce what he calls "the mother'' of all tax proposals. Collateralized debt obligations -- made up of bonds backed by thousands of subprime home loans -- are starting to shut off cash payments to investors in lower-rated bonds as credit-rating agencies downgrade the securities they own, according to analysts and industry executives.

The Charlotte Bobcats reserve forward Adam Morrison will probably miss the season after a magnetic resonance imaging test revealed a torn ligament in his left knee. Morrison was injured Saturday in a preseason game against the Lakers while trying to defend Luke Walton on a drive to the basket.

David Nalbandian beat Roger Federer yesterday, 1-6, 6-3, 6-3, to win the Madrid Masters. On his way to the final against Federer, the world’s top-ranked player, Nalbandian also defeated No. 2 Rafael Nadal and No. 3 Novak Djokovic.Nalbandian broke Federer three times and became the second player this year to beat the top three players en route to winning a title. Djokovic did it in Montreal in August, culminating his run with a victory over Federer.

Emmanuel Mutai won the Amsterdam Marathon in 2 hours 6 minutes 29 seconds to lead a Kenyan sweep. Richard Limo was second in 2:06:45, and James Rotich was third in 2:07:12. Magdaline Chemjor, also of Kenya, won the women’s race in 2:28:16.

Suzann Pettersen won the Hana Bank Kolon Championship in Gyeongju, South Korea, for her fourth L.P.G.A. victory of the year when high wind and unplayable conditions on the putting surfaces forced tournament officials to call off the final round at Mauna Ocean resort. Pettersen opened with a three-under 69 on Friday and shot a 72 on Saturday in wind and cold to take the lead at three under.

Mike Weir won for the first time since early in the 2004 season, shooting a two-under 68 for a one-stroke victory over Mark Hensby in the Fry’s Electronics Open in Scottsdale, Ariz.Weir secured the victory with a 6-foot par putt after hitting his approach on the par-4 18th into a greenside bunker.

Justine Henin won her ninth title of the season, beating 19-year-old Tatiana Golovin, 6-4, 6-4, at the Zurich Open. The top-ranked Henin won the final five games en route to her 20th consecutive victory in 13 tournaments this season.
The New York State Sheep and Wool Festival drew 12,000 people to the Dutchess County Fairgrounds over the weekend.
Several major research libraries have rebuffed offers from Google and Microsoft to scan their books, instead signing on with a nonprofit effort.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice intervened to ward off a strike by Turkey in northern Iraq after Kurdish rebels killed at least 12 Turkish soldiers.
Bobby Jindal will be the nation’s first Indian-American governor in a state where race is inseparable from politics.

A headline in some editions yesterday with an entry in the News Summary about criticism of L. Douglas Wilder for his handling of city business for Richmond, Va., misidentified the office he holds. He is the mayor of Richmond; he is no longer the governor of Virginia.
A boat that capsized after turning into a tugboat’s tow cable had apparently ignored the tugboat’s warning blasts from its horn and its light shining on the cable, the Coast Guard said.
As the Indians prepared to oppose the Red Sox in Game 7 of the American League Championship Series, Paul Byrd said he had used H.G.H. to treat a tumor on his pituitary gland.

A Shirley resident was killed on Saturday evening when his motorcycle crashed into a gas truck and burst into flames, the Suffolk County police said. The man, Thomas Bush, 37, of Tallwood Drive, was driving a 2007 Triumph motorcycle south on Route 112 when he lost control of the vehicle just before 9 p.m. and skidded into the opposite lane, the police said. The bike and driver crashed into a Kenworth tractor-trailer carrying 12,000 gallons of gasoline. The motorcycle became wedged under the truck and caught fire. The truck driver was able to escape from the cab without serious injury, the police said. The Coram Fire Department extinguished the flames before the gas truck ignited, the police said. Mr. Bush was pronounced dead at the scene.

A man was shot dead in the municipal parking lot at Washington and Cooper Streets in Hempstead about 2:20 a.m. yesterday, the Nassau County police said. The man, Antonio Patterson, 20, of Hempstead, was taken by his friends in a private car to Nassau University Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead, the police said. No arrests had been made, the police said. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A man driving a Toyota 4Runner crashed into a house in Brentwood early yesterday, the Suffolk County police said. No one was injured in the crash, but five children and three adults had to be evacuated from the house on St. Peters Drive, the police said. The car smashed through the front door and the living room about 2:30 a.m., the police said. The driver, Jorge L. Camacho, 31, of Brentwood, was charged with driving while intoxicated and driving without a license, the police said. The vehicle was removed, and the building inspector determined the home was uninhabitable, the police said.

A woman was critically wounded in a drive-by shooting in Queensboro Hill early yesterday while sitting in a car with a man who was also wounded, the police said. The victims’ names were not released yesterday. The shooting occurred shortly after 2:30 a.m. at 59th Avenue and Main Street as the couple sat in a parked Nissan Altima, the police said. A dark-colored sedan pulled up and two men opened fire on the man, 24, who was struck in the right shoulder and elbow, and the woman, 29, who was struck three times in the head, the police said. The wounded man drove to New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens, where he was listed in stable condition and she was listed in extremely critical condition, the police said. There were no arrests yesterday.

Two men were stabbed, one fatally, during a robbery in the Bronx early yesterday, the police said. The men were attacked about 3:40 a.m. on East 170th Street, the police said. One man was stabbed in the abdomen and taken to Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center, where he was in stable condition yesterday. The second man was taken to Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center, where he died, the police said. Neither man was identified by the police yesterday.

A gay headmaster at a British boarding school? The idea may not be particularly shocking to the literati or to those who have speculated on the Internet about the sexuality of Albus Dumbledore, master wizard and headmaster of Hogwarts, home to Harry Potter and his mates. But the revelation of Dumbledore’s sexuality by J. K. Rowling, author of the Potter adventures, inspired gasps, as well as applause, when she read and took questions from a full house at Carnegie Hall on Friday night, The Associated Press reported. One young fan asked if Dumbledore finds “true love,” and Ms. Rowling replied, “Dumbledore is gay.” She went on to explain that he was smitten with Gellert Grindelwald, a rival he defeated in a long-ago battle between good and evil. “Falling in love can blind us to an extent,” she said, adding that Dumbledore’s love was his “great tragedy.”.

Henry Fogel will step down as president and chief executive of the American Symphony Orchestra League when his five-year contract expires on June 30. The board has voted to appoint as his successor Jesse Rosen, now the league’s vice president and managing director. With nearly 1,000 member ensembles of all sizes, the league, established in 1942, supports and promotes America’s orchestras.

Doris Lessing, the newly chosen Nobel laureate in literature, told a Spanish newspaper that the attacks in the United States on Sept. 11, 2001, were not “so bad” compared with the actions of the Irish Republican Army, Agence France-Press reported. Ms. Lessing, 88, right, the British author who said she had recently finished writing a book on war, told the Spanish newspaper El País in an interview published yesterday, “Sept. 11 was terrible, but if one re-examines the history of the I.R.A., what happened in the United States wasn’t so bad.” She added: “Some Americans believe I’m crazy. Many people died; two prominent buildings fell, but it was neither as terrible nor so extraordinary as they think.” In 2005 the Irish Republican Army, after a prolonged struggle against British rule in Northern Ireland, declared an end to its armed campaign.

The British pop singer Amy Winehouse was arrested in Bergen, Norway, for possession of marijuana, the BBC reported. Ms. Winehouse, her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, and a third person were taken into custody at a hotel and held overnight after being found with a quarter-ounce of the drug, a prosecutor said. She was released on Friday morning after paying a fine of 500 euros ($715). The prosecutor, Lars Morten, told The Associated Press, “She’s paid the fine, so this thing is over for us now.” Her spokesman, Shane O’Neill, said, “She was released without charge,” and added that her European tour would continue. Ms. Winehouse canceled concerts this year amid newspaper reports that she was in a rehab clinic.

After three years of renovation and reconfiguration, the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s education center is to reopen tomorrow. The Ruth and Harold D. Uris Center for Education consists of 25,000 square feet of public space, including a meeting hall, art study room, lecture hall, studio, classrooms, library and teacher resource center.

Some 5,000 fans gave an enthusiastic welcome to the R&B singer Beyoncé, above, when she began her world tour with a spirited two-hour performance on Saturday night in Addis Ababa, the capital of Ethiopia, The Associated Press reported. The concert was presented as part of the country’s yearlong celebration of its 2,000th year according to the Coptic calendar. Ethiopia is not usually impressed by Western music, and the audience gave only a lukewarm reception to the rapper Ludacris, the opening act. “Rap music doesn’t suit Ethiopia,” said Michael Melake, 36, a local music promoter. “Ethiopians need a melody. Rap music is all about the message, and we don’t identify with that. It’s all about the black American experience, and we don’t relate to that.” As for Beyoncé’s popularity, Enoch Nicano, 30, a nightclub owner, offered an explanation: “She’s hot,” he said. “She’s more than hot.”.

“30 Days of Night,” distributed by Sony and starring Josh Hartnett, above, as the sheriff of an Alaska town beset by vampires, took in $16 million in North America in its debut weekend, ending the one-week reign of “Tyler Perry’s Why Did I Get Married?” (Lionsgate) as box office champion. The Perry film, took in $12.1 million, according to estimates by the tracking company Media by Numbers, moving to second place. In third was the Disney comedy “The Game Plan,” with $8.1 million in its fourth week. “Michael Clayton” (Warner Brothers), starring George Clooney as a law firm’s fixer, took in $7.1 million in its third week to take fourth place. In its first weekend “Gone Baby Gone” (Miramax), the drama about a vanished child that is the directorial debut of Ben Affleck, came in at No. 5 with $6 million.

HELFAT--Bernard . We deeply mourn the passing of Bernard Helfat, father of Jonathan N. Helfat, an esteemed senior member of our Firm. We extend our condolences to Bernard's wife, Lucile, to Jon and his wife, Robin, and their children, Joshua and his wife Abigail, and Benjamin, and to Jon's brother, Mark. Bernard was a well respected member of the Bar for more than 60 years. He spent his final years at home with dignity surrounded by his family. Otterbourg, Steindler, Houston & Rosen, P.C. HELFAT--Bernard A., died peacefully on October 20, 2007 at his home in Douglaston, NY at the age of 90. He practiced law for over 60 years, first with his father, J. Nathan Helfat, and later as a sole practitioner. Mr. Helfat was well known in the textile industry for helping to bring to an end the long-standing practice of design piracy (knock offs). He represented the plaintiff in the landmark case of Peter Pan Fabrics vs. Martin Weiner, Inc. This decision had a great impact, not only on design protection in the textile industry, but for other fashion industries as well. Mr. Helfat grew up in Lawrence, Long Island and was Valedictorian of Lawrence High School, Class of 1933. He also graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, Class of 1934; Harvard College 1938 and Harvard Law School 1941. During World War II, he served on the War Department General Staff in Washington D.C. and obtained the rank of Captain. He was recalled during the Korean War, serving in the National Security Agency, and was a recipient of the Bronze Star. After returning to civilian life, Mr. Helfat and his family settled in Douglaston, Queens where he became active in civic affairs and politics. He was a founding member and a past President of Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, past President of the Douglaston Civic Association, and past Chairman of the New York City School Board for North East Queens. Mr. Helfat was also a past President of the Bayside Democratic Club and ran for Congress on the Democratic and Liberal party lines in 1960. Sailing with his family on the Long Island Sound and tending to his rose garden were favorite past times. He is survived by Lucile, his beloved wife of 64 years; two sons, Jonathan and Mark; his two loving daughters-in-law, Robin and Mendy; as well as his two grandsons, Benjamin and Joshua; and Joshua's wife Abigail. Funeral services will be held at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck (corner of Hicks Lane and Station Road, Great Neck, NY) on October 22, 2007 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Temple Emanuel of Great Neck.

ALLWIN--James M . The entire AEA Team is deeply saddened by the death, on October 19th, of our partner and friend who was CEO of AEA Holdings. Jim was a born leader and business visionary who always kept his eye focused on what was important. We will sorely miss the many personal qualities that endeared him to everyone he met-his personal warmth, good judgment, sense of humor, humility and generosity. He was one of the most positive and optimistic individuals we have ever known, undaunted by even the most seemingly insurmountable challenges. These qualities made him an irresistible friend and treasured business colleague. Above all, we will miss our fun-loving friend with his mischievous humor who treated everyone with kindness. He lived every day of his life to the fullest and brought joy to us and to his wide circle of friends from all walks of life. Jim leaves a big void in our lives. All of us at AEA extend our deepest sympathy to Jim's family and colleagues at Aetos. Vincent Mai, Chairman John Garcia, CEO AEA Investors LLC

VOLPE--John Louis , October 10, 2007. Born October 7, 1960, in Bronx, NY, the youngest son of John and Lucy Volpe, John was a longtime resident of Pleasantville, NY. Graduating from Pleasantville High School in 1978, he went on to graduate from Pace University. He later received a degree in Naturopathic Medicine, and had a practice in Ossining, NY. John studied Okinawan Goju Ryu, and was preparing to receive his brown belt, one level below black belt. He is survived by his brothers, Michael and Joseph, both of Manhattan. His extended family includes his many loving friends who shared his varied interests, including music, bowling, running and the NY Mets. MENDOLIA--Arthur , A former Assistant Secretary of Defense, co-founder and retired Chairman of Cambrex Corporation died October 19, 2007 in Wilmington, Delaware, at the age of 90. Mr. Mendolia served as a Director on the boards of The Bank of New York and UNUM Corporation and was a Trustee of the Delaware Art Museum. Mr. Mendolia received a B.S. in Chemical Engineering in 1941 from Case Institute of Technology. He remained an active and supportive alum, served on the Board of Governors, and in 1979 accepted the Case Alumni Association Gold Medal Award, its highest honor for an alumnus. Throughout his life, he was passionate about learning and selfless in his mentoring of others. Joining the duPont Company in 1941 as a research engineer, Mendolia retired in 1973 as Vice President and General Manager of the Explosives Department. From 1973 to 1975, he served as Assistant Secretary of Defense under Presidents Nixon and Ford. Mr. Mendolia returned to the private sector as President of Halcon International in New York City and Chairman of Oxirane International in Princeton. In 1981, he and Cyril Baldwin co-founded Cambrex Corporation of Rutherford, New Jersey and Mr. Mendolia served as its Chairman and CEO from 1981 to 1987 and remained a Director until 1995. Mendolia and Baldwin received the Winthrop-Sears Award for Entrepreneurship in 1990. A modern-day Renaissance man, Art was a voracious reader, a big band singer and jazz enthusiast, avid golfer, and lover of contemporary art and architecture. He had a fascination with all things high-tech, from building a Heathkit computer in the 1960s to teaching himself film editing at the age of 88. He is survived by Edythe, his wife of 65 years, two daughters, Pamela Abernathy of New York City and Cynthia Keiser of Bedford, New York; four grandchildren, Emily Abernathy-Jones and Kate Abernathy of New York City; William Keiser of Chicago, and Eleanor Keiser of Boulder, Colorado. He also leaves two great-grandchildren, India and Edie Jones. Interment will be private and in lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Arthur I. Mendolia '41 Scholarship and Fellowship Fund and should be sent to the Case Alumni Association and Foundation, 10605 Chester Avenue, Suite 309, Cleveland, Ohio 44106-2240.

A Shirley resident was killed on Saturday evening when his motorcycle crashed into a gas truck and burst into flames, the Suffolk County police said. The man, Thomas Bush, 37, of Tallwood Drive, was driving a 2007 Triumph motorcycle south on Route 112 when he lost control of the vehicle just before 9 p.m. and skidded into the opposite lane, the police said. The bike and driver crashed into a Kenworth tractor-trailer carrying 12,000 gallons of gasoline. The motorcycle became wedged under the truck and caught fire. The truck driver was able to escape from the cab without serious injury, the police said. The Coram Fire Department extinguished the flames before the gas truck ignited, the police said. Mr. Bush was pronounced dead at the scene.

KIMBALL--Dorothy Fisher . A longtime resident of Greenwich Village in NYC and Southold, LI died on Tuesday, October 16 after a long illness. She was 82. Daughter of Harold John Fisher and Florence Lutton Fisher, she was raised in Port Washington, NY, attended the experimental Manhasset Bay School, and graduated from Radcliffe College in 1947. She was a loyal and generous alumna for the rest of her life, serving as director of the Radcliffe Club and as a member, and eventually a chairman, of the Harvard Schools Committee. Her lifelong work as an educator included being a co-founder and director of the West Village Co-operative Nursery School, teaching Latin at St. Luke's School and the Village Community School, serving as the director of the Independent Schools' Chairmen Association, and offering advice and opinions on schools and schooling to all who sought them. She was also the former executive secretary of Huguenot Society of America and, up until her death, the executive secretary of the Waltz Society of New York, an organization that combined her appreciation of music and culture with her tremendous love for New York City. Her other great pleasure was traveling and planning trips with her family. She is survived by her brother, David Fisher; her devoted children, Pamela Kimball Kenney of NYC, William Fisher Kimball of Los Angeles, and Susannah Kimball Rosato of Greenwich, CT; her sons-inlaw, David Kenney and Ernest Rosato Jr.; her daughterin-law, Alexandra Kimball; and her adored grandchildren, Sarah and Alice Kenney, Sophie and Fernanda Kimball, Ernest Rosato III, and William, Colin, Lachlan, and Aengus Rosato. She was predeceased by her former husband and lifelong friend, William Maltby Kimball. All who knew her are invited to a memorial service at the Church of the Ascension at 5th Avenue and 10th Street on Wednesday October 24 at 4pm and to a reception afterwards at the Harvard Club of New York, 27 West 44th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory either to the East Harlem School, 340 East 104th Street, NY, NY 10029 attention: Grace Eagar; to Friends of Alta, PO BOX 8126, Alta, UT 84092; or to St. Michael's Church, Clark's Town, Trelawny, Jamaica, West Indies. Donations to any of these may also be sent to Pamela Kenney, 30 West 70th Street, Apartment 6A, NY, NY 10023, and will be forwarded. Ave atque vale, Babba.

Below, a time line of the case, drawn from The Times’s archives.Aug. 26, 1986: The body of Jennifer D. Levin, 18, is found in Central Park behind the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Linda Fairstein was the lead prosecutor in the 1988 murder trial of Robert E. Chambers Jr. for killing Jennifer Levin in Central Park on Aug. 26, 1986. She oversaw a trial that lasted more than two months and ended, abruptly, on the ninth day of jury deliberations, when Mr. Chambers pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter. He was sentenced to 5 to 15 years; if he had been convicted of second-degree murder, he could have faced 25 years.

Well, it's precisely that combination - the familiarity and the exoticism, the immersion in a particular historical period and the almost eerie "modernity" - that makes the novel so extraordinary and so engrossing. So many events and characters have contemporary, or near contemporary, counterparts. Pierre's attraction to Masonry evokes, for me, all the longing and discontent that drove so many people in the 1960s and 70s to follow some goofy guru or other; every era (including ours) has its spiritual charlatans. Tolstoy's characterization of Napoleon - the pettiness of his vanity, his shortsighted refusal to consider any views that don't mirror his own - is distressingly reminiscent of the absolute worst, and most dangerous, qualities of today's world leaders. The beautiful scene in which Andrei's interest in the war and (by extension) his career is dwarfed by the pressures and terrors of caring for a sick child - variant versions of that are playing themselves out, at this moment, in homes and families everywhere. And yet, as we read the novel, we are constantly being reminded of how much has changed: everyday manners and mores, notions of female virtue and dishonor, the givens of class, status, family obligation. The duel has been replaced by the drive-by, and happily, it's no longer taken for granted that sensible parents can, and actually should, auction off their marriageable daughter (or son, for that matter) to the wealthiest bidder.
