"It is not enough that I know all that's in me, everyone else must know it, too." This is the thought that comes to Prince Andrei, in the middle of Book II as he confronts a gnarled old oak that has burst into leaf - soon after he has become enraptured (in his chilly, restrained way) with young Natasha Rostova. Andrei first noticed the tree in early spring, when the tree, like him, was resisting nature's call to rebirth. Back then, he was pleased to find the oak "scowling, motionless, ugly and stubborn." Seeing it, he thought, "Let others, the young ones, succumb afresh to this deception, but we know life - our life is over!" Andrei had given up his hopes of joy in life until they were rekindled when he met Natasha. The green leaves remind him that his life is not "over at 31," and is not independent, but interwoven with many other lives, and with forces larger than himself. "My life is not only for myself," he realizes. "It is reflected in everyone, and they all live together with me!"
A Canadian cookie arrives in Manhattan, two local bakeries with the same owners, but different styles, and fancy candy on Broome Street.
The decision by the European Union's highest court Tuesday to overturn a 47-year-old law protecting Volkswagen from a takeover, has put Porsche in the driver's seat.

When James E. Cayne, 73, the chief executive of Bear Stearns, flew to Beijing over the Labor Day weekend to discuss a partnership with Citic Securities, China's largest investment bank, the two firm's fortunes were diverging.
Vikram Pandit's rise at Citigroup has been fast and furious. But, Financial News wonders, can he recreate his success at Morgan Stanley at such a substantially different institution?

MediaNews Groupsaid Monday that Hearst had bought a stake in the company for $317 million as part of a complex deal between the two privately held publishers involving several San Francisco-area newspapers.
Now that the Games Have Ended, the real fun begins.

In a 45-minute court conference Monday, an investor group headed by J.C. Flowers & Company abruptly agreed to waive a provision of its $25 billion merger agreement with the SLM Corporation, parent of the student lender Sallie Mae, that SLM contended hampered its ability to conduct business or shop for a replacement buyer.

Venture capitalists in the United States maintained a robust pace in the third quarter, pouring the bulk of their dollars into later-stage deals and putting 2007 on pace to reach the highest funding levels since 2001, according to two new surveys released Saturday.

Alibaba.com is seeking to raise as much as $1.49 billion in an initial public offering after raising the price range to between 12 Hong Kong dollars and 13.50 Hong Kong dollars ($1.55 to $1.74) a share.

After seven months of fierce battling, the Royal Bank of Scotland-led consortium, comprised of Dutch-Belgian Fortis and Spain's Banco Santander, finally won the bid for the Dutch bank ABN Amro for $99.1 billion in the largest financial-services takeover ever.
Nike agreed to buy Umbro for 285 million pounds ($580 million), gaining a contract to outfit the English soccer team and sell replica jerseys worldwide.

The European Commission said Monday it had extended its antitrust review of Google's proposed takeover of the Internet advertising company DoubleClick until Nov. 13 to consider remedies proposed by Google.
Vestar Capital Partners disclosed plans late Friday for a $1.1 billion deal to take Radiation Therapy Services, an oncology treatment provider, private.

ADC Telecommunications said Monday it had agreed to buy LGC Wireless, a maker of in-building wireless networking technology, in a move to expand into one of the fastest-growing areas of the wireless equipment market.
Delphi, which is negotiating terms of a recovery deal with several hedge funds, said it had pushed back its expected exit from Chapter 11 to next year.
Onex has restructured its offer for Husky Injection Molding Systems after the founder and controlling shareholder, Robert Schad, agreed to take a slightly lower amount than regular shareholders.
Unigold, a Canadian gold exploration and mining company, has become the first North American company to list on the Dubai International Financial Exchange.

A hedge fund company, Schultze Asset Management, settled a lawsuit with the Washington Group, an engineering company based in Boise, Idaho, over the planned $2.6 billion acquisition of Washington by URS.

RAB Capital, the hedge fund manager best known for its natural resources investments, may double Asian assets to $2 billion within a year, Rod Barker, director of business development and distribution, told Bloomberg News.
South Korea's STX Group said Tuesday it had acquired a controlling stake in Norway's Aker Yards for $800 million, to expand into the more lucrative cruise line business.
Meliorbanca, the investment bank that is about half-owned by Italian cooperative lenders, hired Lazard to help it evaluate a takeover bid by Banca Profilo and analyze other options.

Technology companies continue to set the pace for initial public offerings in the United States. According to a new report from Ernst & Young, 94 companies registered to go public in the third quarter, up from 64 in the previous period.
Here's a smattering of what I'm consuming or planning to consume, at the moment. I confess in advance that some of these are not exactly breaking news:
Just when things began looking a little brighter for Vonage, which recently settled a patent infringement lawsuit with Sprint Nextel, the Web-calling company got hit with another legal action.
Australia's Macquarie Bank has again raised its offer for Techem, the German-listed provider of utility metering services that it has been trying to acquire for a year.

James Zenni, who co-founded Black Diamond Capital Management in 1995 and sold his interest in the firm in October 2006, is raising $1 billion to invest in distressed debt, according to Investment Dealers' Digest.
Feline tired? There's a reason for that:
- Recipe for "Skid Road Stroganoff," from "The I Hate to Cook Book" (Harcourt, Brace, 1960), by Peg Bracken, who died Saturday at 89.
A clip's evolution on the web from slip ...
For years health authorities have warned of the growing threat posed by drug-resistant bacteria, but most of us have been half-listening. Not anymore.
On first glance, it looks like a good ol' fashioned controversy is shaping up over the U.K. country home market.

Two new questions arise, courtesy of the latest advancement in cellphone technology: Do you want your friends, family, or colleagues to know where you are at any given time? And do you want to know where they are?
Now that we've analyzed the causes for verbal vitriol on the Net, let's consider a cure.
Both the Knicks and Celtics played their stars down to the wire in a preseason game that neither looked nor sounded like an exhibition and ended in a victory for the Knicks.
Defense Secretary Robert Gates, clearly seeking to mollify Moscow, said that the United States might delay activating its planned East European missile defense sites.
By 196 to 173, the House voted to table a resolution to censure Representative Pete Stark for comments he made about President Bush’s veto of a bill on children’s health insurance.
The legal victory will probably block Roche from introducing an anemia drug in the United States and preserve Amgen’s nearly $7 billion franchise.
The transportation department began talks with the airlines today on reducing the number of airplanes that can use Kennedy International Airport.
Depending on whose interpretation of a new study one wants to believe, Medicare may — or may not — have saved money since the introduction of the stents in 2003.
The company also benefited from Apple’s strong sales of the iPhone, for which AT&T is the sole carrier.
More than a dozen wildfires continued to rage today in Southern California, driven by gusting winds that made them all but impossible to control.
Bolstered by lower costs for newsprint and strong entertainment and fashion advertising, The New York Times Company reported a 7 percent increase in net income.
The shuttle Discovery’s mission involves challenging construction work aboard the  International Space Station.
The ruling struck down a 47-year-old German law that had blocked Porsche from taking over Volkswagen.
Wildfires fed by gale-force winds ravaged Southern California, destroying hundreds of buildings and charring 267,000 acres.
Robert Chambers Jr., the so-called “Preppy Killer,” who strangled a young woman in Central Park in the 1980s, was arrested in Manhattan  on charges of selling cocaine, the police said.

Big East Commissioner Mike Tranghese called Louisville Athletic Director Tom Jurich on Sunday, saying referees erred during a disputed punt return for a touchdown by UConn in a game the Huskies won, 21-17. Tranghese told Jurich the officials had made a “terrible” mistake. Tranghese took action against the referee who missed the fair catch signal, but wouldn’t elaborate on the penalty. “The bad part is I can’t change the call,” Tranghese said yesterday.

Guests trying to check in at five resorts in Las Vegas and one each in Mississippi and Detroit have encountered significant delays for at least two days as a result of glitches to a new reservation system that has been sporadically crashing. The Internet sites for the properties, all owned by MGM Mirage, were also frequently unable to taking bookings, putting more than 15,000 hotel rooms out of reach. Phone reservationists, too, from time to time were placing customers on lengthy holds or asking them to call back later. Properties that have been affected are the Beau Rivage in Biloxi, Miss.; the MGM Grand Detroit; and Bellagio, Mirage, Treasure Island, New York-New York and Signature at MGM Grand, a nongambling condominium-hotel attached to the MGM Grand Hotel-Casino, all in Las Vegas.
Cam Ward improved to 5-0 during regulation and the Carolina Hurricanes took over the league lead in power-play goals in their 3-1 victory over the visiting Vancouver Canucks.

An article on Saturday about speeches by several of the Republican presidential candidates at a meeting of Christian conservatives gave the incorrect home state in some editions for Harry Reid, the Senate Democratic leader, who was the subject of a joke by Mitt Romney. Senator Reid represents Nevada, not Utah.

A question in the Saturday Interview column in Business Day last week, with Pradman P. Kaul, the chief executive of Hughes Communications, misidentified the location of the launching site of Hughes’s latest satellite and misstated the name of the company that launched it. It was sent into space from French Guiana in South America, not from the South Pacific, and it was launched by the French company Arianespace, not Ariane. (The rocket is called Ariane.).

Because of an editing error, a golf report from The Associated Press in some editions on Sunday about the Fry’s Electronics Open in Scottsdale, Ariz., misstated Phil Mickelson’s standing after the first two rounds. He was not in position to win on Sunday because he missed the cut on Friday.

An article on Oct. 5 about a Congressional hearing on the federal government’s oversight of public and private laboratories that handle hazardous biological materials referred imprecisely to Dr. Richard Besser, the director of the coordinating office for terrorism preparedness and emergency response at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, who testified at the hearing. He is a career civil service employee; he is not a political appointee of the Bush administration.

Because of an editing error, a film review on Wednesday about “Summer Love,” at the Whitney Museum of American Art, misstated the date through which it is being shown. As noted in a listing of credits and schedule information, it is Dec. 9, not Nov. 9.
An obituary on Sunday about Kisho Kurokawa, the influential Japanese architect and theorist, misspelled the given name of his widow. She is Ayako Wakao, not Akayo.

Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about a decision by the Liberal Party in Canada not to force an early election because of a speech to Parliament last Tuesday about the minority Conservative government’s legislative plans misidentified the person who delivered the address. Although the speech was written by Prime Minister Stephen Harper’s government, it was read by Michaëlle Jean, the governor general of Canada — not by Mr. Harper.

Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about a decision by the Liberal Party in Canada not to force an early election because of a speech to Parliament last Tuesday about the minority Conservative government’s legislative plans misidentified the person who delivered the address. Although the speech was written by Prime Minister Stephen Harper’s government, it was read by Michaëlle Jean, the governor general of Canada — not by Mr. Harper.

An article yesterday about Michael P. Murphy, a Navy lieutenant killed in Afghanistan and the latest recipient of the Medal of Honor, gave an erroneous identification in some editions for the branch of service of Cpl. Jason L. Dunham, one of two Medal of Honor recipients from the war in Iraq. Corporal Dunham was with the Marine Corps, not the Army.
Bowing to a request from Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s office, Darren Dopp, the governor’s former communications director, no longer plans to testify before a State Senate committee next week.
After a weekend in which Rutgers beat South Florida and Pittsburgh beat Cincinnati, the Big East standings are a jumble.
After a decade of hunting through virtually identical stamps, Lawrence Cohen found one with a tiny distinction that made it extremely valuable to other collectors.
Yankees President Randy Levine said he could deal with criticism but that he was displeased that he had been stung by people with “undisclosed conflicts of interest.”
Coach Eric Mangini spread the blame for the Jets’ poor start around the locker room, citing the defense and the coaching staff and the quarterback, but vouched for the character of his players.
Australia’s Macquarie Bank said one of its funds offered 1.43 billion euros ($2 billion) for Techem, a German company that makes meter-reading devices.
Microsoft is cutting the price of its Xbox 360 game console in Japan by 13 percent as the price war among video game consoles heats up ahead of the year-end shopping season.
The Royal Bank of Scotland Group is setting up a fund that will buy the assets of Cheyne Finance, a structured investment vehicle that defaulted last week.
Wal-Mart will pay up to 100 billion yen ($876 million) to take full control of Seiyu after a five-year investment failed to return the Japanese chain to profit.
Commerzbank shares fell sharply after its chief executive warned that its exposure to subprime mortgages in the United States would be bigger than initially thought.
Coach Tom Coughlin has made only slight adjustments for an otherwise unique week as the Giants prepare to play the Miami Dolphins in the first regular-season N.F.L. game played overseas.
Students from different universities gathered amid high security to protest jail terms for three student activists, accused of publishing articles insulting to Islam.
American officials acknowledged that neither the United States nor Iraq had done much recently to constrain the Kurdish group whose raids into Turkey have heightened tensions along the border.

Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff invoked his power to bypass certain laws to restart construction of a fence on the Arizona-Mexico border. Mr. Chertoff’s action allows construction on about seven miles of fence in the San Pedro Riparian National Conservation Area near Naco, Ariz. Work on nearly two miles of the fence had been suspended since Oct. 10, when a federal district judge ordered a delay on its construction, saying the federal government had not fully studied the environmental impact of the fence. Congress gave Mr. Chertoff the power to waive environmental and other laws to build border barriers when it passed the Real ID Act in 2005. This is the third time Mr. Chertoff has used the waiver power.

A car collided with a van from an adult day care center in Starr County, in South Texas, killing seven people in the van, the authorities said. The driver of the car, who was not hurt, failed to yield and faces seven counts of negligent homicide, said a Department of Public Safety spokesman, Johnny Hernandez. The van from the center, La Fuente Home Health Services, was carrying nine people, some of whom were thrown out in the collision. It was unclear whether they were wearing seat belts. Five people died at the scene, and two died later at hospitals, the authorities said.

Republican Party leaders recommended punishing five states for shifting their presidential nominating contests earlier, moving to strip Florida, Michigan, New Hampshire, South Carolina and Wyoming of half their delegates to next year’s Republican National Convention. At least one state, South Carolina, is considering legal action. Iowa, which plans to hold caucuses on Jan. 3, would not be penalized because the caucuses are technically not binding on convention delegates. “It’s very important that our party uphold and enforce the rules that we unanimously voted into place at the Republican National Convention in 2004,” said Mike Duncan, chairman of the Republican National Committee. The rules ban holding votes before Feb. 5.
New Jersey has done “focused and productive work” towards overhauling the way it serves abuses and neglected children, according to a federal monitor.
The four judges face charges of official misconduct for fixing parking tickets for friends, relatives and two of the judges themselves.
The reports have delivered sharply critical judgments about the department’s performance in overseeing private security contractors in Iraq and Afghanistan.

NASA prepared to launch the space shuttle Discovery today, but poor weather at Cape Canaveral might cause the launching, scheduled for 11:38 a.m., to be delayed by a day or more. Katherine A. Winters, the shuttle launching weather officer, said there was a 60 percent probability that rain or other weather conditions would force a delay. The local forecast improves slightly for Wednesday and Thursday. The Discovery and its crew of seven astronauts are set to embark on an ambitious construction mission to the International Space Station that includes five spacewalks and the delivery of an addition to the living and working space, the Harmony module.

The head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, Karen Tandy, said she was resigning, ending her four-year tenure as the first woman to hold the post. Ms. Tandy told employees she was leaving to take a job as a senior vice president of Motorola, said an agency spokesman, Garrison Courtney. Ms. Tandy praised the agency’s 11,000 employees, saying they sacrificed “everything to live our dangerous mission 24-7, every day of the year, in order to protect America’s children and communities.” Ms. Tandy was confirmed to head the D.E.A. in July 2003.

A group of state prison inmates were told that Harris County was willing to appoint a lawyer to review whether they had been wrongfully convicted. The 19 inmates were the first of 180 cases identified as potentially flawed because of shoddy blood analysis work by the Houston Police Department’s crime laboratory. “They were a little suspicious at first,” said a defense lawyer, Bob Wicoff. “But most of them were quickly on board.” Harris County criminal district judges announced plans this month to review the body-fluid cases identified in a final report on the laboratory.

A popular high school English teacher in Tuscola in west-central Texas has been placed on paid leave and faces possible criminal charges after a student’s parents complained to the police that a class reading list contained a book about a murderer who has sex with his victims’ bodies. The teacher, Kaleb Tierce, 25, is being investigated for distributing harmful material to a minor after the student selected and read “Child of God” by the Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist Cormac McCarthy. Mr. Tierce, who has not been charged with any wrongdoing, declined to comment.

A chancery court judge in Nashville agreed to consider an art-sharing proposal between Fisk University and the Crystal Bridges Museum in Arkansas. Fisk, which had sought court permission to sell two paintings from its Stieglitz Collection, had asked the judge to instead consider Crystal Bridges’ $30 million offer to share the collection, which the painter Georgia O’Keeffe donated in 1949. Fisk says the income from Crystal Bridges is vital to keeping the university open. The Georgia O’Keeffe Museum in Santa Fe, N.M., opposes the deal.
Trailed by a dozen lawyers, the judge who ordered the Salander-O’Reilly Galleries on East 71st Street padlocked last week toured it from top to bottom on Monday.
Questions have been raised about whether the meat industry has been given too much leeway to police itself.
The response to the worst drought on record in the Southeast has unfolded in ultra-slow motion.
In another gutsy call by NASA administrators, the space shuttle Discovery is poised to undertake the most challenging construction job yet attempted in space.
If G.P.S. made it harder to get lost, new cellphone services that track whereabouts are now making it harder to hide.
The bipartisan coalition in the Senate that wants to move ahead quickly on legislation limiting emissions of carbon dioxide should be cheered by two reports from unexpected parts of the country.

Each team in the N.I.T. Season Tip-Off will play four games next year under a new format that includes third- and fourth-round games at campus sites. The change will be the third in three years for the 16-team preseason N.I.T. tournament.

ESPN announced yesterday the signing of Rick Reilly, whose contract with Sports Illustrated expires at the end of November. He will write the back-page column in ESPN the Magazine and deliver essays on “SportsCenter” during its golf coverage.Reilly said he succumbed to ESPN after rejecting offers 5 and 10 years ago. “The money was ridiculous,” he said in a news media conference call. “This is an itch I’ve always wanted to scratch, to take my voice to a different place.” Despite being on TV regularly with one-minute commentaries, he said ESPN wanted him for his column. “Believe me, with this nose, I know what’s best for me,” he said.

The NFL Network yesterday spurned as a “gimmick” Time Warner Cable’s proposal to offer the league-owned channel’s eight regular-season games on pay-per-view. Time Warner said the league could have set the price and collected the revenue from the service. Robert D. Marcus, a senior executive vice president of Time Warner Cable, wrote to the network saying that the proposal would guarantee that “no interested fan is unable to watch these games on our systems.” The network and Time Warner have been unable to reach an agreement for full-time coverage of the channel on digital basic. In a letter to Time Warner, Steve Bornstein, the president of the network, wrote, “Unfortunately, it seems that TWC’s content acquisition department cannot grasp that the NFL Network is more than eight games.”.
Myanmar has given the green light for a visit by Paulo Sérgio Pinheiro, the United Nations special rapporteur, or investigator, on human rights in the country.
Lebanon delayed the election of a successor to the pro-Syrian president Émile Lahoud by members of Parliament by almost three weeks.
Prime Minister Ehud Olmert confirmed that the Lebanese group Hezbollah had handed Israel a letter written by the long-missing Israeli airman Ron Arad as part of a prisoner-exchange deal last week.
The retrial of Rayfran das Neves Sales, sentenced to 27 years in prison in 2005 for the shooting death earlier that year of Dorothy Stang.
A fire at a shoe factory in Putian, a small export manufacturing city in Fujian Province, killed 37 people and injured more than a dozen.
Musicians Bonnie Raitt, Graham Nash and Jackson Browne, aging, activist rock stars, have reunited to battle the nuclear power industry on Capitol Hill.
A group of Tamil Tiger fighters, backed by the rebel group’s tiny air force, carried out a surprise predawn attack on the government’s air base at Anuradhapura, north of Colombo.
A United States Navy sailor shot and killed two female sailors in the barracks of an American military base in Bahrain, officials said.
If Washington doesn’t move quickly to ensure peace in Kurdistan, Iraq’s disastrous civil war could spiral into an even bigger disaster — a regional war.
Advances in DNA technology may shed new light on the 17-year-old case of a bouncer killed at a nightclub in Manhattan.
A one-day strike called by the New York Taxi Workers Alliance had “no appreciable impact” on transportation in the city, according to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
Sallie Mae’s would-be buyers say the merger contract allows them to terminate the deal due to recent changes in student lending, which have reduced its potential for future earnings.
In the desperate plight of people trying to deal with cancer without health insurance, I offer Dan and Sharon Brodrick as Exhibit A.
The Yankees have insisted for months that their deadline to re-sign Alex Rodriguez is his opt-out date, 10 days after the end of the World Series, but agent Scott Boras does not seem to believe that.
The hate crimes unit of the Police Department is investigating the delivery of a noose along with a racially charged letter to the principal of Canarsie High School.
Qualcomm Stadium, the home of the San Diego Chargers, proved to be an oasis of order Monday for thousands of evacuees fleeing approaching fires.
A groundbreaking measure in California offers a realistic hope for bringing more murderers, gang members and other armed criminals to justice.
Apple’s earnings beat analysts’ expectations on record sales of its Macintosh computers, showing that Apple is climbing back into the league of dominant computer makers.
The bill is part of a measure aimed at curbing what some consumer advocates say are deceptive lending practices aimed at people with low incomes or poor credit histories.
Like all labor disputes, the one-day strike by taxi drivers on Monday was not only about a tangible issue, but also about dignity and respect.
The C.I.A.’s review of its internal watchdog has drawn criticism from Democrats and Republicans alike, who have suggested that it could have an effect on its independence.
Although Bear Stearns investors want to see the firm increase its international exposure, there is uncertainty as to whether the Citic deal will contribute to earnings.
Texas Instruments posted a 10 percent increase in quarterly profit, but gave a disappointing revenue forecast, which sent its shares lower in after-hours trading.
The bill that passed the Senate is among a range of legislative and legal maneuvers Republicans are mustering to overturn the governor’s plan.
European regulators hailed the deal as a breakthrough that should create more competition, especially for server software that powers corporate data centers and the Internet.
Radiohead, the British rock band, is close to signing a deal to release its next album independently and leave the major record companies behind.
Players on the Colorado Rockies, once described as an organization that adhered to a “Christian-based code of conduct,” say that faith is not a requirement for peer approval.
Racial tensions have long simmered at Ithaca High School, a volatile mix of youths from the city, the surrounding countryside and the children of professors at local colleges.
An Iraqi journalist working in Baghdad for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty was reported missing on Monday morning after police officers found the body of her driver.
All that talk about the defending Super Bowl champion Indianapolis Colts being better this season may be true.
A detective turned himself in on Monday, saying he shot and killed another driver after a traffic argument.
After an advisory panel voted that some pediatric cold products should be banned, the late-night pharmacy run to find the right medicine has become tougher.
Despite his candidate’s improved chances of success in the 2008 presidential election, Rick Davis, John McCain’s new campaign manger, still hasn’t won over his critics.
American Express’s 10 percent rise in earnings were helped by increased spending among its consumer and corporate clients.
ABC News ended an investigation into a consultant it fired for falsifying his résumé and concluded that the reporting he contributed to the network was sound.
For two decades, Charlotte Dennet has been trying to investigate the circumstances surrounding the crash of an Army transport plane carrying her father over Ethiopia in 1947.
President Bush asked Congress on Monday to approve a $1.4 billion aid package over the next two years to help the Mexican government fight narcotics traffickers.
Schering-Plough and Merck posted strong sales from their joint venture in cholesterol drugs, but otherwise their third-quarter earnings were notably different.
A House committee said it would hold hearings into why the agency is withholding 24,000 responses to a government-sponsored safety survey.
In another step away from the direct-to-customer business model that it pioneered, Dell said it planned to sell computers and equipment at 1,400 Staples stores.
A day after Indians pitcher Paul Byrd’s name emerged as a recipient of shipments of human growth hormone, George J. Mitchell said he played no role in releasing the information.
Hasbro said its third-quarter profit climbed 62 percent on higher sales led by Transformers and Spider-Man toys and a favorable tax adjustment.
In a new poll, Afghans said security issues, including terrorism and violence, were the single biggest problem in Afghanistan, a significant increase from a similar poll last year.
Halliburton’s chief executive said it is gearing up to handle more oil field service work in the Middle East, Asia and Latin America, but pricing declines in North America are still a concern.
President Mwai Kibaki dissolved Parliament on Monday, starting the countdown to elections that promise to be the most closely contested ever in Kenya.
While seeking legal immunity, two phone companies held fund-raisers for Senator John D. Rockefeller IV.
An emotionally disturbed man attacked a transit officer guarding Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg as he waited for a Lexington Avenue train in Lower Manhattan, the authorities said.
The Postal Service’s new advertising campaign tries to convey improvements to its service and technology, such as its Web site.
Goldman Sachs and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts agreed to end their $8 billion buyout of Harman International, which makes speakers, and instead buy $400 million of the company’s bonds.
The European Court of Justice is expected to strike down the so-called Volkswagen Law, created by Germany’s government to protect the automaker from an unwanted takeover.
When questioned at a news conference about his reaction to the Terri Schiavo case on Monday, Fred Thompson opened up about the death of his daughter in 2002.
Kimberly-Clark, which makes Huggies diapers and Scott towels, said profit rose more than expected and raised its outlook in light of higher international sales and a weaker dollar.

For the second time in four days, the Georgia Supreme Court ordered a stay of execution for a prisoner, citing the United States Supreme Court’s decision to review the constitutionality of lethal injection.
New renderings of a mansion that once existed on the spot where Gracie Mansion now stands have surfaced, more than 230 years after the building was destroyed by the British.
Whatever the interpretation — a great chance to keep wearing those Bermuda shorts or a harbinger of coming global doom — hot weather is likely to make this October one for the record books.
A new spot for Senator Barack Obama, Democrat of Illinois, began running Monday in New Hampshire, timed to what his campaign said was his 18th visit to the state.
In the wake of Medtronic’s heart device recall, a Congressional committee announced plans to review how rigorously the F.D.A. required heart device components to be tested.
After an early morning skid, markets rebounded, boosted by an optimistic earnings report from Merck and a more favorable outlook for the technology sector.

For all the drama surrounding it, the Values Voter Summit concluded somewhat anticlimactically Sunday, with Christian conservative leaders saying there was still no consensus about a Republican candidate behind whom they could unite. Now, though, comes word that the candidates will have more time — possibly another month — to make their case.
Monmouth Park may not be as famous as Churchill Downs, as stylish as Saratoga or as big as Belmont Park, but there is something about the place that everybody seems to like.
Bank of America said its head of global structured products, Chris Hentemann, left, just one day after the bank reported a poor quarter for its investment banking unit.

New York City officials announced measures yesterday intended to do away with the obligatory long and often expensive trips by friends and relatives of city jail inmates to deposit money into inmates’ spending accounts. Changing the longstanding system of in-person cash deposits at Rikers Island and other city jails, the Department of Correction said that such accounts could now be replenished by Internet or phone deposits using credit or debit cards, or by using storefront kiosks that take cash and other forms of payment. Roughly $18 million is deposited each year into inmates’ accounts, and since the inmates are not permitted to possess cash, they rely on the deposits for commissary purchases, telephone calls and other expenses, including bail. The city is contracting with three companies to accept the deposits, for which there will be a fee.

The F.B.I. is offering $35,000 for information leading to the arrest of two men responsible for several bank robberies in Middlesex County since January, officials said yesterday. Weysan Dun, the special agent in charge of the F.B.I. office in Newark, said that one suspect, described as athletic and with his hair in dreadlocks, was wanted in connection with nine robberies. The second suspect is heavyset and often wears a blond wig. The two men brandished handguns, Mr. Dun said, adding that in recent robberies the stockier man had a Tec-9 assault pistol. He declined to say how much money was stolen in the robberies, but said that the suspects, both in their 20s, had become more violent with each robbery.

A Westchester woman was convicted yesterday in Westchester County Court of second-degree murder for killing her mother during a bitter custody dispute over her young daughter. The woman, Anne Trovato, 27, was found guilty of stabbing her mother, Patricia Mery, 59, and bludgeoning her with a baseball bat on May 11, 2006, in the Ossining home they shared. Ms. Mery, a Spanish teacher, was found sprawled near her front door.

A Williamsburg man was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 20 years in prison for raping three women near the Williamsburg and Bushwick Houses projects. The man, Gerard Mitchell, 31, pleaded guilty on Oct. 11 to one count of first-degree rape. He had been charged with attacking three women, ranging in age from 22 to 38, between October 2005 and February 2006. Prosecutors said that Mr. Mitchell threatened one woman with a knife, told two others he had a gun, and stole money and a cellphone during the attacks. When Mr. Mitchell was arrested, the police recovered a devil mask similar to one described by one of the victims.
The wives of five presidential candidates will convene with Maria Shriver today in Long Beach, Calif., to discuss their lives as mothers, spouses, targets, professionals and, perhaps, competitors.

A college student from Long Island was fatally hit by a car early Saturday morning after being stopped for speeding outside Rochester, the police said yesterday. The student, Kaitlin Anne Charity, 20, of Islip, in Suffolk County, was stopped just before dawn on Route 390 in Mount Morris as she was driving back to the State University College at Geneseo. After the state trooper who wrote the ticket left, Ms. Charity got out of the car and walked to the side of the road. She was struck while returning to her car. Yesterday the police were seeking to interview the drivers of three vehicles seen near the accident site.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said yesterday that the Federal Aviation Administration’s proposal to reinstate limits on flights at Kennedy International Airport would interfere with growth in the region and do nothing to ease the congestion and delays that have plagued the airport for the past year. The Port Authority, which owns the three major New York area airports, said that cutting the maximum number of flights at Kennedy to 80 an hour, as the F.A.A. proposed last week, would mean turning away about 10,000 passengers a day. Airlines, federal aviation officials and the Port Authority have been trying to address delays at Kennedy, which have increased substantially since flight limits were lifted at the beginning of 2007.
Mr. DeDomenico Sr. and his brothers invented Rice-A-Roni, one of the classic kitchen helpers of the 1960s.

9 P.M. (CNN) PLANET IN PERIL In this two-part, four-hour documentary, Anderson Cooper and Jeff Corwin, above, from left, and Dr. Sanjay Gupta travel to some of the most remote places on earth to examine four issues affecting its future: climate change, vanishing habitats, disappearing species and human population growth. Segments delve into illegal wildlife trading in Southeast Asia; deforestation in Brazil; the perils facing species like polar bears and wolves; the retreat of the ice sheet in Greenland; population control in China; the disappearance of Lake Chad in Central Africa; and the Carteret Islands in the South Pacific. Part 2 will be shown tomorrow night at 9.

LOMBARD--Richard S. , former general counsel of Exxon Corporation from 1973 to 1993, died at his home in Tucson, Arizona, on October 18, at age 79. A leader of the New York and national bars, he helped to shape the practice of law in the United States and abroad. Born in 1928 in the Canal Zone, Panama, he attended public schools in the Canal Zone, graduated from Harvard College in 1949 after one year's service in the Army Air Corps, and graduated from the Harvard Law School in 1952. He was an associate with the New York firm of Haight, Gardner, Poor, and Havens, from 1952 to 1955. He began work as a lawyer for Exxon's predecessor, the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, in 1955, spending ten years in the law department of its Venezuelan subsidiary, Creole Petroleum, and eight years in the law departments of Exxon divisions in New York and Texas before becoming Exxon's general counsel in 1973 (vice president from 1980 to 1993). His career with Exxon, in 1973 the largest oil company and largest publicly traded corporation in the world, spanned a period of expansion in worldwide demand for oil and a major restructuring of the oil business. During the seventies, he coordinated Exxon's legal response to the Middle East oil crisis, including the nationalizations of the Iraqi, Libyan, Saudi Arabian, and Venezuelan oil industries between 1972 and 1976, an oil embargo by Arab members of OPEC, and the oil crisis following the Iranian revolution in 1979. Exxon's and other companies' success in using arbitration and negotiation to win compensation for their nationalized assets helped popularize the use of private international arbitration, now the standard mechanism for private international dispute resolution. During the eighties, he coordinated Exxon's response to increased litigation by expanding the size of Exxon's law department and handling much of the company's legal business inhouse, a model later followed by corporate law departments nationwide. From 1989 until 1993, he coordinated Exxon's legal response to the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska. After his retirement from Exxon in 1993, he was of counsel to the Dallas firm of Baker and Botts until 1996, and served as an arbitrator in domestic and international business disputes until 2002. He influenced the profession as a leader of various organizations, as a former chairman of the boards of trustees of the American Arbitration Association and the Parker School of International and Comparative Law at Columbia University, and as a cofounder in the eighties, along with Cyrus Vance and others, of Volunteers of Legal Services (VOLS), to coordinate the provision of volunteer legal work during a time of cutbacks in federal funding for legal services for the poor. He was a former trustee of the Southwestern Legal Foundation (now the Center for International and American Law) at Southern Methodist University, former member of the advisory board at the Columbia University Center for Law and Economic Studies, and former trustee of the Practicing Law Institute, among other groups. He is the author of one book, ''American Venezuelan Private International Law: A Bilateral Study'' (New York, 1965) He is survived by his beloved wife of 55 years, Arlene Olson Lombard of Tucson, Arizona, his son James, also of Tucson, his daughter Anne, of Aliso Viejo, California, four grandchildren, and his sister, Elaine Newland of Bluffton, South Carolina. A memorial service will be held October 26, 1pm, at St. Philip's in the Hills Episcopal Church in Tucson, Arizona Donations in lieu of flowers may be sent to the Primavera Foundation, 702 S. 6th Ave., Tucson, Arizona 85701.

The principal of Canarsie High School received a noose along with a racially charged letter yesterday, the police said. The principal, Tyona Washington, who is black, is in her first year at the school. The hate crimes unit of the Police Department is investigating, but the police said yesterday that there were no suspects. The letter, found around 10:30, was signed with the name of a white administrator at the school, the police said, adding that they believed that the signature was not genuine. According to the police, the letter did not make any direct threats but said, ''I'll give you enough rope to hang yourself.'' The letter also included the words ''white power forever'' and included a racial slur, the police said.

HELFAT--Bernard A. , died peacefully on October 20, 2007 at his home in Douglaston, NY at the age of 90. He practiced law for over 60 years, first with his father, J. Nathan Helfat, and later as a sole practitioner. Mr. Helfat was well known in the textile industry for helping to bring to an end the long-standing practice of design piracy (knock offs). He represented the plaintiff in the landmark case of Peter Pan Fabrics vs. Martin Weiner, Inc. This decision had a great impact, not only on design protection in the textile industry, but for other fashion industries as well. Mr. Helfat grew up in Lawrence, Long Island and was Valedictorian of Lawrence High School, Class of 1933. He also graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy, Class of 1934; Harvard College 1938 and Harvard Law School 1941. During World War II, he served on the War Department General Staff in Washington D.C. and obtained the rank of Captain. He was recalled during the Korean War, serving in the National Security Agency, and was a recipient of the Bronze Star. After returning to civilian life, Mr. Helfat and his family settled in Douglaston, Queens where he became active in civic affairs and politics. He was a founding member and a past President of Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, past President of the Douglaston Civic Association, and past Chairman of the New York City School Board for North East Queens. Mr. Helfat was also a past President of the Bayside Democratic Club and ran for Congress on the Democratic and Liberal party lines in 1960. Sailing with his family on the Long Island Sound and tending to his rose garden were favorite past times. He is survived by Lucile, his beloved wife of 64 years; two sons, Jonathan and Mark; his two loving daughters-in-law, Robin and Mendy; as well as his two grandsons, Benjamin and Joshua; and Joshua's wife Abigail. Funeral services will be held at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck (corner of Hicks Lane and Station Road, Great Neck, NY) on October 22, 2007 at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Temple Emanuel of Great Neck.

RORABACK--Catherine G. , 87, of Canaan and Salisbury, CT, a prominent civil liberties attorney and greatly loved and respected member of her community, died peacefully in her sleep on October 17, happy with the life she had led. Her wisdom, her infectious laugh and memorable stories will be greatly missed by her family. She is survived by her sister, Elizabeth Schmidt of Canaan, her nieces, Christianne Pidgeon, Marta Schmidt and Caroline Jonker, and her nephews, Fred Schmidt and Albert E. Roraback, III. She was predeceased by her brother, Albert E. Roraback, Jr., and her longtime companion Phyllis Chait. A Memorial Service for the public will be held on Saturday, November 10 at 2pm at Music Mountain in Falls Village, CT followed by a reception at 4pm at Geer Village in Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions be made to the Catherine Roraback Law Scholarship Fund of the Litchfield County Bar Association, Connecticut Planned Parenthood, the Connecticut Women's Education and Legal Fund, Music Mountain, or The Canaan Foundation, all c/o Salisbury Bank & Trust Co., 5 Bissell St., Salisbury, CT 06068, attn. Diane Johnstone. RORABACK--Catherine. The American Civil Liberties Union and its Board of Directors mourn the passing of legendary civil rights attorney Catherine G. ''Katie'' Roraback. Roraback was a board member emeritus of the ACLU of Connecticut, and a longtime member of the ACLU's national board, and its National Advisory Council. She was 87 years old. Roraback is remembered by many as a wonderful mentor and inspiration to other lawyers, especially younger women. She made protecting the legal rights of ''dissenters and the dispossessed'' a part of her practice long before the advent of public interest law, defending Black Panthers in New Haven, civil rights workers in Mississippi, and citizens in the denaturalization proceedings during the McCarthy era. But Roraback truly made her mark in a 50year career by fighting for women's reproductive rights. She litigated landmark cases, including the case that established reproductive health rights for women, secured the right to birth control, and established a constitutional right to privacy, Griswold vs. Connecticut. The United States Supreme Court held in that case that the Constitution guarantees a ''right to privacy'' when individuals make decisions about intimate, personal matters such as childbearing. That right to privacy would then be the underpinning of the Court's Roe v. Wade 1973 landmark ruling. Roraback tried Women vs. Connecticut, the state's counterpart to Roe v. Wade, which struck down Connecticut's anti-abortion statutes. Catherine Roraback will be deeply missed by those who value freedom and equal rights for all people.

FOESTE--Dr. William J. Died at his home on August 27th, 2007 after a long illness, with his loving wife Joan, sister Jane, and sister-in-law Christiana at his side. The son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Foeste, Bill was born in Billings, Montana September 6th, 1948. He graduated from the University of Wisconsin in 1970, and in 1974 received his medical degree from the University of Colorado. He completed his medical residency at Downstate/Kings County Hospital Centers. Dr. Bill, as many of his patients affectionately called him, spent most of his professional life serving the medically underserved in the emergency room and drug treatment center at Kings County Hospital. At a time when HMOs put many doctors and patients in adversarial relationships, Bill became even closer to his patients helping them negotiate the complexities of the health care system. Many of his patients had his home and cell phone numbers. In his personal life, he also helped those less fortunate. Without fanfare, he worked to make the world a better place by his commitment to children. All those that he helped attained heights they never could have without his support. An environmentalist before it became fashionable, his carbon footprint was small, his personal footprint was huge. Bill's love of travel, which took him to five continents, as well as his passion for reading benefitted not only himself, but all of his friends for Bill was a witty and brilliant conversationalist. Left to mourn his exemplary life are his beloved wife Joan Spence Foeste; his brother Arthur E. Foeste (Joan) of Madison, WI; sister Jane F. Wittenwyler (Ronald) of Des Moines, IA, and Kay F. Goepfert (Walter) of Madison, WI; God-daughter, Hershley Philogene of Brooklyn; stepchildren Paul and Suzanne Fairweather; nieces and nephews around the world, and a host of close friends. A private memorial service was held at his home on September 3rd, 2007.

JAMES--Seldon Taylor, Jr. , 81, of New York City, East Hampton, NY, and East Dover, VT, died peacefully on October 19 in his East Hampton home attended by his beloved wife, Linda Brady James. Survived also by his daughter Stephanie Brady James, DVM, Dipl. A.C.Z.M. and her partner Marcia Lynn Arland; son Seldon (Jamie) Taylor James, III, and his wife Deena Marie Del Zotto; daughter Alexandra Minnie James Reed and her husband Andrew Lawrence Reed; grandchildren Sarah Jordan James, Nadja James, Avery Etta Reed and Harriet Naomi Reed; and sister Emma Mabel James Hackett. Born August 19, 1926 in Buenos Aires, Argentina, Seldon attended Amherst College in Massachusetts, served in the US Navy in World War II, traveled extensively as a wool trader, then joined Allen and Company before becoming an independent investment banker in New York and a Director of CPAC Inc of Rochester, NY. He loved woodworking, gardening, tinkering in his East Hampton basement, and taking long walks in the woods in Vermont. He valued his friends, adored his children, treasured his grandchildren, and most of all cherished his Linda. Together, Seldon and Linda shared a 45 year love affair filled with travel, adventure, and good food. He was Lindas Viejo, a gifted mentor to family and friends, and a gentleman extraordinaire. Services to be held in East Hampton at St. Lukes Episcopal Church, 18 James Lane, Wednesday, October 24, at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Seldons name to Goddard Riverside Community Center, 593 Columbus Avenue, NY, NY 10024 and Roosevelt Hospital, Development Office, 555 West 57th Street, NY, NY 10019.

The magician David Copperfield has canceled performances in Southeast Asia after the F.B.I. searched his warehouse in Las Vegas and a casino theater where he regularly performs, The Associated Press reported. ''His management sent an e-mail message to organizers Sunday to inform that his shows will be postponed indefinitely,'' said Kittiyong Achawaphong of RSi Dream Entertainment, the company that organized Mr. Copperfield's shows in Thailand. He was also to perform in Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore in the coming weeks. The cancellations came after federal agents carried out searches last week after allegations that Mr. Copperfield, 51, had forced himself on an unidentified woman. The magician's lawyer, David Chesnoff, said the accusations ''are false because David Copperfield has never forced himself on anyone.'' Neither Mr. Chesnoff nor law enforcement officials provided details of the investigation.

SINGER--James . The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, James Singer, and extend sincere condolences to his family. Charles J. Block, President

SCHNEIDERMAN--Herb . We are deeply saddened by the sudden loss of our dear friend. Our sincere condolences to Bobbe, Nancy, Buddy and the entire family. The Lieberman Family SCHNEIDERMAN--Herbert (Herby) ''Poppy'', age 76 of Delray Beach, FL, passed away unexpectedly Saturday, October 20, 2007. Originally from New York, he moved to Florida permanently six years ago with his wife Bobbe, after retiring from a long and very successful career as a manufacturer of women's sportswear. Herby was admired and respected by many as an astute businessman and was considered a beloved friend by countless people. His generosity, kindness, intelligence, strength, sense of humor and guidance will be greatly missed by all those who knew him. He is survived by his devoted wife Bobbe, loving children Buddy (Mindy) Schneiderman of Parkland, FL; Nancy (Olivier) Bernardeau of Palm Beach Gardens, FL; cherished grandchildren Tyler, Jed, Sean and Zoe; special sister Barbara Schwartz of New York; sister-in-law and brother-in-law Marilyn and Harry Seaton of Boynton Beach, FL; and many beloved cousins, nieces and nephews. Services were held at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Boynton Beach, FL. SCHNEIDER--Jacqueline B. Columbia/Barnard Hillel deeply mourns the passing of our devoted board member, Jacqueline B. Schneider. Jacqueline cared deeply about Jewish student life and her passing is a tremendous loss for all our us. Our sincere condolences to Clarence S. Barasch, our former President, and to her entire family. Judith Schwartz, President Earle W. Kazis, Chairman Robert K. Kraft Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, Campaign Co-Chairs Simon Klarfeld, Exec. Dir.

ALLWIN--James M The Founder and Chief Executive Officer of Aetos Capital succumbed to cancer on Friday, October 19, at the age of 54, in Greenwich. He is survived by his wife and his three children. Jim was born on January 13, 1953, in Germany. He received his BA degree from Yale University in 1974. In 1976, he received his MBA from the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth College, where he later served as a member of the Board of Overseers, and founded the school's Initiative on Corporate Citizenship and Ethics. In 1999, Jim founded Aetos Capital, an investment management firm, whose clients have grown to include a number of the world's most sophisticated pension funds, endowments, foundations, and governmental entities, as well as a small set of significant private investors. In 2005, Mr. Allwin became the CEO of AEA Holdings, an entity created from the combination of Aetos Capital and AEA Investors. Prior to founding Aetos Capital, Mr. Allwin was head of the Investment Management businesses of Morgan Stanley, including Morgan Stanley Asset Management, Miller Anderson & Sherrerd and the firm's Private Equity and Real Estate Funds. Over the course of his 23-year career at Morgan Stanley, Mr. Allwin also worked in areas such as Corporate Finance and Mergers and Acquisitions, and served as a member of the Morgan Stanley Management Committee. In addition to his dedicated work in the business sector, Mr. Allwin made important contributions in the areas of education, health care and the arts. For 28 years he has been a Board member of Communities in Schools, the nation's largest stay-in-school program, acting as Chairman for 11 of those years. He also has been serving on the Boards of America's Promise--The Alliance for Youth and the National Mentoring Partnership, as well as the Board of Overseers at the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration at Dartmouth. He previously chaired the Board of Trustees of Greenwich Academy and was a member of the Investment Committee of Yale University. In the area of healthcare, Jim has been actively involved as a Board member of the YaleNew Haven Hospital System, and served as a member of the Howard Hughes Medical Institutes Investment Committee. Jim's interest in modern art led him to serve as a Trustee of both the Dia Art Foundation and the American Patrons of Tate. Jim will be waked on Wednesday, October 24, from 4:00pm--8:00pm at Leo P. Gallagher & Sons, located at 31 Arch Street in Greenwich, Connecticut. His funeral Mass will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral (Fifth Avenue between 50th and 51st Streets) in Manhattan on Thursday, October 25, at 10:30 am. ALLWIN--James. The Trustees of the American Patrons of Tate are profoundly saddened the untimely death of their fellow Trustee. We extended our deepest sympathy to Jim's family and colleagues at Aetos Capital. Our thoughts our with them at this difficult time. Lady Lynn Forester de Rothschild (Chair) Sir Nicholas Serota (Director, Tate) ALLWIN--James. Forest City Ratner Companies and the Nets Organization mourn the passing of Jim Allwin. Jim, an investor in the Nets, founded Aetos Capital in 1999, a dynamic organization of nearly 300 people and $12 billion in assets. A leader in the industry, Jim was a true professional and an exceptional gentleman whose legacy is marked by his extraordinary charitable efforts in the areas of education, health care, and the arts. Jim was a friend for more than a decade and will be missed by Bruce Ratner and everyone at Forest City and the Nets. ALLWIN--James M. The board and staff of Dia Art Foundation are deeply saddened by the death of our friend, Jim Allwin. Jim had a tremendous impact as a Dia trustee, bringing his many talents, as well as his great sense of humor and generosity of spirit, to our group. We treasured his keen intellect, strong leadership, ready smile, and easy humor. We are fortunate to have known Jim, to have learned from his invaluable counsel, and to have shared many happy moments with him. We miss him deeply, and extend our sincere sympathy to his family and many friends. Nathalie de Gunzburg, Chairman Jeffrey Weiss, Director ALLWIN--James M. The entire AEA Team is deeply saddened by the death, on October 19th, of our partner and friend who was CEO of AEA Holdings. Jim was a born leader and business visionary who always kept his eye focused on what was important. We will sorely miss the many personal qualities that endeared him to everyone he met-his personal warmth, good judgment, sense of humor, humility and generosity. He was one of the most positive and optimistic individuals we have ever known, undaunted by even the most seemingly insurmountable challenges. These qualities made him an irresistible friend and treasured business colleague. Above all, we will miss our fun-loving friend with his mischievous humor who treated everyone with kindness. He lived every day of his life to the fullest and brought joy to us and to his wide circle of friends from all walks of life. Jim leaves a big void in our lives. All of us at AEA extend our deepest sympathy to Jim's family and colleagues at Aetos. Vincent Mai, Chairman John Garcia, CEO AEA Investors LLC

City health officials, in their continuing fight against obesity, proposed a new regulation today requiring chain restaurants to post calorie information on their menus after a federal judge struck down a similar measure in September.The new regulation would apply to all restaurants with 15 outlets or more across the country, though it’s aimed squarely at the fast food industry. Many chains, like McDonald’s, Burger King and Starbucks, already provide calorie information on their Web sites, or on posters or tray liners available in their restaurants. But health officials say customers rarely see this information before deciding what to order.

Robert E. Chambers Jr., who became known to New Yorkers as the “preppy killer” after the 1986 killing of Jennifer Levin in Central Park, pleaded guilty to first-degree manslaughter in her death in 1988. He served 15 years in prison. Now Mr. Chambers, 41, is in serious legal trouble again, along with his girlfriend, Shawn Kovell, 39. After neighbors complained about a constant stream of strangers to and from the pair’s apartment in a building on East 57th Street, the police mounted an undercover operation. Over the course of three months, the authorities said, officers bought 246 grams of cocaine for $9,600 from Mr. Chambers and Ms. Kovell, an amount that could fetch $20,000 on the street.

Watching the film this weekend, I was more taken with the visual poetry of the Mr. Marconi's imagery - he always seems to be watching the designer with awe - than I was surprised by Mr. Lagerfeld's directness about sex and the social injustice of fashion. ("I was practicing by the time I was 13," Mr. Lagerfeld says in the film. "I knew earlier, but it didn't seem important. I didn't see the issue. My half-sister was a lesbian, so it didn't matter.")

Is it too early for the inevitable bow to Isaiah Berlin? If so, I apologize, but he has been for at least three decades the refuge of students with a term-paper deadline and no profound original thesis, which is where I find myself this week. And he is, I think, particularly acute on the relationship between Tolstoy and his century, the question Sam has posed for our panel. So let's leave Andrei and Pierre and Natasha and the rest for a moment, and time-machine forward to the 20th century. Berlin's clever template for the discussion of great thinkers was, as the hyperliterates who have been participating in this discussion know better than I, "The Hedgehog and the Fox." The hedgehog, in Berlin's formulation, views the world through one great defining idea, a "single central vision, one system less or more coherent or articulate." To this category Berlin assigns Dante, Plato, Hegel, Nietzsche, Dostoevsky, Proust and others. The more intellectually promiscuous fox, in contrast, pursues "many ends, often unrelated and even contradictory, connected, if at all, only in some de facto way," not joined by an overarching moral or aesthetic principle. Aristotle, Goethe, Pushkin, Balzac, Joyce and, of course, Shakespeare, are foxes.

Whenever people ask me whether employers are amenable to a part-time arrangement for a reason other than parenting responsibilities, I talk about Karl Hampe. After 20 years as a high-powered management consultant, Mr. Hampe was going through one of those "Is this all there is?" periods. He was also itching to do something more creative. Specifically, he wanted to see if he still had a knack for cartooning, a talent he'd neglected since college. It took months of negotiating and crafting a proposal for how his responsibilities would be handled, but eventually his firm agreed. (When faced with the prospect of losing a high performer, firms will often be agreeable to a sensible proposal. It costs quite a lot of money to replace a well-trained employee.)

The markdowns at the securities firm, many of which were across complex debt instruments called collateralized debt obligations, contributed to a net loss from continuing operations of $2.3 billion in the quarter ended Sept. 28, Merrill said.
