President Bush toured fire-ravaged Southern California today, where air tankers worked to contain the fires that still threaten thousands of homes.
The pace of China’s economic development is still strong enough to keep pushing up prices around the world.
A tentative Chrysler-U.A.W. agreement appears headed for approval after four union locals voted in favor of it.

Adrian Aucoin scored the go-ahead goal early in the third period last night, and the Calgary Flames beat visiting Minnesota, 5-3, handing the Wild its first regulation loss in nine games this season.Minnesota earned 15 of 16 available points in its first eight games, winning seven times and dropping a shootout decision at Los Angeles.The Flames rallied after falling behind, 3-0, in the first 10 minutes.Jarome Iginla and Dion Phaneuf got the rally started with power-play goals in the second period, and Alex Tanguay tied the score later in the period. Aucoin gave Calgary the lead at 3 minutes 46 seconds of the third, and Robyn Regehr added a goal at 8:03. In other games: ¶The Washington captain Chris Clark scored his first two goals, and the Capitals’ juggled lineup produced the team’s highest output of the season in a 5-3 win over the visiting Tampa Bay Lightning. Alex Ovechkin had two assists and an empty-net goal with four seconds left to help the Capitals end a four-game losing streak.¶Eric Staal, Jeff Hamilton, Cory Stillman and Bret Hedican scored third-period goals as the Carolina Hurricanes defeated visiting Buffalo, 6-2, for their first victory over the Sabres since Game 7 of the 2006 Eastern Conference finals.¶Olli Jokinen scored twice to become Florida’s career leader in goals and points as the host Panthers edged the Philadelphia Flyers, 4-3. Jokinen’s first goal was his 355th point with the Panthers and his second goal was his 158th.¶Tomas Holmstrom scored his sixth and seven goals, and Matt Ellis also had a goal, as the Red Wings defeated the Vancouver Canucks, 3-2, in Detroit.

A woman was found dead and two men were seriously injured last night in a suspicious fire at a New York City Housing Authority project in the East New York area, the police and fire officials said. The fire broke out on the fifth floor of an eight-story brick apartment building at 730 Euclid Avenue near Dumont Avenue in the Cypress Hills complex. The fire was reported at 10:28 p.m. and was brought under control by 10:44, the Fire Department said. The identities of the victims were not immediately released. Some neighbors said they believed that the fire was set intentionally because of a personal dispute, but fire officials said that the cause remained under investigation.
Josh Beckett continued his postseason dominance as the Boston Red Sox overwhelmed the Colorado Rockies.
The Bush administration will roll out its long-debated statement accusing a Revolutionary Guard Corps division in Iran of supporting terrorism.

A government panel said the former president of South Korea gave a tacit nod to a secret operation in 1993 to kidnap Kim Dae-jung, then a dissident leader who later became the first opposition-backed president and a Nobel peace laureate. The fact-finding panel of the National Intelligence Service also said it could not rule out the possibility that the former president, Park Chung-hee, may have directly ordered the kidnapping of Mr. Kim. South Korean intelligence agents kidnapped Mr. Kim from a Tokyo hotel in August 1973, just days before he was to start a coalition of Japan-based South Korean organizations to work for their country’s democratization. The panel did not draw a clear conclusion on whether the kidnapping was ultimately aimed at killing Mr. Kim, who said his abductors nearly dumped him from a ship at sea a few days after his capture, but stopped when a United States military helicopter made a low pass over the vessel. Mr. Park died in 1979.
Gov. Sonny Perdue banned the washing of state vehicles and ordered inmates to take one quick shower a day as part of an effort to reduce water use in his drought-stricken state.
The editor of The New Republic, Franklin Foer, said he stood by the Baghdad Diarist, an American soldier whose anonymously published columns were labled false by an Army investigation.
A woman who sent her Arab-American boss a threatening note that warned ”Remember 9/11” and ”You and your kids will pay” was sentenced to eight months in a federal halfway house.
The almost forgotten Mardy Collins entered the game late in the first quarter and caused instant havoc, collecting four steals, a blocked shot and three free throws in 10 minutes.
The San Diego Chargers began their week of practice Wednesday at the Arizona Cardinals training facility, unsure of where or when they will play this weekend.

An article on Sunday about environmental and economic development projects in the South Bronx financed by Citgo Petroleum, the American subsidiary of Venezuela’s state-owned oil company, gave an incorrect amount in some editions for discounted heating oil delivered to Americans last winter, and the amount it expects to deliver this winter. It delivered 100 million gallons, not 100,000, last winter, and plans to deliver 110 million gallons, not 110,000, this winter. Picture captions in one edition misidentified a man shown watering a rooftop garden in the South Bronx and standing with other members of a community group that received financing from Citgo Petroleum. He is Stephen Oliveira, not Henry Lajara.

An article on Sunday about environmental and economic development projects in the South Bronx financed by Citgo Petroleum, the American subsidiary of Venezuela’s state-owned oil company, gave an incorrect amount in some editions for discounted heating oil delivered to Americans last winter, and the amount it expects to deliver this winter. It delivered 100 million gallons, not 100,000, last winter, and plans to deliver 110 million gallons, not 110,000, this winter. Picture captions in one edition misidentified a man shown watering a rooftop garden in the South Bronx and standing with other members of a community group that received financing from Citgo Petroleum. He is Stephen Oliveira, not Henry Lajara.

The Heat traded Antoine Walker, a three-time All-Star forward, to the Minnesota Timberwolves yesterday in a five-player deal that came a day after Miami ended a winless preseason.The Heat sent Walker, the backup center Michael Doleac, forward Wayne Simien and a conditional first-round draft pick to Minnesota for the former Miami swingman Ricky Davis and center Mark Blount.With Davis, Miami receives a third scoring option behind Shaquille O’Neal and Dwyane Wade. The Timberwolves have only three players who have been with the team more than one season: Mark Madsen, Rashad McCants and Marko Jaric.

Irish Majesty edged Pink Viper by a nose yesterday in the $56,840 opening-day feature at Aqueduct.With Mike Luzzi aboard, Irish Majesty launched a three-wide rally that carried him to his fifth win in 25 starts. Irish Majesty, ran the mile on the fast track in 1 minute 37.40 seconds, and paid $18.60 on a $2 bet to win.

Shawn Estrada, a middleweight, the light featherweight Raynell Williams and the super heavyweight Michael Hunter took their first steps toward the Beijing Olympics with victories in the preliminary round of the world boxing championships yesterday in Chicago.Estrada defeated Artur Zlatopolski of Israel in a 25-5 decision, after Williams counterpunched his way to a 28-18 decision against France’s Khedafi Djelkhir, a 2004 Olympian.Hunter beat Andres Ruiz Ponce of Mexico when officials stopped the bout with 1:08 left in the third round and Hunter leading by 20 points.The American heavyweight Deontay Wilder lost to Poland’s Krysztof Zimnoch, 23-20.

An appeals committee yesterday unanimously overturned the $10,000 fine levied against a crew chief for Kyle Busch after a Busch Series race in Kansas.The crew chief, Michael Bumgarner, was fined after Busch’s win at Kansas Speedway last month because Nascar said the intake manifold on the Chevrolet did not conform to its standards. Hendrick Motorsports argued that the part, and others identical to it, had been used over the last three seasons and never failed inspection.

The FIFA president, Joseph S. Blatter, wants to end the continental rotation system for playing host to the World Cup. He said yesterday that he would urge the executive committee to adopt his proposal next week, paving the way for open bidding for the 2018 competition. Blatter cited England, the United States, Canada, China, Mexico and Australia as possible sites.

The New Jersey Racing Commission reported yesterday that random blood tests of Breeders’ Cup horses competing at Monmouth Park this weekend were negative.The New Jersey commission, with the cooperation of racing commissions across the country and in Europe, conducted a random sampling of horses pre-entered Oct. 15 for the 11 Breeders’ Cup races. Under regulations adopted last month, the commission can conduct out-of-competition tests for the blood doping agent Epogen, known as EPO, in horses running at any of the state’s tracks. In the past, tests were conducted in the hours before or after a race.

The Washington captain Chris Clark scored his first two goals last night, and the Capitals’ juggled lineup produced the team’s highest output of the season in a 5-3 win over the visiting Tampa Bay Lightning. Alex Ovechkin had two assists and an empty-net goal with four seconds left to help the Capitals end a four-game losing streak.In other games, Eric Staal, Jeff Hamilton, Cory Stillman and Bret Hedican scored third-period goals as the Carolina Hurricanes defeated visiting Buffalo, 6-2, for their first victory over the Sabres since Game 7 of the 2006 Eastern Conference finals.Olli Jokinen scored twice to become Florida’s career leader in goals and points as the host Panthers edged the Philadelphia Flyers, 4-3. Jokinen’s first goal was his 355th point with the Panthers and his second goal was his 158th.Tomas Holmstrom scored his sixth and seven goals, and Matt Ellis also had a goal, as the Red Wings defeated the Vancouver Canucks, 3-2, in Detroit.

Darnell Dodson, a 6-foot-6 guard who was a member of what Pittsburgh Coach Jamie Dixon called his best recruiting class, is planning to transfer to Miami Dade College.Dodson had been allowed to practice with the Panthers as he awaited word on his eligibility for this season, but he stopped practicing this week. When he learned he was not eligible, Dodson decided to transfer.Dodson, a strong outside shooter, had been expected to redshirt this season.
Porsche won a court case against Volkswagen labor leaders, allowing it to set up a European company structure that avoids stricter German labor rules.
STMicroelectronics, the largest chip maker in Europe, said its quarterly profit fell 10 percent, held down by a strong European currency but topping expectations.
The European Union has authorized imports of four genetically modified crop products for sale across its 27 national markets for the next 10 years.
Exports from Japan grew at the slowest pace in two years in September as shipments to the U.S., its largest market, fell, the finance ministry said.

The governor of southeastern Khost Province, Arsallah Jamal, survived a suicide attack on his convoy unhurt, officials said. He has been the target of several attacks. Three people were wounded. “The car bomber hit a vehicle ahead of me,” Mr. Jamal said. “I am fine.”.
Prostitutes in El Alto, outside La Paz, sewed their lips together as part of a hunger strike to demand that the mayor reopen brothels and bars he ordered closed last week.
A journalist who reported extensively for the Voice of America was shot to death outside his office in Osh, near the border with Uzbekistan.

Five houses toppled into a collapsed coal mine tunnel in northern Shanxi Province, killing at least 12 people, the Xinhua News Agency reported. Workers had been extending the tunnel under a residential area in the city of Yangquan when the houses fell. The report did not say if the people who died were in the houses or the tunnel.
German train drivers brought local rail services across the country to a standstill to press their demand for higher wages.
The closing of the All State Café signifies the end of a bar whose history is darker than most — one with its own niche in the annals of New York crime.
Donald T. DiFrancesco has been accused of sexual harassment by a former partner at his law firm, according to a lawsuit filed Wednesday.
A suburban ambulance crew that picked up a dying runner in the Chicago Marathon apparently got lost on the way to a hospital, the authorities said.

Several Oklahoma lawmakers plan to return copies of the Koran to a state panel on diversity after a lawmaker claimed the Muslim holy book condones the killing of innocent people.

President Bush, in issuing his warning on the coming transition in Cuban leadership, is addressing audiences with differing priorities.
With these votes, the tentative agreement between Chrysler and the U.A.W was passing by about 57 percent of workers who had cast ballots, according to a New York Times estimate.
The House’s leading Democratic tax writer will propose a sweeping overhaul of the tax code that would raise taxes on many with incomes above $200,000 but cut taxes for most others.
The secretive world of the Blackwater compound in Baghdad is fraying under intense scrutiny.
The plans to cut 3,000 jobs followed a terrible third quarter in which the investment banking unit’s profit dropped 93 percent after virtually every area performed poorly.
Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice admitted Wednesday that the United States had mishandled the case of a Canadian who was deported to Syria and who has said he was tortured there.
Curt Schilling has not pitched on the regular four days of rest for any of his three playoff starts, but he will in Game 2 against the Colorado Rockies on Thursday night.
Democrats hope to win over more Republicans with revisions that would tighten eligibility for the State Children’s Health Insurance Program.
The brokerage’s $7.9 billion write down raised questions about E. Stanley O’Neal’s leadership and the ability of his top executives to manage the risky assets on the firm’s balance sheet.
The Giants’ Osi Umenyiora, who is tied for the league lead with eight quarterback sacks, was born in Golders Green, a suburb of London.
The investment ends two months of jockeying among Microsoft, Google and Yahoo for the right to invest in and forge close ties with the fast-growing social networking Web site.
A bill that aims to help small businesses is being criticized by some who say it allows venture capital companies to pose as small firms to tap into billions of federal research dollars.

Voters deserve a thorough airing on the issue of the Rockefeller laws and options for reforming the most draconian drug laws the country has yet seen.
Tony Peña was interviewed on Wednesday for the Yankees’ managerial opening and a decision may be made as early as Friday between Peña, Don Mattingly and Joe Girardi.
As sales of existing homes plunged 8 percent in September to the slowest annual pace in nearly a decade, markets rebounded from early losses on hopes the Fed will cut rates.
Richard J. Griffin has been the director of the State Department’s diplomatic security bureau since June 2005 and faced stiff criticism from Congress in recent weeks.
A psychiatrist is suing Columbia University for wrongful termination and charging that another psychiatrist engineered his ouster in a years-long Machiavellian plot.
Shayne Culpepper and Sara Hall are just a few of the runners with Olympic aspirations whose elite-level spouses are competing in New York.

A passenger in a car driven by the man killed in a road-rage shooting in Upper Manhattan on Sunday has denied police reports that he was too drunk to remember what happened, and said he did not believe his friend made a threatening gesture at a police officer just before he was shot.
The N.C.A.A. has declared that “bench decorum” will be a point of emphasis this season, which will likely affect Coach Jim Calhoun and many of the Big East’s other frenetic sideline presences.
Hollywood players skipped work to watch over their estates as the entertainment industry collectively held its breath watching the devastation from the wildfires.
A dispute has erupted between Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and conservative lawmakers over her pursuit of diplomacy with North Korea.
A study suggests that in emergencies when masks are not available or cannot be worn for extended periods, using inhalers can be an effective way of helping to protect workers.
GlaxoSmithKline said it would cut jobs as part of a cost-savings plan after a sharp drop in sales of its diabetes drug and generic competition led to a 5.8 percent drop in profits.
The government now contends that a whistle-blower within Cell Therapeutics was the mastermind of a much bigger scheme than the ones on which he reported.
Despite a pretense of fiscal prudence, President Bush keeps throwing money at his war, regardless of the cost in blood, treasure or children’s health care.
VMware, reporting its first financial results since its I.P.O., said third-quarter profit more than tripled on demand for software that makes computers more efficient.
Allan Stevenson, a retired actor, had a nightly routine.
As valuable as Mike Lowell has been in helping the Red Sox surge into the World Series, there is a chance he could be playing his final games with the team.
The U.N. envoy for Darfur on Wednesday urged fractious rebel groups and the Sudanese government to overcome their internal differences and attend a peace conference scheduled to begin in three days.
The glimmering Prudential Center, the first new sports arena in the metropolitan region in 25 years, is getting mixed reviews from residents as to its benefits.
Military contractors Northrop Grumman and General Dynamics posted higher third-quarter profit and raised their financial forecasts due to strong Pentagon spending.
An American project to replace the Iraqi government’s opaque and easily manipulated accounting system has failed to achieve its goals after four years and more than $38 million.
Leslie H. Southwick won confirmation to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit over the objections of civil rights organizations and many Democrats.

Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo filed legal papers yesterday arguing that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission must require the owners of nuclear plants to defend their reactors from an aerial attack. Although his legal brief was filed as part of a continuing case in California, Mr. Cuomo used the Indian Point nuclear plant, in Buchanan, N.Y., as an example of a facility that he believes should be defended against such an attack. “It is unconscionable that federal regulators don’t require nuclear power plants like Indian Point to defend against airplane attacks,” Mr. Cuomo said in a statement. A commission spokesman said in a statement that it had already ordered operators to take steps to minimize the impact of large explosions or fires; the commission has also said that defending against aerial attacks is beyond its jurisdiction.

The venerable Astroland amusement park in Coney Island will remain open for one more season under a deal announced yesterday with the developer behind the neighborhood’s planned $2 billion makeover. The agreement came after it appeared that the park’s classic rides had gone dark for the last time on Sept. 9. But weeks of talks between the developer, Thor Equities, and the family that owns Astroland, the Alberts, produced a short-term lease. The terms were not made public yesterday. The Alberts, who opened Astroland in 1962, sold the 3.1-acre property off the Boardwalk to Thor last year as part of the developer’s effort to turn 10 acres of Coney Island into a year-round tourist attraction.

A Union City man was sentenced to 15 years in prison yesterday in Federal District Court for masterminding an identity theft scheme in which he defrauded credit card companies, jewelers and the billionaire Sid Bass of more than $100,000. The man, Richard J. Tagliamonte, 58, was convicted in February of eight counts of fraud in connection with the scheme, which he ran from 2000 to 2004. Mr. Tagliamonte was also found to have improperly held two fraudulent checks worth $837,900. He was fined $40,000 and ordered to pay $128,296 in restitution. In all, he held more than 20 credit cards, which he obtained by using fake driver’s licenses and birth certificates.

Federal agents arrested a 49-year-old man this week and charged him with stealing a painting by the Spanish master Goya, the authorities said yesterday. The man, Steven Lee Olson of Carlstadt, N.J., was arrested in his home Tuesday night after being indicted, according to the United States attorney’s office. He was charged with stealing “Children With a Cart,” a 1778 oil valued at $1.1 million and owned by the Toledo Museum of Art. Last November, the museum in Ohio lent the piece to the Guggenheim Museum, but on its way to Manhattan, it was stolen from the back of a truck parked overnight at a hotel in Stroudsburg, Pa. The painting, a detail of which is shown above, was recovered unharmed 12 days later.

Negotiations began yesterday for a new contract covering 26,000 janitors, doormen, elevator operators and repair workers at more than 1,000 office buildings in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens. Mike Fishman, the president of the city’s largest union of building service workers, Local 32BJ of the Service Employees International Union, said its goal was to bring workers’ wages in line with the cost of living at a time when the city’s office rents have been rising. Local 32BJ is negotiating with the Realty Advisory Board, which represents office building owners and management companies. The workers’ current contract expires on Jan. 1.
Student lender Sallie Mae and its would-be buyers agreed to language that enables the company to operate while they battle in court over their collapsed $25 billion buyout.

New York City Transit announced yesterday that it would add 850 hybrid buses to the fleet it operates with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The agency said it already operated the largest hybrid bus fleet in the world, with 548 hybrid buses in service. The M.T.A., which also operates buses in the city, has 284 hybrids on the road. The new buses, made by DaimlerChrysler Commercial Buses North America, are expected to be put in service over the next two years.

Former Senator Bob Kerrey yesterday closed the door once again to the notion of re-entering elective politics, saying he would not return to his native Nebraska to be a candidate for the United States Senate in 2008. For months Mr. Kerrey had been considering whether to seek the Democratic nomination to fill the seat of Senator Chuck Hagel, a Republican who is not seeking re-election. Mr. Kerrey said he would remain president of the New School.

A Legal Aid lawyer who was accused of spying on female colleagues with a camera disguised as a digital alarm clock pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court to unlawful surveillance, a felony. In exchange, the lawyer, Peter A. Barta, 33, was promised conditional discharge, the equivalent of unsupervised probation, and he agreed to get weekly counseling. Mr. Barta worked for Legal Aid in Manhattan from 2001 until 2006, when he was forced to resign after an internal investigation.
Mets catcher Paul Lo Duca is hoping his filly, Grace Anatomy, can do in Saturday’s $2 million Juvenile Fillies what his team could not during the season: get the job done in the stretch.
Facing opposition to his proposed trade deals with Peru, Panama and Colombia, the president is campaigning hard to win approval of the deals, which he says will weaken Mr. Chávez.
The questions people ask make it sound as though I should be morally outraged at myself, as if it’s impossible to scratch the pigs behind the ears and still intend to kill them.
Alarmed that a 52-year-old paper was stoking the arguments of creationists, a chemistry professor has retracted a paper on the origins of life.
Despite some improvements, problems remain in New Jersey’s child welfare system, the state’s child advocate said in a report, released yesterday, on the deaths of four children in 2006.
ConocoPhillips said refined fuel prices failed to keep pace with gains by crude oil, narrowing profit margins on gasoline and diesel.
American Electric Power said its third-quarter earnings rose 54 percent, helped by a warmer than normal summer that increased energy usage.
Matt Holliday is a leading candidate for the Most Valuable Player award. But his teammates suspect that he may soon be eclipsed by his 3-year-old son Jackson.
Children as young as 2 can be given a nasal spray flu vaccine, a federal advisory panel said Wednesday.
Elizabeth Edwards has advised her husband, John, from behind the scenes, defended him in front of audiences and occasionally stolen his spotlight.

In one of those cautionary tales for the Internet age, next time you’re about to send that perfectly succinct nuclear e-mail rocket, consider the travails of a school superintendent before hitting the button.
The brokerage’s move would be a blow to downtown and its supporters in Albany, including Gov. Eliot Spitzer, and it would hobble efforts to re-establish ground zero as a financial center.
Applebee’s plans a rebranding campaign that includes a wide-reaching advertising effort, new logo, new uniforms, redesigned restaurants and a new theme, “Together is good.”
The Department of Defense has identified 3,825 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans on Tuesday:.
A federal appeals court ordered a stay of execution on Wednesday for a prisoner who was scheduled to die by lethal injection in Alabama on Thursday.
Many cancer survivors say they are committed to helping  others with the disease or to solve a particular problem that they encountered in their own treatment.
The WPP Group, the giant advertising company, bought Blast Radius, a leading interactive agency, as part of a digital shopping spree.
The nation’s largest brewer said an increase in international sales helped push its profit up 11 percent in the third quarter.
A rebel attack on a Sri Lankan air base this week caused far more damage than previously acknowledged, destroying eight aircraft, including a vital surveillance plane.
The company said third-quarter profit rose more than expected, boosted by higher aircraft deliveries, but it scaled back next year’s forecast due to delays on its  787 Dreamliner.

In this issue, Michael Lewis explores the life of field-goal kickers, players whose careers are often defined by a single kick made in a pressure situation. Every football fan, of either the college or professional game, can remember a single kick that decided the fortunes of their favorite team. What is the kick that sticks most in your mind?.

Steve Nash, the point guard of the Phoenix Suns, “is one of the more introspective and intelligent athletes in the N.B.A.,” Chip Brown writes in this issue’s cover story, “Not To Get Too Mystical About It.” Sure, Nash has great physical skills, and a particular knack for piercing defenses on the court, but Brown found an elusive quality off of the court as well, and discovered that maybe “what made Nash exceptional was his temperamental inclination to downplay what made him exceptional.” He writes: “Maybe the truest picture of Nash depended on seeing him in motion, in the flow,” both on the basketball floor and in third-world countries. “Enacting himself, as it were, as opposed to talking about himself.” So Brown followed the Canadian-raised star from New York to a charity event in China to scrimmages in Phoenix, all to capture Nash in the flow.

Compared to the world’s other great mountains, climbing Mount Kilimanjaro is simple - no technical skill necessary. But it’s definitely no walk in the park. In “Up The Mountain Slowly, Very Slowly,” Tom Bissell writes about his trek to the mountain’s 19,340-foot peak at a pace, he says, “roughly akin to a finishing-school exercise of walking with a book balanced atop one’s head.” With the help of porters and guides, and some pills to help fight altitude sickness, he pushes past his limit. At 18,870 feet, after walking “without any purpose but ascent,” Bissell fell to his knees and wondered “how I would find the strength to make the last push up to the summit.” And then once there, what would he make of the experience?.

Standing at the top of the Monashee mountain range in Canada, just dropped off by helicopter along with a group of snowboarder friends and a guide, and now peering down at a 3,000-foot decent, Josh Dean had some jitters. Go figure. But with nowhere to go but down, Dean and his friends followed the guide’s path, and it didn’t take them long to realize that it would be no ordinary trip down a slope. In this issue’s Master Class, “Chairlifts Are for Sissies,” Dean details the joys of his first heli-trip as a newbie to snowboarding. He writes, “It took just one run -- no, more like a few hundred yards -- of floating at ludicrous speed on snow the consistency of flour to realize that in all my years of sliding around on snow, I had experienced nothing remotely like this. How was I going to take a chairlift seriously again?”.

It’s no secret that playing sports can cause serious back pain. And no wonder, given that a single, proper golf swing can produce almost 1,700 pounds of pressure on the spine. In this issue’s Phys Ed column, “Twist and Ouch,” Gretchen Reynolds sought answers to the question, “So what, if anything, can you do to preserve and protect your spine?” It helps, most experts agree, to have a solid core, the muscles and tendons and ligaments in the middle of the body that provide rigging for the spine. Endurance is crucial, too, she writes, especially in those core muscles, “since it keeps the stabilizing muscles and connective tissues going through a long workout or game.” Yes, it sounds like a lot of work, but there may be a silver lining: “Having a strong back, you will be happy to hear, means not doing sit-ups. Ever.”.

CALDERON--Joan, 64, of New York City, NY died peacefully on October 22, 2007 after a long and courageous battle with cancer. The employees of Lehman Brothers deeply mourn the loss of our beloved friend and colleague of 19 years. Joan's extended family shared her many interests, including a deep love and compassion for animals and film. Throughout her life, Joan was an active and passionate volunteer on behalf of animal rescue and adoption, particularly with the Pet-I-Care and Brooklyn Animal Rescue Coalition (BARC) organizations; she was also an avid fundraiser for Susan G. Komen Race for the Cure and the March of Dimes. Joan will be remembered for her boundless energy and enthusiasm for life. She will be truly missed by all those who were privileged to have known her, including those families whose lives have been enriched by her pet adoption efforts. A memorial service will be held in New York City on Tuesday, October 30th at 4:00pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel located at 180 West 76th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to New York Pet-I-Care c/o Marilyn Teres, 301 East 22nd St., New York, NY 10010 or the Weill Cornell Medical College, Cancer Research, Development Office, 1300 York Ave., Box 123, New York, NY 10065.

SCHNEIDER--Michael R., 24, died on October 20th. His loving memory lives on in the hearts of his devoted father Richard Schneider of Newburyport, MA and his mother Liz McGowan Schneider of Amesbury, MA, his loving grandmother Bobbie Schneider of Centerport, NY formerly of Quechee, VT and her late husband Victor Schneider, his brother Brent and his aunt Patti Scarola of Centerport. Michael was a graduate of Newburyport HS, class of 2002 and a graduate of Keene State College, class of 2006. He was employed as an editor for Business Wire in Boston. Michael was buried on Thursday at the Oak Hill Cemetery, Newburyport. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to Floating Children's Cancer Center, c/o Dr. L.C. Wolfe, NEMC, Box 014, 750 Washington St., Boston, MA 02211.

DIETZ--Stephen. The NYU Medical Center community is sadden by the death of Stephen Dietz, our longtime friend and President of the Young Men's Philanthropic League. Over several decades, the YMPL has generously supported many areas of the Medical Center. With Stephen's passing we have lost a true friend. Kenneth G. Langone, Chairman, Board of Trustees Robert I. Grossman, M.D., Dean and CEO DIETZ--Stephen I., passed away peacefully on October 20, 2007, at his home in Pittsfield, Vermont at the age of 72. Stephen was born on November 4, 1934 in Brooklyn, NY to Beatrice and Harry Dietz, and grew up in Valley Stream, New York. He served his country as a lieutenant in the Army and then went into his family business. He developed his family business, Dietz International Public Insurance Adjusters, into the leader in the public adjusting industry, representing insureds against insurance companies. He was the president of the National Association of Public Insurance Adjusters in 1968 to 1969. Throughout his career and his life, Stephen devoted his time and his resources contributing to make life better for others less fortunate. From 1979 to 1996, Stephen was the president of Young Men's Philanthropic League, and through the League and on his own, contributed generously to the New York University Medical Center, Hofstra University, and many other charities too numerous to mention. As his second career, Stephen became the consummate collector of antiques and collectibles in Pittsfield, Vermont, and frequented auctions and any place where he could share his encyclopedic knowledge. Stephen was devoted to his wife of 43 years, Marlene, who shared his love of antiques and collectibles. Stephen is also survived by his sister, Suzanne, and his devoted children, Elizabeth, Jonathan, and Matthew, his daughter's - in - law, Melissa and Debbie, and his grandchildren, Maxwell, David and Caroline. His faithful dogs will miss him deeply as well, Marcus, Gunny, Hershey, and Scooby Doo. A private ceremony was held in Vermont, and a memorial celebration will be held in New York City, date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Dietz Stem Cell Research Fund; fund no. 6415622, Bruce K. Young M.D., NYU Medical Center, Ste. 5-G, 530 First Ave., New York, NY 10016.

Ochre began as a design company founded in 1996 by Joanna Bibby and Harriet Maxwell Macdonald, who met in art school in London. (A third designer, Solenne de la Fouchardière, joined them as a partner in 2000.) Just last year the company opened its first retail store, the brainchild of Ms. Macdonald's husband, Andrew Corrie, who had experience as an investment banker working with retail clients. Ochre showcases the three designers' work -- sleek sofas with a bit of slouch, chain mail chandeliers -- as well as the work of artisans, many of them friends from the London art and design world. HANDELMAN--Judith A. Age 70, died suddenly while swimming in her beloved pool at her home in Scarsdale, NY, on Sunday October 21, 2007. Adored wife and traveling companion of Walter J. Handelman for 49 years, devoted mother to David, Dan and Matthew, infatuated grandmother of Helen, Isaac, Nancy, Shea, and Megan. Born on July 7, 1937, in Manhattan, to David Ashe and Lillian Hurwitz, she resided in Brooklyn and graduated from Erasmus Hall High at 16 and Vassar at 19, and got an MPA in Planning from NYU in 1961. She is also survived by her sister, Deborah Warheit of Los Angeles. Judy had a long and varied career as a writer and editor for the Scarsdale Inquirer, The East Scarsdale Association, The Scarsdale Historical Society, Open Arms Homeless Shelter, and the Hudson Link for Higher Education in Prison program at Sing-Sing. Her lifelong enthusiastic community efforts ranged from the founding of the Scarsdale Municipal Pool to serving as a board member of the Student Transfer Education Program (STEP), acting as the director of the Scarsdale Futures program of the Scarsdale Foundation, and serving on the Boards of the Westchester chapter of the American Jewish Committee, Scarsdale Citizens for Senior Housing, and the Westchester County Historical Society. At the time of her death she was trying to garner support for the ''Grow Old at Home'' movement. She was a passionate fan of the Brooklyn Dodgers and New York Mets. Services to be held Thursday, October 25 at 11am at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. Shiva to follow Thursday 3-5pm at the Handelman home, 260 Mamaroneck Road, also on October 26, 11-5pm; October 27, 6-8pm; and October 28, 2-6pm. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to Hudson Link, the National Trust for Historic Preservation (Lyndhurst), or a charity of your choice. HANDELMAN--Judy. The Education Through Music (ETM) family acknowledges with sadness the passing of our friend, Judy Handelman, beloved wife of Walter Handelman, a member of the ETM Board. To Walter and the entire Handelman family, we extend heartfelt condolences. The Staff and Board of Directors of Education Through Music

BLUTT--Herbert, 85, of Windsor, beloved husband of Rose (Deckel) Blutt, died peacefully on Wednesday (October 24, 2007) at his home surrounded by his family. Born on June 20, 1922 in the Bronx, NY, he was the son of the late Harry and Tillie (Cohen) Blutt. Herb was a graduate of Evander Childs High School in the Bronx and went on to study at the City College of New York. He proudly served our country during WWII with the U.S. Air Force in the Philippines and Japan. Herbert was married to the love of his life, his childhood sweetheart, Rose, in 1944. Together they moved to Hartford, CT, in 1956, settling in Windsor, CT, in 1960. Herbert was a member of the Congregation Beth Ahm in Windsor, CT, where he served as the Ritual Committee Chairman since 1997. He attended services weekly for over 47 years and was beloved by the entire congregation. Herbert received the State of Connecticut United Synagogue Distinguished Service Award in 2005. He was a member of the Jewish Community Center of Hartford, CT, where he was an avid swimmer and physical fitness fanatic. Herbert worked as a Diesel Engineer for the Stanadyne Corporation for over 30 years, and taught engineering for various technical schools in the Hartford area. He was also the head of Stanadyne's Worldwide Training Education. Herb had a way with words that was a great help to him in being able to talk with and make friends with anyone. Herb was an avid Yankees Fan, a pass time he loved to share with his wife, Rose. He was a fearless fighter in facing the many illnesses he encountered throughout his life, which helped to put his family at ease. Besides his wife of 63 years, Rose, he leaves two sons, Jay Blutt and his wife Joni of Simsbury, CT, and Mitchell Blutt and his wife Margo of New York, NY; a brother, Seymour Blutt of New York, NY; and five grandchildren, Adam and Andrew Blutt and Gillian, Eliza and Emerson Blutt. A funeral service will be held on Friday, 12:30pm, at the Carmon Windsor Funeral Home, 807 Bloomfield Ave., Windsor, CT. Burial with Military Honor will follow in Congregation Beth Ahm Cemetery, Windsor, CT. In lieu of flowers memorial donations may be made to the Congregation Beth Ahm, 362 Palisado Ave Windsor, CT 06095. Please visit us at www.carmonfuneralhome.com for online condolences.

BLANCATO--Louis S. M.D.; On October 23 in Rye, NY. Beloved husband of late Nancy. Survived by Louis S., Robert, John and Amy and beloved grandchildren Celia and Carly. Also supportive three daughters and son-in-law. Dr. Blancato was a dedicated practitioner and teacher of medicine with a long and distinguished career as an anesthesiologist. Department Chair at St. Luke's Hospital and President of New York State and American Society of Anesthesiologists are among his many accomplishments. He was also a Professor at Columbia University. He received many awards and inspired many. Dr. Blancato was a graduate of Fordham University and the Flower Fifth Avenue Medical School and a proud World War II veteran of the U.S. Army Medical Corps. Dr. Blancato's family, country and Italian American heritage were the foundations of his life. A lifelong New Yorker and a citizen of the world through work, travel and many friendships. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, October 27 at noon in the Osborn Auditorium, 101 Theall Road in Rye. In lieu of flowers the family recommends individuals make a donation to a charity of their choice in the name of Dr. Louis S. Blancato.

GREEN--William S. Prominent lawyer and civic figure in Manchester, New Hampshire, for over half a century, succumbed on October 22, 2007, to complications from Parkinson's Disease. He was 89 years old. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Joan (Jacobson), three children, Dr. William Scott Green, Senior Vice Provost, University of Miami, Nancy E. Green, a clinical social worker in Brookline, Massachusetts, Richard S. Green, a lawyer in New York City, and four grandchildren. Memorial service Friday October 26, 2007 at 1:00pm at Temple Adath Yeshurun, Manchester, NH.

Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about an increase in the number of women having double mastectomies described incorrectly the likelihood that women with a lobular form of breast cancer would choose removal of the unaffected breast. These women are more likely -- not less -- to have the double procedure. A graphic also referred incorrectly to the 11 percent of women in 2003 who had the unaffected breast surgically removed. They were women whose breast cancer was treated by mastectomy rather than lumpectomy; they were not women at all stages of cancer.

New York City Transit announced yesterday that it would add 850 hybrid buses to the fleet it operates with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The agency said it already operated the largest hybrid bus fleet in the world, with 548 hybrid buses in service. The M.T.A., which also operates buses in the city, has 284 hybrids on the road. The new buses, made by DaimlerChrysler Commercial Buses North America, are expected to be put in service over the next two years.

A sports article on Tuesday about the contributions of Dustin Pedroia and Kevin Youkilis in leading the Red Sox to the World Series misstated the score in the seventh inning of Game 5 of the American League Championship Series when they hit back-to-back doubles. The Red Sox led the Cleveland Indians, 2-1; the score was not tied. (The Red Sox went on to win, 7-1.)
LANG--Rosemary. You left so suddenly and we miss your sweet kindness, and soul, so much. With Love, The Goldman, Bertin-Lang, and Lang Families

MEASURING A MELTDOWN Economists say the meltdown in the American mortgage market could, all told, cost financial firms and investors more than the savings and loan crisis of the early 1990's. But the loss in total real estate wealth is expected to be less than that of the stock market collapse earlier this decade. A $2.3 BILLION LOSS AT MERRILL Merrill Lynch said that it would take a $7.9 billion write-down because of its exposure to collateralized debt obligations, complex debt instruments and subprime mortgages. The result was a $2.3 billion loss, the largest in the firm's history. ''We made a mistake,'' said the chief executive, E. Stanley O'Neal. [C1.]

MULROONEY--John Joseph. A longtime attorney of L.A., CA passed away August 27, 2007 at the age of 77. Beloved twin brother of the late Eugene. He is survived by sister, Jeanne, six children, John, Margaret, Shari, Lisa, David and Ryan along with twelve grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren. He is also survived by his dear friend, Celeste. John was a proud Marine Corps Veteran of WWII and the Korean War. After the War he graduated Fordham University and received his Law Degree from Southwestern University. He was a public defender in Los Angeles and ran a private law practice for 40 years. Memorial services with military honors will be held Saturday, October 27th, 2007 at 11:00am at Fishkill Rural Cemetery, 801 Route 9, Fishkill, NY.

PHIPPS--Cynthia. It is with deepest sorrow that the Board of Trustees and staff of The Animal Medical Center mark the passing of our devoted Chairman, Miss Cynthia Phipps. Miss Phipps' passionate belief in the important role of animals in our lives led to her tireless work for 38 years as an active member of our Board, serving for the last eight as Chairman. During her years as a Trustee, she drew countless friends and supporters to our mission, and most recently, spearheaded a capital campaign that doubled The AMC endowment. She was an ardent champion of education for young veterinarians and encouraged the pursuit of advances in medical treatment that keep pets and their families together. Her generosity of spirit, her integrity and her unwavering commitment to improving the care of animals served as an inspiration to us all. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family and all those who were touched by her joy of living and the warmth of her friendship. Her cheerful and energetic presence, with her beloved Poodle, Truffle, at her side, will be missed by all who knew and worked with her at The Animal Medical Center.
INTERNATIONALA3-14 U.S. to Take New Steps Against Iranians

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a charity auction of a letter from 41 Democratic senators complaining about a remark by Rush Limbaugh misidentified the recipient of the letter. It was sent to Mark P. Mays, the CEO of Clear Channel Communications, the parent company of Premiere Radio Networks, which syndicates Mr. Limbaugh's radio program; the letter was not sent to Mr. Limbaugh. The article also misstated the date of the letter. It was Oct. 2, not Oct. 7.

MARSH--Harold. We are filled with wonderful memories of the Marshes' and Salamons' good times together. The Marsala mobile will roll on, but it won't be the same without Hal. Linda, Itamar & the Marsalas MARSH--Harold ''Hal''. Hal died peacefully at Yale/New Haven Hospital on October 23, 2007. Hal was born in 1932 in New York City. A business owner, he was passionate about music, art, travel, dining, friends and above all else, his family. Hal is survived by his beloved wife Dana, his loving daughters Elissa Marsh, Laurie Marsh Levitz and Jaye Benoit; his cherished sisters Barbara Zimmerman and Marilyn Rubinstein; his adored grandchildren Noah, Caleb, Charlie, Isabella, and Sam; and his sons-in-law Dan Levitz and Terry Benoit. We will miss you Hal. Services at BallardDurand, White Plains, October 26 at 10am.

Rayman Boozer opened Apartment 48 in 1994 as a store set up as an actual apartment, with living room merchandise in the living room, kitchen merchandise in the kitchen and so on. While the shop quickly gained a loyal customer base, Mr. Boozer admits it takes a lot of work. ''There's so much mass-market stuff out there that's really well designed,'' he said. ''West Elm's aesthetic is very close to mine, so I have to make sure that I don't overlap or carry similar merchandise. Otherwise my customer will say, we just saw that for $12, and here it's $24.'' MELAMINE NESTING BOWLS FROM PRESENT TIME, $58 FOR A SET OF SIX (OUT OF STOCK)

Nicholas Kekic, a designer and glass blower, sells directly from his studio in southeastern Vermont. His Web site shows the shapes, sizes and colors of most of his glassware, including tumblers ($40), vases ($96 to $480), pitchers ($218), left, decanters ($108 to $216) and decorative items. Orders for pieces in eight transparent colors (or in a frosted matte finish) are taken by phone, and can be shipped all over the country; custom colors are available. At the studio, pieces with slight flaws will be available at 20 to 50 percent off retail prices, on the weekend of Dec. 1 and 2. (Phone orders will also be taken for the sale.) Tsuga Studios, 678 Goldthwaite Road, Chester, Vt., (802) 875-1825 or tsugastudios.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH Good deals and secret sources may be reported to rohrlich@nytimes.com.

BERKOWITZ--Bernard. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Bernard Berkowitz, beloved father of David Berkowitz and father-in-law of Nancy Berkowitz, who together have set a profound example of philanthropic leadership as active members of UJA-Federation's Solelim Fund and in so many other ways. The Berkowitz family has left a legacy of hope for countless individuals touched by their generosity, through their continued involvement in the New York Jewish community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to David and Nancy; to Bernard's grandchildren; and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

A supermarket worker who said he hoped to become Russia's most prolific serial killer was convicted by a Moscow jury of murdering 48 people between 2001 and 2006, most of them in Bitsevsky Park, a wooded area in southwestern Moscow. Nicknamed the Chessboard Killer after his arrest last year, when he claimed to have marked off a chessboard square for every victim, with a goal of filling all 64, Aleksandr Y. Pichushkin, 33, left, sat emotionless, frowning occasionally, while the verdict was read in the packed courtroom. He faces a life sentence, and may be sentenced as early as tomorrow, a court spokeswoman said. Prosecutors said that Mr. Pichushkin wanted to kill more people than Andrei Chikatilo, the so-called Rostov Ripper, who was convicted of 52 murders in 1992.
BERNSTEIN--Sol. Remembering you, Daddy, these 8 years: unassuming, underappreciated, forever loved. B.

SONNABEND--Ileana. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art note with great sorrow the death of Honorary Trustee, Ileana Sonnabend. It is impossible to tell the story of the art of the twentieth century without the artists and works that passed through Ileana's galleries. A good friend to the Museum, Ileana was a beacon of knowledge and taste whose commitment to contemporary art set a very high standard. We extend our sympathies to her entire family, and especially to Nina Sundell and Antonio Homem. Jerry I. Speyer, Chairman Marie-Josee Kravis, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director

An obituary on Friday about the actress Deborah Kerr rendered incorrectly the final line of Robert Anderson's play ''Tea and Sympathy,'' which she spoke in both the Broadway and film versions as her character was about to sexually initiate an anguished student. It is ''Years from now, when you talk about this -- and you will -- be kind.'' It is not ''When you speak of this in future years, and you will, be kind.''

GARELIK--Catherine C. On behalf of our entire organization, the Principals of Newmark Knight Frank wish to express our sincerest condolences to our dear friends and partners, Sandy and Neal, upon the passing of Catherine Garelik -Sandy's beloved wife and Neal's cherished mother. We are in awe of the rich, wonderful and accomplished life Catherine lived and the number of lives she touched in her 87 years. Truly, her memory will be a blessing.

Velocity Art and Design started in 1999 as a Web-only venture in the basement of John and Lara Tusher's house in Seattle while he was an elementary school teacher and she was a nurse. They offered high-design brands like Vitra and Pure Design, and were among the first to sell Jonathan Adler online. They developed enough of a following to open their first bricks-and-mortar store a year later, and this month they moved to a 3,000-square-foot space in the rapidly gentrifying South Lake Union neighborhood. IBRIDE TRAYS, $59

SMITH--David. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the father of our distinguished member, Allen Smith. May his entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Steve Graber, President

A brief report in the Circuits pages in Business Day last Thursday about a 500-gigabyte media server from LaCie misstated its price in comparison with stand-alone hard drives of the same size. At $199, it is not much more expensive than 500GB external hard drives, which some online retailers sell for $175 or less. It is not ''less than the cost of'' such drives.

Helen Ige sells her own lines of decorative pillows and mobiles, along with vintage and new furnishings, at her store near Hancock Park. Of all the shopkeepers interviewed for this article, she may have the best insight into her customers' tastes. As the store's sole employee, she deals with all of them. ''Things that look handmade, organic or like they could be heirlooms from your stylish grandmother sell well here,'' she said. JOHN DERIAN SKELETON PLATE SET, $880

10 P.M. (Sundance) ICONOCLASTS This weekly mutual admiration society begins its third season with the actor and director Sean Penn, above left, and the writer Jon Krakauer, whose efforts recently converged in the film ''Into the Wild,'' Mr. Penn's adaptation of Mr. Krakauer's book. The two men retrace the steps of Chris McCandless, subject of the book and film, along the Stampede Trail in Alaska to the bus where he was found dead, and discuss not only his spirit of adventure but also the creative process it inspires. 8:30 P.M. But when Rosemary turns out to be too radical, Jack (Alec Baldwin) pressures Liz to fire her. So Liz quits instead.

LABOUISSE--Eve Curie, passed away peacefully at her home in Manhattan on October 22, 2007, in her 103rd year. Formerly a resident of Wainscott, Long Island. Beloved wife of the late Ambassador Henry R. Labouisse and devoted daughter of the late Pierre and Marie Curie. Survived by Helene Langevin, Anne and Pierre Joliot, nieces and nephew of Paris and a stepdaughter, Anne Labouisse Peretz of Cambridge, Massachusetts. A private graveside service will be held at the Metairie Cemetery in New Orleans on Monday. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Center for Family Life, 345 43rd Street, Brooklyn, NY 11232.

A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Tuesday about the Brooklyn Academy of Music's spring season misspelled the surname of the director of ''Macbeth,'' one of the offerings. He is Rupert Goold, not Gold.

Eleven years ago, not much was happening retail-wise on Sullivan Street between Prince and Spring. Yet that's where Nathalie Smith, a fashion editor and stylist, opened Global Table. From the start, she focused on tabletop accessories, displaying them on long, low tables that invite shoppers to mix and match. Global Table has become a source both for couples who want a non-Wedgwood registry and neighborhood loft-dwellers looking for (relatively) inexpensive ways to dress a table. LACQUER TRAYS BY THE WORLD TREASURE COMPANY, $50

HILF--Dorothy, peacefully, on October 23, 2007 at age 89. Loving mother of Carolyn David of Euless, Texas, Lois David Thompson (William) of Woodbury, and Michael Gary Hilf of Forest Hills. Doting grandmother of Scott Henry Thompson of Wantagh, and Gregory David Thompson (Danielle) of East Northport. Adored aunt, great-aunt, and cousin. Services at noon, Friday at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, opposite Great Neck LIRR station. No flowers please. Donations may be made to favorite charity.

Heather Wiese-Alexander knew she was taking a chance when she opened Nest, a funky-modern home furnishings store, in Dallas, a town that favors established labels. ''People here do not have the trend-set mentality they might have in New York or Miami,'' said Ms. Wiese-Alexander, a former art director for Neiman Marcus. ''They latch onto trends after they've already been shown in all the magazines.'' But she chose a neighborhood populated by what she calls the ''height of Dallas society,'' and filled her shop with clean-lined furniture and accessories that fit in both modern and traditional interiors.

KLEINMAN--Gertrude R., 85, on October 23. Widow of Sigmund Kleinman; mother of Laurence and the late Frederick Kleinman; grandmother of Laura Kleinman; motherin-law of Linda Kleinman. Private memorial service.

Okooko, a 3-month-old eco-friendly mattress and bedroom-furniture company based in New Zealand, recently opened its first retail store in the United States, in Philadelphia. (There are two other stores, in New Zealand and Hong Kong; a fourth is expected to open in New York this spring.) The company -- which takes its name from the Maori word for ''to cradle in arms''-- sells mattresses ($2,500 to $3,000) made of natural latex, bamboo and wool, and beds ($2,200 to $5,500) made of wood from sustainable forests managed by the New Zealand government. It also sells high-design beds like Float ($25,000, including the mattress), below, by David Trubridge, a New Zealand designer. And for every bedroom suite sold, Okooko promises to plant a native tree in New Zealand. Okooko, 205 Arch Street, Philadelphia, (215) 667-8240 or okooko.com. ANNIE BLOCK

EICHLER--Lawrence B., 82, of New Rochelle, New York, died peacefully, surrounded by his family, on October 23, 2007. Son of the late Archie and Anna Eichler, survived by his devoted wife of 58 years, Thea, his beloved children Teresa, Glenn, Ken, Jocelyn and David and their spouses, as well as his nine loving grandchildren. Born in 1925, Larry served in the United States Air Force before graduating from New York University and New York Law School. He worked as a Certified Public Accountant for many years before founding his own investment management firm. He served several terms on the Westchester County Board of Ethics and served as financial editor for ''50 Plus'' magazine. Larry was an avid chess player and past president of the Westchester Chess Club, as well as a lover of the outdoors, but he will be most remembered for his absolute integrity, his unflagging optimism, his wonderful sense of humor, and the generosity of his spirit. He always believed the best of people, and they usually responded in kind. His children remember his strength of character and most of all his unconditional love. Services will be held Thursday, October 25 at 1:00pm. at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mount Vernon, NY 10552.

For 21 years, Elements has been the go-to spot for design-obsessed shoppers in Chicago. Its owners, Jeannine Dal Pra and Toby Glickman, pack the store with a mix of jewelry and decorative accessories. This week, they moved to a new location in the River North neighborhood and more than doubled their space, to 3,500 square feet. TED MUEHLING BRONZE CANDLESTICKS, $435 TO $1,010

Edward Fields, who was known as the bespoke carpet designer to stars like Princess Grace of Monaco and Mary Tyler Moore from the 1950s to the 1970s, considered his rugs art for the floor. Although the late designer's company was purchased by Tai Ping carpets two years ago, it remains true to his vision. To coincide with the opening of a new showroom in Manhattan, the company is reissuing 60 original rugs; the Deep ($8,960), above, an 8-by-10-foot, hand-dyed wool carpet with varying pile heights, was designed in the 1980s. Prices for the made-to-order, hand-knotted rugs start at about $85 per square foot; to the trade from Edward Fields, 150 East 58th Street (Lexington Avenue), (212) 310-0400. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

An article in Business Day on Saturday about proposals to establish international guidelines for government-owned investment funds misstated the amount of money that ''sovereign wealth funds'' control now and are expected to control in the future. Analysts say the funds now control up to $2.5 trillion, not billion, and that could grow to $17.5 trillion, not billion, in the next 10 years.

When they opened NiBa Home three years ago, Nisi Berryman and Beth Arrowood (alumnae of Holly Hunt's Miami showroom) envisioned it as the go-to store for interior designers looking for accessories for almost-finished projects. The 3,500-square-foot store strikes a nonminimalist note in the middle of Miami's slick design district, with throw pillows, lamps, screens, rugs and ceramic and glass pieces, all grouped in complementary colors. UNION STREET GLASS URCHIN BOWL, $875

DONNER--Richard I. The partners, counsel, associates and staff of Graubard Miller greatly mourn the passing of our esteemed retired partner, Richard I. Donner. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Suzie, his children, Bill and Nancy, and Suzie's children, Steve and Mark, who were all so dear to him. Dick was one of the good guys, a great friend and a proud contributing member of the ''greatest generation.'' We will miss him dearly. Graubard Miller DONNER--Richard I. Dick Donner, beloved husband of Suzie Donner and the late Rose Donner, died October 23rd at the age of 84. Loving father of William Donner and his wife, Sheryl; and Nancy Donner Martin and her husband, Gary; stepfather of Steve Levin, and his wife, Terri, and Mark Levin; and grandfather to Andrew, Charles, and James Donner and Josh, Adrienne, and Rebecca Levin; he is also survived by his brother, Stanley Donner. A veteran of WWII, he retired as a senior partner at the law firm Graubard & Moskovitz. He will be remembered for his love of New York City and his passion for the theater, jazz and the arts. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to either the Southern Poverty Law Center or the Anti-Defamation League. Services will be at Frank Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison and 81st Street, on Friday, October 26 at 1:30pm.

Overall, it's been a fine year for high-end shelter magazines, particularly Elle Décor, whose pages are up nearly 14 percent, according to Steve Cohn, editor in chief of Media Industry Newsletter. Design magazines in the 21st century are enjoying robust health, he said, ''because of the whole nesting thing.'' But pity the poor editors at Elle Décor, Architectural Digest and Vogue. Their new hefty coffee-table books show there's been a slugfest going on for years, a fight to secure the habitats of the Page Six crowd for publication. There are slight allegiances: British bohemian royalty cleaves to Vogue, Hollywood to Architectural Digest and Manhattan's elite to Elle Décor. These tribal distinctions explain the inclusion in the Vogue book of Ashcombe, Mrs. Guy Ritchie's manor house in Wiltshire, England -- which once belonged to Cecil Beaton. (Search out this book first, if only to see a photo of Madonna's sheep, dyed pastel colors, and to read her account of English married life, filled with words like ''cheeky,'' ''brilliant'' and ''laddish.'') The most vivid differences are in presentation: Vogue's portfolio is lush and hip, above right; Architectural Digest's is dour and distant; and Elle Décor finds a cheery middle ground. ''Vogue Living: Houses, Gardens, People'' (Knopf) is $75; Architectural Digest's ''Private Views: Inside the World's Greatest Homes'' (Abrams) is $50; and Elle Décor's ''So Chic: Glamorous Lives, Stylish Spaces'' (Filipacchi Publishing) is $40. PENELOPE GREEN

If for 15 years you have been a relatively successful broker and you have lived through the highs and lows, what are you going to do? Most of them are holding on for dear life and hoping things get better. D. RITCH WORKMAN, president of the Florida Mortgage Brokers Association, on reaction to the housing slump. [A23]

ROHR--Charlotte. The National Yiddish Book Center mourns the passing of Charlotte Rohr (Z''l). May her memory be for a blessing. ROHR--Charlotte. Krule, President Carolyn Starman Hessel, Director Geri Gindea, Director Sami Rohr Prize for Jewish Literature

Kristine Irving has been in retailing since college, when she and a fellow student at Massachusetts College of Art and Design opened a gallery called ArtSmart in Boston. Her current retail endeavor, almost 20 years later, is a shop called Koo de Kir (a phonetic spelling of the French coup de coeur, or ''strike to the heart'') in Beacon Hill. Ms. Irving said the shop sells ''elegant things you can use -- this is not a tchotchke house.'' She mixes reupholstered vintage furniture with contemporary faux bois pieces and plenty of tabletop items, and also offers interior design services. KLEINREID PORCELAIN LOGS, $325

Kelly Wearstler's new 325-square-foot space on Bergdorf Goodman's seventh floor holds just 75 items -- ''pretty things that are pretty unusual,'' Ms. Wearstler, the Los Angeles-based designer, said -- each made in very limited (5- or 10-piece) quantities exclusively for Bergdorf Goodman. And when they're gone, they're gone, she said. It's a very fashion-seasonal attitude from a very fashionable designer, best known for decorating the Viceroy hotel in Santa Monica and the Tides in South Beach.

SHORTER days mean longer nights, and for cyclists this means using a headlight. While many urban pedalers need only enough light to be seen, those traveling in areas without streetlights need more serious illumination. And many states require both a front and rear light for night riding. In the past, headlights used incandescent bulbs, which were often clunky and had short life spans. But the light-emitting diode or L.E.D. changed all that, and the technology is improving so fast that manufacturers worry that their designs will become dated before they even get to market.

A picture caption on Monday with the continuation of a column about the CMJ Music Marathon gave an outdated name for the site where Ben Bridwell and Band of Horses played. While formerly a movie theater known as the Gramercy Theater, it is now used for concerts and known as Blender Theater at Gramercy.

KREVAT--Lawrence. Always a warm smile, always a kind word and always a good joke (well, maybe not always). Cuz, I love you and I'm going to miss you. Steve KREVAT--Lawrence ''Larry'', 83, of Rancho Santa Fe, CA (formerly of Old Westbury, NY) died October 22. Funeral services on Thursday, October 25 at 10am at Guttermans, 8000 Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, NY. We all love you and will miss you very much.

A sports article yesterday about the struggling Miami Dolphins misstated the number of players on the team's 53-man roster at the start of this season who were drafted between 1998 and 2003. It was two, not one. (Receiver Chris Chambers was on the team until a trade earlier this month. A chart correctly noted that the only remaining player from those drafts is the injured safety Yeremiah Bell.)

Updated, 6:51 p.m. | Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the city health commissioner, Dr. Thomas R. Frieden, went on the airwaves this morning to remind adults and children to wash their hands after a drug-resistant infection killed a Brooklyn middle school student. Omar Rivera, a seventh grader at Intermediate School 211 in Canarsie, died on Oct. 14. Health officials said the infection, typically known as a staph infection, was caused from a bacteria called methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, or M.R.S.A. for short. An investigation is under way to determine how and where he contracted the infection.

Updated, 2:09 p.m. | In 34 years, Franklin D. Roosevelt of New York managed to get somewhere: elected a state senator twice, appointed assistant secretary of the navy, nominated as the Democratic vice presidential candidate, elected governor twice and elected president four times. In between, he battled polio, the Depression and the Axis.

When Graci Moore, a designer for Ralph Lauren who was living in France, moved back to New York for work in March, one of her most pronounced culture shocks, she said, came from the long waits to enroll her 2½-year-old son, Zachary Viger, in youth programs. Day care was one of the worst.

When most New Yorkers think of Ellis Island, they probably recall the Great Hall where 12 million immigrants were processed, which opened to the public in 1990 after three decades of neglect and disrepair.

Monday, Oct. 22

A Brooklyn middle school student who died on Oct. 14 had become infected with a virulent, drug-resistant strain of bacteria — methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, or MRSA — that is primarily spread in hospitals but that in recent years has surfaced increasingly in schools, gyms and other nonhospital settings. Friends and neighbors identified the boy as Omar Rivera, a seventh grader at Intermediate School 211 in Canarsie. Health officials said it was unclear whether such cases were increasing or whether news reports had increased awareness of the infection.
Cold Spring, N.Y., is a great place for New Yorkers to easily escape the big city.
Pilots with their own planes are replacing lazy Sunday drives with something a little more exciting.

Two tournaments, two dominating performances. Hikaru Nakamura swept to victory in the Casino de Barcelona, an invitational tournament that ran from Oct. 18 to 26. Nakamura scored 7 points (six wins, one loss and two draws) to finish a full point ahead of the field. The tournament's official Web site, which is in Spanish, lists the players, the results and has all the games.
Hopeful singers contend for a coveted spot in the Mormon Tabernacle Choir.

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton just signed a pledge that commits the next president to investing $50 billion by 2013 to combat AIDS around the world. She is also planning to deliver a formal policy on AIDS.

Max Mosley spoke to a small group of the French press today after the FIA's general assembly, and he told them that the appeal concerning the fuel irregularities on the BMW Sauber and Williams cars would take place in Paris on Nov. 15, the FIA has confirmed.

Let me set a scene for you. The time is the middle of the afternoon and the place is Falluja, Iraq, in April of 2004. I am laying face down in a shallow irrigation ditch on the side of a dirt road. There is a lot of noise. The kind that can only be known in war. It is multiple medium-weight machine guns raining the terror of lead. I am looking around and seeing my friends in the same predicament. I also see dirt popping up inches from my face and body. This does not come from just anywhere. The dirt is flying into the air because there are 7.62-millimeter bullets landing everywhere. Was I scared? You bet your sweet life I was. This is when I realized that I was going to die. Not when I was old or even back home in St. Petersburg. I was going to die on a dirt road in a place that if it is not hell they share the same zip code. There was nothing I could do but wait. I lit a cigarette and threw my pack of Newports behind me so my buddy Murph-dog could enjoy his last smoke, too.

Before I tackle Sam's question about what time or place "War and Peace" evokes for me, I want to revisit the fruitful topic Bill Keller raised, about Isaiah Berlin, foxes and hedgehogs, and the stumping question of whether Tolstoy had more in common with the devious brush-tailed creature, or the straight-ahead spined one. I think Tolstoy wrote like a hedgehog, but acted like a fox. My father, a Russian literature professor, has been corresponding with me during this panel (as have many of my friends, notably one who recently translated Zamyatin's "We," a book that should be more often read - at least as often as "1984," which seems to have won the totalitarian futuristic fable competition). My father reminded me that Tolstoy did not bring his Olympian understanding of human nature to his own family life - at least, according to his wife Sofia Andreevna. In her letters (now on display at American University, along with photos of Yasnaya Polyana, the Tolstoy estate), she complains about his need to be treated like a god, and not to be bothered by daily concerns. He died, essentially, running away from home. But why can't a man's reach exceed his grasp? That 's not my question of course; it's Browning's.

I agree that it might be a good idea to read the book every five years, to note the astonishing way it seems to change as the world around us changes. I mentioned in an earlier post that I read the novel right after 9/11, and I remember thinking that the scene in which Pierre sees the French cook being flogged as a spy reminded me of the ways in which innocent Muslims were being targeted. Once more, the book seems relevant to the current moment. I only wish that the battles Tolstoy describes sounded less like the war in Iraq. Obviously, the weaponry and technology are very different. Satellite communications have replaced those poor messengers galloping in with the bad news; missiles and tanks have taken the place of muskets and stallions. And the military strategists no longer (literally) stand on the hilltops watching all hell break loose on the plains below. But nearly everything else - the inequities, the dispositions of power, the costly mistakes and the inadequate responses to those mistakes, the bloodshed and chaos and misery - all that seems painfully familiar. Old Kotuzov dies in his bed, and Napoleon and the Tsar aren't the ones being blown to bits at Borodino; young men were, and are still, taking the hit - so to speak - for the leaders who send them off to battle. I've always thought that Tolstoy's mini-essay, in Volume IV, on the difficulty of waging war against small, mobile, highly motivated bands of guerilla fighters should have been, and should be, required reading for everyone in the military, from rank and file soldiers to Pentagon planners, all the way up to the Secretary of Defense. Quite honestly, this has been, for me, the least pleasant aspect of rereading the novel: the sobering realization of how modern those sections seem, and of how little we appear to have learned in almost two centuries.

Tens of thousands of riders on Lexington Avenue trains were delayed during last night’s rush period when a robbery suspect being chased by the police ran onto the tracks at the 116th Street station just after 4 p.m., transit officials said. Power to all 4, 5 and 6 trains between there and the 96th Street station was cut off for about an hour and a half. The shutdown also disrupted service north and south of the affected stations, delaying riders from the Bronx to Brooklyn. Six passengers left one of several trains stalled between stations, though transit officials warn against such unauthorized evacuations. Another passenger suffered an asthma attack, transit officials said. The police said that the robbery suspect eluded them.

He spoke amid rising concern that the year-old coalition, ranging from communists to centrist Catholics, might soon crumble over disagreement on his proposed budget and fighting among ministers. His predecessor, Silvio Berlusconi, now the opposition leader, is calling for new elections.

President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo issued a pardon for Joseph Estrada, her predecessor and rival who just a month ago was handed a 40-year-prison term for amassing millions of dollars from bribes and kickbacks during his presidency. Mrs. Arroyo’s spokesman explained that Mr. Estrada, 70, had pledged that he would not seek public office and that the government had a policy of releasing prisoners who have reached the age of 70. Government critics said the pardon was an attempt by Mrs. Arroyo to quell accusations of corruption against her administration from Mr. Estrada’s supporters.
