DIETZ--Stephen I. Past President of Young Men's Philanthropic League was laid to rest on October 22nd, 2007. Our sincere condolences to Marlene, Elizabeth, Jonathan, and Matthew. He was a great philanthropist and humanitarian. DIETZ--Stephen I., passed away peacefully on October 20, 2007, at his home in Pittsfield, Vermont at the age of 72. Stephen was born on November 4, 1934 in Brooklyn, NY to Beatrice and Harry Dietz, and grew up in Valley Stream, New York. He served his country as a lieutenant in the Army and then went into his family business. He developed his family business, Dietz International Public Insurance Adjusters, into the leader in the public adjusting industry, representing insureds against insurance companies. He was the president of the National Association of Public Insurance Adjusters in 1968 to 1969. Throughout his career and his life, Stephen devoted his time and his resources contributing to make life better for others less fortunate. From 1979 to 1996, Stephen was the president of Young Men's Philanthropic League, and through the League and on his own, contributed generously to the New York University Medical Center, Hofstra University, and many other charities too numerous to mention. As his second career, Stephen became the consummate collector of antiques and collectibles in Pittsfield, Vermont, and frequented auctions and any place where he could share his encyclopedic knowledge. Stephen was devoted to his wife of 43 years, Marlene, who shared his love of antiques and collectibles. Stephen is also survived by his sister, Suzanne, and his devoted children, Elizabeth, Jonathan, and Matthew, his daughter's - in - law, Melissa and Debbie, and his grandchildren, Maxwell, David and Caroline. His faithful dogs will miss him deeply as well, Marcus, Gunny, Hershey, and Scooby Doo. A private ceremony was held in Vermont, and a memorial celebration will be held in New York City, date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Dietz Stem Cell Research Fund; fund no. 6415622, Bruce K. Young M.D., NYU Medical Center, Ste. 5-G, 530 First Ave., New York, NY 10016.

DENTON--George Edward, passed away on Monday September 17th in Rancho Bernardo, California. He was the beloved husband of Esther Denton and father of Deanna McHose, Mary Ellen Roderick, David Denton, and William Denton. Mr. Denton was born in Flora, Indiana on October 27th, 1918 and was 88 years old at the time of his death. George and Esther were married on April 18th, 1937 in Nappanee, Indiana and celebrated their 70th anniversary earlier this year. Mr. Denton worked as a machinist at the Rock Island Arsenal during WWII and served in the US Army Air Force. After the war, he worked at Ford Motor Company for 23 years, and achieved the position of Manufacturing Engineering Manager for Ford of Europe before joining Rockwell International as President of Golde GmbH in Frankfurt West Germany. He subsequently worked for Rio Grande Industries as President of Arrow Development in Mountain View California. George Denton is survived by his wife Esther, four children, nine grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren. Saturday October 27th, 2007 would have been George's 89th Birthday. Rest in Peace Pop, we will never forget you.

FORBES--John Barrington December 5, 1936-October 12, 2007. John Barrington Forbes, 70, of Manhattan, NY. died peacefully October 12, 2007. Memorial Services will be held 3pm Monday December 3 at Heavenly Rest Episcopal Church, 2 East 90th St. Manhattan, NY. John Krtil Funeral Home handled arrangements. Survivors include daughter Julia F. Burnett of Sarasota, Florida and son Graham L. Forbes of Winter Park, Florida; son-in-law Matthew S. Burnett and daughterin-law Margarita Forbes; grandsons Alexander F. Burnett age 8 and James G. Forbes age 2; brother Henry H. Forbes; sister-in-law Elizabeth R. Forbes and nephews, Douglas H., Kenneth W., and Michael K. Forbes. Mr. Forbes was a graduate of Collegiate High School in 1954 and Princeton University in 1958 majoring in English. He served in the US Army. He spent his entire career of 43 years as a photo editor for the NY Times newspaper. He was well known for his participation and generosity in many organizations such as The Audubon Society, Mystic Seaport, Cape May Observatory, Wild Life Conservation Society, Central Park Conservancy and The American Museum of Natural History. He was also a member of the Manhattan Squash Club and Masthead Cove Yacht Club of Huntington, NY. He was a longtime member and board member as well as choral singer in the St. Cecilia Choir. He was an avid sailor, skippering, racing and cruising both large class and dinghy class sailboats. He spent many happy hours on his 28ft. Pearson sailboat ''Blue Jacket''. His enthusiasm for wild life conservation and bird observation led him on many pleasurable excursions throughout the country. He will be greatly missed by those who loved and knew him, especially for his humble and gracious ways, his laughter and lighthearted sense of humor and his unending puns and quick wit. Lest not forget his love for the Yankee baseball team, a Yankee fan forever. In lieu of flowers, those planning an expression of sympathy might consider Memorial SloanKettering or any of the above organizations.

WHETHER you're a farmer or, more likely, just someone who eats food, you should be disappointed with the farm bill, the five-year, multibillion-dollar piece of legislation being debated in the Senate. Luckily for New Yorkers, our best hope of salvaging it may lie with our state senator, Charles Schumer. The farm bill should be the government's best effort to guide how American farmers grow food and how we all eat. Instead this anachronistic piece of legislation rewards a minority of Midwestern farmers and the commodity giants that buy from them. According to United States Department of Agriculture data, just 10 percent of all farmers, almost entirely in the center of the country, collect 62 percent of the taxpayer dollars. The majority of farmers, including those here in New York, don't receive any subsidies because they grow fruits and vegetables, not the corn, wheat, soy, rice and cotton supported by the bill.

HEROLD--Richard, passed away on October 23, 2007, at age 98. He was the founder and former President of Sulzer Brothers USA, a subsidiary of the Swiss multinational engineering and manufacturing firm Sulzer Brothers Ltd. Richard was born in 1909 in St. Moritz, in the Swiss Alps. He grew up in Paris, where his father directed the French business of the JP Morgan Bank. He went to school in Paris and in Switzerland, and earned a Masters degree in Mechanical Engineering from the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich. Richard began his career in the automobile industry in Michigan and Indiana, participating in the design of several new car engines. Hired by Sulzer Brothers, he established corporate headquarters in downtown New York, close to the shipping and textile industries, and to financial centers. The company prospered, having the right new products at the right moment. He remained President for 35 years. Richard was proud of many of the projects of Sulzer Brothers USA. Shortly after WWII began, Sulzer began large-scale production of marine diesel engines for anti-submarine destroyers escorting shipping convoys. Sulzer USA engineered the pumping plant in the Tehachapi Mountains of central California, bringing water from the Feather River to Los Angeles and San Bernadino. Sulzer developed the revolutionary projectile weaving machine, four times faster than any looms then in existence. In 1943 Richard married Johanne Randlov, from Denmark. Initially living in New York, they moved to Far Hills, New Jersey, where they lived for 40 years. After Richard's retirement, they moved to Lyme, New Hampshire, to an old farmhouse on 120 acres they discovered by chance. In 2000 they moved to an apartment at the Kendal Community in Hanover. Surviving Richard are his wife Johanne, brothers Werner Herold and Andre Herold of Zurich, Switzerland; sister Jacqueline Theves of Paris, France; son Christopher Herold of Pottersville, New Jersey; daughter Sylvie Herold of Cranbrook, Kent, England; daughter Karen Herold of Cumberland, Maine; son Robert Herold of Lexington, Massachusetts, and twelve grandchildren. A memorial celebration will occur on November 3 at 2pm in the Gathering Room at the Kendal Community, 80 Lyme Road, Hanover, NH. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Kendal C. E. Fund, 80 Lyme Road, Hanover, NH 03755.

The über-agent would rule the room based solely on his relationship with A-Rod, but he actually brings so much more to the table, like free agents Andruw Jones, Kyle Lohse, Eric Gagne, Greg Maddux, Julian Tavarez and Jeff Weaver, to name just a few of his guys who could leave Nashville with truckloads of dough. How can one man so dominate the game? He's the smartest guy in the room: This is his life, and his legacy; he has changed the game of baseball, bending it to his will rather than the other way around. He has the best front office: Some wags joke that the Boras Corporation's front office and support staff should be considered the 31st franchise. It's not really a joke. He's voracious: Boras is ruthless about going after players he wants. This might make him some enemies among other agents, but it certainly doesn't make him many enemies among players. He has A-Rod: The man on whom he built his empire has never been in a more powerful position. The mammoth $252 million deal Boras negotiated with the Rangers seven years ago is still the largest contract in sports. And Boras is likely to opt out of it. He's aiming for more: His old rival Jeff Moorad has now become the president of the Arizona Diamondbacks. Many believe that Boras might consider making a similar move, though you could argue that he already controls half of the teams, anyway.
Can More Planes Means Less Noise?

Yes, it's one more off-season when we have to endure talk about Barry Bonds. Now that he has been exiled from San Francisco's AT&T Park -- which means the Giants' best hitter next year may be Barry Zito -- Bonds could rival A-Rod in the volume of chatter generated. It's impossible to tell which teams might have an interest in Bonds; presumably he's more attractive to American League clubs as a designated hitter, even though his defense isn't as bad as people think. Oakland is a possibility, as is San Diego, but it may just come down to how little money he's willing to sign for. If he drops his price a bit, the number of potential suitors will multiply, ranging from Toronto to the Cubs to even St. Louis. But before you ask: no, he won't land in the Bronx or Flushing.

The winter meetings aren't just for g.m.'s. Inevitably, baseball-starved fans flock from all across this great land to watch a bunch of middle-age men in ties carry briefcases. The gawking opportunities are few and far between, but here are a few with potential. Join the gaggle around Peter Gammons: Theoretically, the Hall of Fame reporter is there to find out what the team executives are doing. It's just as likely the executives are talking to him for the same reason. snicker at the job seekers: Wide-eyed graduates in suits and skirts hope to trade an Ivy League degree for the chance to work 80 hours a week for the minimum wage. Their shameless electioneering is priceless, and you can get them to buy you drinks if they think you can help, even if you can't. Touch greatness: Or at least gather some autographs. The best way to grab the attention of a baseball player (or especially an exec) is to be an attractive woman. Or have one with you.

ZATZKIS--Mark, M.D. Died peacefully at Saint John's Hospital on October 24th from brain cancer, he was 53. Mark graduated Harvard College in 1975 with an A.B. in chemistry. He attended Columbia Medical School in New York City. He completed his internship and residency at U.C.L.A., followed by a cardiology fellowship at U.C.S.F. He went on to complete a year learning how to perform angioplasties at The San Francisco Heart Institute at Seton Medical Center. He had been a practicing cardiologist in Santa Monica, CA, for the past 20 years. Mark was loved by all who knew him. He was a unique man. He was warm, compassionate, and sweet. He was intelligent yet modest; sensitive and downto-earth. He loved people, and he had a way of making everyone around him comfortable. He loved conversing with his many friends and patients, and he was admired by many. Mark had a great sense of humor and a wonderful zest for life! He loved his work and his patients! Mark loved reading, running, following the stock market, and anything having to do with numbers. He enjoyed traveling with his wife and kids. He loved practicing cardiology. Most of all, he loved the New York Yankees! Mark is survived by his wife, Melissa, who adored and treasured him. He leaves behind his three children: Elliot, Hayley, and Greg, whom he loved so very, very much! He is also survived by his loving mother, Natalie. Mark also had a wonderful father, Henry, and a very special brother, David, both who predeceased him. He also leaves behind his loving caretaker, Dawn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Neuro-Oncology Department at U.C.L.A., Attention: Timothy Cloughesy, M.D. Funeral Services will be held at Hillside Mortuary in Culver City, this Sunday, October 28th, at 11:00am.

My first exposure to the precarious social status of the professional field-goal kicker came unexpectedly, at a game between the Detroit Lions and the New Orleans Saints on Nov. 8, 1970. There were just two seconds left, and the Saints were losing, which wasn't unusual. The unusual thing was that the game was still close: 17-16. The Saints had the ball, and a field goal would win it -- except the ball was in the Saints' half of the field, on the 43-yard line. And the record distance the ball would have to travel -- 63 yards -- was only the first of the kicker's problems. He was kicking from a dirt surface churned up like a World War I battlefield. The ball would need to cut through the thick, humid New Orleans air and into the closed end of Tulane Stadium, where the wind swirled unpredictably. On top of all that, the kicker lacked the most basic requirement for his job: a foot. His name was Tom Dempsey, and he was born without fingers on his right hand or toes on his right foot. The gnarled stub of his arm jutted from his jersey with an effect, to my 9-year-old mind, so grotesque that even from a great distance my first instinct was to look away. The foot, however, wasn't repellent -- less a malformed appendage than the business end of a useful tool. Other professional football teams had kickers. We had a sledgehammer, or the head of a 1-wood, attached to the end of a 260-pound cripple.

WALWORTH--Edward H. Former Chairman of William Zinsser & Company and longtime resident of New Canaan, CT, died October 15 at his home after a brief illness. He was 92. Under his leadership, William Zinsser & Company the oldest importer, processor and seller of unbleached shellac in the United States diversified into non-shellacbased products, moved out of New York City into modern facilities, and sustained an unbroken record of profitability. Mr. Walworth also served on the boards of trustees of the New Canaan Library and New Canaan Nature Center. Stationed at the Pentagon during World War II, Lt. Walworth met his future wife, Nancy Zinsser, in the office of Assistant Secretary of War John McCloy. They were married in 1944 and remained devoted to each other for 63 years. He was always friendly, always curious, always the gentleman. He will also be remembered for his unfailing optimism and dry wit that attracted everybody and brightened every day, even to the end. In addition to his wife, he is survived by four children who adored him: Edward, Joyce, Seth, and Cornelia. A memorial service has been scheduled for December 1st at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan at 1pm. Hoyt F Funeral Home Inc. www.hoytfuneralhome.com

Late in the workday, do you ever get the craving to watch a rugby match? Me neither, but thanks to the newly re-launched ESPN360, it's possible to plug into an IV drip of nonstop sporting events. ESPN360 is a broadband service that functions as a control room for the cable empire's many GameCasts. Once you sign up for 360 (which is free with certain broadband providers; go to espn360.com for details), you can configure your computer screen to show as many as 10 games at a time, either live ones or the recently aired. (Typically, a college football game will air live on 360 and then appear in the archives immediately afterward.) On a recent afternoon, I filled up my monitor with the following: a Brazil-versus-Denmark women's soccer game; a rugby match between clubs called Hindu and Sic; the X Games; a West Virginia University football press conference; and -- a profoundly interesting discovery -- Mexican college football. What's more, I could monitor all of them without the whiplash attendant to sitting in a sports bar. ESPN 360 is faintly reminiscent of the early days of the cable channel, when ESPN would fill airtime with the ''exotics.'' A familiar complaint about ESPN these days is that it doesn't show enough sports. Petrifying in my office chair in front of 360, I had the opposite thought: is it possible to show too much?

SCUBA DIVING AT THE BARI REEF, Aug. 21, 2007 Tony Salinas, 49, a television engineer from Sunland, Calif. ''My family and I all dive. Every year we try to go to a new destination. It's actually, I think, the third time we've been to Bonaire because we like it so much. That's a beautiful sponge called a tube sponge. I'm really thinking just of the beauty of such a simple thing. It's simplicity at its greatest. It's living there in harmony with its surroundings. That's one thing about diving: it's very peaceful and quiet. You kind of leave civilization for about an hour when you go diving. Underwater, I enjoy the peacefulness, the serenity, almost the loneliness of that. An enjoyable loneliness -- no pagers, no cellphones, no talking, nothing. Just basically you and the bubbles you make.'' As told to J. R. Romanko

After purchasing a vast unbroken wilderness in Adirondack Park that only loggers and a few hunters have ever seen, the Nature Conservancy will not preserve it all as public land. In June, the conservancy’s Adirondack chapter paid $110 million for 161,000 acres of highly prized wild lands. As part of the deal, the conservancy agreed to continue logging to supply wood to the Finch Paper mill — owned by Finch, Pruyn & Company, the land’s former owner — in Glens Falls, N.Y., for the next 20 years.

Updated, 5:23 p.m. | Paper or plastic? It’s no longer much of a choice in the United States, where plastic bags — introduced in 1977 — make up 90 percent of all grocery bags, according to the Progressive Bag Alliance, which represents plastic bag manufacturers. Now two City Council members, concerned about the number of plastic bags entering the New York City waste stream, say supermarkets should be required to take an active role in recycling them.City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn and Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. are proposing legislation today that would require grocery stores to collect, transport and recycle the bags. The bill would put New York near the forefront of a movement to curb plastic bag use. The United States goes through an estimated 100 billion plastic bags a year, as Peter Applebome noted in an Our Towns column in September.

One interesting difference between the Marine Corps and civilian life is job turnover. In the military every job at every unit has a new person filling it on a cycle that lasts anywhere from six months to three years. The commanding officer of a unit usually has command for two years. Company grade officers and staff non-commissioned officers usually change jobs within the unit every 12 to 18 months, and some field grade officers may serve an entire three-year tour in the same job before transferring units. The intent is to create marines that are well-rounded, have experienced a variety of responsibilities, and are ready to tackle a myriad of tasks. Furthermore, if you don't like the way things are running, just wait a while - they'll change. You may not like the way they change, but you can be assured that new personalities will come and bring their own way of doing things.

On Monday, shares of Goldman Sachs, the giant securities firm led by Mr. Blankfein, touched $241.32, their highest level since the firm went public in 1999. Monday's gain came amid what Jon Najarian of OptionMonster.com described as a surge of trading in Goldman stock and options, much of it by institutional investors.

In the old days, seeing "The Last Supper" meant flying to Milan and then waiting on a long line. Over the weekend, though, a high-definition digital image of the painting was posted to the Web by HAL9000, an Italian company named after the icewater-voiced computer in the film "2001: Space Odyssey."
"Among the big American media companies, NBC Universal was late to move into international markets," Eric Pfanner writes in Sunday's International Herald Tribune.
New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg spends a lot of his time trying to get people to stop killing themselves.

Updated | 3 p.m. On the heels of his vow in an interview with our Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny to take on Senator Hillary Clinton more forcefully Senator Barack Obama has released a new ad on Social Security.

The world watched as a protest movement led by Buddhist monks was brutally ended, and world leaders have tried to formulate a response ever since. But gaining leverage over Myanmar's self-sufficient, insular junta is proving as hard as it sounds.

This story in today's New York Times analyzes the business model for Current TV, which was started by Al Gore and a partner, Joel Hyatt, and wonders whether there is an audience for a filtered, high-minded version of YouTube on television.

On Monday, Ken Auletta interviews Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC Universal, over breakfast at the Bryant Park Grill, at an event sponsored by the Newhouse School at Syracuse University.

Mitt Romney has landed a big endorsement in the Granite State. Senator Judd Gregg, a New Hampshire Republican, will be endorsing Mr. Romney today and accompanying him when he officially files his candidacy in Concord at 12:30 p.m., according to Kevin Madden, a spokesman for the campaign.
What did you do on Sunday? Kevin Smith set five Central Florida records as the Knights beat Southern Mississippi.

Michael Moore may love Britain's National Health Service, but growing numbers of its patients seem to be less pleased. "Record numbers of Britons are travelling abroad for medical treatment to escape the N.H.S. - with 70,000 patients expected to fly out this year," reports The Daily Mail of London.

COLUMBIA, S.C. -- At Barack Obama's gospel concert here last night, more than 2,000 black evangelicals were singing, waving their hands and cramming the aisles -- most enthusiastically when Donnie McClurkin, the superstar black gospel singer, decried the criticism he has generated because of his views that homosexuality is a choice.

Grosvenor Capital Management, a fund of hedge funds manager, said on Monday that Hellman & Friedman will become a minority investor, taking over a stake once held by Value Asset Management. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.

On a winter night at the Museum of Modern Art early last year, Richard S. Fuld Jr. addressed more than 135 newly anointed Lehman Brothers managing directors and senior executives, telling them, their spouses and partners exactly how he viewed the landscape on Wall Street.

With November arriving this week, Congressional Democrats are set to begin making their first serious moves in what has become an intricate legislative chess match with the White House over the stalled annual spending bills.
Analysts looking for signs of how Asia's business landscape is developing need look no further than the changes afoot at Lehman Brothers' operations in the region, according to The Financial Times.

As Barack Obama trails Hillary Clinton by 20 percent in some polls, is divine intervention his best hope to catch up? Two articles this morning - one in the Los Angeles Times and one from the Washington Post - explore the role of God in Mr. Obama's campaign.

I like everything I'm hearing about a new book called Mass Career Customization written by two colleagues from Deloitte. The book outlines how one firm is responding to the increasing number of employees who want to, for lack of a better phrase, "customize their career paths" within one company.

Terra Firma is already trying to trim its equity stake in EMI amid a major strategic review of the music company's business that could result in big changes, including a possible sale of its physical distribution business, The New York Post reported citing unnamed sources.

The news media is more obsessed than ever with the horse-race aspects of the presidential campaign, according to a new study. Despite the campaign's early start, the study said, the media has not been more reflective on the issues but more focused on tactics and strategy.

UBS, which is scheduled to report earnings Tuesday, confirmed Monday that its third-quarter loss will be in line with its previous guidance. The Swiss bank said it made the announcement in response to a "media report over the weekend."

E. Stanley O'Neal's six-year reign at Merrill Lynch is coming to an end. After an $8.4 billion write-down and an unauthorized merger approach to a rival bank, Wachovia, Mr. O'Neal has lost the confidence of his board and is expected to resign as chairman and chief executive as early as Monday, The New York Times reported.

Most Wall Street chief executives struggle to keep the job they have. Laurence D. Fink, the founder of the BlackRock investment management firm, has the opposite problem. His name constantly surfaces for new ones.

After seeing the reaction to my post on trans fats, it occurs to me that there's been a weird trajectory in public health policy since the Surgeon General's report on tobacco in 1964: The science has been getting weaker, but the policies have been getting stronger.
Stephen Nash's pencil and ink drawings have become valuable tools in helping locate rare species and persuading people to help conserve them.

The Anglo-Swiss mining giant Xstratahas reached a friendly deal to buy a nickel mining company, Jubilee Mines, for 3.1 billion Australian dollars ($2.9 billion), continuing the firm's acquisitive streak.
The Federal Communications Commission on Friday approved a $27.5 billion buyout of Alltel, the nation's fifth-largest wireless carrier, to a private investment group.

Private equity bidders for Jaguar and Land Rover are demanding that Ford Motor lend them the money to buy it, The Guardian reported. The demand may test just how desperate Ford is to get rid of its last remaining British subsidiary.
A preliminary proxy filing for SAP's $5.7 billion acquisition of Business Objects, a French software firm, reveals that two other bidders had stepped forward.

A Qatari investment fund attempting to buy the British grocer J Sainsbury revealed Friday that it was seeking further financing for the deal as regulators set a tight deadline for the group to come forward with a formal bid or to walk away.

The British insurer Resolution dropped its support for a 4.9 billion-pound ($10.1 billion) bid from Standard Life to take a neutral stance in the takeover battle between Standard Life and the Pearl Group.

Four teenagers were shot, one fatally, last evening, the police said. The shootings occurred at 6:25 p.m. near the corner of Osborn and Newport Streets in the Brownsville neighborhood. The police had no comment on suspects or motive. An 18 year-old was shot in the torso and was pronounced dead on arrival at Brookdale Hospital, the police said. Two other victims, 15 and 16, were treated for their wounds and released, while another 16-year-old remained hospitalized for a thigh wound and was in stable condition, the authorities said. The police did not identify the victims, but a woman named Doris Cann said that her son, McKinley, was the hospitalized survivor. She said he had been with friends and was hit after returning from an ice cream vending van. She said she believed that the teenagers were innocent bystanders.
Alex Rodriguez has opted out of his contract, his agent said, a move that may end his career with the Yankees.
Two off-duty New York City firefighters were arrested Sunday on charges of spreading and igniting flammable fluid outside a Manhattan firehouse early Saturday, Fire Department officials said.
Anthony P. Piscitelli, New York City’s former chief lobbyist in Albany, is being investigated for possible violations of lobbying rules, city authorities said Sunday.
New York is on pace to be among the first states to adopt the federal Real ID program, whose critics have included civil libertarians, immigration advocates and many lawmakers.

New Jersey voters will decide four questions in the Nov. 6 election — the most submitted to voters by the state since 1995. The voters will be asked whether to dedicate money from last year’s sales tax increase to property tax relief; borrow $450 million for stem cell research; borrow $200 million for land preservation; and revise language in the State Constitution outlining when voting rights can be denied by substituting the words “person who has been adjudicated by a court of competent jurisdiction to lack the capacity to understand the act of voting” for the phrase “idiot or insane person.”.

A 30-pound chunk of the Willamette meteorite, which was found in Oregon in 1902, was withdrawn from sale at an auction yesterday. The chunk was offered by Bonhams auction house, which estimated its value at $1.3 million, but it was withdrawn after bidding ended at $300,000. The entire meteorite, weighing more than 15 tons, has been owned by the American Museum of Natural History since 1908. The small piece was offered at auction by Darryl Pitt, curator of the Macovich Collection, a collection of space rocks, who traded it to the museum in 1998 for a Martian rock.

A Rowan University student was fatally beaten during a campus robbery, the university and the police said. The student, Donald Farrell, 19, of Boonton, died early yesterday at Cooper University Hospital in Camden, where he was taken after the attack about 9:15 p.m. Saturday, said a Rowan spokesman, Joe Cardona. The authorities said that Mr. Farrell and some friends were walking on the Rowan campus in Glassboro when a group of men approached them, asking for directions. Mr. Farrell started speaking with them, but the men severely beat him, taking his cellphone and wallet, and then ran away, the authorities said. “It happened so quickly that the people who were with him had no time to react,” Mr. Cardona said.

Two police officers who spotted black smoke pouring from a house in the West Farms neighborhood yesterday rescued families from the house and a building next door, the police said. About 9:15 a.m., Officers Christopher Scott and Michael Welsh banged on the door of the house, which is on Bronx Park Avenue, and removed seven people, including a 2-month-old baby. The officers then entered the adjacent building, which was also on fire, and evacuated five people, the authorities said. No injuries were reported among the people who were evacuated, but Officer Scott sustained a minor burn and both officers suffered smoke inhalation, the police said.

A man who was shot and wounded by police officers during a chase on Sept. 22 has said he was unarmed and has asked for an investigation by the Bronx district attorney’s office, his lawyer said yesterday. The man, Derrick Plowden, 19, was shot around 3 a.m. on Alexander Avenue after plainclothes officers saw him running with a handgun, the police said. He was struck once in the back of the knee, his lawyer, Damien M. Brown, said yesterday. He was charged with weapons possession, reckless endangerment and resisting arrest, the police said. Mr. Brown said that Mr. Plowden was being chased by a suspect in the shooting of one of his friends, that the gun found was not his, and that officers used excessive force after his arrest. A police spokesman, Paul J. Browne, said yesterday that Mr. Plowden was armed and posed a “grave threat” to officers. A spokesman for the Bronx district attorney said the office was investigating Mr. Plowden’s claim that he was beaten after his arrest.

(Sundance) RUNNIN’ DOWN A DREAM: TOM PETTY AND THE HEARTBREAKERS The director Peter Bogdanovich chronicles three decades in the life and times of the man he calls “an American troubadour in the truest sense of the word” in this four-hour documentary, using interviews as well as archival and concert footage of Mr. Petty and his band, below. Stevie Nicks, Eddie Vedder, Dave Grohl, George Harrison, Jackson Browne, Roger McGuinn, Dave Stewart, Rick Rubin, Jimmy Iovine and Johnny Depp, among others, weigh in. A Political Memo article in some editions on Wednesday about an intraparty rivalry among South Jersey Democrats included an outdated reference to the relationship between two allies, Joseph J. Roberts Jr., speaker of the State Assembly, and George E. Norcross III, the leader of the Camden County political machine and one of the state's most powerful political forces. LOOKING FOR A RATE CUT The markets are betting that the Federal Open Market Committee will cut its benchmark interest rate when it meets on Tuesday and Wednesday. The Fed cut the rate a half percentage point, to 4.75 percent, when it met last, on Sept. 18. COMPANY REPORTS Earnings season is in full swing. Among the companies reporting are Kellogg and Verizon Communications (Monday); Colgate-Palmolive, Procter & Gamble, Qwest Communications and United States Steel (Tuesday); Kraft Foods, Weyerhaeuser and MasterCard (Wednesday); Blockbuster, CBS, CVSCaremark, Eastman Kodak and Exxon Mobil (Thursday); and Chevron, Cigna and International Paper (Friday).

They have gone from exorcism to coronation in record time. The Boston Red Sox, who fought ghosts for most of the last century, are the premier team of the new millennium. The Red Sox won their second World Series in four years Sunday, edging the Colorado Rockies, 4-3, in Game 4 at Coors Field. They are the first team to win multiple championships since 2000, and with a deep payroll and a stable of talented young pitchers, they may be poised for more.

An article on Thursday about a fight between conservatives and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice over United States policy on North Korea misinterpreted comments by Senator Joseph R. Biden, Democrat of Delaware. In an interview on Wednesday, Mr. Biden declined to talk specifically about intelligence related to an Israeli strike in Syria on a suspected site of a nuclear reactor that North Korea might have been helping to build. When Mr. Biden talked of using a diplomatic approach to North Korea ''to rein these guys inside a deal that has some transparency,'' he was discussing a theoretical approach, not one based on new information. A graphic with the article also gave the incorrect dimensions in some copies for the building at the site of the suspected reactor. The square building was 154 feet on each side, not 154 feet high.
SCHINDELMAN--Harvey M. M.D., loving husband, father and grandfather. You will always be in our hearts.

VINCENT--Valerie McMahon, on October 26, 2007 after a brief illness. She is survived by her children Anne (Patrick), Bill (Amy), and Ted (Christine); her beloved grandchildren Jack, Benjamin and Tyler, Laura and Kate; and her sister Elise Furer (Bob). Reposing November 1, 2007 3-7pm at Fred D. Knapp and Son, 267 Greenwich Ave, Greenwich, CT. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Mary's Church, 178 Greenwich Ave, Greenwich, CT, November 2, 2007 at 10:00 am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Columbia University, Pancreatic Cancer Research, c/o Bill Horan, Suite 29D, 630 W. 168th St, NY, NY 10032.

An article on Thursday about an Israeli Supreme Court ruling in a religious dispute and other developments, including remarks by President Shimon Peres of Israel at a ceremony on the 12th anniversary of the assassination of Prime Minister Yitzak Rabin, described imprecisely one of Mr. Peres's recollections of the day of the assassination. Although Mr. Peres spoke of standing next to Mr. Rabin at a rally on the day the prime minister was killed, Mr. Peres was not standing next to Mr. Rabin when he was shot.

LEVOWITZ--Eunice H., passed peacefully in her home on October 25, 2007. She is survived by her beloved husband Dr. Bernard S. Levowitz, devoted daughters Lisa and Joyce, son-in-laws Alan Hurwitz and Jim Maffezzoli, adoring grandchildren Grace and Joy Hurwitz and Daniel, Gabrielle, Michael and Emily Maffezzoli, and her loving sister Leona Charron. She had a zest for life and was passionate about her work in the travel industry. A memorial service in November will be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated. She will be in our hearts forever.

STRAUSS--Jerome. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board of Govenors and members deeply mourn the passing of their fellow former member and past President Mr. Jerome Strauss and offer their deepest sympathy to his wife, Lenore and the Strauss Family. Alpine Country Club Robert Hershan, President
SAVAGE--Marilyn. 10/29/452/9/94. Wonder if, at 62, you'd finally look 42. Wish I could see it -and you. Miss you so much. Love, Vicki

Colts Improve to 7-0 Peyton Manning threw two touchdown passes yesterday, breaking Johnny Unitas's team record, in the Colts' 31-7 victory over the Panthers. Manning was outplayed early by Vinny Testaverde, who led host Carolina (4-3) on an opening 80-yard touchdown drive that lasted 18 plays and more than 11 minutes. But when Testaverde left at halftime with tendinitis in his right Achilles' tendon, Manning made sure the Colts (7-0) remained unbeaten heading into next Sunday's showdown against the Patriots (8-0). Manning was only 14 of 30, but his second touchdown pass, a 59-yarder to Reggie Wayne, moved him past Unitas.

WILLIAMS--Anne Wright. Died peacefully at home in New York City on October 20, 2007. She was 85 years old. Anne had been born in New York City, and was a lifelong resident of East Hampton, Long Island, having spent part of every year of her life there. She grew up there with her parents, Anne and John Wright, and beginning in 1941 she lived in a house on Woods Lane. During her childhood in East Hampton, she was an avid tennis player and horsewoman. Anne was first married to Matthew A. Baxter of Cleveland, Ohio. His paternal grandparents, the George White Baxters, lived in East Hampton. The marriage ended in divorce in 1953. In 1986 she married E. Coe Kerr, a well known art dealer in New York City. He died in Portugal in 1973. In 1990 Anne married David R. Williams Jr. from Tulsa, Oklahoma. They had known each other for over 40 years. He was the founder and former President of the Williams Companies in Tulsa. He died in 2000. Anne lived for 22 years in Cleveland where she was on the board of University Hospital and the Rainbow Hospital for Children, and was an active member of the Cleveland Garden Club. She was also an enthusiastic sculptor and began a life long love of painting. She left Cleveland and moved to New York to marry Coe Kerr. While in New York, she was on the boards of the Visiting Nurse Service and the Turtle Bay Music School. During her marriage to Williams, Anne lived in Oklahoma and Arizona for 5 years before he semiretired to New York City and East Hampton. Anne was on the board of the East Hampton Library for 15 years and served as its President in 1972, 1973 and 1975. She was Chairwoman of numerous committees and hosted many meetings in her beautiful and comfortable home. In the 1970's, Anne was appointed to several Garden Club of America jobs. Anne loved her own garden and spent many happy hours working there. She also continued her painting, occasionally exhibiting her work, and she served on the board of the D'Amico Art Barge. Though she traveled extensively and lived in other places, her daughter says that East Hampton was always Anne's favorite spot in the world. Mrs. Williams is survived by her daughter, Anne Baxter of Point Reyes, California, her son Matthew A. Baxter of Lyme, Connecticut, two stepdaughters, Polly Williams Lampshire of Camden, South Carolina, Rachel W. Costello of Tulsa, Oklahoma, and a stepson, David R. Williams III of Beverly Farms, Massachusetts, and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Church in East Hampton at 11am on Saturday, November 17. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the East Hampton Library or the Garden Club of East Hampton, or the D'Amico Art Barge. WILLIAMS--Anne W. The Board of Trustees of the Victor D'Amico Institute of Art/ The Art Barge expresses its deep sorrow at the loss of our dear friend, artist, and fellow Trustee, Anne W. Williams. Our sympathies and condolences to her family. Christopher Kohan, President

Current has gained a lot of attention -- mainly because of the involvement of Al Gore -- but it is not clear whether the channel is attracting an audience. [C1.]

GOTTLIEB--Ferdinand (Fred), died peacefully at home in Dobbs Ferry on October 27. He was 88. A noted architect, he designed numerous landmark structures and was a decorated WWII veteran who, after escaping from Nazi Germany, lived in British Palestine before emigrating to New York in 1937. He is survived by his loving wife of 54 years, Bernice, their children Peter, Richard, and Susannah, and grandchildren Degen, Michael, Bobby, Samantha, Inbo, and Zoli. The funeral will be at Westchester Hills Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, on October 29, 2:00 pm.

HASCOE--Norman. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our dear friend, Norman. His smile, laugh, candor, intellect, and joy of life will be with us forever. Our heartfelt condolences to Suzanne and the entire family. Linda and Earle Altman

ELIAS--Sylvia, New Yorker. Born October 15, 1911, died October 25, 2007. Adored widow of Sylvan Elias, Labor Lawyer; cherished mother of Roberta Krinick and Felice Miller; mother-in-law of Howard Krinick and Jordan Miller; devoted grandmother of Nancy, Michael, Pam, Amy, Ari and Gina; great-grandmother of Eric, Matthew, Bradley, Brendan, Liam and Nathan. Vitally interested in family, world affairs, cultural arts and teaching of English and Drama.

LIBRESCO--Emile WWII navigator, business executive, educator, civic leader, and Democratic Party loyalist, died on August 30 at 85. He received a B.A. from City College and an Ed.D. from Columbia University. Dr. Libresco had multiple careers: as a labor arbitrator at General Baking; a senior executive at Norton Simon Industries, American Can Company, and International Paper; and as a marketing professor at Fordham and Columbia Business Schools, and at Skidmore College (where he was the F. William Harder Professor of Business Administration). He was a Board Member of the NYC Midtown Planning Board, the CT Advisory Board for the US Civil Rights Commission, the Long Wharf Theater, the Westport Friends of Music, and the Westport Library. He is survived by his brother Leonard Libresco (Marilyn) of Castro Valley, CA; his three children, Josh Libresco (Sharon) of San Rafael, CA, Nicole Libresco of Arlington, MA, and Andrea Libresco (Mike D'Innocenzo), of Mineola, NY, and five grandchildren.

It was then he moved along with his family to the Whitman Square Section of Washington Township. A graduate of Washington Township High School, Jim then achieved his B.A. from the University of Penn and M.B.A. from Fordham University; majoring in Chemical Engineering. Jim traveled extensively throughout the World, enjoyed cooking and collecting ''things''. He is the devoted partner of Kenneth Viali; beloved son of Patricia (nee Cona) and William Morris; loving brother of Margaret A., William J. Jr., Stephen P. and Christopher J.; loving uncle to Frances and Henry Schober, William J. III, Theresa Leigh-Anne, Danielle, Kimberly, William C. and Richard R Morris; special newphew of Chris and Lorrie Cona; also survived by many other aunts and uncles. Relatives and friends are invited to attend his viewing on Wednesday 6:30-9pm and Thursday 10-10:45am in the McGuinness Funeral Home, 573 Egg Harbor Rd., Washington Township (Sewell), New Jersey, where funeral services will be held Thursday 11am. TRAYMAN--Rae L., passed away peacefully at her home in Manhattan on October 26, 2007 at the age of 100. Devoted wife of the late Murray B. Trayman and beloved mother of Felicie Balay, who was by her side. Always elegant, she was a liberated woman before they needed labels to prove such things.

A picture credit was omitted in Business Day on Friday with an article about the heavy pollution of China's cement industry. The photograph of workers unloading cement bags at a dock in eastern China was by Jianan Yu of Reuters.

READE RAPPORT--Muriel, 89, of Lake Worth, FL, formerly of Hewlett, NY, passed away unexpectedly Thursday, October 25th, 2007. Mrs. Rapport was born in Brooklyn, NY and was a prominent couture coats and suits designer for some of the most respected fashion houses in New York City. Mrs. Reade Rapport was the loving daughter of the late Louis Halpern and the late Anna Halpern (nee Gilbert). She was the widow of Sidney Reade and later of Robert Rapport. Muriel is survived by her cherished son Andrew (Mindy) Reade and granddaughters Sydney and Melissa Reade, who she loved dearly. They were her daily strength. She is also survived by her stepchildren Paul (Carole) Rapport and Joanne Fischer and her circle of friends who she loved dearly. A graveside service was held at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in East Farmingdale on Sunday, October 28th. The family suggests that memorials be made to the North Shore LIJ Health System Foundation, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021.

An article on Oct. 2 about anti-government protests in Pakistan before the Oct. 6 presidential elections misspelled the given name of the former prime minister and leader of the opposition Pakistan People's Party. She is Benazir Bhutto, not Bebazir.
An article last Monday about a warning to Iran made by Vice President Dick Cheney during a speech in Virginia misspelled the name of the town in the dateline. It is Lansdowne, not Landsdowne.

An article on Oct. 8 about Erik D. Prince, the founder of Blackwater USA, a security contractor, misstated the location of Hillsdale College, which Mr. Prince attended. It is in southern Michigan, not western Michigan.

KLEIN--Sam W. Beloved friend passed away. Claire and Seymour Baruch mourn him, great friend, we honor him. His memory is cherished forever. A true man (mensch), great soul. Condolences Jayne and families.

A report on Thursday in some editions of the World Briefing column about the South Korean government's complicity in the kidnapping of Kim Dae-jung, a former dissident leader who later became the first opposition-backed president, misstated the year of the kidnapping. It was 1973, not 1993.

GOLDIN--Alan Gary, of Milwood, NY lost his battle with Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma on Saturday October 27, 2007. Alan underwent an autologous stem cell transplant in July and fought valiantly. We were all so amazed by his strength. He was born on August 5, 1942, the son of Harvey and Nita Goldin who predeceased him. He leaves behind his beloved wife and partner of 38 years, Harriet (Brandler), two daughters whom he treasured, Stacey Wittekind and Allison; a son-in-law of whom he was proud, Marc; two darling grandchildren, Kevin Henry and Sydney Grace, a myriad of close friends and extended family whom he respected and loved. Alan was a product of the NYC school system -Bx Science; CCNY, from which he received a B.S. degree in Economics and Statistics; Baruch Graduate School where he was granted an MBA in Marketing. He then completed a stint in the Army Reserve before beginning a career in advertising, first in Media Research and then branching out into Media Planning. He started out at Grey Advertising; moved to Ogilvy & Mather; BBD&O, where he was Media Director for several years; Kenyon & Eckhardt; and then moved to the other side of the fence when he joined Jos. E. Seagram & Sons to head up a new in-house Media Agency. When that was disbanded several years later Alan landed various other posts at DeWitt, Grace & Rothschild and CIA. Four years ago he finally ventured out on his own and co-founded 3 Plus Media, the culmination of a life-long dream. During his career, Alan served as Chairman of the AAAA Media Research Committee, the AAAA Consumer Magazine Committee and the Agency Media Research Council and as Vice Chairman of the Media Advisory Committee for the Audit Bureau of Circulation. He was a Board member of Advertising Information Services and the Traffic Audit Bureau for Media Measurement. Alan was a highly sought after speaker and gave countless talks in the US and abroad. Alan's passion in life was golf. He was a member of the Whippoorwill Club in Armonk, a member of the Westchester Golf Association and a sought after partner throughout the advertising industry. His wit and low handicap always ensured him of a foursome. He will be missed by all who knew him and loved him. Funeral services will be graveside on Tuesday, October 30, 2007, at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Lymphoma Research Foundation, 111 Broadway, 19th Floor, New York, NY 10001-1005.

Because of an editing error, a chart on Oct. 13 with an article about Al Gore's transformation from a defeated presidential candidate to a Nobel laureate misstated one of his career highlights. Although he did become vice president in 1993, he did not run for president in 1992. (Mr. Gore considered a race that year, but announced in August 1991 that he would not run, as he had done in 1988.)

The Straphangers Campaign, an advocacy group for subway and bus riders, today conferred its sixth annual Pokey Award for the slowest bus route in New York City. The dubious distinction went to the M23 crosstown bus, which crawls along at 4 miles per hour at noon on a weekday, according to the campaign’s research. (By comparison, an average person walks at a speed of 3 m.p.h.)

Updated, 3:45 p.m. | The fire in Rosedale, Queens, this morning killed a Correction Department captain and her two children, the authorities have confirmed.Fire and police officials did not release their identities, but Ronald Whitfield, president of the Correction Captains’ Association, spoke to reporters at the scene and identified the woman as Captain Renee Chong, 40. He said Captain Chong’s two sons, Elliot, 9, and Noah, 6, also died in the fire.

Immigration advocates cheered earlier this month when Gov. Eliot Spitzer quietly rolled back a post-9/11 state policy under which state driver’s licenses obtained by legal foreign visitors were marked with the words “temporary visitor” and the date that the visitor’s visa expired.The move followed his decision in late September to allow illegal immigrants to apply for driver’s licenses beginning early next year, with the administration arguing that it made no sense that the stamp would be superfluous under a policy where people get licenses even if they entered the county illegally.

When the St. George terminal of the Staten Island ferry system reopened in May 2005 after a $124 million renovation, Staten Islanders rejoiced. Many landlords in struggling neighborhoods of New York City are now turning away Section 8 vouchers, which have long been a pillar of rent support for needy families and currently serve about 270,000 city residents. Unlike many cities, including Chicago and Washington, New York City — home of the largest Section 8 program in the country — has never had a law prohibiting discrimination against voucher holders.

The fake news conference held by the Federal Emergency Management Agency last week is becoming a story that just won't go away. It's a worst-case scenario for FEMA, whose new leadership team, installed after the Hurricane Katrina debacle, has been waiting for the next major disaster to show the American public that it had learned its lessons. But now everyone's attention is focused instead on what is universally seen as the boneheaded handling of the news briefing last Tuesday. Instead of a simple update for reporters on the response to the California wildfires, the agency whipped up a mini-scandal.

Melanie Brown, the singer formerly known as Scary Spice of the Spice Girls, wowed the judges with her rhumba on Monday's "Dancing With the Stars," as the show attracted its largest audience of the season. "Heroes" on NBC was in second place, delivering 10.5 million viewers at 9 p.m. but matching its all-time low in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic.

Just as a colleague here in the New York Times Washington bureau asked, "is anybody watching these debates,'' came an answer in our in-box, in the form of a release from Nielsen Media Research. Nielsen provided a breakdown of the audiences for all of the debates so far, and the answer is: Far fewer than would watch the lowest-rated prime-time show, but, that said, they have at times drawn at least a couple of million viewers.

I discussed the extraordinary retreat of Arctic Ocean sea ice this year, and the implications of opening northern waterways, on Marty Moss-Coane's Radio Times show on Monday on WHYY radio in Philadelphia.

Brett Favre isn't just collecting records this season. Last night he added a classic play to his career highlight reel, throwing an 82-yard touchdown pass on the first play of overtime to beat the Broncos in Denver, 19-13. (You can watch the final play here.) It was the kind of risky, exhilarating play you hardly see in overtime in the N.F.L. anymore, but Favre had been defying convention all night. He did not hesitate to challenge the best cornerback tandem in the N.F.L., Champ Bailey and Dre Bly, burning each on long touchdown passes.

Green tells Brett Vito of the Denton Record-Chronicle that he was suspended from the team because he said "We are from the 'hood" on the sideline on Saturday.

Oh, dear. I was so hoping that this question wouldn't come up. Let me begin by saying that there are many gorgeous, sonorous, and precise sections in the new translation, among them the lovely passage that Sam quotes. And let me say also that translators are precious resources, that (perhaps needless to point out) there would be no such thing as "world literature" without them, and that every so often, when something from another language is translated into English for the first time - I'm thinking of Chris Andrews's pitch-perfect recent translations of the fiction of Roberto Bolaño - we can't help wondering how many masterpieces, how many works of genius would be unavailable to us without the (often under recognized and generally underpaid) work of translators. Having said that, I have to confess that I gave up reading the new translation after about fifty pages, and - after consulting several alternatives - decided to use the Ann Dunnigan translation, which appeared, I believe, in the late 1960s.

It's not a trick question, but rather the, um, answer on a Jeopardy! category next Wednesday, Nov. 7. The category will be called "Blogs of The New York Times." The other four answers? Without giving it all away, they have to do with sports, fashion, technology and "the hidden side of everything."

The Andrew Meyer seen in YouTube clips does not apologize. He rants at Senator John Kerry, struggles with police officers trying to escort him out of the room, implores them to "don't tase me, bro," and, quite disturbingly, wails in pain as they do it anyway.
Brian Lamb, the founder of C-SPAN, will receive the Presidential Medal of Freedom -- the nation's highest civilian honor -- from President Bush next week.

Eden Ross Lipson, the Book Review's legendary and longtime children's book editor - she retired in 2006 - used to say that there was no way to tell if a classic kid's book had arrived until a generation (or two, or three) had passed. The question isn't whether you'll read a new book to your kids. It's whether they will read the same book to their kids, and so on down the line.
It appears that Joe Torre will not be unemployed for too long. Tyler Kepner, my colleague, is reporting that the Los Angeles Dodgers will dismiss Grady Little as manager and replace him with Torre.

Aired Monday night on NBC: As part of a promotion that Taco Bell did during the World Series, everybody in America will receive a free taco tomorrow. Experts say that the promotion is a good business move for Taco Bell and an even better one for Charmin toilet paper.

-- From an article in the Sunday Times about the thriving comedy improv scene in New York, where (unlike in Chicago) "amateur comics can reasonably hope that their next onstage impersonation of a hypochondriac hamster might land them a job on television."

Aired Monday night on NBC: Welcome to Los Angeles. We have gone past global warming. We're on global burning right now. Now when Paris Hilton says, "That's hot," it's because she's actually on fire. In fact, there's been so much smoke, David Hasselhoff now eats his burgers off the floor to avoid the smoke inhalation.

Aired Monday night on CBS: Now here's the deal: For a long time, we were all complaining about global warming ... and today it's freezing. Here's how cold it was today: O.J. Simpson was stealing mittens.

The following is a transcript of the Democratic Presidential debate in Philadelphia, as provided by Federal News Service.

Yet another week, yet another debate. Tonight the Democrats will appear at Drexel University in Philadelphia and it will be broadcast on MSNBC at 9 p.m. Eastern.

Call it a tale of two investment banks. Whoever takes over as chief executive of Merrill Lynch will assume control of what is essentially two companies: a thriving wealth management operation growing at 70 percent a year and a beaten-down bond business that could end the year with over $10 billion in credit losses.

Reading Senator Gary Hart's comment about Kutuzov's battle strategy against the French: "Patience and time; time and patience" - a philosophy the Senator brought to his own career - I was reminded of a marvelously strong line in the Rosemary Edmonds translation of "War and Peace," in which General Raevsky, on the heels of the brutal battle of Borodino (which weakened Napoleon's advancing Grande Armée at the cost of tens of thousands of Russian lives) advises Field Marshal Kutuzov to hold the Russian line - not to retreat, in spite of the shocking casualties. Raevsky says (time proved him right): "Where the issue is undecided it is always the most stubborn who come out victorious." It's a good motto for any campaigner.

CCMP Capital Advisors said on Tuesday that it had closed its latest fund with total commitments of $3.4 billion. The private equity firm, based in New York, said that the closing increases its assets under management and committed capital to $10 billion.
The race for the next big Chinese investment in private equity is on.

Laurence D. Fink is being bandied about as one of the top candidates to succeed E. Stanley O'Neal as head of Merrill Lynch. He would bring a strong track record as the leader of BlackRock, the asset management firm he founded in 1988 and merged with Merrill's asset management arm in 2006, as well as blend of banking and trading acumen.

The last thing I need is another online destination to take me away from working on my blog posts and columns. But when BuzzDash, a free online polling site, asked me to consider featuring some of their polls on Shifting Careers, it was the perfect storm of multitasking. I could spend hours "working" by reading polls about such things as if people have had sex at work or lied on their resumes. At the same time, I could be thinking about ways my readers could use BuzzDash to enhance their careers. The poll above is a sample I created to see how it works; it's now live on BuzzDash.

Alex Rodriguez's decision to spurn the Yankees and test his worth as a free agent has the team's fans smarting, not just because his big bat will most likely be missing from the lineup next year, but also because the $30 million a year he is thought to be seeking seems so outsized.

Robert L. Nardelli, the new Chrysler chief executive, has tried hard to sound like a "car guy" from the moment he landed in Detroit. He boasted at his first news conference, in August, about his well-stocked garage that included a Jeep, a Plymouth Prowler and a PT Cruiser.

Like venture capitalists' misfortunes after the dot-com bust in 2001, when it became clear there was too much money in Silicon Valley chasing too few deals, the credit crunch has buyout barons stretching to put the $500 billion they've raised in the past two years to work.

Philadelphia defenseman Randy Jones was suspended for two games by the N.H.L. for his violent hit on Boston’s Patrice Bergeron. He is the third Flyers player suspended for a dangerous play this season. Jones’s banishment is brief compared with those of Steve Downie (20 games) and Jesse Boulerice (25 games). The difference is that the N.H.L. disciplinarian, Colin Campbell, said he thought Jones did not try to hurt Bergeron.

The Detroit Tigers addressed one of their biggest needs yesterday when they acquired shortstop Édgar Rentería from the Atlanta Braves for two prospects. Rentería batted .332 in 124 games with the Braves this season, with 12 home runs and 57 runs batted in. Detroit went into the off-season needing to add a shortstop after deciding to shift Carlos Guillén to first base. The Tigers gave up the right-hander Jair Jurrjens and the minor league outfielder Gorkys Hernández.

The backup quarterback Ryan Perrilloux and linebacker Derrick Odom are not expected to play for No. 3 L.S.U. against No. 17 Alabama on Saturday because of their part in a nightclub brawl. Coach Les Miles said they would not practice this week. No one was arrested in the fight near the L.S.U. campus early Friday when Perrilloux and Odom got into a shoving match with a group of bouncers, a police report said. Brent McClellan, the owner of the Varsity nightclub, said Perrilloux and Odom refused to leave at the 2 a.m. closing time.

Nearly four months after giving birth, Lisa Leslie is back on the court with the United States women’s national team for its eight-team college tour beginning tomorrow night against Maryland. Leslie, who gave birth to Lauren Jolie Lockwood on June 25, sat out the W.N.B.A. season while she was pregnant. Leslie, the W.N.B.A. most valuable player in 2006, won gold medals with the national team in the 1996, 2000 and 2004 Olympics.

Nascar conceded that water got into the fuel supply of more than two cars during Sunday’s race at Atlanta Motor Speedway, apparently leading to a crash that took out several top contenders in the closing laps. Denny Hamlin was leading the Pep Boys Auto 500 with three laps to go when his car stalled while taking the green flag after a caution period. Martin Truex Jr., who led the most laps, smashed into the back of Hamlin’s car and finished 31st. Hamlin slipped to 24th. “There are multiple teams that are showing positive for some level of water contamination level in their fuel,” said John Darby, Nascar’s Nextel Cup director. Darby dismissed sabotage as a possible explanation.

The Nets acquired David Wesley from the New Orleans Hornets for Bernard Robinson, Mile Ilic and cash. The Nets plan to waive Wesley, General Manager Ed Stefanski said. Stefanski said the move was made for roster flexibility. The team has 13 players, and Stefanski said the Nets had no immediate plans to fill out the roster.

A State Supreme Court justice set bail at $25,000 cash for Shawn Kovell, who is accused of selling cocaine with her companion, Robert E. Chambers Jr., who was convicted in the so-called Preppy Murder.

A convicted burglar pleaded guilty to the deaths of five people abducted from a fast-food restaurant in a long and unsolved mass murder case. The burglar, Romeo Pinkerton, confessed in a plea bargain offered by the Texas attorney general’s office. Mr. Pinkerton, 49, received five life sentences. Four victims worked at a Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant in Kilgore, 115 miles east of Dallas. The fifth was a friend of one of them.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) — The Tennessee Valley Authority is expected to file an application, perhaps as early as Tuesday, with the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to build two nuclear power reactors in Alabama.

President Bush announced the recipients of the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the nation’s highest civilian award. The winners, to be honored next Monday at the White House, are Gary S. Becker, an economist and 1992 Nobel Prize winner; Oscar Elías Bisce, a human rights advocate imprisoned in Cuba; Francis S. Collins, director of the National Human Genome Research Institute; Benjamin L. Hooks, former executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People; Henry J. Hyde, the Illinois Republican who served for 32 years in the House, where he was known for his battles against abortion rights; Brian Lamb, president of C-Span; Harper Lee, author of “To Kill a Mockingbird”; and President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf of Liberia, first woman elected president of an African nation.

A man whose lawyer says he can testify that O. J. Simpson asked him to take guns to a confrontation with two dealers of sports memorabilia said he would accept a plea deal and testify against Mr. Simpson and two other men. The man, Michael McClinton, 49, of Las Vegas, became the third person to agree to plead guilty to reduced charges in return for his testimony. Mr. McClinton said he would plead guilty to robbery and conspiracy to commit robbery. He wielded a gun and acted like a police officer on Sept. 13, when Mr. Simpson and five other men confronted the dealers at a casino hotel, police reports said.

Explosions and a fire at a chemical plant northeast of Des Moines closed Interstates for an hour and a half as smoke billowed from the plant, Barton Solvents, a wholesaler of industrial chemicals, oils, surfactants and plasticizers under the Barsol brand. Neil Shultz of the Polk County Sheriff’s Office described mushroom clouds of flames and 55-gallon drums’ exploding and flying. A worker was treated at the scene.

Environmental groups have announced that they are suing Washington over a fleet of mothballed warships east of San Francisco Bay. The Natural Resources Defense Council and other groups say the Maritime Administration should curb pollution from the vessels. More than 70 ships are in the Suisun Bay Reserve Fleet, some dating from World War II.
Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein announced a plan Monday to limit gifted and talented programs to students who score in the top 5 percent on admissions tests.
For those who show up at the TKTS booths without a list of shows in mind, the line for theater tickets can become an exercise in gathering the wisdom of crowds.

Officials think that two firefighters arrested for arson on Saturday may have been playing a prank when they allegedly set off a large fireball at a Manhattan firehouse.

Hertz Global Holdings posted a 51 percent increase in quarterly profit yesterday, supported by increased car rental revenue, but shares fell nearly 2 percent on a cautious outlook for equipment rentals.

The Swedish truck maker Scania said its third-quarter profit rose by 37 percent, citing larger sales volumes and price increases. The company earned 1.75 billion kronor ($273 million) for the three months ended Sept. 30 from 1.28 billion kronor a year earlier. Third-quarter sales were 19.91 billion kronor ($3.10 billion), up 21 percent from 16.51 billion kronor a year ago. Scania’s order bookings increased to 18.3 billion kronor ($2.85 billion) from 13.5 billion kronor in the third quarter of 2006.

Dubai World, the ports operator, agreed to buy Labroy Marine of Singapore for 2.4 billion Singapore dollars ($1.7 billion) to add shipyards and cargo vessels to its maritime assets. Dubai Drydocks World, a unit of the state-run holding company, will pay 2.8425 Singapore dollars a share for Labroy, it said. That price is 3.4 percent more than the closing price on Oct. 26, the date when the stock last traded.

The Swiss mining company Xstrata has bid $2.8 billion for Jubilee Mines of Australia, the companies said. The acquisition, unanimously recommended by Jubilee’s board, would be the latest in a series of purchases by Xstrata in Australia, but would be its first foray into nickel mining in the country. Xstrata, based in Zug, has copper and zinc operations in Australia. Xstrata bid 23 Australian dollars ($21.11) a share, a 35 percent premium to Jubilee’s closing price on Friday.

Staples and United Parcel Service are opening co-branded stores in China, the companies said. The first two stores, called Staples U.P.S. Express, opened in Beijing, and two more locations are expected to open in Shanghai by the end of 2007, they said. The stores combine office supplies and document processing services from Staples with packaging and international shipping services from U.P.S.

Microsoft, seeking to expand in the medical sector, has agreed to acquire the assets of a privately held Thailand-based health information company, it said. The Thai company, Global Care Solutions, specializes in creating software for hospitals’ clinical and administrative operations. Financial terms were not disclosed. Peter Neupert, a vice president of Microsoft’s global health solutions group, said Microsoft would acquire software, intellectual property and other assets of Global Care, which is based in Bangkok.
The United States is reconsidering some aid to its Mideast ally Yemen after the release of a convicted leader of the destroyer Cole in 2000.

William S. Lerach, a former law partner at Milberg Weiss, pleaded guilty to conspiracy for a role in pursuing companies with class-action lawsuits when their share prices dropped.

President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono has released his first music album, a collection of love ballads and religious songs he wrote.
President Hosni Mubarak announced plans to build several nuclear reactor, following Iran’s lead.
United Nations and African Union officials said they were sending diplomats to the Darfur region to recruit more rebels to join peace talks being held in Libya.
At least 30 people were burned to death when a full fuel truck overturned and caught fire on a busy highway in Ogun State.
More than 6,000 people will be forced from their homes to make way for the country’s fourth space launching center, the Xinhua news agency reported.
NASA will tack a day on to the mission of the space shuttle Discovery so crew members can do “exploratory surgery” on part of the International Space Station.

What does it mean to be the Democratic front-runner at this stage in the race? Not as much as Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who is now leading in the national polls, might wish, if past elections are any indicator. Starting in 1952, the Democrats have contested the presidency 11 times (not counting 1964, 1980 and 1996 when they nominated incumbents). Of those 11 times, only five of the candidates who were leading in national polls in January won the nomination: Adlai E. Stevenson in 1956, John F. Kennedy in 1960, Walter F. Mondale in 1984, Bill Clinton in 1992 and Al Gore in 2000. The so-called front-runners who did not win the nomination included Estes Kefauver in 1952 (Stevenson won), Lyndon B. Johnson, who shared the lead with Robert F. Kennedy in 1968 (Hubert H. Humphrey was nominated after Johnson dropped out and Kennedy was assassinated), Edmund S. Muskie, left, in 1972 (overtaken by George McGovern), Edward M. Kennedy in 1976 (Jimmy Carter pulled ahead), Jesse Jackson and Gary Hart in 1988 (Michael S. Dukakis took over) and Howard Dean in 2004 (lost to John Kerry).

9 P.M. (13, 49) THE UNDERTAKING ''Every year I bury a couple hundred of my townspeople,'' Thomas Lynch writes in his book ''The Undertaking: Life Studies From the Dismal Trade.'' He is not being metaphorical. Mr. Lynch is a funeral director in a small town, Milford, Mich., where for three generations his family has cared for the dead -- and the living. In this ''Frontline'' documentary Mr. Lynch opens the doors to Lynch & Sons and allows viewers to peer into the difficult business of dying. Among the stories told are those of Anna Dugan, who is making preparations for her 89-year-old mother, who has had a stroke, and Anthony and Nevada Verrino, above, who are planning for the death of their 2-year-old son, who was born with a rare genetic disorder. ''What I've written is that while the dead don't care, the dead matter,'' Mr. Lynch says. 8 P.M. (13, 49) MARATHON CHALLENGE Yes, even you can run the Boston Marathon, if this ''Nova'' episode is to be believed. Tonight the series takes to the course at the Boston Marathon to follow 13 novice runners as they prepare to run the 26.2-mile race, bolstered by a nine-month training period monitored by doctors and exercise and nutrition scientists at Tufts University, who also chronicled the participants' physical transformations.

FUCHS--Jerome H., on October 28, 2007 of East Meadow (formerly of Massapequa). WWII 2nd Lt. Army Air Corps 1943-1946, graduated Syracuse University cum laude 1950, MBA 1951 sigma Iota epsilon honorary. Retired professor at Hofstra University 1987-2000, President of Fuchs Associates 1960-2000, clients included several fortune 500 companies and The Federal Small Business Administration. He was listed in Who's Who in the East, Who's Who in America, Who's Who in the World, Who's Who in Finance and Industry and Contemporary Authors. Charter member of The Society of Professional Management Consultants, founding member of The Institute of Management Consultants. Adjunct Professor: Syracuse University 1950-1952, Johns Hopkins University 1953-1957, Drexel University 1955-1957, Queens College 1963-1965, SUNY Stony Brook 1987-1991. Author of: ''Making the Most of Management Consulting Services'' (1975), ''Management Consultants in Action'' (1975), ''Computerized Cost Control Systems'' (1976), ''Computerized Inventory Control Systems'' (1977), ''Administering the Quality Control Function'' (1979), ''The Prentice Hall Illustrated Handbook of Advanced Manufacturing Methods'' (1988). Beloved husband of Eleanor (nee DeRoo), devoted father of Jerome S. Taylor (Chris), Susan Decker (John) and Sandy Lombino (the late Thomas). Reposing at the Charles G. Schmitt Funeral Home Inc., 3863 Merrick Road, Seaford (2 traffic lights East of Rt. 135). Graveside service Wednesday 11am at Grace Church Cemetery (Massapequa) hours today 2-4 and 7-9pm.

SHADWELL--Wendy. The Board of Trustees and staff of the New-York Historical Society mourn the passing of Wendy Shadwell, Curator of Prints Emerita. Wendy joined the Society in 1966 and worked diligently in several capacities before retiring in 2002 as Curator of Prints. In this role, Wendy safeguarded and interpreted a collection of approximately three million items that document the City, its environs and the State of New York from the earliest times, and of the American experience from the early years of the nation to the present. We offer our deepest sympathy to Wendy's friends and colleagues. Roger Hertog, Chairman, Board of Trustees Louise Mirrer, President and CEO

KORNBERG--Arthur. The faculty, staff and students of The City College of New York mourn the passing of Dr. Arthur Kornberg, 1937, 1959 Nobel Laureate in Medicine. Dr. Kornberg was a member of the extraordinary City College of New York Class of 1937, which produced three Nobel Laureates; his discovery of DNA polymerase helped ignite the biotechnology revolution, and changed the possibilities for humanity. Like so many CCNY alumni, he was a child of immigrants for whom a City College education proved to be a pathway to upward mobility and achievement. When he returned to campus in 2003 to serve as a juror in our student research conference, Dr. Kornberg spoke with humor and passion about climbing the steep incline from the subway to his ''City on the hill''. His interest in our students invested them with all the gravitas and weight that his accomplishments conferred, reminding them that he once stood where they did, and encouraging them to reach ever higher. We extend our sincerest condolences to his family. Dr. Gregory H. Williams, President

Judith Sloan, an actress, writer and radio producer, admits that Queens — New York City’s most populous borough — does not always inspire the warmest feelings. “It’s not the easiest place in the world to fall in love with or feel at home in,” she says. “Its urban landscapes are often mundane, sometimes hideous, occasionally even toxic. My husband, Warren, grew up in Queens and, frankly, he hated it.”But Ms. Sloan and her husband, Warren Lehrer, did fall in love with Queens, where they have now lived for years. Their 2003 oral history of Queens immigrants, “Crossing the BLVD: Strangers, Neighbors, Aliens in a New America,” based on hundreds of interviews, amounted to a whirlwind tour and love poem of what has often been called the most racially and ethnically diverse county in America.

The discussion this week of the translator's art has made for a fascinating round, and has brought out some perceptive comments from readers. For a former foreign correspondent - and an editor with reporters dispersed around the globe - this is a discussion with decidedly extra-literary implications. While we try to assign correspondents overseas who are fluent in the relevant language, there is no way that a paper as serious about international news as The Times can operate without interpreters. Many, many interpreters. As a reporter, I've worked with native interpreters of languages from Armenian to Zulu, and have come to believe that the craft of working with an interpreter is at least as important in our line of work as the mastery of languages. The obvious imperative in working with a translator is to get the facts right. (Witness the recent dispute over what Ahmadinejad actually said about gays during his speech at Columbia University.) But beyond that, it's about getting the voice right. The quality of a translation goes not just to accuracy of detail or intent, not just to felicity of language, but to clarity, nuance and credibility. An intellectual who makes a powerful point in Polish or Pashto can sound less convincing in a clumsy translation. A good translation can convey the charisma of a rabble-rouser, the egotism of a tyrant, the wit of a poet, the heartbreak of a victim; a bad translation can deny us the sense of character.

Yahoo.com's Michael Silver takes it all in and declares Randy Moss to be a rousing success. Really. And, finally, in case you don't want to bother with the real thing, ESPN.com used a computer to predict the winner, and it's the Patriots. Never mind that foxsports.com did the same thing, and it's the Colts.
