The authorities arrested a 17-year-old in connection with a street shooting that left one teenager dead and three other teenagers wounded, the police said yesterday. The suspect, Willie Mays, faces charges of murder, assault and criminal possession of a weapon in the shooting on Sunday in Brownsville that killed Darius Jenkins, 18. At the time of the attack, the police said the four youths had been the targets and were not accidental victims. The police did not release information on possible motives for the shooting. The three surviving victims — two brothers, 15 and 16, and a third male, 16 — suffered gunshot wounds to the leg and arm.

The number of jobless in Germany dipped below 3.5 million in October, a 12-year low. The Federal Labor Agency said the unadjusted jobless rate fell to 8.2 percent, down from 8.4 percent a month earlier. That meant that 3.43 million Germans were without work in October, 110,000 fewer than in September. In adjusted terms, the jobless rate fell to 8.7 percent from 8.8 percent in September. That is its lowest in 14 years, with the adjusted numbers of jobless down 40,000 to 3.6 million. Germany has been emerging over the last two years from a long period of economic stagnation that pushed up unemployment and prompted Germans to tighten their purse strings, leading to slack consumer demand. Much of the recovery is powered by exports into a growing world economy.

HSBC Holdings, the biggest bank in Europe, has sold its Marbles and Beneficial branded credit cards in Britain to a specialist lender, SAV Credit, for £385 million ($796 million). HSBC said the portfolios consisted of 338,000 accounts and were not a core part of its strategy to expand its card business. HSBC acquired Marbles as part of its purchase of Household, a lender in the United States, in 2003. Marbles closed to new credit card customers in April. SAV was founded in 2001 as a provider of credit cards to consumers unable to get cards among mainstream lenders. It has opened more than 150,000 credit card accounts.

The German chemical company BASF said its third-quarter profit nearly doubled on improved sales across all its divisions, notably agricultural chemicals, fertilizers and plastics. The company, based in Ludwigshafen, said it earned 1.21 billion euros ($1.74 billion) in the July-September period compared with 613 million euros the year before. Sales rose 5 percent, to 13.9 billion euros ($20 billion). The company said a spate of acquisitions helped push sales higher in the quarter and in the first nine months of the year.

Komatsu, the Japanese maker of earth-moving equipment, said profit rose for a fourth straight quarter and raised its full-year forecast as demand grew in China, Southeast Asia and the Middle East. Net income climbed 43 percent to 47.3 billion yen ($413 million) from 33 billion yen a year earlier, the company said. Sales in the period, which ended Sept. 30 and was the second quarter of Komatsu’s fiscal year, gained 17 percent, to 539.2 billion yen. Komatsu countered the worst United States housing recession in more than a decade by taking advantage of an oil-funded construction surge in the Gulf nations and a bid by China to develop its hinterland.

Because of an editing error, a report in sports on Sunday previewing the Washington-New England game misstated the outcome in some editions for the Redskins’ game against Detroit. Washington defeated the Lions.

An article on Monday about the presidential election victory of Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, wife of Argentina’s president, Néstor Kirchner, misidentified the birthplace of Eva Perón, the powerful wife of Gen. Juan Domingo Perón. It is Los Toldos, a village in Buenos Aires province — not La Plata, which was once known as “Eva Perón City” and is where Mrs. Kirchner grew up.

An article on Monday about the presidential election victory of Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, wife of Argentina’s president, Néstor Kirchner, misidentified the birthplace of Eva Perón, the powerful wife of Gen. Juan Domingo Perón. It is Los Toldos, a village in Buenos Aires province — not La Plata, which was once known as “Eva Perón City” and is where Mrs. Kirchner grew up.

An article on Monday about Israel’s reduction of fuel supplies to the Gaza Strip as part of the Israeli response to rocket attacks launched by Palestinian militants based in Gaza misstated the name of a fuel that will be reduced. It is benzine, a petroleum distillate similar to gasoline — not benzene, a toxic chemical used in paints, insecticides and other products.
A federal court’s oversight of Microsoft has been extended through January to give a judge time to consider a motion to extend that oversight for another five years.

One of two suspects in three slayings in Cheshire this summer pleaded not guilty in State Superior Court here yesterday amid heavy security and a swarm of television cameras. The suspect, Joshua Komisarjevsky, 27, of Cheshire, also waived his right to a probable-cause hearing. Mr. Komisarjevsky could face the death penalty if convicted in the killings of Jennifer Hawke-Petit, 48, and her daughters, Hayley, 17, and Michaela, 11, in a botched home invasion on July 23. Compiled by John Sullivan.

The State Division of Parole has ordered a new hearing for Charles E. Friedgood, left, a former surgeon from Long Island who was convicted in 1976 of murdering his wife, Sophie. At 89, he is the oldest state prison inmate in New York. Three weeks ago, a board of three commissioners rejected his application for parole, the fifth time he had been refused release since serving the minimum of his 25-year-to-life sentence. Mark E. Johnson, the division’s spokesman, said yesterday that the division disagreed with the board’s conclusion that “there was a reasonable probability” that if released, Dr. Friedgood “would not live and remain at liberty again without violating the law.” A new hearing will probably be held within a few weeks.

Inspectors have found meat that was recalled a month ago at seven more stores in New Jersey, state consumer safety officials said yesterday. In the past week, inspectors have seized 138 boxes of frozen hamburgers made by the Topps Meat Company, which issued a nationwide recall on Sept. 29 for 21.7 million pounds of frozen patties. Last week, officials said 19 boxes of frozen burgers had been found at a store in Union City, in Hudson County. Since then, the meat has been found at four stores in Jersey City and three in Bergen County, said Jeff Lamm, a spokesman for the State Division of Consumer Affairs. Topps, based in Elizabeth, closed six days after the recall.

State budget officials said yesterday that deficits for the next three fiscal years would be higher than expected, owing to a slump on Wall Street and the decrease in income tax revenues that will probably result. According to figures released by the Budget Division, the state budget is expected to remain balanced during the current fiscal year, which ends March 31, but the next year’s deficit will increase by about $651 million, to $4.3 billion, from a $3.6 billion gap projected in July. The deficits are expected to grow by an average of about $1 billion during each of the next two years, leaving deficits totaling $6.2 billion in 2009 and $7.9 billion in 2010.

Lawyers for three former workers at 167 Nail Plaza, a salon on the Upper West Side, announced yesterday that they had won more than $225,000 on behalf of the workers. On Friday, a jury in Federal District Court awarded one worker, Susan Kim, $182,000 for overtime violations and as compensation for being fired for demanding lunch breaks. Another worker received $40,000 in a settlement over overtime and retaliation claims and a third worker received a $3,500 settlement. An employee at the salon said it was sold a month ago. The former owner, Dong Rim Park, did not respond to a phone message. The workers were represented by the Asian American Legal Defense and Education Fund and Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison.
Several New York City hospitals did not inform indigent patients lacking health insurance that they could qualify for public assistance as required by a new state law.

The police are looking for a man in attacks on two women on the same street at the same time of night in SoHo in the span of a month. In the first attack, on Sept. 30, a 25-year-old woman was standing in front of the Box nightclub at 189 Chrystie Street about 3 a.m. when a man grabbed her from behind and forced her into a sport utility vehicle, the police said. The man forced her to drink an unknown liquid and drove her over a bridge. He then raped her, forced her to remove money from an A.T.M. and dropped her in Queens. In the second attack, a 23-year-old woman hailing a cab was picked up in the same area about 3 a.m. on Saturday by a man in a black sedan. The man drove over the Williamsburg Bridge into Brooklyn, parked in an alley and raped the woman. Each victim described her attacker as a white man, but the two women gave varying physical descriptions. The police ask anyone with information to call 1-800-577-TIPS.

The mother of a 12-year-old Brooklyn boy who died from a staph infection last week has given notice that she will sue the city for $25 million. The mother, Aileen Rivera, made her announcement at the offices of the Cochran law firm. Her son, Omar Rivera, died Oct. 14. The family said he had been sent home from Kings County Hospital Center after treatment with allergy medicine. The hospital has said it is examining whether it could have done anything more to detect the infection.

The Department of Education said yesterday that it would move to fire a teacher who investigators said began courting a student when she was 15, then had sex with her after she turned 17. In a report yesterday, Richard J. Condon, the special commissioner of investigation for the city schools, said that after the girl graduated from the Robert F. Wagner Jr. Secondary School for Arts and Technology in Long Island City, the teacher, Mario Quinones, 58, continued to have sex with her. Mr. Quinones, a social studies teacher, did not respond to messages left at the school or at his home. Mr. Condon said he would forward his findings to prosecutors, but noted that because the girl was 17 when the sex began, Mr. Quinones could not be prosecuted. Still, Dina Paul Parks, a spokeswoman for the Education Department, said that Mr. Quinones, a teacher since 1974, should have been aware that sexual relationships with students are forbidden.
Ilya Kovalchuk scored the decisive goal in a shootout last night to give the Atlanta Thrashers a 3-2 victory over the Canadiens in Montreal.
Lawmakers in the National Assembly approved a budget amendment that more than doubled the annual salary of President Nicolas Sarkozy.
Israeli aircraft hit a Hamas-run police station in Khan Yunis, killing at least four people, Palestinian security and hospital officials said.
For the 16th straight year, the United Nations General Assembly voted to lift the 46-year-old American trade embargo of Cuba.
One of Italy’s most infamous mobsters, Raffaele Cutolo, behind bars for the last 43 years, has fathered a daughter through artificial insemination, local reports said.
Prime Minister Hun Sen said he planned to legally disown his adopted daughter, who is a lesbian, so she cannot claim any inheritance.

A 19-year-old man was charged with second-degree murder in the killing of a woman who answered an advertisement for a baby sitter on Craigslist, the online bulletin board. The authorities said the man, Michael J. Anderson, lured the woman to his home Thursday, shot her and left her in her car’s trunk. The body of the woman, Katherine A. Olson, was found in the car Friday near Mr. Anderson’s house in Savage, about 15 miles south of Minneapolis. A complaint filed in Scott County District Court said Mr. Anderson had admitted he was present but said the killer was a friend who “thought it would be funny.”.

The chief of the Justice Department’s voting rights section apologized for saying that laws requiring voters to show identification affect elderly whites more than blacks because minority voters “die first.” The official, John Tanner, told a House Judiciary subcommittee that his comments at a Latino forum this month were “hurtful” and “clumsy,” but he stuck by his assertion that statistics show minorities have a shorter life expectancy. The apology did not mollify the panel’s Democrats, who accused Mr. Tanner of relying on stereotypes to justify policy.

A hunter is recovering after he was shot in the leg at close range by his dog, a spokesman with the Department of Natural Resources said. The hunter, James Harris, 37, of Tama, was hit in the calf Saturday, the opening day of pheasant season, said the spokesman, Alan Foster. “He took between 100 to 120 pellets in about a four-inch circle to his calf,” Mr. Foster said. Mr. Harris was hit when he put his gun on the ground to retrieve a bird, Mr. Foster said. The dog stepped on the gun and tripped the trigger when Mr. Harris was about three feet away. The dog was not injured.

Lawmakers are poised to end Ohio’s distinction as the only state that reduces unemployment payments to people over 62 by the full amount of their Social Security benefits. States began to abolish or reduce the deduction of the benefits after the mid-1980s, when Congress amended a law that had required it. Forty states no longer deduct any percentage of Social Security benefits, and nine states deduct 50 percent, according to the Department of Labor. The governor has said he will sign the measure. The cost of the change is estimated at about $25 million annually and will be covered by the state’s unemployment fund.

A University of Florida student stunned by a police Taser and arrested after an outburst at an event last month featuring Senator John Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, will not go to court if he stays out of trouble while on probation for 18 months, prosecutors said. The student, Andrew Meyer, shouted, “Don’t Tase me, bro!” to no avail as the campus police dragged him away. Video clips of his arrest became an Internet sensation. Mr. Meyer, 21, will return to school in January, said his lawyer, Robert Griscti. The officers involved returned to work last week after officials determined they had used appropriate force.
A 10-pound inert training bomb fell from a fighter jet, landing near a warehouse in Virginia Beach, the Navy said. Minimal damage was reported.
The Giants are counting on key differences — physical health and mental maturity, mostly — to forge a different outcome in November and December than they had last season.

Brazil, which has won a record five World Cups, was awarded the 2014 tournament yesterday by FIFA’s executive committee. Brazil last was the host of the competition in 1950, losing to Uruguay in the final. The unanimous vote came on the same day the 2011 Women’s World Cup was awarded to Germany, which beat out Canada. Germany was the host for the 2006 men’s World Cup. Brazil was the only candidate for the men’s 2014 World Cup because the rotation system meant it had to be played in South America. Colombia had said it would bid but withdrew in April.

Connecticut will play its first game as a ranked team Saturday night against Rutgers, but many fans in Connecticut and New Jersey will be unable to watch. The game will be televised on ESPNU, which is not carried by Comcast, a cable provider with 1.4 million customers in New Jersey and 525,000 in Connecticut.Jeff Hathaway, the UConn athletic director, said he believed the network was using the game to leverage cable companies to add ESPNU. But Burke Magnus, the vice president and general manager of ESPNU, called that assertion “ridiculous.” He said the decision to put the game on ESPNU was made before UConn upset South Florida and jumped to No. 16. Magnus said talks with Comcast would continue.

The former major leaguer José Offerman will serve two years of a special form of probation for attacking two players with a bat during a minor league game in August. Bridgeport (Conn.) Superior Court Judge James Ginocchio granted Offerman, a two-time All-Star, accelerated rehabilitation after hearing from current and former major league players supporting Offerman. Two felony assault charges will be erased from his record if he abides by the terms of the probation.

The bantamweight Gary Russell Jr. and the featherweight Raynell Williams qualified for the Olympics with convincing victories and increased the United States team’s momentum at the World Boxing Championships in Chicago. Russell outpointed his fellow 2005 world bronze medalist Ali Hallab of France, 22-14, in the Round of 16, and Williams led by 23-3 when his bout with Azat Hovhannisyan of Armenia was stopped in the third round. No United States boxer has won a gold medal at the worlds since 1999, but the Americans are 18-3 and in good position to end the drought.
Major League Baseball’s procedures may allow players time to mask their use of performance-enhancing drugs.
Pharmaceutical ingredients exported from China are often made by companies that are neither certified nor inspected by Chinese drug regulators.
The Nets’ hopes of re-emerging as an elite team again hinge on their Big Three: Jason Kidd, Vince Carter and Richard Jefferson.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 (AP) — Goodyear Tire & Rubber, helped by the sale of its engineered products unit, swung to a big profit in the third quarter, even though North American tire sales were down 6 percent.
The stay indicates that a Supreme Court majority intends to block all executions until a lethal injection case is decided next spring.
The Hawaii Legislature has approved a bill that allows a ferry to begin carrying cars, trucks and passengers between the islands before completion of an environmental impact assessment.
However, the attorney general nominee told Senate Democrats he could not say whether waterboarding, which simulates drowning, was illegal.
There are many reasons to ratify the Law of the Sea, not least the fact that it would allow the U.S. to play a role on a range of global ocean issues.
Congress needs to add more visa slots and approve resettlement benefits to Iraqis and Afghans who have served America at great risk.
A throng of fans lined up all the way from Fenway Park to City Hall cheered on the 2007 Red Sox one last time.
A contest between two rising political stars is on the way to becoming one of the most expensive campaigns in the history of the New Jersey State Legislature.
The Office for National Statistics in Britain disputed Rudolph W. Giuliani’s assertion that the chances of surviving prostate cancer in England is only 44 percent.
As Merrill Lynch begins to search for its next chief executive, the company named Alberto Cribiore as its nonexecutive chairman and leader of its search committee.
The hard questions were easy; it took the easy ones to stump Linda Schiro.
Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s administration was anxious about any opposition from the secretary of homeland security.
Sony Pictures is considering selling half of its animation studio and even more of its thriving digital visual-effects company, although the matter is still at an early stage.
A 13.4-minute video accusing Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of campaign finance fraud is being shown on college campuses and has generated significant Web attention.
They were athletes, homecoming queens, aspiring lawyers and future doctors who took a few days to spend time with their college pals, when a fire erupted as they slept .
Tim Duncan had 24 points and 13 rebounds, and the San Antonio Spurs got their title defense off to a successful start last night with a 106-97 victory against the visiting Portland Trail Blazers.
Representative Charles B. Rangel’s proposal has shaped the debate over whether to keep President Bush’s tax cuts.
Robert Goulet played a dashing Lancelot in 1960 and went on to a wide-ranging career as a singer and actor, winning a Tony, a Grammy and an Emmy.
Eddie Jordan resigned on Tuesday, pressed by a $3.7 million race discrimination judgment against him that threatened to shut down his office.
Is a 3-4 team ever in a better position than a 4-3 team? Depends, according to the Web site Coolstandings.com.
The torn panel on the International Space Station has created a new difficulty for a space shuttle mission that has already had more than its share.
Mike Morgan and Brian Sell are part of the Hansons-Brooks Distance Project, whose goal is to give runners a chance to see if they can compete internationally at the highest levels.
People typically associate mountains of gold with Fort Knox, in Kentucky. But there’s also a lot of gold stored in Manhattan.
The Justice Department approved AT&T’s $2.8 billion purchase of Dobson Communications but will require the company to divest some assets to preserve competition.
I think the first frost has finally come. Two mornings in a row the pasture has turned white, and the thick stands of goldenrod have turned silver.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 30 (AP) — United States Steel said Tuesday that its third-quarter profit fell 35 percent, hurt by lower prices, shipments and costs related to raw materials and a recent acquisition.

A former employee in New York City’s medical examiner’s office admitted yesterday that he ran an elaborate scheme in which he and a subordinate stole millions of dollars earmarked for identification of victims of the World Trade Center attack.
The parents and grandmother of two college students in Miami whose fight for legal immigration status came to symbolize the hopes of illegal immigrant students were deported to Colombia on Tuesday.
The sheriff of Orange County, his wife and a woman described in court papers as his “longtime mistress” were indicted Tuesday on federal charges that they used his office for financial gain.
Avon Products’ profit soared 61 percent in the third quarter as the company enjoyed strong revenue growth across all divisions.
Forget all the jokes about what should be done with the lawyers. What should be done with the law students?
Will the Steinbrenner family still need Howard J. Rubenstein to be his master’s filtered voice now that Hank Steinbrenner’s has emerged as the blunt voice of the Yankees?
President Bush selected Dr. James B. Peake, a thoracic surgeon, on Tuesday to head the Department of Veterans Affairs.
With a final inspection planned for Wednesday, the program to improve security at 25 classified sites on 12 Russian bases will be finished two years ahead of schedule.
As smoke and flames billowed from a house in Queens, neighbors frantically pounded on the door and screamed in an attempt to save the woman and two young boys who lived there.
People will soon be able to sign up for do-not-track lists, which will help shield their Web surfing habits from marketers eager to deliver specific ad pitches to them.
The animated film “Shrek the Third” helped DreamWorks quadruple third-quarter profit, as the film neared $800 million in worldwide revenue.
In Los Angeles, Skid Row is the easiest place for the city’s homeless to find services, shelter and three square meals a day.
The second annual Mayor’s Cup New York City Kayak Championships featured 98 racers from seven countries.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg backed away from his earlier statements that James Zadroga, a police detective, was “not a hero” because the city’s chief medical examiner ruled his death was not directly related to ground zero dust.
After years of fragmentation and isolation, Darfur’s resistance movements have broken down into a fractious bunch of men.
Veterans receiving treatment for depression are no more likely to take their own lives than are civilian patients, a large Department of Veterans Affairs study found.
Pete Kendall’s recent past and present will collide Sunday at the stadium he called home for the past three seasons when his new team, the Washington Redskins, visit the Jets.
In a new wave of global outsourcing, personal chores are moving offshore, and this is leading to some daunting challenges, both economic and cultural.
Even though oil prices fell by more than $3 a barrel, stock investors hunkered down amid expectations that the Fed will cut interest rates by a quarter-point.
In a city that is increasingly becoming home to major chains, Halloween Adventure retains a raffish local feel, even if it, too, is part of a nationwide franchise.
Commissioner David Stern, in an interview broadcast Tuesday, delivered his harshest assessment yet of the Knicks, who lost a sexual-harassment case earlier this month.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, responding to shrinking revenues from a cooling economy, imposed a hiring freeze for all agencies Tuesday.
A professor at the University of New Hampshire is teaching a class  devoted to studying the presidential primary in his state.
Twenty-one states will run out of money for children’s health insurance in the coming year, a new federal study says.
Cravath, Swaine & Moore raised the salary bar for law associates in New York, saying it will award a special bonus in addition to the year-end bonus the firm already pays.
Arthur Levitt Jr. said the current pension system was fraught with problems, including conflicts of interest, opaque accounting and a tendency to overpromise benefits.
Whether the Taliban were looking to establish permanent control over the area in Afghanistan or were simply carrying out raids was unclear on Tuesday night.
On Staten Island, a woman’s effort to gather narratives from ex-soldiers and victims of Liberia’s civil wars has proven challenging.
Free-agent closer Mariano Rivera showed up at the Yankees team offices in Tampa, Fla. on Tuesday and the sides want to make a deal.
Wyeth, the largest maker of hormone-replacement medicines used during menopause, won dismissal of a lawsuit in Minnesota linking its Premarin and Prempro drugs to breast cancer.
Mr. Feklisov was an intelligence officer for the Committee for State Security, best known by its Russian abbreviation, K.G.B.
The first woman to lead a branch of Nigeria’s legislature has faced calls for resignation after a series of scandals, including charges of abuse of office.
More than $100 billion has been devoted to rebuilding Iraq, but output in critical areas like water and electricity remain below U.S. goals.
The military in Myanmar, struggling to meet recruiting quotas, is buying, kidnapping and terrorizing boys as young as 10 to fill its ranks.
There is no blackboard and no lectern, and, most glaringly, no students in the university classroom of the future.

Groups are charging that pharmacies across the city routinely fail to help non-English speakers understand their prescriptions, raising the chances that customers could harm themselves by taking medicines incorrectly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (Bloomberg News) — Companies that lease tracts in the Gulf of Mexico in an oil and natural gas sale planned for March will pay higher federal royalties, the Minerals Management Service said Tuesday.
Top oil-producing countries have blamed the advance of crude prices toward $100 a barrel on financial speculation, geopolitical instability and a shortfall in refining capacity.
An alliance of companies led by Google plans to roll out a common set of standards to allow developers to write programs for Google’s Orkut and other social networking Web sites.
Marilson Gomes dos Gomes, who had run four previous New York City Marathons without winning, became the first South American to win last year.
Although Procter & Gamble and Colgate-Palmolive posted big jumps in quarterly profits, only P.& G. issued a cautious outlook in the face of rising commodity costs.
Scandals involving the freshness of products by popular confectioners have shaken Japanese consumers.
Over objections from the Bush administration, a Senate committee adopted legislation to extend the authority of the Consumer Product Safety Commission and increase its budget.
Jonathan Vilma, the Jets’ defensive captain, ended his weeklong silence regarding his season-ending injury Tuesday during a conference call, but cleared up next to nothing.
Justice Department lawyers said a federal prosecutor withheld  evidence from the defense in the first major terrorism case announced after the Sept. 11 attacks.
Ms. Anderson was a woman with learning disabilities whose wedding to her husband, who has similar disabilities, was the subject of the Vows column of The New York Times on Sept. 16.
The vote makes it less likely that the money-losing railroad service will face cuts in its subsidy and that passengers will face cuts in service.
Congress authorized spending of $43.5 billion over the past year to operate spy satellites, remote surveillance stations and C.I.A. outposts overseas, according to a budget figure released Tuesday.
At Chelsea Market, many of the two dozen retail tenants are expanding their businesses in ways that they say would have been incomprehensible a decade ago.
Although UBS predicted a return to profitability in the fourth quarter, the losses from subprime mortgage investments left analysts wondering about further big write-offs.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 30 (Reuters) — The chief executive of Countrywide Financial, Angelo R. Mozilo, has been sued by a pension fund that accused the company of helping executives pocket improper gains by artificially inflating its stock price through share buybacks.
Renowned for its exhausting nonstop play and rough, often bloody, full contact, rugby has tapped into a deep well of Syrian Arab pride over the past three years.
The move will accompany a reshuffling of several positions, including Ann McDaniel in a powerful new role that oversees both the editorial and business sides of the magazine.
In a trend known as consumer-generated content, an 18-year-old student and Apple devotee was hired to make a television commercial for Apple’s new iPod Touch.
As the years went by, I began to wonder if the house’s haunting was something I’d invented out of perversity, or boredom, or sheer loneliness.
As environmentally friendly buildings grow in popularity, it is no surprise that the architecture firms that build these edifices have the greenest offices of all.
The Kaufmann House, set into the California desert, enjoyed a restoration after years of neglect and is to be auctioned in May.
For many years, the Prado was almost a secret in plain sight, but now an extension moves the museum, stuck so long in the 19th century, into the 21st.
The Big Apple has assembled a first-rate combination of clowning, wire-walking, juggling, acrobatics, animal antics and other feats.
As the white truffle season starts this year in northern Italy and Croatia, some people in the business say they have never seen such scarcity. They fear it may be a sign of what’s to come.
The Fed opines on “Hannah Montana,” Iran hides Western masterworks, dead but still the king and more culture news.

The architect Santiago Calatrava has sued the city of Bilbao, Spain, for $4 million, claiming it violated copyright by allowing another architect to build an extension of his Campo Volantín footbridge.
Paintings by van Gogh, Picasso, Renoir, Monet and Gauguin are among an estimated $5 billion worth of Western art locked in a basement beneath the Tehran Museum of Contemporary Art.
The Federal Reserve Bank doesn’t just worry about the sort of fiscal complexities that prompted Thomas Carlyle to call economics the dismal science.
“Women in Modernism,” a colloquium held on Thursday night at the Museum of Modern Art, sought to take a more positive look at the role women have played in architectural history.
A flea market sofa bed bought for $215 yielded a 17th-century painting that sold last weekend for $27,630 at an auction in Hamburg, Germany.
Elvis Presley may be gone, but his earning power has reclaimed the top spot on the Forbes.com seventh annual compilation of Top-Earning Dead Celebrities.
Christopher Paolini, author of the best-selling fantasy novels “Eragon” and “Eldest,” will write a fourth novel in the “Inheritance” series, expanding it beyond the planned trilogy.
Melanie Brown, the singer formerly known as Scary Spice of the Spice Girls, wowed the judges with her rumba on Monday’s “Dancing With the Stars.”
Rajiv Joseph’s new play, about the overthrow of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan by the military in 1977, is so timely that daily headlines have made sick jokes of some of its lines.
Wegmans has announced that it will become the first supermarket chain to adopt strict environmental and health standards for the farmed shrimp it will sell in its stores.
A new biography brings to life Jerry Thomas, the first bartender to publish a drink book in the United States.
The choreographer John Jasperse has taken to rummaging through garbage.
To the Editor:.
An attempt by an obscure French charity to fly 103 African children from Chad to France was escalating into a diplomatic dispute on Tuesday.
To the Editor:.
Video games have rarely been known for the artistry of their animation. All that is changing this week with the release of Insomniac Games’ Ratchet & Clank Future: Tools of Destruction.
To the Editor:.
To judge by the postshow conversation, the audience loved “Dance Rocks,” a benefit for Career Transition for Dancers on Monday night at City Center.
The Thelonious Monk Institute of Jazz wrapped up its 20th annual jazz competition on Sunday with an emblematic scene.  Herbie Hancock sported a shoulder-slung synthesizer and a high-wattage smile.
Tom Coash has written a small, sensitive romantic drama that also tries to be about the tangled relationship between East and West.

New York performances by William Christie and his brilliant early-music ensemble, Les Arts Florissants, have long been dependable sources not only of historical elucidation but also of vibrant entertainment.
Look, Then Eat.

Julie Taymor’s quirky, puppet-filled production of Mozart’s “Zauberflöte” was one of the Met’s hottest properties when it was first staged and since then it has done extra duty winning over children in a cut-down version.
The Russian president visited a memorial at a site where thousands were executed, as Russia marked the 70th anniversary of Joseph Stalin’s Great Terror.
Ice Theater  wants to elevate ice dance to an art form, but you can’t do that if you don’t sink into skating’s particulars.

In a program called “Les Goûts Réunis,”  Jordi Savall and Le Concert des Nations performed works representing both the 17th-century French style and the more Italianate sound of the early 18th century.
Draft legislation that lifts immunity for foreign private security companies gained the consent of the Iraqi cabinet on Tuesday.

The old and the new go head to head in the music of Charles Ives, but conflict may not be the right word to describe it.

A tiny and usually peaceful minority, who practice a secret religion, are suspected in an attack on a cellphone tower, prompted by fears that it emits cancer-causing radiation.
Smith’s, Bacaro, Bun and Community Food & Juice open this week; Zen Palate in Union Square closes.

An article on Dec. 7, 2005, about the wine shop Sherry-Lehmann and its training of part-time workers for the Christmas season, referred incorrectly to the family of the owner, Michael Aaron, who commented on handing off the company to the next generation. Mr. Aaron has a son, Alexander; he is not childless. The error was pointed out to the reporter a few months after the article ran, but because of a misunderstanding, no correction was published. Lawyers for Alexander Aaron requested a correction in April, but their letter went astray at The Times. Editors received another request last week.
In its golden age, Hollywood excelled at manufacturing stars, large and small. This book explains how the machine worked.
L.S.U.’s game Saturday is nominally about preserving a shot at a championship.  More urgently, it’s a referendum on Coach Les Miles, who will face his predecessor, Nick Saban of Alabama.
Prices of homes in 20 major U.S. metropolitan areas fell 4.4 percent for the 12 months through August.
The Constitutional Court of Indonesia upheld the death penalty for serious drug offenses on Tuesday, dimming hopes of a reprieve for three Australians facing execution.
Even though one stepson left for college nine years ago, the other five years ago, I am still cooking for four, sometimes six. Here’s one meal I should stop cooking altogether.

The Russian foreign minister made a surprise visit to Iran to meet with President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad and discuss Iran’s nuclear program.

GROSSMAN--Richard, 81, died October 23, 2007, surrounded by his family. Born in 1926, son of Max and Jean Schick Grossman, he is survived by Eleanor, his best friend and wife of 58 years, daughters Jan and Susan, son-in-law Josh, aunt Edith, brothers-in-law Larry and Harold, and his grandchildren Sarah, Dan and Andy, who made him proud beyond measure. He was loved, too, by sister Eda, and son-in-law, Angel, who predeceased him. Richard graduated from Fieldston in 1944 and the University of Chicago in 1949, served in the Army Air Corps from 1944-1946, and was the author of ''A New Leash on Life'' (Random House, 1950). An influential and muchloved leader in pharmaceutical advertising, he was for many years Executive V.P. and Creative Director at Kallir, Philips, Ross. A writer of exceptional intelligence and style, he was treasured by his family, lifelong friends and colleagues for his wonderful sense of humor, acceptance of others, warmth and laughter. He believed, above all, in his love for his family and in their love for him. A memorial service is planned.
11 East 53rd Street; (212) 308-1099 or altorestaurant.com.

Memorial donations may be made at the Kennedy Endowment Fund, St. Vincent's MC, 2800 Main Street, Bridgeport, CT 06606.

SHECKMAN--Dr. Edward (known as Eddie), born October 24, 1917 in New York City, died at age 90, peacefully at home in New York on October 29, 2007 after a long illness. He was surrounded by family and friends. He graduated from the University of Michigan and after he completed his medical studies at NYU, he served in the army as Captain and Surgeon during WWII. He returned to New York to become Chief resident at NYU Medical Center and was a lifetime faculty member at NYU Medical School. In addition to practicing medicine, he was a true renaissance man. He broadened his interest to include a successful business career, and became an accomplished photographer whose work was exhibited in New York and Florida. A consummate New Yorker, Dr. Sheckman loved art, classical music, jazz, opera, and just about anything New York had to offer. He was a member of many of our city's museums, and a lifetime supporter of the New York Philharmonic. More than anything he loved people, especially those closest to him. The longevity of his friendships are astounding. Both his wives, Mona Bronfman of Montreal and Dorothy Morrow of New York, predeceased him. He is survived by his adoring granddaughter, Meadow Rose of New York, a brother, Dr. Nathan (Ruth) Sheckman of Fort Meyers, Florida, a sister, Dorothy Lazarus of Wareham, Massachusetts, four nephews, Dr. Peter and Richard Sheckman and Melvin and Steve Lazarus. At the request of the family, services will be private. Donations may be made in Dr. Sheckman's name to Continuum Hospice Care, 1775 Broadway Suite 300, NY, NY 10019.

MEZEY--Kalman, a native of Hungary, known for his work on drug development, died on May 20, 2007, in Baltimore, MD, at age 97. He received his M.D. from the University of Basel, Switzerland, specialized in Internal Medicine and Pharmacology in Basel and in Vienna, Austria, and in 1941 immigrated to Colombia. He was a founding member of the Javeriana Medical School in Bogota, chaired the Department of Pharmacology and did extensive teaching and research on cardiovascular drugs. He determined beneficial cardiovascular properties of plant extracts and analyzed toxicological properties of poisons which the indigenous tribes in Colombia extracted from plants for use on their arrows. He received the ''Orden de Boyaca'', the highest honor awarded by the Republic of Colombia, and a Medal of Honor from the Colombian Congress. Appointed Director of Clinical Research at Merck Sharp & Dohme International in 1958, and later a Vice President, he traveled around the world in relation to clinical trials and drug development and both organized and was chairman of an International Medical Advisory Board. He founded the Merck International Fellowships in Clinical Pharmacology, and fellows from all over the world became leaders in Clinical Pharmacology in their respective countries. In 1974 he became Clinical Professor of Medicine at the New Jersey Medical School in Newark and at the VA Medical Center in East Orange where he was principal investigator of VA cooperative studies on hypertension. Elisabeth Mezey, a native of Switzerland, and his wife for 70 years, died in 2005. Surviving are his son Esteban Mezey, M.D., of Baltimore, two daughters, Gabriela Gray of Potomac, MD, and Yolanda Terbell of Pasadena, CA; eight grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren.
Lemos & Van Zeller 2003 $55

FIELDSTON--Dr. Kenneth Charles, 60, of Tenafly, NJ. Gail, Evan, Ross, Todd, and Brett mourn the sudden passing of a devoted husband and father. Ken was an extraordinary father to his children, who he described as the absolute love, joy, and pride of his life. Ken was born to Jacob and Phyllis Finkelstein and spent his lifetime in New Jersey, contributing in personal and professional ways to the vibrancy of the community. After meeting at the University of Pennsylvania, Ken and Gail had a loving marriage for 34 years. He was a graduate of the University of Pennsylvania School of Dental Medicine and the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law. Ken practiced dentistry in Bergen County, finding joy in improving the smiles of his patients; he found such great satisfaction from his work that he hoped never to retire. Ken was an avid historian and classical music fan, who emphasized learning above all else. He inspired his sons to reach for their dreams and, in 2009, all four boys will complete their educations, having collectively earned four Ivy League undergraduate degrees and six graduate degrees in medicine, law, business, and public policy. Ken took incredible pride in these accomplishments and was a driving force behind them. He spent most of the last 14 years hopping between university campuses to share in the intellectual endeavors of his children, leading them to nickname him the ''Visiting Professor.'' In addition to his wife and sons, he will be greatly missed by his parents, Jacob and Phyllis Finkelstein; his sister, brother-in-law and nephews, Karen, Mark, Ron and Brian Geschwer; his mother-in-law, Francine Seideman; his brother-in-law Bruce Seideman and his family; his daughter-in-law, Lisa Fieldston; and his soon-to-be daughters-in-law Stephanie Foxx and Sara Woldin. He will continue to inspire us all for a lifetime and more.

Samascott Orchards in Kinderhook, N.Y., will sell its own fresh chestnuts in the Greenmarkets through Thanksgiving. Last week at the Dag Hammarskjold Plaza market, it not only had the chestnuts, but also the last of its own strawberries, the everbearing kind to be sure, but still, strawberries with chestnuts, and it's late October. The chestnuts, $3.25 a pound, are also at Union Square on Fridays and at Inwood on Saturdays, among other markets. They're a blight-resistant American-Asian cross, at the forefront of the reviving native chestnut crop, decimated by disease. But a passion for eating local is necessary to buy these over, say, Italian imports because they are small; count on a few hours for roasting and peeling a couple of pounds.

GRAY--Jonathan Ellis, age 59, was finally defeated by esophageal cancer on October 29th, 2007, after a heroic, six-year struggle with the disease. Beloved husband of Bonnie (Ellin), proud father of sons Jordan and Zachary, devoted son to Harriet and the late Phillip Gray, and loving brother to Esther Gray Peacock, Jonathan was never without the warmth of family. A securities analyst following the savings and loans industry and government sponsored enterprises, Jonathan reigned as the number one researcher in his field for 29 illustrious years at Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. and its successor firm, Alliance Bernstein. Following his diagnosis, Jonathan devoted the remainder of his life to the scientific, financial, and political pursuit of a cure for cancer-for the sake of himself and the rest of humanity. Impassioned scholar, respected professional, family man, and a paradigm of moral purity, Jonathan embodied all that an individual should aspire to be. We will miss him. Services today, 10:30am, Central Synagogue, Lexington Ave and 55th St. GRAY--Jonathan. We will miss your brilliant mind, your kind heart and your friendship. Gail and Jimmy GRAY--Jonathan. We will miss our courageous friend, a man of wit and integrity. Our hearts are with his family. He will always be in our thoughts. Francine, Adrienne and Gary GRAY--Jonathan. You fought with spirit and bravery to the end. We will miss our courageous friend. Our heartfelt condolences to Bonnie, Jordan and Zachary. Adrienne, Kenny, Adam, Jaime and Jon. GRAY--Jonathan. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its member Jonathan Gray. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Howard F. Sharfstein, President GRAY--Jonathan. Jonathan, our dear friend. A remarkable person who loved his wonderful family. Your appetite for knowledge and integrity inspired us all. We have been enriched by your life and will miss you. Our love to Bonnie, Jordan and Zachary from all of us. The Bandier, Fuld & Sirulnick Families GRAY--Jonathan E. The AllianceBernstein community mourns the passing, at age 59, of Jonathan Gray-our partner, colleague, friend and one of the funniest people you'd ever meet-after a courageous six-year battle with cancer. Born in Kingston, PA, Jonathan received a B.A. from Wesleyan University and an M.B.A. from New York University before joining Sanford C. Bernstein & Co., Inc. in 1973. He remained with SCB & Co. and its successor firm, AllianceBernstein, for his entire career. Starting as a securities analyst following the savings and loan industry, Jonathan approached his research with enthusiasm and a keen intellect. He quickly made his mark, having an immediate impact on the investment decisions at Bernstein and gaining a wide following in the investment community at large. Elected to the Institutional Investor All-Star team for the first time in 1976, Jonathan was similarly honored for 29 out of 30 years-missing only in 2003, due to his illness. Over the years, he expanded his coverage to include government sponsored enterprises (Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac, Sallie Mae), mortgage banking companies and mortgage insurers. Widely quoted in newspapers and magazines, and author of voluminous research on the industries and companies he followed, Jonathan also wrote a white paper for the FDIC titled Financial Deregulation and the Savings and Loan Crisis (1988) and testified before Congress on a variety of subjects -on the problems of savings and loans and the creation of the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989 (FIRREA), on legislation concerning government - spon sored enterprises (1992), and on student loans (1998). We offer our deepest condolences to Jonathan's wife Bonnie and his sons Jordan and Zachary. We will miss Jonathan's insight, his commitment and his wit.

The quiet Galilee village of Pekiin turned into a battleground as police officers clashed with rioters from the Druse community, police officials and village leaders said. Dozens of police officers and residents were wounded. The clash erupted when more than 100 police officers entered the village at 4 a.m. with the intention of arresting men suspected of vandalizing a cellphone antenna and came under a barrage of rocks, the police said. The police responded with live fire. Residents say they believe radiation from the antenna causes cancer.

A sports article last Wednesday about the impact of stricter drug testing on horse racing and the Breeders' Cup misstated the effect of Erythropoietin, or EPO. It stimulates the production of red blood cells, which can boost the body's ability to carry oxygen to the muscles; the drug does not increase the number of red blood cells by allowing more oxygen to enter the muscles.

According to a 1960 magazine article, the Kennedys would celebrate Thanksgiving in Hyannis Port, Mass., with two roasted turkeys: a gorgeously bronzed one to show guests and a second to carve and serve. You might follow suit by considering two of these cheesecakes from Neiman Marcus for the holiday table, one as a centerpiece and one for dessert. This Harvest Pumpkin cheesecake is a stunner, enrobed in a tinted white chocolate fondant (the stem is milk chocolate). Inside, the simple creamy cheesecake is swirled with hazelnut toffee and sits on a cookie crust. Measuring seven inches in diameter, it is billed as serving 10, but after a rich dinner, count on at least a dozen portions. It comes frozen and extremely well packed, $99 plus $17 for shipping from (888) 888-4757 or neimanmarcus.com.

An obituary on Oct. 20 about Robert Lantz, an agent for many celebrities, misstated the origins of the relationship between Mr. Lantz's father and Albert Einstein, who gave Mr. Lantz advice on his mathematical studies when he was 7. A colleague of Mr. Lantz's father had married a stepdaughter, not a daughter, of Einstein. The obituary also misidentified the position held by one client, William H. Rehnquist, at the time he was introduced to Mr. Lantz by Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas. Mr. Rehnquist was an associate justice on the court; he had not yet become chief justice of the United States.

Russia's foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, visited Tehran for the second time in two weeks and talked about Iran's nuclear program with President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, the Interfax news agency reported. Afterward, Mr. Lavrov said unilateral sanctions, like those recently imposed by the United States, could undermine diplomatic negotiations on the nuclear issue.

8 P.M. (TCM) BEDLAM (1946) ''When I was 9,'' Boris Karloff once said, ''I played the demon king in 'Cinderella' and it launched me in a long and happy life of being a monster.'' Tonight, Turner Classic Movies spends Halloween with the king of the boogeymen in a seven-movie tribute, starting with this horror film about an actress (played by Anna Lee) who campaigns for the reform of an insane asylum, only to be committed there by its cruel master (Karloff). At 9:30, Bela Lugosi joins Karloff in ''The Invisible Ray'' (1936), about a scientist who kills everything he touches, and the two reappear at 11 in ''The Body Snatcher'' (1945). The fright fest continues with ''The Old Dark House'' (1932), above, at 12:30 a.m.; ''Die, Monster, Die!'' (1965) at 2; ''The Walking Dead'' (1936) at 3:30; and the eerie ''Isle of the Dead'' (1945), with Karloff as a Greek military commander marooned on an island infected by a plague, at 4:45. 8 P.M. (NBC) PHENOMENON Criss Angel and Uri Geller watch over this live two-hour Halloween episode in which six competing mentalists demonstrate their talents and two others are sent home. Presumably they saw it coming.

THAL--Aaron, of Atlanta, GA, passed away on October 29, 2007 at Maine Medical Center in Portland, ME where he and his family have a summer home. He was born on July 4, 1920 in Dayton, OH, and was the youngest of three sons of Joseph and Pearl Thal. He attended school in Dayton, OH, and went on to graduate from Mercersburg Academy in Pennsylvania. He then went on to Union College until World War II began, at which time he joined the Army Air Corps. When the war concluded, Aaron went to Atlanta, GA, and became the owner/ operator of the JP Allen Store there. The Thal Co. owned women's specialty stores throughout the eastern part of the country. He was well respected in the business community and sponsored many charitable events. He had an enormous fashion sense not only for his own wardrobe, but most especially for his customers. He and his wife were active in many of Atlanta's social events. During the Christmas holiday season, no merchandise was displayed in any of the JP Allen store windows only holiday greetings to all. Mr. Thal married his wife, Nancy Braunfield, in October of 1958. She survives him along with their loving daughter Amy Thal, New York; stepdaughter, Marcy Ford, Atlanta; four grandchildren and several nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his stepdaughter, Meg Roop, of blessed memory. A private graveside service will be held at Arlington Memorial Park. The memorial service will be held at a later date at The Temple in Atlanta. Sign online guest-book: www.edressler.com. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The American Heart Association (1101 Northchase Parkway, Marietta, GA 30067). Services by Dresslers Jewish Funeral Care, 770451-4999.

LAMNECK--Joseph D., of Rye Brook, NY, died October 30, 2007 at age 79. Born August 14, 1928 in Brooklyn, NY, to Margaret (Ansbro) and Philip Lamneck, he married Kathleen Maloney on September 17, 1949. He attended St. John's University and Pratt Institute, NYC. He began his career as an art director in live TV and went on to produce numerous awardwinning TV commercials for Warner Brothers, Leo Burnett, Kenyon & Eckhardt, and others. His commitment to the sanctity of life led him to write and direct the film Champions For Life featuring NFL athletes. Joe is survived by his wife of 58 years and eight children: Kathleen Gandolfo, Denise Richards, Joann Lamneck, Ken Lamneck, Peggy Robinson, Geri Walter, Mary Pat Phillips, Terri Wyker, 12 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A life long New York Giants fan, he will be missed by all. Visitation: November 1, 2007, Craft Memorial Home, Inc, Port Chester, NY. Mass of Christian Burial: November 2, 2007, 10am, at Our Lady of Mercy Church, Port Chester, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Padre Pio Shelter, P.O. Box 55, Larchmont, NY 10538.

LAMSTEIN--Benjamin, M.D. Retired RVC Pediatrician. Deeply loved and cherished husband of Marylyn; father of Shari, Dan, Lisa, Matthew, Jill, Jonathan; grandfather of Taylor, Elise, Jeremy, Yehoshua, Andrew, Cory, Sara, Rebecca, Dena; brother of Elinor, Norman, Lorraine, Michael. Adored uncle, cousin and friend. Service Wednesday, 10am, Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Blvd., Manhasset. We will always miss your guidance and devotion. Donations to Schneider Children's Hospital, c/o North Shore LIJ Foundation, 125 Community Drive, Great Neck, NY 11021.

A ploughman's lunch in a London pub can be as fine a combination as a B.L.T., if the Cheddar, rough-cut relish and crusty bread have character. The bread and cheese are easy. But the relish? A diced vegetable concoction called Branston Pickle Relish, from the 1920s in England, is the classic choice. Now, Jon Orren, the owner of Wheelhouse Pickles in Brooklyn, has introduced his version of the relish, which he is calling Ploughman's Pickle. It has pedigree, having been seasoned with the wort (the mixture that will become beer once it ferments) of Brownstone Ale made by Sixpoint Craft Ales of Brooklyn. It's murky looking, with some nice chewy bits and mustardy spice, with a good texture for slathering on a piece of bread.

Brooklyn prosecutors said they would drop the murder case against a retired F.B.I. supervisor, Roy Lindley DeVecchio, after tapes discredited the main witness, a gangster’s mistress. The tapes came to light in a report in The Village Voice by the reporter Tom Robbins that showed that the main witness, Linda Schiro, had changed her account and damaged her credibility.

Out-of-towners traveling to New York City specifically to commit suicide have accounted for 5.3 percent of city suicides and more than 10 percent of all Manhattan suicides since 1990, according to a new research study. The two highest concentrations of such suicides took place near the George Washington Bridge, in Upper Manhattan, and in the Midtown tourism district, which includes Times Square, the Empire State Building and other skyscrapers, and most of the city’s major hotels.Nonresidents committed 21 to 40 suicides in each of those two areas from 1990 to 2004, according to the study, which is to be presented on Monday to the American Public Health Association at its annual meeting in Washington. The research paper [pdf], “Suicide Tourism in Manhattan, New York City, 1990–2004,” appears in the November/December issue of The Journal of Urban Health.

As part of eliminating TimesSelect, The New York Times has decided to make all the public domain articles from 1851–1922 available free of charge. I have invited Susan Strayer to do a guest post on why the résumé above is a recruiter's dream. As the corporate director of talent management for the Ritz-Carlton Hotel company and private career coach, Ms. Strayer has reviewed thousands of résumés. She is also the author of The Right Job, Right Now, which was published earlier this year. But before we get started, I have a caveat. I think we are getting to the point where many people (especially entrepreneurial types) won't be using traditional résumés. Instead, they will rely on narrative bios, personal Web sites, or preformatted résumés posted on social networking sites like LinkedIn. But until that time, it's wise to have a traditional résumé handy.

The Bank of Japan cut its annual economic growth forecast by 0.3 percentage points and held interest rates steady as uncertainty in the global economy continued to cloud Japan’s outlook. “The environment overseas has changed, and uncertainty over the global economy persists,” Gov. Toshihiko Fukui, left, said at a news conference. The central bank lowered its growth forecast for the fiscal year through March to 1.8 percent, from 2.1 percent in April, noting “uncertainties regarding overseas economies and global financial markets” stemming from the subprime loan crisis in the United States.

Scottish & Newcastle, fighting a takeover bid from Carlsberg, started arbitration aimed at forcing Carlsberg to give up its stake in a joint venture the companies share in Russia. Scottish & Newcastle said it would ask a Swedish tribunal “to confirm breaches” by Carlsberg in the ownership agreement for the Russian venture, Baltic Beverages Holdings. Carlsberg, based in Copenhagen, called the move a “distraction” and said it could take more than a year for the arbitration process to complete.

Penn West Energy Trust, a Canadian energy trust, agreed to acquire Canetic Resources Trust for about 3.6 billion Canadian dollars ($3.8 billion) to cushion the impact of a new tax. The combined trust would have tax pools, or accrued credits used to reduce tax payments, valued at about 5.5 billion Canadian dollars at the end of 2007, according to the statement. Canetic’s unit holders would receive 0.515 of a Penn West unit and a distribution of 9 cents a Canetic unit before the closing, according to the companies. That values the offer at 15.84 Canadian dollars for each Canetic unit, 7.1 percent above the closing price on Tuesday. Both companies are based in Calgary.

U.N. Secretary General Ban Ki-moon expressed “great concern” over information supplied him by Israel that Hezbollah had rearmed to a level higher than before the 2006 Israeli-Hezbollah war in Lebanon.
The 40-year dictatorship of Gen. Francisco Franco was formally condemned by Parliament, 32 years after his death ended his dictatorship.

European inflation accelerated in October more than economists forecast, while confidence in the economy declined, underlining the European Central Bank’s quandary over whether to raise interest rates. The inflation rate in the 13-nation euro area rose to a two-year high of 2.6 percent, from 2.1 percent in September, the European Union’s statistics office in Luxembourg said. That was above the 2.3 percent expected by economists. An index of executive and consumer sentiment fell to a 19-month low of 105.9 in October, according to a separate report.

Sanofi-Aventis, the French drug company, reported a 9 percent profit increase for the third quarter, lifted by a strong increase in the sales of vaccines and the blood-thinning drug Plavix. Sanofi also raised its forecast for 2007, saying it expected earnings per share excluding exceptional items to grow around 10 percent. Net profit after minority interests in the three months up to Sept. 30 rose to 1.85 billion euros ($2.67 billion), from 1.70 billion euros a year earlier. Net sales grew 4.4 percent, to 7.03 billion euros ($10.13 billion), ahead of analysts’ expectations of 6.92 billion euros.

Louisiana State linebacker Derrick Odom was charged with a misdemeanor yesterday, accused of smashing a car window after a brawl at a nightclub last week. Soon afterward, Coach Les Miles kicked Odom off the team.Odom faces one count of simple criminal damage to property, according to the Baton Rouge police. Miles said Odom was dismissed as was walk-on linebacker Jeremy Benton. The backup quarterback Ryan Perrilloux, who was also in the fight but was not charged, will remain on the team but will not play Saturday, when No. 3 L.S.U. faces No. 17 Alabama in Tuscaloosa, Miles said.

The last ball from Boston’s 2007 World Series victory may not get back to the Red Sox, after all. Jason Varitek caught the final strikeout Sunday night to complete a four-game sweep of Colorado, and he put the ball in his back pocket. Varitek said after the game that he would give the souvenir to the team, but yesterday he said he gave it to closer Jonathan Papelbon. Papelbon does not know where the ball is, his agent, Sam Levinson said.Ownership of the last ball became an issue in 2004, when the Red Sox swept St. Louis. Doug Mientkiewicz, who caught the final out, kept the ball. Larry Lucchino, the team president, wanted it back. A settlement was reached, and Mientkiewicz loaned the ball to the team for a year and then donated it to the Hall of Fame.

Roger Federer beat Ivo Karlovic, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3, yesterday to reach the third round of the Paris Masters and earn a chance to avenge a recent loss to David Nalbandian. Nalbandian, a 6-4, 6-4 winner over Carlos Moyá, beat Federer to win the Madrid Masters on Oct. 21 and has won both times the two have met in a final.

Tennessee tailback LaMarcus Coker and defensive tackle Demonte Bolden will miss Saturday’s game against Louisiana-Lafayette because of a violation of team rules. Bolden is a starter; Coker is a backup who returns kicks. Coach Phillip Fulmer would not elaborate on the violation.

Rau’shee Warren beat Violito Payla of the Philippines, 25-11, yesterday at the World Boxing Championships in Chicago, earning a spot in Beijing next year in the flyweight division. Warren, who was 17 when he competed in Athens in 2004, can become the first American boxer since in 1976 to participate in two Olympics.

Memory can be an odd thing. Nearly four months after Tom Bissell climbed Mount Kilimanjaro, suffering through pounding headaches from altitude sickness, the pain is almost forgotten. The memories that remain, Bissell said this week, are of the good stuff: the camaraderie, the great treatment by the 39 porters and four guides who helped his group, and the amazing views. “Any way you cut it,” he said, “it was breathtakingly beautiful.”.

PICCIONE--Jean M. Widow of Joseph John Piccione, died 29th of October after a full life and brief illness. Greatly loved, and dearly missed by her three sons Russell of NYC and Shelter Island, NY, Ronald and his partner David Enloe of NYC and Deer Isle, ME, and Joseph John with his wife Nancy (nee Myers), and three grandchildren, all of Metamora, IL. Funeral services to be held privately Friday November 2.

RAMOS--Victor. Passed away on October 21 at age 77, after a short bout with pneumonia. Ramos, born in Los Angeles, was the son of Victor Ramos, Sr. There are no family survivors. After his wife, Virginia Loew, died in 1964, Ramos came to New York and enjoyed great success as a casting director throughout the 1970s and 1980s, helping to cast more than 25 films and television shows. In 1981 he founded Ramos Management, a talent management agency. Friends, clients and colleagues will gather for a Memorial Service at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue at 2:30pm on Friday, November 9th. Contributions in Victor Ramos' honor should be made to The Ailey School, 405 West 55th Street, New York, NY. Sandy Erickson, Ramos Management

SUNG--Hsi - Yuan, passed peacefully in White Plains on October 28th, 2007 at the age of 86 surrounded by his beloved wife Chinyee, and children Tina, Victor, Cynthia, Alan, and Andy. Also survived by eight granddaughters and brother Hsi-Heng. Proudly served in the United Nations for 50 years as translator and interpreter. Loved travel and Chinese literature. Born January 26, 1921 in Nanjing, China. Graduated National Southwest United University in Kunming, China; MA University of Illinois. The funeral will be at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave, New York, on November 3rd, 9:30am. Memorial contributions may be made to Lowenthal Infusion Center, White Plains Hospital, Davis Ave., White Plains, NY 10601.

GRAY--Jonathan Ellis, age 59, was finally defeated by esophageal cancer on October 29th, 2007, after a heroic, six-year struggle with the disease. Beloved husband of Bonnie (Ellin), proud father of sons Jordan and Zachary, devoted son to Harriet and the late Phillip Gray, and loving brother to Esther Gray Peacock, Jonathan was never without the warmth of family. A securities analyst following the savings and loans industry and government sponsored enterprises, Jonathan reigned as the number one researcher in his field for 29 illustrious years at Sanford C. Bernstein & Co. and its successor firm, Alliance Bernstein. Following his diagnosis, Jonathan devoted the remainder of his life to the scientific, financial, and political pursuit of a cure for cancer-for the sake of himself and the rest of humanity. Impassioned scholar, respected professional, family man, and a paradigm of moral purity, Jonathan embodied all that an individual should aspire to be. We will miss him. Services today, 10:30am, Central Synagogue, Lexington Ave and 55th St. GRAY--Jonathan E. The Rockefeller University deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend Jonathan Gray. A member of The Rockefeller University Council, Jonathan was an impassioned advocate for the advancement of biomedical research. With his beloved wife, Bonnie, also a member of the Council, he championed the pursuit of scientific knowledge that is the hallmark of the University. He applied his formidable talents and his personal warmth to strengthening the Precollege Science Outreach Program at Rockefeller. His agile mind and indomitable spirit informed his tireless pursuit of a cure for cancer and inspired all who met him. We are saddened that Jonathan's time with us was cut short and in his memory we renew our commitment to transforming biomedicine for the benefit of humanity. Our deepest condolences are sent to his wife, Bonnie, and his sons Jordan and Zachary, and to his entire family. Paul Nurse, President Russell L. Carson, Chairman Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Bonnie Kaiser, Precollege Science Outreach Program GRAY--Jonathan. Alan Levine, Alison Newman, David M. Warren, and the other partners and employees of Cooley Godward Kronish wish to express their sorrow at the passing of Jonathan Gray. Jonathan was a valued client, a dear friend, and a man of enormous talents and achievements. We extend our condolences and sincerest sympathy to his wife, Bonnie, and to his sons, Jason and Zachary. GRAY--Jonathan, to our dear friend and partner -we are inspired by your spirit and intelligence. Our hearts go out to Bonnie, Jordan and Zachary. Ron and Jane Zimmerman Ron and Linda Mandle

TAYLOR--Ann Bonfoey, died peacefully at her Denver home on Sunday, October 28, 2007 surrounded by loving family members. Born December 3, 1910 in Ardmore, PA and raised in Quincy, IL. Ann exhibited an early passion when as a six year old her father introduced her to flying in open two-seater biplanes. At twelve years of age her father hired a pilot to teach Ann to fly and despite the then all-male atmosphere of the age and a resentful teacher, Ann learned to fly and loved it. Married to James Cooke in 1928. They had two children, Diane and Jay. Early in their marriage, Ann's expertise at tennis led her to competing at Wimbleton. Ann moved to Vermont after marrying. Ever the sportswoman, she started ski racing in Stowe, acquiring the nickname Nose-dive Annie. She became an alternate in 1939 on the Womens Olympic Ski Team, skiing until her late 80s. Ann's marriage to James ended. She then turned to civil engineering and the study of flying, leading to the pursuit of a pilot's license. When World War II broke out, she became a flight instructor for flight students, which included Navy and Army pilots. After the end of the war, Ann returned to Stowe where a great sense of style led her to design her own ski clothing which became very popular. Very shortly her clothing appeared on the covers of Harpers Bazaar and other magazines and in the Fifth Avenue windows of Lord and Taylor, as well as other prominent Fifth Avenue retailers. In l947, after a whirlwind courtship, Ann married Vernon ''Moose'' Taylor, Jr., of Indiana, PA and San Antonio, TX. Ann realized her new-found success would have practical limits and decided to give up her new career to become a full-time wife and mother. In l954 Ann and ''Moose'' moved to Denver where they raised their family. It was in Denver that Ann developed a passion for horses and become an expert in dressage, hunting and jumping which she and ''Moose'' engaged in not only in Denver, but also in Middleburg, Virginia and Leicestershire, England, riding into their late 80s. ''Moose'', even in their earliest courtship said he wanted to build a ski house with Ann. In l963, as one of the founders of Vail, they built one of the first ski chalets in the new town where they thrived skiing with family and friends over 40 years. In addition to Vail, Ann and ''Moose'' had a cattle ranch in Montana where they held their annual Fourth of July gettogether for family and friends from around the world for many years. Ann also served on the Advisory Board of the American Associates of the Royal Academy Trust and the World Wildlife Fund. Ann was predeceased by her daughter Diane Cooke and grandson Ryan Taylor. She is survived by her loving husband and children, Jay Cooke (Gail) of New York City; Vernon Taylor, III (Naomi Marks) of Long Island; Douglas Taylor (Monica) of New York City; Robert Taylor (Joni) of Vail; and Craig Taylor (Michelle) of Santa Barbara, California and eleven grandchildren. A private service is being held for family members. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations be made to the American Associates of the Royal Academy Trust, 555 Madison Ave., Ste. 1300, New York, NY 10022 or a charity of choice.

Archivia, the long-lamented art, architecture and design bookstore that shut its doors on the Upper East Side six years ago, has reopened on Lexington Avenue, four blocks from its original location. The store, which was a regular haunt of curators from the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Frick, as well as a slew of designers, has doubled its size, to 800 square feet, and is done in blond wood with a Verner Panton chandelier. Already, designers like Charlotte Moss, David Netto and Carolina Irving have descended on it. Even the windows are stylish: This week's display is devoted to Liz O'Brien's ''UltraModern'' ($95), a monograph of architect Samuel Marx's work, surrounded by original Marx drawings and furniture. Archivia Books, 993 Lexington Avenue (72nd Street), (212) 570-9565 or www.archiviabooks.com. BROOK S. MASON

JENSEN--Edward, 92, died peacefully at home on October 27 in Delray Beach, FL, with his family by his side. The beloved husband of Patricia Murcott for almost 57 years, he is also survived by his children, Richard and Claudia Jensen of Larchmont, NY, Kathleen Jensen and James Barnes of Dunwoody, GA, Deborah and Peter Rice of Centreville, VA, Christopher and Christine Jensen of Riverside, CT, and Patricia Jensen and Paul Fehlner of Ridgewood, NJ, as well as his 18 adoring grandchildren, Caroline, Hilary, Josh, Jimmy, Ned, Kirsten, Meg, Christian, Nicholas, Peter, Callie, Leigh, Emily, Luke, Tommy, Andie, Kaj, Aksel and Kiri. Edward is survived by his sisters Helga Bennett, Doris Gifford and Ellen Chassell, and was predeceased by his brother Erik. Born Soren Anton Edvard Jensen on August 23, 1915 in a logging camp in Kingman, ME to Danish immigrants Karoline and Aksel Jensen, and raised in Washington Depot, CT, and Ridgewood, Queens, Edward graduated from Newtown H.S. in 1933. He began working for Borden's in 1932 and retired as General Manager of the Borden Flavor Dept. in Brooklyn in 1978. He served as a regimental sergeant - major with the Victory Division's 24th Infantry Regiment in WWII in the South Pacific, and his battle experience included landing on Leyte's A-Day as well as operations in New Guinea, Biak, Luzon, Bataan, Corregidor and Mindanao. He was a true patriot who vehemently opposed the war in Iraq. Known for his intelligence and quick wit, Edward was an avid reader of the Times for 85 years, and continued to complete the crossword puzzles in pen until his death. We remember him as an incredibly hard-working, loving father and husband who wanted the best for his family. A memorial service will be held in the NYC area in December.

FED LOWERS SHORT-TERM RATES The Federal Reserve gave investors what they wanted, lowering short-term rates by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 4.5 percent. But it pointedly warned Wall Street not to assume that more reductions were ahead. For stock investors, the Federal Reserve delivered just the right tonic. But in the bond, commodities and currency markets, investors worried that cheaper credit would stoke inflation. [C4.]

LAMNECK--Joseph D., of Rye Brook, NY, died October 30, 2007 at age 79. Born August 14, 1928 in Brooklyn, NY, to Margaret (Ansbro) and Philip Lamneck, he married Kathleen Maloney on September 17, 1949. He attended St. John's Universityand Pratt Institute, NYC. He began his career as an art director in live TV and went on to produce numerous award-winning TV commercials for Warner Brothers, Leo Burnett, Kenyon & Eckhardt, and others. His commitment to the sanctity of life led him to write and direct the film Champions For Life featuring NFL athletes. Joe is survived by his wife of 58 years and eight children: Kathleen Gandolfo, Denise Richards, Joann Lamneck, Ken Lamneck, Peggy Robinson, Geri Walter, Mary Pat Phillips, Terri Wyker, 12 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A life long New York Giants fan, he will be missed by all. Visitation: November 1, 2007, Craft Memorial Home, Inc, Port Chester, NY. Mass of Christian Burial: November 2, 2007, 10am, at Our Lady of Mercy Church, Port Chester, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Padre Pio Shelter, P.O. Box 55, Larchmont, NY 10538.

EVEN the thought of trying to strap on leaky, foggy raccoon-eye goggles is enough to sink the workout of many swimmers. But just as indoor pools are heating up for the winter, new underwater eye gear has surfaced. This season's fleet of swim goggles includes anti-fog lenses, fluted frames and UV protection. Silicone straps and gaskets, along with streamlined clips, have been designed to provide better comfort and easy adjustment while sealing out the pool water.

9 P.M. (HBO) TO DIE IN JERUSALEM In 2002 two teenage girls -- Rachel Levy, a 17-year-old Israeli, and Ayat al-Akhras, an 18-year-old Palestinian suicide bomber -- attractive, intelligent students with long brown hair who could have been mistaken for sisters, died together in a Jerusalem market. The incident led Ms. Levy's mother, Avigail, above left, to speak with Um Samir, above right, the mother of her daughter's killer. This documentary by Hilla Medalia chronicles that heart-rending encounter four years after the bombing. ''The film doesn't suggest a solution to the conflict, but it unabashedly explores the difficulties, fears and gaps between opposing sides,'' Ms. Medalia has said. ''However, as Avigail Levy and Um Samir al-Akhras agree to meet, a channel of communication begins to evolve, and with it, new hope for a better future.'' 8 P.M. (CW) SMALLVILLE Kara is captured and given a kryptonite serum, and Clark tries to rescue her -- but not before they've both had a vision of his mother (Helen Slater).
