There are many ways to describe the high-tech hideaway bed called the Zoom-Room: A mattress that is stored vertically behind cabinets or an entertainment center, and that, with the push of a remote control button, slips down the wall and out into the room like an enormous upholstered snake. A German-made bed that rests on bowed beechwood flats and uses a mechanism reminiscent of an automated garage door, if you can picture a garage door mechanism upside down. An irresistible piece of equipment with which to torment a cat. Then there's the description offered by Peter Medvin, the owner of Zoom-Room, who is importing the bed from Germany.

Ann Gish is holding her annual sale of sample, discontinued and overstocked linens next week, from Nov. 5 to 16, just in time for holiday shopping. Silk sheets, coverlets, pillows, duvets and table linens sold at department stores like Neiman Marcus and Bloomingdale's will be sold at 50 to 90 percent off retail. The November plaid pillow, shown, will be $85 (marked down from $200), and the queen-size quilted silk coverlet will be $270 (reduced from $1,100). Other silk coverlets, regularly $350 to $1,200, will be $100 to $300, and washable silk pillowcases, usually $40, will be $13. The sale will be held at 599 11th Avenue (45th Street); information: (212) 969-9200. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

HAVENS--Oliver Hershman, of Jupiter Island, Florida died on October 28, 2007 from complications of Parkinson's Disease. He was born on July 19, 1917 in Bradley Beach, NJ to the late Abram Vaughn Havens and Sara Mildred Atkinson Havens. He grew up in Westfield, NJ, attended public schools there and graduated Magna Cum Laude in Economics from Princeton University in 1939. He received a Bachelor of Laws (JD) degree from Yale Law School in 1942, and immediately entered the U.S. Army where he served in the American, European and Pacific theaters. He was released from active duty as Captain in the Signal Corps in 1946, and joined the Wall Street law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel as an associate and was admitted to the firm as partner in 1955 and retired in 1982. From 1976 to 1979, he was the firm's resident partner in Paris. He was admitted to the New York Bar in 1947 and to the Conseil Juridique in France in 1978 and was a member of the American Bar Association, the New York State Bar Association, and the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and an original member of the latter's Special Committee on Securities Regulation. A lifelong Episcopalian, Oliver served on the vestries (and in other capacities) at St. Paul's Church, Westfield, NJ, the American Cathedral in Paris, Christ Church, Short Hills, NJ, and Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island, FL. In his retirement he served as General Counsel to the United States Golf Association from 1985-1988 and was the Mayor of the Town of Jupiter Island from 1987-1993. An avid, golfer, Oliver belonged to Echo Lake Country Club, Baltusrol Golf Club, and Pine Valley Golf Club in New Jersey, and the Jupiter Island Club and Seminole Golf Club in Florida, and the Sportive du Golf de St. Cloud, France, and Royal & Ancient of St. Andrews, Scotland. He was also a member of the Short Hills Club, the Princeton Club of NY, India House, and the Nassau Club, Princeton. Oliver married the former Ervanna Josephine Cummings in 1941, who preceded him in death. He is survived by his wife of 30 years, Elizabeth Lykes Carrere Havens and by his brother, Joseph Buckley Havens and wife Elizabeth Darlington Havens, of Kennebunk, ME, and by his daughters Jan Havens Greer and husband Chilton Greer of Houston, TX and Judi Havens and husband Jerry Ferrari of Marion, MA, and his grandchildren Andrea Greer, C. Tobin Greer, Matthew Bullard, and Kate Sherman. He is also survived by his wife's children John Carrere and wife Claire, Michael Carrere and wife Elizabeth, Margaret Johnson and husband Kevin, and Joseph Carrere and wife Michele. A memorial service will be held at a later date at Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island. In lieu of flowers. donations may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, Palm Beach, FL 33407 or to the charity of your choice.

Pursuing an initial inquiry into abuses in the student-loan industry, the Education Department said it had sent letters to 55 colleges and 23 lenders, asking for details of the colleges' relationships with lenders. The 55 are winnowed down from an initial round of 921 colleges that were questioned last spring and process many federally backed loans. At 48 of the colleges, a single lender holds 95 percent of the loans. Additionally, the department is publishing final rules today in The Federal Register that first proposed in June, barring gifts from lenders to universities, including travel and other perks.

The New York Review of Books this week would have you believe that you'll learn a lot about Diane Keaton from a new book, ''California Romantica.'' A collection of 20 houses from the heyday of what is known as the California Style -- a bit Mission, a bit Spanish revival, always mestizo, or of mixed ancestry -- this moodily photographed portfolio of 1920s architecture is introduced by Ms. Keaton, who has restored and lived in two such houses. The textual pleasures, though, come from the writing of D. J. Waldie, a contributor to The Los Angeles Times and the author of ''Holy Land: A Suburban Memoir,'' who is a gorgeous distiller of architectural and social history. If you're yearning for remembrances of Ms. Keaton, snack on Larry McMurtry's essay in the aforementioned magazine. ''California Romantica'' (Rizzoli) is $65. PENELOPE GREEN

Because of an editing error, a picture caption with an article on Oct. 21 about young voters in Poland's parliamentary elections misidentified the woman in the center shown with two colleagues at a Warsaw cafe, and because of an editing error, a correction in this space on Oct. 23 misstated the gender of the colleague shown on the left. The woman is Marta Poslad -- not Kasia Szajewska, the colleague. As stated in the article, Kasia Szajewska is a woman.

Anthony Aziz and Sammy Cucher, Manhattan-based artists and life partners, saw the ''Tapestry in the Renaissance'' exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art five years ago and had an epiphany. ''It blew us away,'' Mr. Aziz said. ''We thought we should try our hand at weaving.'' Nightgarden, shown, is part of their first collection of nine rugs for NyingZemo, a Nepalese manufacturing company. The artists created the mysteriously colored floral pattern by digitally manipulating a photograph of passionflowers. The hand-knotted rug is wool, silk and cotton, and comes in various sizes, from 6 by 9 feet ($9,450) to 10 by 14 feet ($24,500); custom colors and sizes are also available. A + C Studio, 134 West 26th Street, (646) 234-0559 or www.ac4nz.com. ELAINE LOUIE

The Basics column in Science Times on Tuesday, about a rigorous high school physics class in the Academy of Science program in Loudoun County, Va., referred incorrectly to Newton's law of inertia. It is Newton's first law of motion, not second. (The second law states that acceleration of an object is equal to the force applied on it divided by its mass.)

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced today his support for a national carbon tax. In what his aides called one of the most significant policy addresses of his second and final term, the mayor argued that directly taxing emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases that contribute to climate change will slow global warming, promote economic growth and stimulate technological innovation — even if it results in higher gasoline prices in the short term.

I realize that this is always an irksome issue in translation: perfect fidelity versus greater felicity. So let me just go on record as saying that when my work is translated into other languages, I give my translators full permission to fix my mistakes, and to make my work sound more graceful and elegant, better - rather than clumsier and worse - than it is in English. Ultimately, the pleasure of the reader should trump even the brilliance of the translator.

Now I am not at all religious. But I've always thought that one of the great experiences that most visitors to Rome overlook is the chance to see the Pope -- live and in action. Of course, they visit the Colosseum, the Trevi Fountain and the Vatican Museums. So why not check out the Pope himself? It is a bit of living history and you can see the Pope without much trouble (no lines, no metal detectors!), when he delivers his weekly message to the crowds in St. Peters Square.

Thursday night, with Sam's strongly-voiced, fair-minded support of Mr. Pevear and Ms. Volokhonsky's translation of "War and Peace" much on my mind, I sat in an auditorium at the Morgan Library, listening to the new curator of literary and historical manuscripts, Declan Kiely, speak on some of the gems in the library's collection. One of these was a handwritten draft of a broadcast E.M. Forster delivered on the BBC Radio's Far Eastern Service in 1943, about Marcel Proust and "The Remembrance of Things Past."* In the broadcast, Forster argued that "Remembrance" was the second greatest novel in European literature ("War and Peace" being the first, though he scants it in the essay); and that, as such, readers needed to understand better how to read Proust to get from him what they should. "Be patient with him," Forster urged. "He does not go with a swing, and only gradually draws you into his mesh. And be intelligent. It is so easy to read books stupidly, not with our full powers, and Proust makes no concessions to stupidity. Some writers - and they are great writers - do make concessions. Dickens does, for instance, and even Tolstoy does. Proust doesn't. He expects a constant awareness, both from the mind and from the senses."

Chrysler announced Thursday it would eliminate 11,000 hourly and salaried jobs in the United States and Canada and cut shifts of workers at five plants. The decision comes on top of a plan, announced in February, to eliminate 13,000 jobs and close a factory in Newark, Del. Taken together, Chrysler will be reducing its 2006 work force of about 80,000 employees by 30 percent.

MetroPCS, which made an unsolicited takeover bid in September, now says that despite "widespread investor and analyst enthusiasm" for a deal, it could not engage the target in "meaningful negotiations."

A Halloween night clash between groups of youths in Howard Beach ended with two white teenagers injured and five minority suspects arrested on charges of assault, the police said, adding that the incident is under investigation for possible bias crimes. Investigators said the dispute began with a minority youth approaching whites and glaring at them. A white youth tossed an egg toward him, but missed, the police said. Then, 30 to 40 minority youths gathered and chased the whites, two of whom ran into a McDonald’s restaurant. Some minority youths pursued them, the police said, punching one in the face and hitting the other with a stickball bat, causing a head injury requiring seven staples and an overnight hospitalization. One antiwhite epithet was reported by a restaurant worker. The attack occurred in Howard Beach, a predominantly white community where racial tension and violence have flared before. In 1986, Michael Griffiths, one of three black visitors fleeing an attack by whites, darted into a street and was hit and killed by a car.

Athletes who finished behind Marion Jones, who returned the five medals she won at the 2000 Sydney Games after admitting to steroid use, will move up in order, the International Olympic Committee chief, Jacques Rogge, said. “We move them up,” Rogge said during a forum at a New York hotel. Rogge said top finishers down to five places were automatically tested by the I.O.C., along with three random finishers, and their results were stored for eight years so they would be cleared to be awarded medals.Jones won gold in the 100 meters, 200 meters and 4x400 meter relay in Sydney. She took bronze medals in the long jump and 4x100 meter relay.

An article on Saturday about the potential payout to E. Stanley O’Neal upon his departure as chief executive of Merrill Lynch misstated the amount of money he was paid in his five years on the job. It was more than $70 million, not “roughly $160 million.” (His payout is expected to be at least $159 million.).

An article yesterday about the acquittal of a former federal prosecutor on charges that he illegally withheld evidence from defense lawyers in a major terrorism case misstated his given name. He is Richard G. Convertino, not Robert. A picture caption misspelled the surname of another lawyer and misstated his role in the case. He is Thomas Cranmer, not Crammer, and he represented Mr. Convertino’s co-defendant, Harry R. Smith III, who was also acquitted; Mr. Cranmer was not the lawyer for Mr. Convertino.

The Books of The Times review on Wednesday, about “The Star Machine,” by Jeanine Basinger, misspelled the given name of an emerging star who appeared in the 1932 film “Three on a Match.” She was Ann Dvorak, not Anne.

Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about African-American executives misstated the employment plans of Time Warner’s chief executive, Richard D. Parsons. Mr. Parsons’s contract with Time Warner expires in May; he has not announced plans to retire in March.

A report in the “Arts, Briefly” column on Tuesday about the bequest of 18 paintings to two British museums misspelled the given name of one artist whose work is included in the bequest. He is Lucian Freud, not Lucien.

An article on Monday about Superheroes Anonymous, a group of volunteers who gathered near Times Square to publicize their efforts to make their communities cleaner and safer, included an imprecise reference from one participant, Chaim Lazaros, who spoke at the event. He is a co-founder of the group, along with Ben Goldman; Mr. Lazaros is not the sole founder.

Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 11 about a meeting on climate change attended by Nobel Prize laureates noted for their environmental work misstated the position of the United States on the Kyoto Protocol, the international treaty aimed at fighting global warming. It was signed by the United States but not ratified by the Senate; the United States did not refuse to sign the treaty.

An obituary on Oct. 12 about Bud Ekins, a motorcycle and auto stunt driver, referred incorrectly to two of his stunts in the 1968 crime thriller “Bullitt.” Mr. Ekins drove a Ford Mustang, not a Dodge Charger, as he doubled for Steve McQueen in part of the famous chase scene; the villains were in the Charger. In another scene, in which he laid down his motorcycle in front of a skidding truck, he played an innocent stranger who had been riding by; he was not doubling for Mr. McQueen.

An article on Saturday about the death of a New York City public school student who had been infected with a virulent, drug-resistant strain of bacteria misstated the given name and, because of an editing error, the title of a city official who discussed steps taken to clean Intermediate School 211, which the student attended. The official is James Lonergan, not Joel, and he is the chief executive of all school facilities, not the head of school facilities at I.S. 211.

A picture caption on Wednesday with a review of “The Leopard and the Fox,” a play about the overthrow of Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan in 1977, at the TBG Theater in Manhattan, misidentified the actor playing a Washington reporter. He is Michael Crane — not Dave Cherry, the character he played.

Because of an editing error, an article on Oct. 11 about a meeting on climate change attended by Nobel Prize laureates noted for their environmental work misstated the position of the United States on the Kyoto Protocol, the international treaty aimed at fighting global warming. It was signed by the United States but not ratified by the Senate; the United States did not refuse to sign the treaty.

Chargers cornerback Drayton Florence has been fined $15,000 by the N.F.L. for his helmet-to-helmet hit that gave Houston quarterback Matt Schaub a concussion. Florence hit Schaub after he threw his second interception of the game Sunday. Schaub did not return. It was the second consecutive week Schaub was knocked out of the game by a helmet-to-helmet blow. He will not start Sunday’s game against Oakland.

The Indianapolis Colts practiced again without the eight-time Pro Bowl receiver Marvin Harrison and may not have him against New England on Sunday. Harrison sat out for the second consecutive day with a bruised left knee that has forced him to miss two of the last three games. “If he doesn’t practice today, I’d say it’s doubtful he’ll play Sunday,” Coach Tony Dungy said before the workout.

The suspended cornerback Pacman Jones will meet with Roger Goodell, the N.F.L. commissioner, in New York today about a possible early reinstatement. Goodell suspended Jones, a Tennessee cornerback, in April for the 2007 season.

A judge in Norristown, Pa., who sentenced the sons of Philadelphia Eagles Coach Andy Reid to jail yesterday likened the coach’s home to “a drug emporium” and questioned whether his adult sons should live there, given their drug problems. Montgomery County Judge Steven O’Neill noted that searches of the Reid family’s home and vehicles found a long list of drugs, guns and ammunition.“There isn’t any structure there that this court can depend upon,” O’Neill said before sentencing Reid’s son Britt to up to 23 months in jail plus probation.Earlier yesterday, O’Neill sentenced Garrett Reid, a drug addict and a dealer, to up to 23 months in jail for smashing into another motorist’s car while high on heroin.

An outbreak of cholera in Congo’s eastern city of Goma is raising fears of an epidemic among tens of thousands of refugees in camps, aid workers said.

A man accused of murder in the killings of a Cheshire woman and her two daughters in July pleaded not guilty yesterday, while his lawyers accused the Cheshire Police Department of leaking details about the case to a local newspaper. The suspect, Steven Hayes, 44, of Winsted, also waived his right to a probable-cause hearing in his 10-minute appearance under heavy security in State Superior Court. A second man, Joshua Komisarjevsky, 27, of Cheshire, pleaded not guilty on Tuesday. The men are charged in the deaths of Jennifer Hawke-Petit, 48, and her daughters Hayley, 17, and Michaela, 11, in a home invasion on July 23. Judge Richard A. Damiani scheduled a hearing for Tuesday to consider the defense lawyers’ request for a gag order. Lt. Jay Markella of the Cheshire police said the lawyers’ allegations were unsubstantiated.

A Bronx man convicted of manslaughter last month in the fatal beating of his girlfriend’s 4-year-old son was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 15 years in prison. The man, Jose Calderon, 19, left, was convicted on Oct. 17 for acting recklessly in the beating death of the boy, Quachaun Browne, in January 2006. Quachaun’s mother, Aleshia Smith, 28, pleaded guilty this year to manslaughter for failing to seek immediate medical attention for her son. She is serving 2 ½ to 7 ½ years in prison.

A fire on Tuesday killed 13,000 to 15,000 ducks at the nation’s largest producer of foie gras, the company said yesterday. The fire may have been caused by a short circuit in a boiler in the duck coop, said Michael Ginor, president of the company, Hudson Valley Foie Gras. But the loss of the ducks will not hurt the production of foie gras, he said. The ducks that died, female Pekins, had been set aside to breed with Muscovy males to produce the Moulard ducks that are used for foie gras. Mr. Ginor estimated the loss at more than $100,000.

A security guard who tried to stop a group of young men who were throwing eggs on Halloween night was fighting for his life yesterday after being shot in the head and chest, the Mount Vernon police commissioner said. The guard, Neville Webb, 52, of North White Plains, was in extremely critical condition at Jacobi Medical Center in the Bronx after being shoot in Mount Vernon, Commissioner David Chong said. Just before 9 p.m., Mr. Chong said, Mr. Webb, a former correction officer, tried to break up a group of young men who were throwing eggs at cars and people on East Lincoln Avenue. Mr. Webb’s son Christopher Webb is a candidate for the Mount Vernon City Council.

The former mayor of Atlantic City, who was missing for two weeks amid questions over his war record, pleaded guilty yesterday to lying to enhance his veterans benefits. The former mayor, Robert W. Levy, 60, who was making his first public appearance since stepping down from office on Oct. 10, admitted in Federal District Court that he had falsely claimed to have been awarded two military medals and had embellished his record. A claim by Mr. Levy, above, that he was a member of the elite Green Berets during the Vietnam War was exposed as a lie last year by The Press of Atlantic City.

Four people were shot and one was stabbed in Union Square early yesterday, the police said. The shooting took place about 12:45 a.m. at Union Square West and East 14th Street. The shooting victims, young men ages 19, 18, 19 and 15, were taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where they were in stable condition, the police said. Officers who responded to a report of shots also found an 18-year-old man who had been stabbed, the police said. He was in serious condition at St. Vincent’s Hospital. The police said the matter was under investigation and could not say what led to the violence.

Gov. M. Jodi Rell announced yesterday that the state had filed a lawsuit to block a new Federal Aviation Administration plan to reroute as many as 150 planes a day over southwestern Connecticut to relieve congestion. At New Canaan Town Hall, she said that the agency, contrary to federal law, had failed to consider safety and environmental issues and the effect on residents’ quality of life.

The owners of Madison Square Garden will modify the arena to provide greater access to people with physical disabilities, federal prosecutors said yesterday. Under the agreement announced by Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan, the owners will add 50 wheelchair-accessible seats and make other changes to increase access. In a statement, a Madison Square Garden spokesman, Barry Watkins, said the owners had worked for several years to reach an agreement with the government over how best to modify the arena, which was built in 1968.

The United States Department of Labor announced yesterday that it had recovered more than $66,000 in back wages on behalf of 46 workers at seven nail salons in New York City. The department said it had uncovered minimum-wage and overtime violations as part of an initiative to help low-wage workers. The department found violations at Classic Nails; Nails on 54th; Fifth Avenue Beauty; Hair, Nails and Tanning; and several other salons.
Even as Ford posted its 12th consecutive monthly U.S. sales decline, General Motors and Toyota each gained market share in October on higher truck sales.
Joe Girardi was announced as the new manager of the Yankees Thursday, ready to take his turn at chasing the team’s 27th title.

After the 2005 transit strike, a judge took away a powerful money-raising tool from the Transport Workers Union, but now the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is urging its restoration.

Meryl Streep will portray Julia Child in the movie “Julie & Julia,” being adapted by Nora Ephron from the Julie Powell book “Julie and Julia: 365 Days, 524 Recipes, 1 Tiny Apartment Kitchen,” Variety reported. The lawyer for the British pop singer Amy Winehouse, below, said yesterday that she will appeal her fine last month for marijuana possession in Norway because she did not understand that under Norwegian law, accepting a fine amounts to pleading guilty, The Associated Press reported. The lawyer, Ole Kvelstad, contended that she had been questioned without legal representation or an interpreter and had not understood the Norwegian-language charges she signed. He said that pleading guilty in a drug case could have serious consequences when Ms. Winehouse, who has spoken openly about her taste for marijuana and alcohol, seeks to enter the United States. Police Attorney Rudolf Christoffersen of Bergen said she was questioned by an English-speaking officer, who translated the charges and explained the consequences of accepting the fine. Ms. Winehouse and her husband, Blake Fielder-Civil, were arrested in Bergen on Oct. 18 and held overnight on charges of illegal drug possession. They were released the next morning after paying fines of $715 each for possessing a quarter-ounce of marijuana.

To the Editor: Re “Home, Sweet {hellip} Yikes!” (Oct. 26): It’s not only relocated urbanites who have trouble with the country. Robert Frost, America’s poet laureate of snowy woods, golden maples and roads not taken, addresses the subject in three little-known, but chilling poems, “The Fear,” “The Oft-Repeated Dream,” and “House Fear,” which reads in part: “Always — I tell you this they learned — / Always at night when they returned {hellip} They learned to leave the house-door wide/ Until they had lit the lamp inside.”William Lach.

So how does Richard Garriott's Tabula Rasa stack up? The thing to understand is that playing a ''massively multiplayer'' online game, or M.M.O., is a commitment -- both of money and time -- unlike any other electronic diversion. M.M.O. players routinely spend hundreds or even thousands of hours on their favorite games over many years. All of that time is an investment in building up the powers and abilities of one's virtual identity, not to mention the fun of adventuring with friends. For all that, players generally spend around $15 a month.

'BERLIN: SYMPHONY OF A CITY' Who wouldn't jump at the chance to be transported to Berlin at the height of its Weimar glamour? Part of the thrill of watching Walther Ruttmann's 1927 film ''Berlin: Symphony of a City'' is the almost encyclopedic way it documents the metropolis, from the empty streets at dawn to the nightclubs and bright marquees of midnight. In between it shows you, well, everything: the sewers and sparkling office buildings; factories, printing presses and mechanized gewgaws in shop windows; postmen, milkmen, street cleaners; schoolchildren and bustling street life; dogs and cats (and an elephant and hippo); horse-drawn carts, cars and trains (lots and lots of trains). Before directing ''Symphony of a City'' -- showing tomorrow as part of Carnegie Hall's ''Berlin in Lights'' series, in partnership with the Museum of Modern Art -- Ruttmann made avant-garde films, evident here in his accent on form and the flow of images. Laurence Kardish, senior curator in MoMA's department of film, said that while ''Symphony'' was ''made with the idea that a score would be played with it,'' the visual aspect ''carries its own rhythm, its own velocity, its own speed.'' Because the original score, by Edmund Meisel (who also wrote music for ''Battleship Potemkin'') was lost, Mr. Kardish said that he, like many movie scholars, only knows ''the film as a silent work.''

'THE USUAL FREAK SHOW' In the mid-1980s Jeffrey Essmann was writing and performing satirical character comedy, revuelike shows that were neither theater nor exactly cabaret. ''The whole East Village thing was kicking in,'' he said recently, describing a scene busy with performers trying new things in joints now long gone. ''It wasn't even worth remembering the names of the clubs because they only lasted a few weekends.'' His sidekick, who composed and played the piano in shows like ''Jeffrey Essmann's Artificial Reality,'' was Michael John LaChiusa, who yet to write the musicals ''The Wild Party'' and ''See What I Wanna See.'' Despite good reviews into the early 1990s, Mr. Essmann, above, eventually became frustrated that his career was not taking off. ''As far as I was concerned I was still working in a video store,'' he said. So he left for Chicago.

CABARET CONVENTION The durability of the New York Cabaret Convention is a reassuring sign of continuity in a show business climate where mass recognition nowadays can be as fleeting as a flash of YouTube notoriety. Celebrating its 18th year, this long-running fusion of national trade show and marathon concert series was founded by Donald Smith, the intrepidly dedicated executive director of the Mabel Mercer Foundation. The four concerts, Monday through Thursday, honor the great American songbook (with British side trips) and the performers who bring it to life. It's one of the few big-ticket musical events in which yesterday becomes today and tomorrow.

Tomorrow morning, 134 American distance runners will compete in the United States Olympic marathon trials in New York. TAKEOVER The powers that be at the Brooklyn Academy of Music are very trusting. Tomorrow they are opening all the public spaces in their buildings for an all-night event called Takeover. Starting at 9 p.m. as many as 2,500 hipsters will descend on the august Howard Gilman Opera House for performances by five bands, including local acts like Dirty on Purpose, above, and the Antibalas orchestra, as well as Be Your Own Pet, young, lo-fi punks from Nashville. At Rose Cinemas are music films like ''Stop Making Sense'' and ''Gimme Shelter''; ''When Animals Hug,'' a series featuring shorts of adorable critters; and a retrospective of the Lindsay Lohan oeuvre, such as it is. D.J.'s will create a dance party atmosphere in the cafe; the Mighty Robot A/V squad will design a live video loop of the crowd. No nook will go un-cultured. Works by artists like Jean Shin, who contributed a sculpture made of melted records, and Leo Villareal, who was commissioned to create a piece using 14,000 L.E.D. lights, will be displayed throughout; roving burlesque performers will even fill the stairwells and lounges.

Built in 2004, this house has a detached 432-square-foot in-law suite with one bathroom, a kitchenette and a living room. The main house, located on a peninsula called Martins Point, is 2,484 square feet and has three and a half bathrooms, a detached two-car garage and a large screened porch. The interior includes custom cabinets, a wood-burning fireplace and a surround-sound system. Agent: Brad Beacham, Beach Realty and Construction, (252) 261-3815; www.bradbeacham.com.

Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about a bill debated in the Spanish parliament that would honor victims of the 1936-39 civil war and those who endured the repression that followed under the dictatorship of Francisco Franco misidentified, in some editions, the side responsible for the killing of thousands of Roman Catholic clergy members during the early phase of the war. It was the Republican forces who opposed Franco -- not the forces allied with him, which included many clergy members.

Situated about five minutes from the town of Aroda on three acres of open meadow, this 2,990-square-foot Cape Cod-style house has an in-law suite on its lower level. MAYHEM POETS When Scott Raven Tarazevits, above right, proclaims from the stage of the New Victory Theater -- an enterprise devoted to family audiences -- how much he loves breasts and thighs, you may be tempted to cover the ears of the child sitting next to you. But it soon becomes clear that this isn't necessary. The juicy breasts and thighs Mr. Tarazevits is drooling over are the kind found at a barbecue, not a brothel. And before long his onstage compatriots, Kyle Sutton, above left, and Mason Granger, have leapt into the audience, busily flapping and clucking their accompaniment. Mr. Tarazevits's ode to chicken is just one of the ways that he, Mr. Sutton and Mr. Granger, collectively known as Mayhem Poets, subvert expectations. Although their spoken-word performances derive from hip-hop, their material wouldn't make your grandmother blush, and there's nothing gangsta about their pose. (Their message is to write, not fight.) Having met several years ago as students at Rutgers University, the young men have said that their name is a play on the world-domination Mayhem Project mentioned in the film ''Fight Club.'' But their only weapon is words, specifically the snappy, streetwise art known as slam poetry.

In the Samish area near Washington State University, this 2,314-square-foot house backs onto a greenbelt area and has mountain views. Agent: Christopher Walton, Keller Williams Bellingham, (360) 483-9599; www.kwbellingham.com.

(Animal Planet) ORANGUTAN ISLAND Deep in the forest of Borneo, illegal logging is destroying the last stronghold of the country's orangutan population, leaving hundreds of babies orphaned and homeless. But a new project is offering hope for the survival of the species. This series follows the 35 red-haired classmates of Forest School 103 at the Nyaru Menteng rescue and rehabilitation center. There, Cha Cha, Saturnus, Daisy, Hamlet (above) and some other ''children of the forest,'' as they're known to their teachers, led by Lone Droscher-Nielsen, learn to form their own society and get some education in the real world. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) DOG WHISPERER Cesar Millan tries to tame Opie, a black lab mix who has been compared by his owner to both Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde; Flirt, a tiny dog with a hugely neurotic personality; and Bubba, who's just plain spoiled rotten. And then there's Garrett, a German shepherd who won't stop chasing his tail.

THE Visitor Center at the Presidio (50 Moraga Avenue; 415-561-4323; www.nps.gov/prsf), in the former Officers Club, is open daily from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. On weekends, the free PresidiGo shuttle takes visitors to 40 sites, including Fort Point (www.nps.gov/fopo). MARIA HASSABI For many Americans the word ''dancer'' has implications that go beyond the artistic. As the choreographer Maria Hassabi pointed out recently, ''You meet some people and say, 'I'm a dancer,' and they say, 'Oh, you must be so flexible,' and there's always a sexual connotation there.'' In ''Gloria,'' which opens Wednesday at Performance Space 122, Ms. Hassabi, above, plays with and ultimately pushes beyond those sexual implications. A formal, strongly female duet for herself and the wondrous Hristoula Harakas, this evening-length piece, which Ms. Hassabi describes as ''live sculpture,'' often has the two women taking poses that some might find provocative, such as spreading their legs wide. But the dancers hold these positions for so long that the sexual layers peel away. Created separately, the solos inhabit the same space but are not linked other than through the connections viewers make, Ms. Hassabi said. When ''you're walking behind two people'' on the street, she explained, they might not be together ''but you see them in one frame in front of you; you make relationships.''

A headline in some editions on Thursday with an article about efforts by Dr. Mazoltuv Borukhova, the widow of a Queens orthodontist, to compel the city to return her daughter to her left the incorrect impression that Dr. Borukhova was in court because she had shot her daughter. The shooting victim was Dr. Daniel Malakov, Dr. Borukhova’s estranged husband — not their child, Michelle Malakov, who was placed in the custody of Dr. Malakov’s relatives. Neither Dr. Borukhova nor anyone else has been charged in Dr. Malakov’s killing.

A television review last Saturday about “Silence of the Bees,” on PBS, misstated the cause of death of a honeybee colony’s males and also included imprecise references to other aspects of hive life. The males, called drones, die after mating or are driven out of the colony by the females and die of exposure; they are not worked to death. (The females do the work.) The life span of the males can range from two or three weeks to nearly two months or more; their life span is not always limited to 30 days. The number of males in a colony can be in the hundreds or more; a colony is not limited to 100. At the height of the nectar-gathering season, colonies can include 50,000 bees or more; thus a queen can be attended by more than 30,000 subjects, not just 30,000.

Bruton Smith, the chairman of Speedway Motorsports, confirmed yesterday that he had agreed to buy New Hampshire International Speedway for $340 million from Bob Bahre, the track’s 80-year-old owner, in a deal that should be completed early next year. Smith said he did not have plans for changes at the track. He has expressed a long-standing desire to add a second Nextel Cup race at Las Vegas, one of the six other tracks he owns.

Scott Verplank made enough birdies on his first nine holes on the Magnolia Course in Lake Buena Vista, Fla., that he was not too bothered by closing with nine straight pars, giving him a second consecutive six-under-par 66 and a one-shot lead over Tag Ridings, Stephen Ames and Ryan Armour at the Children’s Miracle Network Classic.

Trailing by a point in the second round of his flyweight semifinal bout at the boxing world championships in Chicago, Rau’shee Warren overcame a sore right shoulder that had bothered him in his last three matches to land a solid right against Samir Mammadov of Azerbaijan and then took off, using his quickness and counterpunching. Warren, an American, won the final 3 points of the round to go up, 12-9, took control with a 10-2 advantage in the third and finished off a 26-13 victory. His opponent today will be Somjit Jongjohor of Thailand, who easily defeated Vincenzio Picardi of Italy by 13-2 in the first semifinal.

A prosecutor is suing the judge overseeing the capital murder trial of a man accused in a rampage that began in an Atlanta courtroom, seeking to resume jury selection and questioning whether the judge should be removed. Repeated delays in the trial “create an emergency situation,” District Attorney Paul L. Howard Jr. of Fulton County said in a complaint to the Georgia Supreme Court. The trial has been continuously bogged down in friction with the state public defender’s office over fees and expenses for lawyers representing the defendant, Brian Nichols, in the 2005 shootings.

A cigarette or other smoking materials may have caused a beach-house fire last Sunday that killed seven South Carolina college students, the authorities said, though a preliminary investigation failed to determine the blaze’s origin. Mayor Debbie Smith of Ocean Isle Beach said the investigation confirmed initial reports that the fire started on the back deck. All seven students died of smoke inhalation and carbon monoxide poisoning.

Security officials at the nation’s largest nuclear power plant detained a contract worker with a small pipe bomb in the back of his pickup truck, and investigators were searching his apartment, the authorities said. The incident did not appear to be an act of terrorism, the authorities said. The worker, identified as Roger W. Hurd of Goodyear, Ariz., was stopped and detained at the entrance of the Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station, about half a mile from the containment domes where the plant’s nuclear material is stored, said a plant spokesman, Jim McDonald. Security officials put the nuclear station on lockdown.

The state police searched the house of a police sergeant from a Chicago suburb whose wife disappeared last month. The warrant was executed on Thursday at the house of Sgt. Drew Peterson, whose wife, Stacy, was reported missing last Sunday. Investigators also searched a nearby pond, the police said. “No criminal charges have been filed,” said Charles Pelkie, a spokesman for the Will County state’s attorney’s office. “And no one has been taken into custody.” Sergeant Peterson, 53, of the Bolingbrook Police Department, has said his 23-year-old wife called him on Sunday night and told him that she was leaving him.

Federal agents learned three weeks in advance that O. J. Simpson and a memorabilia dealer planned an operation to retrieve personal items that Mr. Simpson said were stolen from him, according to F.B.I. reports. The dealer, Thomas Riccio, said he had reported a collector who claimed to have belongings taken from Mr. Simpson in a meeting on Aug. 21 with the bureau in Los Angeles. “The guy flat out told me he had items stolen from O. J.’s house,” Mr. Riccio said. But Mr. Riccio was not clear how the operation would unfold, and there was no mention in the report of guns being used in it. Mr. Simpson is accused of storming a Las Vegas hotel room with others armed in a bid to recover the items.

After living nearly her whole life in the Alaska Zoo, Maggie the elephant made her way to a new home in California. The 25-year-old African elephant arrived at Travis Air Force Base in Fairfield bound for the Performing Animal Welfare Society in San Andreas, about 75 miles away. The Air Force agreed to transport Maggie, for years Alaska’s only elephant, as part of a training mission after officials with PAWS and the zoo discovered she was too big for a commercial airline. After arriving at the base, Maggie was trucked to her new home at the sanctuary, where she will have 30 acres to share with nine other elephants. Maggie arrived in Alaska in 1983 after her herd was culled in South Africa.

KERNOCHAN--John Marshall, the Nash Professor Emeritus of Law at Columbia Law School, music publisher and founder of the Kernochan Center for Law, Media and the Arts, whose work in intellectual property law spurred protections for artists, died Monday. The Columbia Law School community mourns his passing. Kernochan prodded the U.S. to amend its copyright laws so it could become party to the Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works in 1989. He developed the U.S. chapter of the Association Littraire et Artistique Internationale. He wrote doggerel verse and bawdy limericks, and composed religious music. He graduated from Columbia Law School in 1948, and married Adelaide Chatfield-Taylor. As head of Galaxy Music Corporation he published Pulitzer - winning composer Robert Ward and inspired a revival of English and Italian madrigals. He is survived by five children: John of Cambridge, MA; Denny of Santa Monica, CA; Sarah of New York City; Wayne of Wellesley, MA; and Rose of New York City. Dean David M. Schizer, Lucy G. Moses Professor of Law Columbia Law School

KRYGER--Lawrence. The Hillcrest Jewish Center mourns the passing of our devoted member and benefactor, Larry Kryger. Larry served as chairman of our school board, of the board of trustees and as longtime treasurer. Larry always acted with dignity and devotion. He was a real MENCH and will be sorely missed. Our deepest condolences to his loving family.

KASMAN--Dorothy, retired corporate librarian, died on Wednesday, October 31st, 2007 at the Mayflower Nursing Home, in West Yarmouth, MA. She was 89 years old. She died of pneumonia and complications of Alzheimer's, her family said. Funeral services will be held Sunday, November 4th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York City, at 10:00am. Miss Kasman, a native of Trenton, gained a Bachelor of Arts from Douglass College (now part of Rutgers University) in 1941 and Master of Library Science in 1957. She received a Masters in Business Administration from New York University in 1970. From 1956 to 1958 she was the librarian at the Textile Research Institute, in Princeton, NJ. She moved to New York City in 1958, joining Coopers & Lybrand (now PricewaterhouseCoopers), as Chief Librarian, a position she held for over 30 years. During those years, she gave freely of her time, mentoring many individuals who wished to enter the library profession. In addition to her corporate work, she volunteered as a tutor for young adults learning English as a second language. She was an honored member of the Special Libraries Association, serving on numerous committees over the years, was awarded the Distinguished Member Award in 1988 and inducted into the SLA Hall of Fame in 1991. She was a past chairperson of the SLA Business & Finance Division and a past treasurer for the organization (1979-1982). She was the co-author of ''Education for Special Librarianship,'' Special Libraries 67:504-509 (Nov 1976). During WWII, she volunteered at the USO, the Red Cross, and the Army & Navy War Training Program. Miss Kasman never married. She is survived by her nieces and nephews, Stephen Gayner, Jay Gayner, Howard Kasman and Sandy Kasman and grandnieces and grandnephews. She will be remembered forever as ''Auntie Dot.''

TAYLOR--Ann Bonfoey, died peacefully at her Denver home on Sunday, October 28, 2007 surrounded by loving family members. Born December 3, 1910 in Ardmore, PA and raised in Quincy, IL. Ann exhibited an early passion when as a six year old her father introduced her to flying in open two-seater biplanes. At twelve years of age her father hired a pilot to teach Ann to fly and despite the then all-male atmosphere of the age and a resentful teacher, Ann learned to fly and loved it. Married to James Cooke in 1928. They had two children, Diane and Jay. Early in their marriage, Ann's expertise at tennis led her to competing at Wimbleton. Ann moved to Vermont after marrying. Ever the sportswoman, she started ski racing in Stowe, acquiring the nickname Nose-dive Annie. She became an alternate in 1939 on the Womens Olympic Ski Team, skiing until her late 80s. Ann's marriage to James ended. She then turned to civil engineering and the study of flying, leading to the pursuit of a pilot's license. When World War II broke out, she became a flight instructor for flight students, which included Navy and Army pilots. After the end of the war, Ann returned to Stowe where a great sense of style led her to design her own ski clothing which became very popular. Very shortly her clothing appeared on the covers of Harpers Bazaar and other magazines and in the Fifth Avenue windows of Lord and Taylor, as well as other prominent Fifth Avenue retailers. In l947, after a whirlwind courtship, Ann married Vernon ''Moose'' Taylor, Jr., of Indiana, PA and San Antonio, TX. Ann realized her new-found success would have practical limits and decided to give up her new career to become a full-time wife and mother. In l954 Ann and ''Moose'' moved to Denver where they raised their family. It was in Denver that Ann developed a passion for horses and become an expert in dressage, hunting and jumping which she and ''Moose'' engaged in not only in Denver, but also in Middleburg, Virginia and Leicestershire, England, riding into their late 80s. ''Moose'', even in their earliest courtship said he wanted to build a ski house with Ann. In l963, as one of the founders of Vail, they built one of the first ski chalets in the new town where they thrived skiing with family and friends over 40 years. In addition to Vail, Ann and ''Moose'' had a cattle ranch in Montana where they held their annual Fourth of July gettogether for family and friends from around the world for many years. Ann also served on the Advisory Board of the American Associates of the Royal Academy Trust and the World Wildlife Fund. Ann was predeceased by her daughter Diane Cooke and grandson Ryan Taylor. She is survived by her loving husband and children, Jay Cooke (Gail) of New York City; Vernon Taylor, III (Naomi Marks) of Long Island; Douglas Taylor (Monica) of New York City; Robert Taylor (Joni) of Vail; and Craig Taylor (Michelle) of Santa Barbara, California and eleven grandchildren. A private service is being held for family members. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested donations be made to the American Associates of the Royal Academy Trust, 555 Madison Ave., Ste. 1300, New York, NY 10022 or a charity of choice.

PINCUS--Lillian, is at peace. Mother, grandmother, greatgrandmother, sister, daughter, cousin, niece, volunteer and friend. March 11, 1913November 1, 2007. Survived by her sons Stephen and Arthur and her daughters-in-law Donna and Ellen, her loving granddaughters, Alisa and her husband David Nathanson and Suzanne and her fiance Dan Shidlovsky, and grandsons Matthew, Benjamin and his wife Debbie, David and his wife Jessica, and Joshua and his wife Michelle. And by her seven greatgrandchildren, Shaina, Sydney, Aaron, Madeleine, Olivia, Jack and Violet. Service Friday, November 2, 2007 at 11:15am at the Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

FISCHER--Jerome M., retired Chairman, President and Director of Planning Research Corporation Engineering, Inc., and a lifelong international consulting civil engineer, passed away on November 1, 2007 at his home in Scarsdale, NY. He is survived by his loving wife of 61 years Rhoda Fischer, children Steven (Linda) Fischer, Karen Englander, Michael (Eneida) Fischer, and Marion Fischer, and 11 grandchildren/greatgrandchildren. Funeral services will be held at Synagogue Kol Ami, Chapel in the Woods, 252 Soundview Ave, White Plains, NY on Monday, November 5th, at Noon. Burial to follow, Mount Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY.

LERNER--Abram (Al), passed away October 31st, 2007. Beloved brother-in-law of Dorothy Hanenberg and uncle of Kate Hanenberg, Richard Hanenberg and Sophia (Lee) deBoer. Devoted and loving great-uncle to Maisie, James and Annie. He will be missed. Loving sympathy to his daughter, Aline Libassi and grandchildren, Matthew and Francesca Libassi.

10 P.M. (Cinemax) NIGHT AT THE MUSEUM (2006) Ben Stiller, above, stars as Larry Daley, a divorced, unemployed schlump on the verge of losing his 10-year-old son, (Jake Cherry), who takes a job as night watchman at the American Museum of Natural History so that he won't have to do the unthinkable: move from Manhattan to Queens. Never mind that the museum's aged guards, played by Dick Van Dyke, Mickey Rooney and Bill Cobbs, seem to have something up their uniform sleeves. Soon enough, everything dead -- including a Tyrannosaurus rex, a stone head from Easter Island and a cheeky monkey named Dexter -- has come back to life. Robin Williams plays a wisdom-dispensing Teddy Roosevelt intent on whipping Larry into shape. If only Teddy could muster a little of that bluster as he pines for Sacajawea (Mizuo Peck), who is stuck inside the glass case of a Lewis and Clark diorama. 7 P.M. (WE) ABDUCTED BY UFO'S The channel adds to its Saturday-night supernatural programming block with this two-hour special, in which ''ordinary people abducted by aliens,'' according to a news release, ''recall their frightening experiences.'' Should be scary.

KAPLAN--Madge. Beloved Board Member and Fundraising Chair of The Great Neck Student Aid Fund, Inc. for more than 20 years. Her caring and concern for all the children she helped through the years served as a model for us all. We will be truly at a loss without her.

BRODIE--Joyce A. (nee Ramoy), age 79. Beloved mother of Karen, David, and James, and grandmother of Ariana and Reilly. She loved her adopted California, but always remained at heart a New Yorker in her taste and style. Devoted mother, wife, special - education teacher who helped many children, artist, and loyal friend. We remember and cherish her artistry, taste, love, and gentle spirit. We love you always, Mom.

STEIN--Linda. The Board, Advisory Board and staff of The Breast Cancer Research Foundation are deeply saddened by the death of our longtime and devoted Advisory Board member and generous friend. Linda brought a dedication and passion second to none, and we will miss her very much. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family and friends, especially to her father, Ira; her sister, Arlene; her beautiful daughters, Mandy and Samantha, and her granddaughter, Dora. Evelyn H. Lauder, Chairman Myra Biblowit, President Jeanette Wagner, Vice President Deborah Krulewitch, Secretary Larry Norton, M.D., Scientific Director STEIN--Linda. Your many close friends and former colleagues at Sotheby's International Realty extend our heartfelt condolences and deepest sympathies to your cherished family: daughters, Samantha and Mandy; granddaughter, Dora; father, Ira Adler; sister Arlene, nephews Mark and David and to Seymour Stein. We were privileged to know and work with Linda. We will miss her beautiful smile, great wit and zest for life. She was one of a kind and we will never forget her. STEIN--Linda S. Prudential Douglas Elliman Real Estate deeply mourns the loss of our beloved agent and friend, Linda Stein. An icon in the industry and a top agent since starting her real estate career in the early 1990s, Linda was devoted to her work and her customers, many of whom are notables in the entertainment industry, especially musicians and other performing artists she met while co-managing the music group the Ramones in the 1970s. Linda loved the challenge of working in this competitive industry and representing the worldwide real estate needs of the famous people who considered her their friend first, real estate agent second. She moved as comfortably in transacting business in France and London as she did in Manhattan and the Hamptons. The consummate professional, Linda didn't let her battle with cancer get in the way of her serving her customers nor prevent her from reaching out to help others by serving on the board of the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. Linda will leave a lasting impression on all who knew her. She will be terribly missed by all of us. STEINLINDA ST#

FARRELL--James H., of Wantagh, NY, on October 31, 2007 in his 95th year. Beloved husband of the late Elizabeth. Loving father of James G. (Jaqueline), Janet E., and Eileen F. Cherished grandfather of Aleyna Wicke (Brendan), Cara, and Lochlin Farrell. Dear great-grandfather of Max and Ben. James was a proud U.S. Army Staff Sgt. of WWII, and was the oldest Okinawa survivor. James was also the Vice President of Bankers Trust, NYC for over 50 years. Reposing after 2pm Saturday at The Charles J O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Ave (exit 28N SS Parkway) Wantagh. Funeral Mass Monday 11am at St. James R.C. Church, Seaford, NY. Entombent to follow at Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn, NY. Family will receive friends Saturday and Sunday 2-5 and 7-9pm.

CONDREN--William J., Palm Beach, Florida and Southampton, New York died after a lengthy illness on October 29, 2007 at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, surrounded by his family. He was 74 years old. A graduate of Chaminade High School, Fordham University and Harvard Law School, he was a private investor with interests in real estate and equipment leases. In 1966, after practicing law for seven years, he pioneered the leveraged lease financing of railroad equipment and aircraft, which structure he later applied to public utility generating equipment, off-shore drilling equipment, oil tankers and other marine equipment. He was involved in the syndication of subsidized housing projects in New York, Florida and Massachusetts, and the financing of the initial rehabilitation of a block on West 42nd Street known as Theatre Row Phase II, which was sold in 2004 for further redevelopment. He was a lifelong fan of horseracing and co-owned several successful horses, including two Kentucky Derby winners and a Preakness winner. He was a co-founder and director of the National Thoroughbred Association, a trustee for the Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association, and a director of the Grayson-Jockey Club Research Foundation. He is survived by his wife Mary Jo, son Colin, and daughters Elizabeth and Jennifer. A memorial service will be held in New York City on Friday, November 9th, at 10:00am at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street. CONDREN--William J., The Board of Governors and membership of Deepdale Golf Club note with sorrow the untimely passing of our esteemed member. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. D. Dixon Boardman, President

BROUNER--Leonora, of Manhattan and Woodstock, NY passed away just before midnight Saturday, October 27. Dancer, lover of music, art and antiquities, elegant lady, devoted mother. Services at Woodstock Artists Cemetery on Friday at 1:00pm. Friends may call at Lasher Funeral Home, 100 Tinker St. in Woodstock 11am-12:30pm.

KITTAY--William R., 84, died October 9 from a stroke and Rhoda Siegelman Kittay, 78, died October 31 from a tragic fall in September. For 56 years, they were two halves of a whole. Both were loved and adored by their family and friends -Bill for his kind heart and wry sense of humor; Rhoda for her generosity and vivaciousness. They were the devoted and proud parents of David R. Kittay and daughter-in-law Jan Kittay and Debby Kittay-Parker and son-in-law Josh Parker. They are also survived by their wonderful grandchildren, Leigh and Bear Kittay and Jessie, Jonah and Julia Parker, and their granddog Yoshi. While we will miss them both terribly, we know that they were meant to be together in this world and beyond. A memorial service will be held on Sunday November 4 at 1:15pm at Congregation Sons of Israel, 1666 Pleasantville Road, Briarcliff Manor, New York. Donations in their memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605-2523, or the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place, SW, Washington, DC 20024-2126.

ROZELLE--Carrie. The National Center for Learning Disabilities Board of Directors, Professional Advisory Board and staff is saddened by the passing of our founder. NCLD is committed to Carrie's vision of improving the lives of the millions of people across the nation affected by learning disabilities. Along with our constituents, we extend our condolences to Carrie's family and many friends.

PAPADOPOULOS-Constantin D., M.D., 1929-2007. Born in Cairo, Egypt, Constantin D. Papadopoulos received his bachelor of science degree and medical degree, Summa Cum Laude, from the University of Louvain, Belgium. After a short internship in Paris, France and at the French Hospital in Manhattan, he began a long association with The Brooklyn Hospital Center where he started as a surgical resident in 1955 and rose to Chief of Vascular Surgery in 1963 until his retirement in 1998. He was president of the Brooklyn Surgical Society, member of the Steering Committee for the Federation of Cardiovascular Clinics of the New York Heart Association from 1969-1979. He was a member of the New York Cardiovascular Society, Diplomat of the American Board of Vascular Surgery, Clinical Professor of Surgery, New York University, Clinical Professor of Surgery at SUNY and International Society of Cardiovascular Surgery, having studied under Dr. Michael Debakey, he was a member of the Michael E. Debakey Cardiovascular Society, Eastern Vascular Society, Society for Clinical Vascular Surgery, American College of Surgeons, New York Academy of Medicine and many others. Dr. Papadopoulos, a professor of vascular surgery was an avid teacher having trained in excess of 140 chief residents in surgery and 18 fellows in vascular surgery. With 22 vascular surgical publications and unparalleled clinical experience, Dr. Papadopoulos rose to the rank of clinical professor of surgery in 1985 and was the first surgeon to be certified in vascular surgery by the American Board of Surgery in the borough of Brooklyn and was recertified in 1993 at the age of 64. In 1962, through his efforts, the first vascular laboratory was created at the Brooklyn Hospital Center, the first such facility in New York. Through his efforts and his keen interest in what was new, in 1991 the first endovascular suite in New York State was created at the Brooklyn Hospital Center. SCHULTZ--Peggy. We record with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Peggy Schultz. We send our sincere condolences to the entire family in their time of sorrow. Her many years of friendship and kindness will be remembered. Philip Laskawy, President Robin Carlin, Secretary Quaker Ridge Golf Club SCHULTZ--Peggy C./d, died peacefully in her home on Friday, November 2, 2007. Beloved wife of the late David H. Schultz, loving mother of Michael, Bob, Andy and Amy, devoted grandmother of Maggy, Lucy, Katherine, Reed, Rebecca, Eliza, Sam and Mollie, cherished companion of Frank Bingham. Peggy was born September 9, 1929, raised in New York City, and lived happily for more than 50 years in Scarsdale. A woman of exceptional warmth, grace and energy, Peggy was deeply interested in everyone she encountered, was always planning the next family get-together, and was a dedicated volunteer for numerous organizations. An extraordinary mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, companion and friend, Peggy will be missed beyond words. Funeral services will be held at 11:30am on Sunday, November 4th, The Chapel in the Woods at Congregation Kol Ami, 252 Soundview Ave., White Plains, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the David and Peggy Schultz Memorial Endowed Scholarship Fund of the University of Pennsylvania, 634 Franklin Building, 3451 Walnut Street, Philadelphia, PA 19104-6285.

BERGER--Rabbi Philmore. We're deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend. His warmth, advice and love will be cherished forever. Love... Fran, Jim & Becker Family BERGER--Philmore. It is with great sadness that we announce the death of Rabbi Philmore Berger, Rabbi Emeritus of Temple Avodah of Oceanside, NY. Beloved husband and friend to his wife Ginger Friedman Berger and the late Anita Berger. He was greatly loved and respected by many. He lived his life by ma'asim tovim and tikun olam. He will be greatly missed by his children: Debi and Gary Lerner, Daniel and Lynn Berger, David and Nancy Berger, Diane and Jeff Lieberman; his stepchildren: Ilene and Anthony Pellecchia, Joni and Michael Eberlin; and a loving Zaida to Max, Ross, Fred, Amanda, Scott, Tatyana, Danielle, Ian, Charles, Rebecca and Jessica. Rabbi Berger dedicated over 40 years, beginning in 1963, to serving the congregation at Temple Avodah and the people of Oceanside. He served his country as a Chaplain in the Air Force as well as the Chaplain of the Nassau County Jail. He ran a pastoral counseling center in Manhattan and was an Assistant Director of Camp Eisner, a URJ camp, for many years. He will be remembered for all the love his life brought to everyone he touched. Funeral services will be held today 12 noon at Temple Avodah, Oceanside, NY. 516-766-6809. BERGER--Philmore. The Officers and Board of Trustees of Temple Avodah of Oceanside, NY mourn the passing of our esteemed Rabbi Emeritus, Philmore Berger, who served our temple with extreme love and devotion for over 35 years. Services will be held at Temple Avodah Friday at 12:00 noon. May God console his family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

In Book 10 of Milton's "Paradise Lost," Adam asks the question so many of his descendants have asked: why should the lives of billions be blighted because of a sin he, not they, committed? ("Ah, why should all mankind / For one man's fault... be condemned?") He answers himself immediately: "But from me what can proceed, / But all corrupt, both Mind and Will depraved?" Adam's Original Sin is like an inherited virus. Although those who are born with it are technically innocent of the crime - they did not eat of the forbidden tree - its effects rage in their blood and disorder their actions.

Rubin and Winfried Bischoff sent Citi's employees two memorandums addressing the shakeup. Richard Johnson birdied the final three holes for a four-under 67 and a one-stroke lead over Tom Scherrer after the third round of the season-ending Nationwide Tour Championship in Lakeside, Calif. The top 25 on the money list after the tournament will earn PGA Tour cards.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 3 (AP) — Navy needed 44 years and three overtimes to beat Notre Dame. The Midshipmen snapped an N.C.A.A.-record 43-game losing streak against the Fighting Irish with a 46-44 victory Saturday.

Geno Hayes returned Matt Ryan’s third interception of the game for a 38-yard touchdown with 1 minute 10 seconds to play last night to help Florida State upset No. 2 Boston College, 27-17, ending the Eagles’ run at an unbeaten season and shaking up the Bowl Championship Series standings yet again.
Ryan Shay’s death the day before the New York City Marathon cast a pall over an event that usually serves as a citywide celebration.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 3 (AP) — Chad Henne’s 31-yard touchdown pass to Mario Manningham with 2 minutes 28 seconds left Saturday lifted 15th-ranked Michigan to a 28-24 victory over Michigan State in the teams’ 100th matchup.
More than 100 cars and trucks crashed on a fog-shrouded freeway Saturday, killing at least two people and injuring dozens more, the California Highway Patrol said.

The flyweight Rau’shee Warren and the welterweight Demetrius Andrade became the first Americans in eight years to win gold medals at the World Boxing Championships with convincing victories in the finals yesterday in Chicago. Warren beat Thailand’s Somjit Jongjohor, 13-9, despite having two front teeth knocked out. Andrade’s bout with Thailand’s Non Boonjumnong was stopped in the second round because of an injury to Boonjumnong’s right arm.

Scott Verplank was two shots behind with three holes to play yesterday, then surged into a share of the lead at the Children’s Miracle Network Classic in Lake Buena Vista, Fla., simply by making pars. Verplank wound up with a 71 and was tied with Stephen Ames going into the final round.

Kevin Harvick won another race and the runaway points leader Carl Edwards wrapped up his first Nascar Busch Series championship yesterday at Texas Motor Speedway in Fort Worth. Edwards, who built a lead of more than 800 points in the first half of the season, put away the title with an 11th-place run in the O’Reilly Challenge. He leads the runner-up David Reutimann by an insurmountable 552 points with two races to go. Harvick, running a limited Busch schedule this season after his runaway title in 2006, won for a series-high sixth time in 24 starts in 2007.

Two members of the Jaguars — the rookie linebacker Justin Durant and the second-year offensive tackle Richard Collier — were arrested in separate incidents early yesterday, and neither made the team’s trip to New Orleans for today’s game against the Saints. Police officers in Jacksonville, Fla., arrested Collier for driving under the influence, and Durant was charged with resisting arrest without violence. Eight Jaguars players have been arrested since January 2006.
PERCY HARVIN, left, became the first player in Florida history to have 100 yards receiving and rushing in a game. He ran for 113 yards and 2 touchdowns, and caught 9 passes for 110 yards.

Rafael Nadal reached the Paris Masters final yesterday by beating Marcos Baghdatis, 4-6, 6-4, 6-3, and knocking him out of contention for the season-ending Masters Cup.

Fernando Alonso has reportedly been asked to return to Renault, his Formula One team when he won the 2005 and 2006 world championships. Alonso quit McLaren on Friday after clashing with Ron Dennis, the part owner of the British team, and his teammate Lewis Hamilton. Alonso finished third in the points race behind the champion Kimi Raikkonen of Ferrari and Hamilton. “I have presented a project for the future to Fernando,” Flavio Briatore of Renault was quoted as saying yesterday on the Web site of Gazzetta dello Sport.
Momoko Ueda had a five-under 67 to move into a tie for the lead with Laura Davies at the Mizuno Classic yesterday in Shima, Japan. Ueda had six birdies to finish at seven-under 137.

A scrambled injury-time goal by William Gallas gave Arsenal a 2-2 draw yesterday with visiting Manchester United, preserving its unbeaten record and keeping it on top of the Premier League. Arsenal leads with 27 points from 11 matches; United is second with 27 from 12 games.

Justin Rose struggled early before shooting an even-par 71 yesterday to lead Padraig Harrington by four shots after the third round of the Volvo Masters in Sotogrande, Spain. Rose is at four-under 209.

The Chicago Cubs and Daryle Ward exercised a $1.2 million mutual option for next season, but the team declined options on outfielder Cliff Floyd and pitcher Steve Trachsel yesterday.Ward batted .327 in 79 games last season after signing as a free agent. Ward led the team with 54 pinch-hit appearances and went 11 for 41 (.268). Floyd hit .284 with 9 homers and 45 runs batted in. His option was for $5 million. Trachsel, acquired in a trade with Baltimore on Aug. 31, was 1-3 with an 8.31 earned run average in four starts for Chicago. Trachsel gets a $100,000 buyout. His option was for $4.75 million.

SINCE the Asian restaurant Pearl East opened in Manhasset 10 years ago, its owner, Cathy Huang, has been disposing of the excess cooking grease from egg rolls and fried noodles in a big trap outside that had to be pumped out monthly. She put waste vegetable oil into big barrels and paid a hauler $40 a month to take it for recycling.

Technically, buffalo refers to animals of Asia and Africa — water buffalo and species like Cape buffalo. Those big shaggy symbols of the American West, revered by certain Indian tribes, driven to near extinction and often referred to as American buffalo, are in fact bison with the Latin name Bison bison.

When Europeans arrived in North America around 1600, there were, it is generally believed, 30 to 60 million buffalo roaming from the Hudson Bay to Mexico except for the extreme southeast and southwest of what is now the United States.

Paris is cuckoo for cocottes. Qu’est-ce que c’est que ca? A cocotte is both the covered casserole in which something is cooked and that delicious something itself. At his fourth restaurant, Les Cocottes de Christian Constant (135, rue Saint-Dominique), the celebrated chef Constant says he evokes his “mother’s cuisine for a younger generation” with individual pots filled with seasonal ingredients like pigeon roasted with figs. (Staub casseroles are also for sale.) Coco & Co (11, rue Bernard Palissy; 011-33-1-45-44-02-52), a just-opened cafe devoted to the egg, offers 20 cocotted versions and also allows for custom creations. And a bit of wordplay — cocotte is also a term of endearment used between girlfriends — informed the name of the new food bookshop/patisserie La Cocotte (below; 5, rue Paul Bert; 011-33-1-43-73-04-02), which is run by four women. This month, the store invites the chef and cookbook author Sonia Ezgulian to host a night of TV dinners. On the menu? Cocottes, of course. For information, go to www.lacocotte.net.

Get out the blinis. This fall, Tsar Nicoulai, the San Francisco purveyor known for its domestic caviar, will introduce trout and whitefish roe infused with the likes of kaffir lime leaf, brandy and vanilla. The unusual collection, called Passot Roe, came about because Roland Passot, the chef who owns La Folie restaurant, began experimenting with adding flavors to trout roe, which has a firm, almost crunchy texture and is fairly inexpensive. “It’s like perfume: it’s subtle,” says Passot, who created the line “to have fun with.” His idea of fun might be monkfish foie gras served with potato salad sprinkled with truffle caviar. (For the rest of us, toast points and a dollop of crème franche with vanilla trout caviar will have to do.) A roster of international chefs is being tapped for future flavors. A gift set — with beet and saffron, truffled tiger-eye and wasabi whitefish roe, along with vanilla bean trout caviar — is being sold through the Williams-Sonoma catalog and Web site this holiday season. Passot Roe is also available at www.tsarnicoulai.com.

Have you been piggy at the table? Do you know which side the fork goes on? These are questions about the “landscape” of dining that Topoware, a new collection of china, linen and place mats, tries to address. Designed by Alexandra Deschamps-Sonsino and Karola Torkos, using the undulating circles and lines used in topography maps, Topoware bowls are marked “full,” “hungry” and “very hungry”; plates read “modest,” “moderate” and “greedy.” The pine place mats point to where your table setting goes. “We borrowed the visual language of geography,” explains Deschamps-Sonsino, who is based in London. “I don’t think our collection is going to change the world, but we do want it to cause a moment of self-reflection.” Go to www.topoware.org.

Peter Arnell, the mastermind behind advertising and branding for Donna Karan and M&M’s, also designed Jacob the Jeweler’s Manhattan store. Now his boundary-averse company has expanded into products. Arnell Group designed this fire extinguisher for HomeHero, a brand it developed with the Home Depot. While people know they should have an extinguisher, Arnell says, “what was stopping them from buying or keeping them handy is that they are just so ugly.” Hence, this sleek, ergonomically designed model, which you’d be happy (and smart) to give pride of place in your kitchen.

Every auction has its long shots, yet these two, oddly enough, are emblazoned on catalog covers for the sales. The Gauguin is vibrant, it's beautifully painted and it has a distinguished pedigree. (It once belonged to Joan Whitney Payson, the philanthropist and onetime owner of the New York Mets.) Still, a Tahitian woman with her dress hiked up around her waist, squatting in the water, may not be the most appealing image, especially for the estimated price of $40 million to $60 million. Warhol's ''Liz,'' owned by the actor Hugh Grant, also carries a hefty estimate. But experts say the image is heavy-handed and not as sharp as the 12 other Elizabeth Taylor paintings in the series. If it doesn't do well, Christie's may be stuck. It gave Mr. Grant a guarantee that insiders estimated at $20 million.

A report on Oct. 21, about the marriage of Lina D'Orazio and Adam Baer, included outdated information on the location of the ceremony. After the article went to press, the wedding was moved from Malibu to the Mulholland Tennis Club in Los Angeles because of the California wildfires. The report also misstated the date of the ceremony. It took place on Oct. 21, not the day before.

A private eye, a super spy, Hong Kong heavies, Taiwanese stragglers and a couple of firemen who are a firemen couple all arrive on Tuesday: ''Chinatown'' gets the ritzy treatment in a new edition; ''The James Bond Ultimate Collector's Set'' is a fan's holiday fantasy gift; two Hong Kong wowsers, ''Election'' by Johnnie To and ''The Killer'' by John Woo, class up the joint; the latest from the Taiwanese director Tsai Ming-liang is ''I Don't Want to Sleep Alone''; and, for a different take on gay life, there's ''I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry.'' It's just as busy on Nov. 13: William Holden made his film debut alongside the woman he credited with saving his career, Barbara Stanwyck, in the movie version of Clifford Odets's great play ''Golden Boy''; Charlotte Rampling falls for a chimp in Nagisa Oshima's ''Max Mon Amour''; ''Live Free or Die Hard'' proves to be the most subversive entry in the action franchise, while action of another kind can be seen in Werner Herzog's Vietnam epic, ''Rescue Dawn''; cheer or be appalled at the B-movie smash ''Walking Tall,'' there's no denying the proficiency of Phil Karlson's direction; Eurosleaze fans can rejoice over the second volume of the luscious Laura Gemser in ''Black Emanuelle's Box,'' from the cheerfully perverse folks at Severin Films; and -- finally -- the home video release of Charles Burnett's revered ''Killer of Sheep.'' Charlize Theron fans retain fond memories of her in ''2 Days in the Valley''; see why on Nov. 20. The musical version of ''Hairspray'' comes to DVD the same day, as does a new edition of the famed art film ''I Am Cuba.'' ''Ford at Fox'' (Dec. 4) is a huge chunk of John Ford films, including ''The Grapes of Wrath'' and ''My Darling Clementine.'' Two different kinds of outsiders highlight releases that day: Catherine Deneuve, above, does very bad things in Roman Polanski's ''Repulsion,'' and Jonah Hill and Michael Cera do superbad -- and supersweet -- things in ''Superbad.'' ''Mr. Bean's Holiday'' (Dec. 11) leaves a sweet aftertaste. What is being called the final cut of ''Blade Runner'' comes out in several editions (Dec. 18). And for a bright start to the new year, there is Rip Torn's acclaimed performance as a low-down country music star in ''Payday'' (Jan. 8).

GREBB--Jack A., M.D., a psychiatrist who worked for 15 years leading the development of various psychiatric, neurologic, and pain drugs at pharmaceutical companies, died on November 1. He was 54. The cause was esophageal cancer. Dr. Grebb graduated from Mount Hermon School, and obtained his B.A. and M.D. degree's from the University of Vermont. Dr. Grebb completed his psychiatric internship and residency at the University of California at San Francisco, after which he completed a research fellowship at the National Institute of Mental Health in Washington, DC. Following his training, Dr. Grebb held joint academic appointments at the Laboratory of Molecular and Cellular Neuroscience at The Rockefeller University, and in the Department of Psychiatry at New York University Medical Center. His major areas of research interest were schizophrenia, substance abuse, and the study of signal transduction in the nervous system. In 1992, Dr. Grebb started work at Abbott Laboratories, and subsequently moved to Johnson & Johnson, and then BristolMyers Squibb Company, at which companies he was in charge of the development of a number of major pharmaceuticals used in the treatment of psychiatric, neurological, and pain disorders. In addition to his research activities, Dr. Grebb was a contributing editor for the Kaplan & Sadocks Comprehensive Textbook of Psychiatry, a leading textbook in the field. His extensive contributions centered on the areas of basic neuroscience and clinical psychopharmacology. Dr. Grebb also maintained his lifelong interest as a performer of classical organ music. Dr. Grebb started playing the organ when he was five years old, and held numerous church positions throughout his early training. Following his medical training, Dr. Grebb continued his music career by presenting benefit concerts in the US and Europe for a wide range of social and medical causes, including groups focused on the support of individuals and families with major mental illnesses. Dr. Grebb was born on April 8, 1953 in Worcester, MA. Dr. Grebb is survived by his life partner, George Merema, of Stony Creek, CT; his mother, Jean Grebb, of Arlington, VA, and his brother, Michael Grebb, of Arlington, VA. Dr. Grebb lived his life with integrity and passion and his generosity and kind heart were an inspiration to all who knew him. Friends and family are invited to attend a memorial service on January 20, 2008 at 2:00pm in Branford. For directions go to www.firstcongregational branford.org or call 203-4887201.
