Somewhere between the inevitable ''It's a Wonderful Life'' and the creepily campy ''Ernest Saves Christmas'' there is a perfect holiday movie for the whole family -- one that will keep both the smirk on your teenager's face and the tears flowing from your in-laws' eyes. That movie is Billy Wilder's 1960 masterpiece, ''The Apartment.'' Not a classic Christmas movie, you say? Look again. The action takes place primarily from Christmas Eve to New Year's Eve, with moments that sum up to perfection the Christmas spirit according to Wilder: the despicable Sheldrake (played with greedy zest by Fred MacMurray), handing his downtrodden mistress, Fran Kubelik (Shirley MacLaine), her present, a crisp $100 bill; the prolonged Christmas Eve-to-Christmas Day sequence, in which Buddy Baxter (Jack Lemmon, above) finds her, overdosed on sleeping pills, at his apartment and, with the help of his next-door neighbor, force-feeds her coffee and slaps her repeatedly to keep her from collapse; and, most memorably, Sheldrake on the phone in his White Plains house, his children playing with their new toys around the Christmas tree in the background as he heartlessly hears the news of his mistress's suicide attempt. When Fran finally dumps Sheldrake and races back to Buddy's apartment on New Year's Eve, she hears, just as she reaches the door, the loud retort of a suicide shot -- only to discover that the sound was Buddy, alone, popping open a magnum of Champagne.

MOONDOG Before He Was Famous

Richard Lester's 1964 ''Hard Day's Night'' showed the Beatles, right, working eight days a week. In Mr. Lester's ''Help!,'' released a year later, John, Paul, George and Ringo try to take a holiday -- an enforced one, as they flee various baddies who covet a ceremonial ring that has become stuck on Ringo's finger -- and find escape is impossible. Absurd, delightful and exuberantly messy, ''Help!'' is pure pleasure to watch (especially now that, for the first time, it's available in a letterbox version). But there is also a great deal of sweet sadness around its edges. The Beatles' casual charm was part of what made them lovable. Two tweedy old ladies on the street catch sight of the boys and beam at them with affection: ''So natural! And still the same as they was before they was.'' But they aren't the same. One of the most enduring images of ''A Hard Day's Night'' was that of the Beatles being pursued by armies of screaming girls. In ''Help!'' a power-mad potentate (played by the silly and wonderful Leo McKern) hurls darts at their images, projected onto a screen; later they perform ''I Need You'' in a field while protected by army tanks. They're a pop group under siege. Even their hair had talismanic value. In one of the documentaries included in the extras here, the movie's hairdresser, Betty Glasow, recalls fielding requests from fans worldwide for locks of Beatle hair. She confesses that she still has a bit of John's, tucked away in a copy of his book ''A Spaniard in the Works.'' She tells us what he wrote inside: ''To Betty, with hair.'' (Capitol, Nov. 6, two-disc set, $29.98; two-disc deluxe version, $134.99) STEPHANIE ZACHAREK

FRIED ROTHFELD--Kay. With loved ones by her side, Kay entered eternal rest after a long illness on October 20, 2007. Born in Rockaway, Queens to Harold and Clare Krueger; she lived in NYC for the past 50 years. She was predeceased by her husband Bertram Rothfeld. She is survived by her three beloved sons, Richard Fried of Connecticut, Brian Fried and his wife Dawn of Connecticut, and Michael Rothfeld and his longtime girlfriend Debbie Perez of New York. Kay is also survived by her adoring granddaughters, Katherine, Elisabeth, and Madeline Fried. Other surviving relatives include the Cornings of Queens, and life-long friend, Judith Porter of California. Kay was a NYC public school educator for 30 years, spearheaded the P.E.P. program at PS 198 in the 80's and co-authored ''Opening Hearts and Classrooms to Love and Learning''. After her retirement, she taught Citizenship and ESL classes. Her love for animals led to passionate involvement in animal rights groups and to the Catskill Animal Sanctuary. A memorial service will be held on December 1, 2007 at 10:00am at Saint Joseph's Church at 404 East 87th St., New York, NY.

KELLEHER--Bradford. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Brad Kelleher, who for the past 58 years has been a stalwart, inventive, inspirational, and brilliant member of the Museum's staff, pioneering and then cultivating to its broad level of success the field of museum merchandising. At a pivotal moment in 1950, as a young sales manager, he opened the Met's first art and book shop -little more than a rack of postcards at first -at the main information desk. Under his leadership the popularity of the publishing and reproduction business grew, soon to include not only books and other printed materials but James R. Houghton, Chrmn. Philippe de Montebello, Dir. Emily K. Rafferty, President

Auctions are often the last resort. After years of quietly offering works to collectors without success, sellers turn to the auction houses in the hope that wider exposure and a heady mood will bring strong prices. While Christie's catalog says that ''Le Jas de Bouffan'' is ''property from a distinguished collection,'' it is actually being sold by Seibu, a Japanese corporation, which acquired it at Sotheby's in 1990 for $7.1 million. For years Seibu has sought unsuccessfully to sell it privately. Similarly, the dealers Walter Feilchenfeldt (Zurich) and William Acquavella of New York have been quietly trying to sell van Gogh's ''Fields'' for months.

If anything characterizes the 21st century, it's our inability to restrain ourselves for the benefit of other people. The cellphone talker thinks his rights go above that of people around him, and the jammer thinks his are the more important rights. JAMES KATZ, director of the Center for Mobile Communication Studies at Rutgers University. [20]

With a year to go until Election Day, the Republican and Democratic Parties are going through internal battles over their very identity, even as the races for their presidential nominations intensify. In many ways, the battles over how the parties will define themselves in the post-Bush era are nearly as significant a political fight as the presidential contest itself. The continued strength of Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York mayor who supports abortion rights and gay rights, is testing the question of whether social issues still drive Republican primary voters. Mr. Giuliani is talking about terrorism, cutting taxes, his record in managing New York City government -- but he has made no serious effort to shade his positions to appeal to the social conservatives who helped reshape the party over the past three decades and helped President Bush win the White House twice.

de TRENCK--Charles, born in Moravia in 1920, died November 1, Fort Lauderdale, Florida. He is survived by his son, Charles and daughter, Alexandra and his grandchildren, Charlotte, Thomas, and Arianne. Charles lost his partner of over 50 years, Mary Elizabeth Irvine de Trenck in January 2006. He was a resident of NYC, Geneva, Switzerland, Scottsdale, Arizona, and Fort Lauderdale. Charles came to the US in 1942 and served in the US Army after having served in the French army before it was disbanded at the outset of WWII. He later began a career on Wall Street at Bache Securities (1952-1958), after running an Army Jeep re-sale business and working in real estate after WWII. By 1964 he was at American Express and moved his family to Switzerland where Charles ran two private banks between 1965 and 1973. Charles' optimism, good humor, generosity and deep sense of honor were appreciated by all. There will be a memorial service at St. John the Baptist Catholic Church, 4595 Bayview Dr., Fort Lauderdale on Saturday November 10, 10am. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Society of St. Vincent de Paul.

SHECKMAN--Dr. Edward. A beloved brother who enriched our lives and will be missed. Ruth and Nathan SHECKMAN--Dr. Edward (known as Eddie)/d, born October 24, 1917 in New York City, died at age 90, peacefully at home in New York on October 29, 2007 after a long illness. He was surrounded by family and friends. He graduated from the University of Michigan and after he completed his medical studies at NYU, he served in the army as Captain and Surgeon during WWII. He returned to New York to become Chief resident at NYU Medical Center and was a lifetime faculty member at NYU Medical School. In addition to practicing medicine, he was a true renaissance man. He broadened his interest to include a successful business career, and became an accomplished photographer whose work was exhibited in New York and Florida. A consummate New Yorker, Dr. Sheckman loved art, classical music, jazz, opera, and just about anything New York had to offer. He was a member of many of our city's museums, and a lifetime supporter of the New York Philharmonic. More than anything he loved people, especially those closest to him. The longevity of his friendships are astounding. Both his wives, Mona Bronfman of Montreal and Dorothy Morrow of New York, predeceased him. He is survived by his adoring granddaughter, Meadow Rose of New York, a brother, Dr. Nathan (Ruth) Sheckman of Fort Meyers, Florida, a sister, Dorothy Lazarus of Wareham, Massachusetts, four nephews, Dr. Peter and Richard Sheckman and Melvin and Steve Lazarus. At the request of the family, services will be private. Donations may be made in Dr. Sheckman's name to Continuum Hospice Care, 1775 Broadway Suite 300, NY, NY 10019.

TALESNICK--Barry, age 60, died well on October 21 at home with a quiet mind and almost no effort. Tender husband to soulmate Gaynor Cote, devoted son of Harry and Dorothy, brother of Ken and Terry, uncle, loving friend, he was a native New Yorker, taxi driver, school teacher, City administrator, performer and massage therapist. A member of the a capella group ''The Art Mob'', he appeared often as the heartthrob lead singer of ''Barry and the Barrytones''. Barry was grateful for his near-decade survival since the diagnosis of an advanced cancer. His great realization was to live in the moment. Please donate to City Harvest and eat a simple meal with consciousness and gratitude.

IN A SEASON of boyfriend cardigans -- slouchy oversized sweaters designed to look as if the wearer borrowed them from her Big Strong Boyfriend -- Nanette Lepore's sequined version is leaving the competition behind. In charcoal gray with panels of bronze sequins, the wool-and-cashmere-blend sweater ($275 at saksfifthavenue.com) is cut generously without being overpowering. A perfect example of fall's penchant for daytime sequins, it can dress up skinny jeans or leggings or add a touch of glamour to a no-nonsense shirt-dress or pencil skirt. Or simply throw it on over a flirty minidress. Best of all? You don't have to worry that your boyfriend will try to steal it back.

After writing some of the best screenplays Hollywood had ever heard (like ''Chinatown'' and ''Shampoo''), Robert Towne let the images do the talking when he made his directing debut with this 1982 film about women's track and field. Only Kon Ichikawa's epic documentary ''Tokyo Olympiad'' (1965) surpasses it for the sheer ability to put audiences in the bodies of athletes. Reversing the solemn, phony ''Chariots of Fire'' approach, Mr. Towne and the cinematographer Michael Chapman shoot the beginnings of scenes in slow motion, emphasizing what goes into the moments before a shot put, a pole vault, a race. The movie drinks in the Southern California light and air; after a while the amplified breathing on the soundtrack might feel like your own. And because the emphasis, as the title suggests, is on ''personal best,'' the movie stands in opposition to the world-beater ethos that, in the Reagan years, boomed out of Hollywood and Washington. ''Personal Best'' caused controversy because the movie explores its subject through the story of Chris (Mariel Hemingway, below right, with Jodi Anderson at center), a talented teenage athlete lacking in confidence, and Tory (the athlete Patrice Donnelly, above left) proving herself an instinctual, immensely likable actor), an experienced track-and-fielder who becomes Chris's mentor and lover. The gay press accused Mr. Towne of portraying lesbianism as a phase, which proved the blindness of viewing art through the lens of ideology. The love story is the natural response of two people trained to think with their bodies. To believe that Chris is ''cured'' of her orientation when she and Tory break up, you'd have to be foolish enough to believe that first love lasts, and you'd have to ignore the movie's final line. ''Personal Best'' is agog with wonder at the women before its camera, at the awesome capabilities of the human body and at the staggering variety of human potential. That wonder can't be dwarfed by anyone's insistence on what the norm should be. (Warner Brothers, Jan. 8, $19.97) CHARLES TAYLOR

It may seem like a small thing -- a new well to give decent drinking water to 71 families in Raquette Lake, a small town north of Utica in the Adirondacks. But the town's request for permission to build the well on state parkland is the only constitutional issue that voters across New York will be asked to approve next Tuesday. New Yorkers should vote yes. And lovers of the Adirondacks should be extremely relieved that even this modest request, for a structure 10 feet wide and 12 feet long, needs statewide approval before it can be built in one of the pristine areas of the park. The reason for all this effort is that since the six-million-acre park was created in 1892, nearly three million acres of forest has been preserved as ''forever wild'' by the state Constitution. There is plenty of private land in the park, with 130,000 permanent residents, and there are enough lakes and mountains and trails and cabins to lure about 10 million visitors a year. But when the founders of the park put some sections off limits -- deeming it to be of such importance that almost nothing new should be built on it -- they clearly meant business.

The Future Is Drying Up Instead of comparing Las Vegas's water boss, Pat Mulroy, to Robert Moses, Jon Gertner (Oct. 21) would do better to draw the comparison to William Mulholland, who similarly tried to solve his city's water needs with a pipeline. In Mulholland's zeal to supply growing Los Angeles with water, he turned Owens Valley from a verdant agricultural oasis to a desert.

Eric Mangini vs. Joe Gibbs At first glance, the coaches who meet today at Giants Stadium seem like opposites. Washington's Joe Gibbs turns 67 this month. The Jets' Eric Mangini is 36. Gibbs's expertise is offense, and Mangini is a defensive specialist. Gibbs led the Redskins to a 5-11 record last season; this year, they are 4-3. Last year, Mangini guided the Jets to a 10-6 record; this year, they are 1-7.

LENA PHILIPPOU KORRES of Korres Natural Products, a line of high-end plant-based beauty products made in Greece, is delighted that the brand's first American store just opened on Wooster Street in New York. ''I love SoHo,'' she said from her office in Athens. ''I'll never forget my first time there. It was eight years ago, and I was pregnant, so I couldn't shop.'' Now, she can make up for lost time. Mrs. Korres, 36, a chemical engineer who is married to the company's founder, George Korres, said that her personal style mirrors the brand's philosophy. ''Korres's packaging and products are understated, polite and kind,'' she said. ''I love Hermès and Gaultier, but they might be a bit much for the brand. I wear a lot of jeans by J Brand and Dsquared. And I love Balenciaga and Martin Margiela, but I don't wear their most bold things.''

KASMAN--Dorothy, retired corporate librarian, died on Wednesday, October 31st, 2007 at the Mayflower Nursing Home, in West Yarmouth, MA. She was 89 years old. She died of pneumonia and complications of Alzheimer's, her family said. Funeral services will be held Sunday, November 4th at Riverside Memorial Chapel, New York City, at 10:00am. Miss Kasman, a native of Trenton, gained a Bachelor of Arts from Douglass College (now part of Rutgers University) in 1941 and Master of Library Science in 1957. She received a Masters in Business Administration from New York University in 1970. From 1956 to 1958 she was the librarian at the Textile Research Institute, in Princeton, NJ. She moved to New York City in 1958, joining Coopers & Lybrand (now PricewaterhouseCoopers), as Chief Librarian, a position she held for over 30 years. During those years, she gave freely of her time, mentoring many individuals who wished to enter the library profession. In addition to her corporate work, she volunteered as a tutor for young adults learning English as a second language. She was an honored member of the Special Libraries Association, serving on numerous committees over the years, was awarded the Distinguished Member Award in 1988 and inducted into the SLA Hall of Fame in 1991. She was a past chairperson of the SLA Business & Finance Division and a past treasurer for the organization (1979-1982). She was the co-author of ''Education for Special Librarianship,'' Special Libraries 67:504-509 (Nov 1976). During WWII, she volunteered at the USO, the Red Cross, and the Army & Navy War Training Program. Miss Kasman never married. She is survived by her nieces and nephews, Stephen Gayner, Jay Gayner, Howard Kasman and Sandy Kasman and grandnieces and grandnephews. She will be remembered forever as ''Auntie Dot.''

A few women of style, seen in New York and Paris, have revived the daytime clutch or envelope bag, moving away from the large bag with handles. The clutch, a fixture in the 1930s, was replaced after World War II by the handbag with handles. It's hard to believe the clutch, with its limited space, is upstaging the current status symbols. The idea that working women are reintroducing the bag, once an elegant symbol of women who lunch, flies in the face of practicality.

At the time of its release Martin Scorsese's ''New York, New York'' (1977) came off as a failed experiment: Mr. Scorsese had wanted to make a highly stylized movie musical, complete with exuberant, candy-toned production numbers, about a couple whose relationship is not just frayed at the edges but on the verge of rotting through. Robert De Niro, left, is an ambitious swing-era musician who somehow plays with feeling, even though his face has the blank coldness of an empty staff. Liza Minnelli, left, is the singer who falls for him against her better judgment. (Ms. Minnelli's eager warmth, and the way her character approaches this jagged, damaging romance with the optimism of the doomed, make the performance deeply touching.) ''New York, New York'' befuddled and angered audiences at the time -- Weren't movie musicals supposed to be cheerful? And why is Mr. De Niro playing such a creep? -- although over the years adventurous moviegoers have warmed to its admittedly chilly charms. This 30th-anniversary edition -- the uncut version, more fully rounded than the one originally released in theaters -- offers the chance for another look at this strange, ambitious almost-masterpiece. Mr. Scorsese, the cinematographer Laszlo Kovacs and the production designer Boris Leven gave the movie a striking, retro-inventive look: A tense romantic confrontation takes place among a stand of poetically fake-looking trees that appear to be something out of ''Camelot.'' And although the movie is awkwardly paced, it digs fearlessly into dangerous, subterranean emotions. Its troubled characters know the real meaning of singin' in the rain. (MGM, Dec. 4, $19.98) STEPHANIE ZACHAREK

I saw ''The Poseidon Adventure'' when it was released, December 1972. I was 10 years old. I saw it at my local cinema (the Olympia on 107th and Broadway -- your feet stuck to the floor!) at least three times. Every single time the audience gasped and screamed and leaned sideways in their seats as the boat capsized and was utterly silent when the seas finally calmed. I really identified with Robin, the little boy played by Eric Shea, who was about my age. (I got hold of the book by Paul Gallico soon after I saw the movie and was shocked to see that he pretty much killed Robin off right away. Happily, the producers chose to let him live.) I was sure that, given the chance, I would be the one who had the information that the adults did not. (''The hull is only an inch thick by the propeller shaft!'') I wished that I could scramble up a green tinsel Christmas tree and make my way to the top of an upside-down boat. What better way to spend New Year's Eve?

LERNER--Abram, the founding director of the Joseph H. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in Washington, DC, died October 31st in Connecticut at the age of 94. Mr. Lerner became Joseph H. Hirshhorn's curator, advisor, and confidant in 1955 and was instrumental in building a collection that became a part of the Smithsonian Institution. He oversaw research, conservation, and installation of more than 6,000 items brought from the Hirshhorns' Connecticut estate and other properties to the Hirshhorn Museum located on the Mall in Washington, DC. He was the museum's director from its opening in 1974 until his retirement in 1984. The Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden is one of the world's leading museums of international modern and contemporary art. He was also a painter whose work is represented in the Hirshhorn Museum and in various private collections. He leaves his daughter, Aline Libassi and two grandchildren, Matthew Benjamin Libassi and Francesca Libassi. LERNER--Abram (Al)/d, passed away October 31st, 2007. Beloved brother-in-law of Dorothy Hanenberg and uncle of Kate Hanenberg, Richard Hanenberg and Sophia (Lee) deBoer. Devoted and loving great-uncle to Maisie, James and Annie. He will be missed. Loving sympathy to his daughter, Aline Libassi and grandchildren, Matthew and Francesca Libassi.

You are not seeing double. Sotheby's and Christie's both have mystical gray-and-black paintings by Mark Rothko, executed the same year and painted on the same size (60 by 68 inches) canvas. The sellers of Sotheby's version, the Iowa collectors John and Mary Pappajohn, bought it at Christie's for $800,000 in 1996. Christie's Rothko was purchased from the John Weber Gallery by an unidentified collector. Why Sotheby's Rothko is supposedly worth $2 million to $3 million more is anyone's guess.

In Cristian Mungiu's ''4 Months, 3 Weeks and 2 Days'' (Jan. 25) the Romanian actress Anamaria Marinca plays Otilia, a college student in her early 20s in Bucharest, who, by the story's end, has the disillusioned gaze of someone who isn't young at all. The movie, which won the Palme d'Or at Cannes this year, is set on a single day in 1987 in Romania, two years before the violent end of the Ceausescu regime, which had outlawed both abortion and contraception. Otilia's best friend, Gabita, is pregnant and barely capable of facing the brute reality of her circumstances. It falls to Otilia to wheedle, bribe and contend with the grotesque demands of the leather-jacketed abortionist who creepily calls himself Mr. Bébé, and to provide what comfort she can to her hapless friend.

THE REST IS NOISE: Listening to the Twentieth Century, by Alex Ross. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $30.) In his own impressive feat of orchestration, The New Yorker's music critic presents a history of the last century as refracted through its classical music. LOST GENIUS: The Curious and Tragic Story of an Extraordinary Musical Prodigy, by Kevin Bazzana. (Carroll & Graf, $28.) The rise, fall and peculiar comeback of the pianist Ervin Nyiregyhazi.

The Canadian actress Ellen Page is a phenom waiting to happen. She has been working steadily for 10 years and caught Hollywood's eye with her scarifying turn in the 2005 female revenge drama ''Hard Candy.'' But, along with another fine young actor, Ben Foster, she was wasted in last year's disappointing ''X-Men: The Last Stand.'' Now she's getting the breakout movie she deserves. As the eponymous heroine of ''Juno'' (Dec. 5), a comedy about a pregnant 16-year-old that is being touted as this year's ''Little Miss Sunshine,'' Ms. Page, left, owns her character the way Audrey Hepburn owned Holly Golightly, and the role is going to make her a star.

As the editor in chief of Vogue Living, as well as the author of the new book ''Vogue Living: Houses, Gardens, People'' (Knopf), Hamish Bowles knows his Rose Cumming chintz from his Tassinari & Chatel taffeta. So it wasn't too much of a stretch to ask him to select items from Restoration Hardware that would be at home in his overstuffed living room. Among his selections were ''elegant prewar debutante'' glass and Lucite lamps; crystal-tipped curtain rods that are ''one step away from Adnan Khashoggi''; glass étagères for the bath, repurposed for the living room (''I could sort of see having pairs of these with a series of Cecil Beaton photographs or Windsor biographies on them''); tufted chairs to flank a console (though he'd ebonize the legs); and an English-looking love seat to add a ''faintly David Hicksian feel -- or it would by the time I reupholstered it.'' Says the globe-trotting savant with a sigh, ''I think my living room might not hold any more than that.''

PAPADOPOULOS-Constantin D., M.D., 1929-2007. Born in Cairo, Egypt, Constantin D. Papadopoulos received his bachelor of science degree and medical degree, Summa Cum Laude, from the University of Louvain, Belgium. After a short internship in Paris, France and at the French Hospital in Manhattan, he began a long association with The Brooklyn Hospital Center where he started as a surgical resident in 1955 and rose to Chief of Vascular Surgery in 1963 until his retirement in 1998. He was president of the Brooklyn Surgical Society, member of the Steering Committee for the Federation of Cardiovascular Clinics of the New York Heart Association from 1969-1979. He was a member of the New York Cardiovascular Society, Diplomat of the American Board of Vascular Surgery, Clinical Professor of Surgery, New York University, Clinical Professor of Surgery at SUNY and International Society of Cardiovascular Surgery, having studied under Dr. Michael Debakey, he was a member of the Michael E. Debakey Cardiovascular Society, Eastern Vascular Society, Society for Clinical Vascular Surgery, American College of Surgeons, New York Academy of Medicine and many others. Dr. Papadopoulos, a professor of vascular surgery was an avid teacher having trained in excess of 140 chief residents in surgery and 18 fellows in vascular surgery. With 22 vascular surgical publications and unparalleled clinical experience, Dr. Papadopoulos rose to the rank of clinical professor of surgery in 1985 and was the first surgeon to be certified in vascular surgery by the American Board of Surgery in the borough of Brooklyn and was recertified in 1993 at the age of 64. In 1962, through his efforts, the first vascular laboratory was created at the Brooklyn Hospital Center, the first such facility in New York. Through his efforts and his keen interest in what was new, in 1991 the first endovascular suite in New York State was created at the Brooklyn Hospital Center. In 1995, Constantin Papadopoulos, M.D. was awarded the prestigious Walter E. Reed Medal given to those who carry on a tradition of excellence and commitment. Constantin Papadopoulos passed away on Wednesday, October 31st in Greenwich, Connecticut and is survived by his wife Julie, sons Dimitri and Tomas and daughter Tara. A viewing will be held from 2-4pm and 7-9pm on Monday and Tuesday, November 5th and 6th with a memorial service being held at 8pm, Tuesday November 6th. Viewing and memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street in New York City, Telephone: 212-288-3500.

TANDEM SKYDIVING OVER THE ROCKIES, JUNE 14, 2007 Gianni Tanza (with face visible), 23, a butcher's apprentice from Denver. ''We didn't get to do it in the Marine Corps, so my friend Fred and I were like 'Hey, for 190 bucks, let's do it.' The plane was a little Cessna -- kind of a jalopy of a plane. And there was some young 16- or 18-year-old kid flying it, so it was like, 'Wow, I guess these guys are professionals.' As we were climbing, I was just looking down on Boulder with all the lakes that are around it, and I'm thinking, 'I don't even know where I'm going to be landing.' At about 10,000 feet, I think, they open the door and you just fall out of the airplane. It was pretty exhilarating. You look up and the airplane keeps getting smaller and smaller, and you look down and the ground is getting closer and closer. It's crazy. I was screaming with excitement, giving a good war cry.''

Ahmad Khan Mahmoodzada was 11 when he was chosen to play his first movie role, one of two Afghan boys -- Hassan and Amir -- who are friends in ''The Kite Runner'' (Dec. 14). Marc Forster's adaptation of the 2003 best-selling novel by Khalid Hosseini is about the search for redemption by the adult Amir, years after betraying his boyhood companion. But in the lengthy flashback to the boys' friendship, Ahmad, above, is so quietly powerful that his Hassan ranks among the great child performances on film. As has been widely reported, the event that sets Amir's betrayal in motion is the attack on Hassan by a posse of older boys whose leader rapes him; although the depiction of the rape on screen is discreet, it is expected to be so offensive to conservative Afghan sensibilities that both young actors and their families are leaving Afghanistan and moving to the United Arab Emirates at the expense of Paramount Vantage.

Flights to Ibiza from the United States require a plane change. A recent online search for flights in mid-November found an Iberia flight from Kennedy Airport via Madrid, starting at $620, and a Delta flight to Barcelona with a change to Air Europa Lineas Aereas, starting at $680; a Continental flight from Newark, with a change in Barcelona to Spanair, started at $922. A car is needed to get around the island. Alamo, Hertz and Eurocar have offices at the airport, with rentals for about $75 a day. Cas Gasi (Camino Viejo de Sant Mateu; 34-971-19-77-00; www.casgasi.com) is a large farmhouse that was converted into a beautiful agritourism hotel, with 10 modest rooms, two suites and a restaurant with an organic menu. Guests have included Robert DeNiro and Kate Moss. Rooms start at 303 euros, or about $440 at $1.45 to the euro.

SEIGLE--Harold J., 84, Former CEO, Golfer, and Gardner. Woodstock, Vermont and Palm Beach, Florida. A celebration of life will be held for Hal Seigle, who died October 31, 2007 after a long battle with lymphoma cancer at Forest Hills Cemetery, Boston, Massachusetts on November 17, 2007 at the Forsyth Chapel 11:00am, graveside burial to follow after service. Hal was born in Philadelphia, PA in 1923. He attended Leigh University and majored in chemical engineering, earned varsity letters in soccer and track. While attending college he was in ROTC and was called to active duty for WWII. He returned to Leigh after the war to complete his undergraduate degree with honors in 1947. He later took night classes and received a Master's at the University of Michigan and a MBA at the University of Chicago. He had a very successful career in business, becoming President of Head Ski Company in 1967 in Timonium, MD, then onto Executive President of King-Seeley Thermos in Connecticut and Michigan in the 70s, and his final business position was President of Sunmark Candy Company (Willy Wonka/ NERDS) in St. Louis, MO until his retirement it the late 80s. After retiring Hal spent time between Woodstock, VT and Palm Beach, FL, enjoying visits from his family and friends. He was an avid golfer, cribbage player, and loved gardening. He also volunteered with SCORE mentoring small business people and donating his time and expertise in business to local boards. Survivors include his wife Rosemarie of Woodstock, VT. His children Lisa Byrnes of Towson, MD, Jeff Seigle of Vienna, VA, Jody Loring of Woodstock, VT, John Loring of Honolulu, HI, Susan Moscillo of Waterown, MA, Cindy Hinnendael of Bluffton, SC, 10 grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, his sister Shirley Shils of Narbeth, PA, and nieces and nephews. Memorial contributions may be made to Dana Farber Cancer Institute, 44 Binney Street, Boston, MA 02115 and Make-a-Wish Foundation, 10920 Connecticut Avenue, Kensington, MD 20895.

FIRST, JESSICA KAGAN CUSHMAN inscribed mammoth tusk bangles with flip pop-culture phrases. Now, Derrick Cruz, the designer of Black Sheep and Prodigal Sons, takes scrimshaw a bit more seriously. His unisex necklaces originate in some spectral Edwardian parlor: they're made from vintage piano keys, salvaged from instruments that preceded the ivory-trade ban (Mr. Cruz prefers 1920s Drachmann player pianos). The keys are set in sterling silver with gold rivets and etched with a needle, in the tradition popularized by 19th-century whalers. Look for the Moby Dick-inspired Lovers necklace (far left) embellished with a squid and a whale, and the Raging Sea necklace, on which a ship founders in a tiny tempest; $620 to $685 at BBlessing in New York, (212) 378-8005. The terrible and wonderful thing about Alan Parker's 1982 ''Shoot the Moon,'' in which Albert Finney and Diane Keaton play the two halves of a disintegrating couple, is how well it understands that mutual bitterness is still a connection. Memories of happiness may be stronger than happiness itself. No wonder those memories sometimes calcify into a kind of superglue between two people who were once in love. ''Shoot the Moon'' is a relic from a time when you could make a Hollywood movie about two adults and their problems. All of the drama comes from the dialogue (the script is by Bo Goldman, who wrote ''Melvin and Howard'' and adapted ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'') and from the actors' faces. Mr. Finney, above with Dana Hill, left, and Tracey Gold, plays George, a stubborn, volatile writer who has worked hard over the years to support his wife, Faith (Ms. Keaton), and the couple's four daughters; he has also been having an affair with a somewhat younger woman, Sandy (Karen Allen, whose performance is terrific because of its unnerving crispness). Faith has looked after the children all these years and kept her husband going too. When, after a cool but vicious fight, George concedes it's time to move out of the house, Faith announces she has already packed his bag. The suggestion is that she can't break old habits, that she still needs to ensure he will have enough underwear, shirts and socks for his new life, even if it doesn't include her. ''Shoot the Moon'' never allows our sympathies to rest comfortably with one party or the other. Ms. Keaton's performance is a marvelous rendering of resolve and vulnerability at war with each other. But even if her character is the more aggrieved party, there is no way to write off the anguish on Mr. Finney's face when, after George tries to pay Faith a compliment, she shoots an insult straight into his heart by recalling some ancient transgression. ''You always remember the wrong things,'' he tells her, his voice (and his heart) numbed and flattened -- though the movie knows, as we do, that once a couple has reached the point of no return, remembering the right things is far more painful. (Warner Home Video, Nov. 6, $19.98) STEPHANIE ZACHAREK

BLUTT--Herbert, 85, of Windsor CT, beloved husband of Rose (Deckel) Blutt, died peacefully on October 24, 2007 at his home surrounded by his family. Born on June 20, 1922 in the Bronx, NY, he was the son of the late Harry and Tillie (Cohen) Blutt. Herb was a graduate of Evander Childs High School in the Bronx and went on to study at the City College of New York. He proudly served our country during WWII with the U.S. Air Force in the Philippines and Japan. Herbert was married to the love of his life, his childhood sweetheart, Rose, in 1944. Together they moved to Hartford, CT, in 1956, settling in Windsor, CT, in 1960. Herbert was a member of the Congregation Beth Ahm in Windsor, CT, where he served as the Ritual Committee Chairman since 1997. He attended services weekly for over 47 years and was beloved by the entire congregation. Herbert received the State of Connecticut United Synagogue Distinguished Service Award in 2005. He was a member of the Jewish Community Center of Hartford, CT, where he was an avid swimmer and physical fitness fanatic. Herbert worked as a Diesel Engineer for the Stanadyne Corporation for over 30 years, and taught engineering for various technical schools in the Hartford area. He was also the head of Stanadyne's Worldwide Training Education. Herb had a way with words that was a great help to him in being able to talk with and make friends with anyone. Herb was an avid Yankees Fan, a pastime he loved to share with his wife, Rose. He was a fearless fighter in facing the many illnesses he encountered throughout his life, which helped to put his family at ease. Besides his wife of 63 years, Rose, he leaves two sons, Jay Blutt and his wife Joni of Simsbury, CT, and Mitchell Blutt and his wife Margo of New York, NY; a brother, Seymour Blutt of New York, NY; and five grandchildren, Adam and Andrew Blutt and Gillian, Eliza and Emerson Blutt. His funeral and burial, with Military Honors, was held on Friday October 26th in Windsor, CT. Please visit www.carmonfuneralhome .com for online condolences.

1. Alain Ducasse may be celebrated for his multi-starred cuisine, but his latest venture is all about wine. Not only is the dining room of Adour (scheduled to open in January in New York's St. Regis Hotel) surrounded by an open wine cellar, but there's also a state-of-the-art interactive tasting room that enables diners to project the details of a vintage onto their table. ''New Yorkers have become much more interested in pairing food and wine, and this is a totally unique approach,'' the chef says. 2. Two of his pet picks are the 2004 Fombrauge, ''an elegant and powerful white from St. Ãmilion, a terroir known mainly for its reds,'' and the 2003 Pape Clément, ''an absolute coup de coeur of mine.'' He would pair them both with his shellfish velouté, a mixture of clams, cuttlefish, squid and bread. ''This is a dish that completely sums up Adour,'' he notes. ''It can go with both a white and unexpectedly a red.'

Paul Dano has always been an extraordinarily contained, even enigmatic young actor. In his award-winning performance in last year's ''Little Miss Sunshine,'' as the gawky, goth big brother who takes a vow of silence, he was poignant, weird and lovable all at once. But he didn't reveal his emotions openly; you had to guess at them from his body language and mobile face. Before that Mr. Dano, 23, above, was hardly idle. Since his standout performance in the 2001 ''L. I. E.,'' as an emotionally abandoned suburban teenager who falls under the sway of a predatory older man, he has contributed solid supporting work in nine feature films.

CONDREN--William J., Palm Beach, Florida and Southampton, New York died after a lengthy illness on October 29, 2007 at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, surrounded by his family. He was 74 years old. A graduate of Chaminade High School, Fordham University and Harvard Law School, he was a private investor with interests in real estate and equipment leases. In 1966, after practicing law for seven years, he pioneered the leveraged lease financing of railroad equipment and aircraft, which structure he later applied to public utility generating equipment, off-shore drilling equipment, oil tankers and other marine equipment. He was involved in the syndication of subsidized housing projects in New York, Florida and Massachusetts, and the financing of the initial rehabilitation of a block on West 42nd Street known as Theatre Row Phase II, which was sold in 2004 for further redevelopment. He was a lifelong fan of horseracing and co-owned several successful horses, including two Kentucky Derby winners and a Preakness winner. He was a co-founder and director of the National Thoroughbred Association, a trustee for the Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association, and a director of the Grayson-Jockey Club Research Foundation. He is survived by his wife Mary Jo, son Colin, and daughters Elizabeth and Jennifer. A memorial service will be held in New York City on Friday, November 9th, at 10:00am at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street.

''A well-tied tie is the first serious step in life,'' wrote Oscar Wilde. So of course neckwear, well tied and not, shows up on campus. Ties and scarves aren't just for college dandies, but preppies have a decided home-field advantage. George Hilton (above, in bow tie and flip-flops), a sophomore at Washington & Lee in Lexington, Va., says he and his buddies dress up for fun. One of his friends wears a bow tie every Tuesday -- ''Tie Tuesday,'' he calls it. At Vanderbilt, classes are the special occasion. ''People here treat it like going out,'' says Greg Russell (at right), a senior who also wears a tie for tailgate parties and career events. Vandies, too, don bow ties, in imitation of their recently departed chancellor, Gordon Gee. ''It just became a Vanderbilt thing,'' he says.

Each season there are always a few works that set hearts beating. The Picasso head, depicting his mistress as a Greco-Roman goddess of sorts, was conceived in 1941 and cast in the 1950s in an edition of two. Insiders say it is considered one of his greatest sculptures and may well go far higher than its estimate. Experts are also buzzing about Matisse's richly patterned ''Odalisque.'' Abandoning the carefully delineated odalisques of the 1920s, he made a breakthrough in this painting to a spontaneous, simplified style. The result was a portrait that bore little resemblance to his subject, Lydia Delectorskaya, a Russian émigré and former studio assistant who was one of his favorite models.

JERRETT--Elizabeth, 63, passed away October 25, 2007, after a fierce battle with breast cancer. One of the first women to graduate from Harvard Business School, she held executive positions with Elizabeth Arden, Germaine Monteil, Converse Shoes and Posner Laboratories, before forming her own consulting firm. Elizabeth's 13 year war on breast cancer included weekly infusions of chemotherapy. Through it all she raised a son, enriched her friends with her wit, sharp humor and frequent dinners, and was determined to lead a normal life as if she were cancer-free. Raised in Baltimore, she was a passionate New Yorker, an avid reader and was nourished by the theater, concerts, the movies, the museums and her beloved Central Park. She is survived by her adored son, Trevor Huston, family and countless friends for whom she was a central thread in the fabric of their lives. Memorial donations may be made to Susan G. Komen For The Cure.

IT is tuna time in New York. I don't mean it's time for local bistros to put salade niçoise on their menus. I mean it's the time when real, live tuna -- some of them eight feet long -- enter our waters en route to their spawning grounds in the Gulf of Mexico. Here in the miraculous roiling currents of the Mudhole, 17 miles southeast of Manhattan, and further out at hotspots like the Dip, off Montauk, tuna hunt squid and speed at 30 miles per hour alongside whales, porpoises and sea turtles. It is the wildest display of unbridled nature a New York sport fisherman like myself can ever hope to see.

AS HAIRSTYLES GET smoother and bangs become the mode, the demand for flatirons has risen with celerity. In response, Warren-Tricomi has downsized with a minified version of the classic straightening iron. The six-inch wonder has ceramic tourmaline-coated plates and tucks neatly into handbags or desk drawers. Not merely for traveling or workplace preening, the diminutive appliance also offers greater control so that amateur stylists can easily tame frizzy bangs, tight side tendrils and hard-to-manipulate short cuts. It costs $90 at the Warren-Tricomi flagship salon in New York, (212) 262-8899, or warrentricomi.com.

HAVENS--Oliver Hershman, of Jupiter Island, Florida died on October 28, 2007 from complications of Parkinson's Disease. He was born on July 19, 1917 in Bradley Beach, NJ to the late Abram Vaughn Havens and Sara Mildred Atkinson Havens. He grew up in Westfield, NJ, attended public schools there and graduated Magna Cum Laude in Economics from Princeton University in 1939. He received a Bachelor of Laws (JD) degree from Yale Law School in 1942, and immediately entered the U.S. Army where he served in the American, European and Pacific theaters. He was released from active duty as Captain in the Signal Corps in 1946, and joined the Wall Street law firm of Cahill Gordon & Reindel as an associate and was admitted to the firm as partner in 1955 and retired in 1982. From 1976 to 1979, he was the firm's resident partner in Paris. He was admitted to the New York Bar in 1947 and to the Conseil Juridique in France in 1978 and was a member of the American Bar Association, the New York State Bar Association, and the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and an original member of the latter's Special Committee on Securities Regulation. A lifelong Episcopalian, Oliver served on the vestries (and in other capacities) at St. Paul's Church, Westfield, NJ, the American Cathedral in Paris, Christ Church, Short Hills, NJ, and Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island, FL. In his retirement he served as General Counsel to the United States Golf Association from 1985-1988 and was the Mayor of the Town of Jupiter Island from 1987-1993. An avid, golfer, Oliver belonged to Echo Lake Country Club, Baltusrol Golf Club, and Pine Valley Golf Club in New Jersey, and the Jupiter Island Club and Seminole Golf Club in Florida, and the Sportive du Golf de St. Cloud, France, and Royal & Ancient of St. Andrews, Scotland. He was also a member of the Short Hills Club, the Princeton Club of NY, India House, and the Nassau Club, Princeton. Oliver married the former Ervanna Josephine Cummings in 1941, who preceded him in death. He is survived by his wife of 30 years, Elizabeth Lykes Carrere Havens and by his brother, Joseph Buckley Havens and wife Elizabeth Darlington Havens, of Kennebunk, ME, and by his daughters Jan Havens Greer and husband Chilton Greer of Houston, TX and Judi Havens and husband Jerry Ferrari of Marion, MA, and his grandchildren Andrea Greer, C. Tobin Greer, Matthew Bullard, and Kate Sherman. He is also survived by his wife's children John Carrere and wife Claire, Michael Carrere and wife Elizabeth, Margaret Johnson and husband Kevin, and Joseph Carrere and wife Michele. A memorial service will be held at a later date at Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island. In lieu of flowers. donations may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, Palm Beach, FL 33407 or to the charity of your choice.

Wounded WWII veteran and recipient of Bronze Star. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Greater Boca Raton Cancer Group, 1192 E. Newport Center Dr., Deerfield Beach, FL 33442.

Twenty years ago, New York City embarked on an experiment aimed at better protecting its most vulnerable black and Latino children. At its heart, the effort involved creating and supporting foster care agencies that would, at long last, be run by men and women of color. The Times spent months examining this ambitious, billion-dollar investment in minority-run agencies – what once seemed a bold and overdue shift in one of the most challenging areas of social policy. It found a trail of scandals and disappointments, as well as a new commitment to better caring for the city’s vulnerable black and Latino children. “Breach of Faith,” by Leslie Kaufman, the first in a series of three articles, appears today on the front page. Readers are invited to post their comments here. (See an and a at one foster care provider.)

Under a blunt new A through F rating system, whose results Mayor Michael R. To find the data for your school, consult this graphic, which lists, for each school, the letter grade, the overall score and scores for school environment, student performance, student progress and additional variables.

For about a century, Mount Loretto, on the southeast coast of Staten Island overlooking the Raritan Bay, was a haven for homeless and disabled orphans. The Rev. John Christopher Drumgoole, himself an Irish immigrant, founded the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin in 1871 to help care for Irish children who had lived on Manhattan’s streets after the Irish potato famine and the Civil War. The mission moved to Staten Island in 1883 and continued, for decades, to provide vocational training and religious instruction for its charges.

This weekend, as I wrapped up my rereading of "War and Peace," I moved on to the book that will be discussed tonight in my book club - a group I formed 7 years ago, to help ensure that, what with all the editing, research, and reviewing I did in my working life, I did not lose the habit of reading for pleasure. (The same sentiment applies to all the women in my group, though some of us are not editors or writers.) A handful of books made me love reading: "Jane Eyre," "David Copperfield," "Pride and Prejudice," "The Red and the Black," "A House for Mr. Biswas," "The Brothers Karamazov," "The Heart of the Matter," "Père Goriot," everything by P.G. Wodehouse, and yes, "War and Peace." We have read several of those in book club, not "War and Peace" however. (We've noticed that books longer than 400 pages tend to defeat our best intentions.)

LAS VEGAS -- Mounting an iPod in the center of your steering wheel may seem like a convenient place to put it. But in the event of a hard frontal impact, one of two things is likely to happen: 1. Talks between the writers’ unions and producers failed to avert a strike over payments for new media, among other issues.

The failing city schools could be closed by the end of the year based on the results of a blunt new A to F system.
Drugs to raise so-called good cholesterol may still have a future despite the failure last year of an experimental treatment from Pfizer, researchers said.
Officials argued that it would be counterproductive to let Pakistan’s political turmoil interfere with their best hope of ousting Al Qaeda’s central leadership.
PetroChina, the state oil and gas giant, became the world’s first company to pass $1 trillion in market capitalization when it debuted on the Shanghai Stock Exchange today.

Nashville goalie Chris Mason made 30 saves to end a seven-game personal losing streak against the Blackhawks, and Alexander Radulov and Jason Arnott each had a goal and an assist in the Predators’ 5-2 victory in Chicago.
The Cowboys (7-1) turned in a performance to give the Giants (6-2) plenty to worry about when the teams meet Sunday in East Rutherford, N.J.

Daniel Alfredsson and Antoine Vermette scored on Ottawa’s first two chances in the shootout and Martin Gerber stopped Boston’s first two shots to lift the visiting Senators to their 12th win in their first 13 games, 2-1 over the Bruins.

David Nalbandian beat Rafael Nadal, 6-4, 6-0, to win the Paris Masters, clinching his second straight Masters title after winning in Madrid last month. Nalbandian broke Nadal in the ninth game of the first set and three times in the second. He won the match with a forehand that bounced off the net and landed inside the line. Nadal struggled with his serve in the second set, which lasted only 27 minutes. He won only 17 percent of his second-serve points and had 5 winners to Nalbandian’s 25.

Pascal Leclaire stopped 21 shots for his N.H.L.-best fifth shutout of the season as the host Columbus Blue Jackets beat the St. Louis Blues, 3-0. The Blue Jackets (8-3-2) are off to the best start in the franchise’s seven seasons.

Richard Johnson won the season-ending Nationwide Tour Championship to lead the 25 qualifiers for the 2008 PGA Tour, shooting a four-under 67 for a one-stroke victory over Michael Letzig in Lakeside, Calif.
Lindsay Davenport won her second title in three events since returning from the birth of her first child, beating third-seeded Julia Vakulenko, 6-4, 6-1, in the Bell Challenge in Quebec City.

A picture caption in Science Times on Tuesday with an article about sites in Manhattan related to the Manhattan Project misidentified the location of a cyclotron that was used for physics experiments. The cyclotron shown was the one at Nevis Laboratories in Irvington, N.Y., not the one in Pupin Hall on the campus of Columbia University. (Nevis is owned and operated by Columbia.).

A film review in Weekend on Friday about the documentary “Darfur Now” misidentified the university attended by Adam Sterling, who worked to get a bill passed to force California to divest from companies whose business benefits Sudan. It was U.C.L.A., not the University of Southern California.

The E-Commerce Report column in Business Day last Monday, about online travel agencies, misidentified the location of LeisureLogix, a technology company that has introduced a personalized search service for travelers. It is based in Tampa, Fla., not Southlake, Tex. The column also misstated, in one reference, the name of the search service on the Travelocity Web site. As the column noted, it is the Road Trip Wizard — not the Road Trip Warrior.

The On Education column on Wednesday about online courses included the incorrect cost, from a Pennsylvania State University professor, for the master’s program in business administration at the university. It is $49,000, not $52,000. Because of an editing error, the column also referred incorrectly to a course the writer once took that he said would not be as effective if taught online. It was a graduate-level course, not an undergraduate one.

The headline with an article on Saturday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign and the issue of treating women and men equally in presidential politics overstated Senator Clinton’s response to suggestions that she had been using her gender as a shield against criticism from her male opponents. Mrs. Clinton said her rivals were “picking on” her because she was winning, not because she was a woman. She then went on to say: “I anticipate it’s going to get even hotter — and if you can’t stand the heat, get out of the kitchen. And I’m very much at home in the kitchen.” Mrs. Clinton did not “retreat” on issues of men versus women.
Martin Lel of Kenya and Abderrahim Goumri of Morocco turned the New York City Marathon into Part 2 of a battle they began in the London Marathon last April, and once again, Lel was victorious.
At least six people were killed when a small plane crashed into a residential district of São Paulo just after taking off on Sunday.

After suffering stress fractures in his shins during his first New York City Marathon last year, Lance Armstrong vowed to never enter the event again. This year he broke that vow and posted an even better time.
The 39,085 runners who started Sunday’s race left a surreal amount of garbage and treasure behind, but hundreds of volunteers and sanitation workers were standing by to swoop in.
The Bush administration signaled that it would likely continue aid to Pakistan’s military, despite the detention of rights activists and government opponents.
The question of gender has burst into the foreground of the campaign in the aftermath of a contentious debate.
While much of Villahermosa remained under water on Sunday, in a city that floods frequently there is a certain pride in toughing out the waters.
More than 100 bands, with nearly 800 performers, took to the city’s streets Sunday in support of the runners and thousands of fans who lined the marathon course.
In a speech on Monday, John Edwards plans to say that Hillary Rodham Clinton is voting like a hawk in Washington, while talking like a dove in Iowa and New Hampshire.
Zach Randolph, making his home debut, sealed the Knicks’ first victory of the season with one big rebound and one critical free throw in the final seconds.
An autopsy was performed on Ryan Shay, who died during the United States Olympic trials for the marathon, but the results will not be final until perhaps the end of the week.
Cancer and a car accident nearly sidelined Ian Brooks, the public-address announcer at the New York City Marathon.
Senator Arlen Specter, the top Republican on the Senate Judiciary Committee, said Sunday that he would support  Michael B. Mukasey’s nomination despite concerns over his stance on torture.
Iraq’s shrinking Christian population now has a cardinal in the Roman Catholic Church, the first in Iraq in modern times.
The Bush administration should withdraw private armies from Iraq, and Congress must act swiftly to ensure that American justice applies to all those who remain.
A Queens man was charged with the murder of his 13-month-old daughter after the girl was found bruised and unconscious in the family’s home in South Ozone Park, the police said.

A Staten Island man has been charged with fatally stabbing another man during an argument on Saturday morning, the police said. The suspect, Saverio Fabozzi, 25, of Arthur Kill Road, was charged with second-degree murder and assault, the police said. Mr. Fabozzi is accused of fatally stabbing Joseph Flagg, 26, during an argument about 3 a.m. on Excelsior Avenue, the police said. The police said Mr. Fabozzi also stabbed a 21-year-old man, whose name was not released and who was in stable condition at Staten Island University Hospital.

Two people have been arrested in connection with the shooting of a Linden police officer on Friday night, the police said yesterday. After being called to Speedy Check Cashing, on Routes 1 and 9, to investigate a report of a fraudulent check at about 6 p.m. on Friday, Officer Dave Manganiello was shot once in the chest at close range. Officer Manganiello’s bullet-resistant vest stopped the round. He was treated at University Hospital in Newark and released. A suspect, Leonardo Grullon, 34, has been charged with attempted murder in connection with the shooting. A woman who came to police headquarters to check on Mr. Grullon, Brenda Hernandez, 35, of Elizabeth, was also arrested, the police said. She has been charged with hindering apprehension and theft by deception, the police said.

Home sales in parts of New Jersey hit hard by the subprime mortgage lending crisis have fallen significantly, The Star-Ledger of Newark reported yesterday. The number of home sales in those areas dropped 34 percent during the first six months of the year as compared with the same period last year, the newspaper reported. Home sales dropped 59 percent in East Orange, 41 percent in Elizabeth and 37 percent in Newark. The newspaper based its analysis on home sales figures that were reported to the state. Compiled by John Sullivan.

An oil tanker slammed into a light tower off Staten Island, hobbling a navigation aid that helps watch over the main shipping lanes to New York Harbor, the Coast Guard said yesterday. The shipping lanes remained open, but the Coast Guard urged boaters to avoid the tower, called Ambrose Light, until it could be fixed. Coast Guard crews were working yesterday evening on setting up temporary navigation aids until permanent repairs could be made to the tower, about 12 miles southeast of Staten Island and four miles outside the shipping channel. The tanker, Axel Spirit, rammed into the 76-foot steel tower about 2 a.m. Saturday, damaging the tower’s legs, the Coast Guard said. The ship’s owner, Teekay Corporation of Vancouver, British Columbia, said yesterday that it was cooperating with the Coast Guard on an investigation.
With all of the major campaigns — and even many of the more marginal ones — now running television commercials, Rudolph Giuliani’s continued absence from the airwaves has puzzled his rivals.

A Bronx man was fatally shot in Longwood early yesterday, the police said. An officer responding to a report of gunshots found the man, Hashim Osbourne, 28, of Gleason Avenue, lying at the corner of Kelly Street and East 163rd Street about 3:15 a.m., the police said. Mr. Osbourne had been shot multiple times in the torso and once in the head, the police said. Medical workers pronounced him dead at the scene. No arrests had been made as of yesterday evening.

Daniel Alfredsson and Antoine Vermette scored on Ottawa’s first two chances in a shootout last night and Martin Gerber stopped Boston’s initial pair of shooters to lift the visiting Senators to a 2-1 victory, their 12th in their first 13 games.
Jon Kitna threw two touchdown passes and Detroit scored twice on defense as the host Lions defeated the Denver Broncos, 44-7, for their third consecutive victory.

Stephen Ames wanted to escape the chill of Calgary for the final PGA Tour event, a decision that paid off yesterday when he closed with a four-under-par 68 for a one-shot victory in the Children’s Miracle Network Classic in Lake Buena Vista, Fla. Ames emerged from a typically crowded leader board at Disney with three straight birdies on the back nine of the Magnolia Course, then saved par from 65 feet out of the bunker to avoid a playoff with Tim Clark. “I came down here to work on my golf swing,” Ames said. “Here I am winning an event, which is awesome.”.
As he coaches one of the highest-ranked high school soccer teams in the country, Martin Jacobson also battles hepatitis C, a disease he contracted in an earlier life as a drug addict.

Momoko Ueda became the first Japanese winner of the Mizuno Classic in nine years, closing with a five-under 66 that included a double eagle. Ueda held off Reilley Rankin and Maria Hjorth to win by two strokes. She finished at 13-under 203 in Shima, Japan, and earned $210,000 for her first L.P.G.A. Tour victory.

Now that Joe Calzaghe has beaten all comers in the supermiddleweight ranks, he is waiting for the light-heavyweight Bernard Hopkins.“Whatever way he wants it he can have it as long as Joe gets well paid,” Frank Warren, Calzaghe’s promoter, said in Cardiff, Wales, after the unbeaten Calzaghe captured the W.B.A. and W.B.C. supermiddleweight belts from Mikkel Kessler on Saturday to go with the W.B.O. title he has held for 10 years. “So there’s no excuses. Be a Ray Leonard. Be a Marvin Hagler. That’s what we want to see from Bernard Hopkins. He can pick the date, he can pick the town.”.

The world champion Brian Joubert won Skate Canada in Quebec City, hours after the ice dancer Melissa Gregory was injured in a fall. Joubert won despite jumps that were not anywhere near the quality he produced in winning the world title last March in Tokyo. He tumbled to the ice on his quad at the start. “I’m disappointed with the quad,” Joubert said. Gregory was responsive and alert in a hospital after falling during the warm-up for the free dance.Mao Asada won the women’s title Saturday.

Justin Rose secured the European tour’s money title by reaching a three-way playoff at the Volvo Masters at Valderrama, where he rolled in a 12-foot putt at the second extra hole to win the season-ending tournament over Simon Dyson and Soren Kjeldsen in Sotogrande, Spain. Rose rallied after losing a four-shot lead with nine holes to play to top the money list, known as the Order of Merit.
Steve Williamson, a Tampa Bay Lightning fan, began a journey last month that will take him to a game at each of the league’s 30 arenas in 30 consecutive days.
Chad on Sunday released seven of the Europeans detained for over a week after they were accused of trying to kidnap 103 African children.
A strike by Hollywood writers began in New York just after midnight Monday, the first industry-wide strike since writers walked out in 1988.
A rebel commander said the move was meant to soften relations with Turkish officials, who are mulling whether to carry out attacks on Kurdish bases in northern Iraq.
There’s a magic to the project to build a memorial to President Franklin Delano Roosevelt on Roosevelt Island.
Each time a new governor has been elected since 1968, a subway and bus fare increase has been approved within a year of his taking office.
As the Writers Guild of America begins picketing, it must deal with complications created by the economic disparity among its members.
The Justice Department’s voting rights section has been taken over by ideologues most interested in denying the ballot to minorities, poor people and other groups likely to vote Democratic.
Jimmie Johnson won a dramatic duel with Matt Kenseth at Texas Motor Speedway, grabbing his third consecutive victory and wresting the Nascar Nextel Cup points lead from Jeff Gordon.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 4 (AP) — Minutes after Adrian Peterson lost a fourth-quarter fumble at the San Diego 20-yard line, the ball was back in his hands.
DETROIT, Nov. 4 (AP) — The Detroit Lions had confidence in themselves back in training camp, when Jon Kitna boldly declared he would be disappointed with anything short of 10 victories.
A 19-year-old Rowan University sophomore was beaten to death in what authorities say was a robbery gone awry, thrusting Glassboro, N.J., into the national spotlight.
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s comments about a police detective who died after working at ground zero showed the impolitic tendencies that he has worked hard to control.
A bill to expand insurance for poor children symbolizes the inability of President Bush and Congress to work together.
The announcement raised hopes that ministers from the former rebel group from the south would return to the coalition government.
Drew Brees passed for 445 yards and 3 touchdowns in the Saints’ fourth straight victory, a 41-24 win over the Jaguars. Of his 35 completions, 25 were for first downs.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 4 (AP) — Add one more uncommon distinction to the glittering résumé of Brett Favre.
The Energy Department has fallen behind on its plans to consolidate storage of nuclear bomb fuel and other high-risk materials, according to a government report.
At the New York City Marathon, Gete Wami of Ethiopia picked up the most valuable second-place finish of her career.
Ten weeks have passed in this volatile college football season, and there finally seem to be some clues as to how it will end.
Pirates released two South Korean-owned vessels and their crews held since May off Somalia in one of the world’s most dangerous waterways.
David Nalbandian beat Rafael Nadal, 6-4, 6-0, to win the Paris Masters Sunday, clinching his second straight Masters title after winning in Madrid last month.

Mr. Berle spent decades fighting for open space and clean water as a New York State assemblyman, commissioner of the State Department of Environmental Conservation and president of the National Audubon Society.
Alex Zanardi, the Italian racecar driver who lost his legs in a crash in 2001, competed in the handcycle division of the New York City Marathon.
Pentagon officials said Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates planned to press for a more open dialogue on China’s military while discussing ways to build trust and cooperation.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,836 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
A plan for high-rise buildings on a former Con Ed property will include hundreds of apartments for poor and working-class tenants, as well as space for a school.
For decades, Khun Sa symbolized the seeming impunity of heroin traffickers in the area encompassing the northern reaches of Myanmar (formerly Burma), Laos and Thailand.

The victory will make the Patriots the undisputed favorite to win the Super Bowl as they continue their bid to become the only team since the 1972 Miami Dolphins to complete an undefeated N.F.L. season.
Dr. Orgel’s studies of early life on primitive Earth helped lead to the formation of a now widely accepted theory about the development of DNA.
In a statement issued by his public relations firm Sunday, Arizona Coach Lute Olson said the matter was not health related.
Prime Minister Ehud Olmert’s backing of U.S. peace efforts raises the possibility of finding a peace deal with the Palestinians before the end of the Bush administration.
Mr. Brand conceived and administered the Albert S. Bard Award, an architectural prize intended to raise the standard of excellence for building design in New York City.
Cyclists, who have long revered Portland for its bicycle-friendly ways, are helping the city build a cycling economy based on a growing number of smaller businesses.
Before there were celebrity chefs, Chef Tell, who was born Friedman Paul Erhardt in Germany, came out of the kitchen to become one of the first chefs to appear on television.
Diplomacy with Serbia is reported to be near a dead end and analysts say the region is likely to declare independence unless an agreement is settled soon.

The first American military officer to visit a radar system that Russia offered as an alternative to missile defenses in Europe said he was impressed, but said it would not be an adequate replacement.
A Jewish advocacy group seeks to call attention to the more than 850,000 Jews who left their homes in Arab lands after the declaration of the state of Israel in 1948.
In the face of increasingly onerous regulations, none of the usual fireworks, bonfires or burning of effigies to celebrate Guy Fawkes day will take place in York this year.
The board of Citigroup accepted the resignation of Charles O. Prince III today and appointed Robert E. Rubin, the former Treasury secretary, as its chairman.
Pakistan’s government detained opposition figures and said parliamentary elections could be delayed for as long as a year.
The indie-pop band the Decemberists have canceled the remaining dates on their fall tour, citing the illness of an unidentified member.
The blackened, leathery mummified remains of the Egyptian boy king Tutankhamen were freed from their linen burial windings, Agence France-Press reported.

A man has pleaded guilty to two felony charges in connection with the theft of computers and photographs with confidential material related to the forthcoming film “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull.”
This musical snapshot revealed Mr. Barry’s penchant for distorted Irish melodies, abrupt juxtapositions of chaos and calm, vehemently percussive piano and string pizzicatos.
Protests by Jewish groups ended plans for a rock concert at the site of a Nazi death camp in Belgrade, Serbia, The Associated Press reported.
Jam Master Jay’s unidentified killer had a tattooed neck, according to a witness, The Associated Press reported.
Tutankhamen faces his public, “American Gangster” swats “Bee Movie” at the weekend movie box office and more culture news.
“American Gangster” won the battle of the buzz by outdrawing “Bee Movie” at North American box offices.
Civil rights leaders, cultural critics and others are debating how to represent the diversity of black life while minimizing offensive words and images.
Writer-producers would be required to continue performing their managerial duties in the event of a writers strike. Would some of them continue to write?
Ford seeks to assure Wall Street that it is not backtracking on its revamping while the United Automobile Workers union will try to win support for the deal with a layoff-weary membership.
Good will on mass transportation and confusion at the art museum.
At a time when indie bands and their devotees are worried about short, blog-enabled cycles of hype and backlash, the Fiery Furnaces have decided to reward their fans by overwhelming them.
Around 3,000 people, seemingly all in their 20s and 30s, attended the first Takeover at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
Soon after PetroChina makes its debut Monday on the Shanghai Stock Exchange, some expect the firm to surpass Exxon Mobil as the world’s largest company by market capitalization.
If the Hollywood screenwriters go on strike, the typical American household will not run out of content any time soon. But will the audience return after a lengthy strike?
Ms. Lemper’s program focused, as those familiar with Ms. Lemper might expect, on Brecht and Weill.
“Untitled (Prayers) 1996-2007,” the first of Performa 07’s “Dance After Choreography” programming, places Ms. Cool in an austere environment.
A magazine editor, tired of public relations e-mail spam, strikes back.
The conservative radio talk show host Glenn Beck has secured a contract extension valued at $50 million over five years.
Problems finding a winner to accept a prize complicated a food sculpting contest, revealing a common pitfall for companies that solicit content from their customers.
Cyriac Roeding, executive vice president of CBS Mobile, is an unapologetic entrepreneur who isn’t afraid to take a trial-and-error approach to fielding fresh talent.
The trend toward radio stations switching to Christmas music ever earlier in the year seems to have abated somewhat, but the first station to make the switch did so this week.
Retailers are increasingly relying on the Internet to market $3,000 skirts and $5,000 suits to consumers who think nothing of spending that much on clothing.
What you will not hear in this revue is a singer who captures more than a distant echo of Lee Wiley’s allure.
When the quality of the singing, the elegance of the orchestra playing and the production arrive in a dead heat, we have had quite an afternoon of opera.
An upstart weekly newspaper has won a court battle against a publishing and industry giant in the Canadian province of New Brunswick.
One of the greatest bridge players of all time, Tim Seres, died Sept. 27 at 82 in Sydney, Australia, where he lived most of his life.
Mr. Abas, a former child prodigy on the piano, returned to Carnegie Hall, or at least to Weill Recital Hall, with a program of classical standards.
It was good to see that the Balanchine-Stravinsky “Agon,” which opens the company’s program, held its own with no effects more special than live music and brilliant dancing.
Highlights from Bits, the technology blog updated all day at nytimes.com/bits.
Two large social networking sites are showcasing new ways to use information about their members to deliver specialized advertisements.
Max Raabe, the wry, unsmiling and nonchalantly charismatic vocalist who headlines the Palast Orchester of Berlin, opened the ambitious 17-day festival Berlin in Lights at Carnegie Hall.
The Hollywood Reporter introduced a New York-based edition last Friday — nine years after its rival, Daily Variety, made the same move.
A new company offers publishers a way to hunt down any place across the Web where a significant chunk of thier work has been copied, with or without permission.
Tom Brokaw’s book stages a virtual reunion of America’s Class of 1968, accompanied by a full spectrum of opinions about the impact of that pivotal year.
A companywide program to reduce greenhouse gases will turn NBC Universal’s logos green this week.
Accounts.
The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week included today’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.
PokerPro mixes the speed and efficiency of Internet poker with the stare-them-down, in-your-face quality of playing live.
As major marketers shift more of their advertising spending to the Web, media companies like Hearst Magazines are scrambling to keep up.
Martin Lel of Kenya edged Abderrahim Goumri of Morocco after a neck-and-neck battle in the final stages of the New York City Marathon.
Eschewing the aimlessness of the “odyssey years,” some superfocused 20-somethings offer advice on coping with those years of experimentation.
An experimental drug from Eli Lilly reduced heart attacks in patients with heart disease by 24 percent compared with the current standard treatment.
Don’t sue phone companies for letting the government listen in.
The estates of several deceased writers have expressed an interest in seeing manuscripts published in their original pre-edited form.
