Part 3 for In Advertising e-mail newsletter for Mon., Nov. 5 by Stuart Elliott.

9 P.M. (22, 26) CAROL BURNETT: A WOMAN OF CHARACTER Whether descending the staircase at Tara dressed in a curtain, with rod, or emitting one of her Tarzan yells, Ms. Burnett, above, made America laugh while also smashing stereotypes and showing that women could be at once feminine, empowered and funny. This “American Masters” documentary pays tribute to her life and career, using one of her signature devices: the audience question-and-answer session that opened her weekly show, which won 25 Emmys during its run from 1967 to 1978. This program includes clips of Ms. Burnett’s appearances on other television shows, in films and on the stage. It also features interviews with performers she inspired, including Tracey Ullman, Ellen DeGeneres, Kristin Chenoweth and Jenna Elfman. Alas, Ms. Burnett’s childhood wasn’t a laughing matter. But as her grandmother once told her, “Comedy is tragedy plus time.”.
Álvaro Colom, a gawky policy wonk and businessman who made fighting poverty his campaign’s centerpiece, won Guatemala’s presidential election on Sunday.
A Pentagon-sponsored robot race at a former Air Force base revealed that computer-controlled vehicles, at least to date, have failings that are all too human.
A movement to restrict smoking in apartments and condominiums is having some success.
Jay-Z’s 10th proper album, “American Gangster,” was inspired by the new movie — directed by Ridley Scott, starring Denzel Washington and Russell Crowe — for which it’s named.
New releases from Chris Brown, Josh Turner, Little Big Town, Buck 65 and others.
There is debate about whether the United States should grant asylum to African women who have been victims of genital cutting.
Kelly and Edison Cabrera needed to move to an apartment with space for a wheelchair and physical therapy sessions for their disabled son, Bernave.
The Patriots (9-0) are as pulverizing as Joe Frazier’s left hook; they flattened the Colts Sunday the way Frazier flattened Ali 36 years ago.
Paula Radcliffe and Gete Wami raced well at the New York City Marthon on Sunday. In the shadow of Ryan Shay’s death, it was the only way.
At their annual meetings in Orlando this year, baseball’s  general managers will yet again discuss the prospect of instant replay.
Two former Iraqi Health Ministry officials, both Shiites, will be tried in the killing of hundreds of Sunnis.
Clinton Portis led the way for the Redskins running game with a season-high 196 yards on 36 attempts against the Jets on Sunday.
Laveranues Coles, who sustained a concussion a week ago against Buffalo, watched the Jets’ overtime loss to Washington from the sideline.
Top executives at two of the world’s largest banks have come under scrutiny for ignoring one of the fundamental principles of the banking business.
“Heroes” remains the most engaged drama on television at the moment, a big hand with fingers dangling in every pot.
After enduring accusations in the media of questionable interactions with Citigroup, CNBC’s Maria Bartiromo is now in the midst of a turnaround year.
Get out your handkerchiefs, if you please, for “Rock ’n’ Roll,” the triumphantly sentimental new play by Tom Stoppard.
Google announced that it is leading an industry alliance to transform mobile phones into powerful computers.
Robert E. Rubin, named chairman of Citigroup, will seek to revive the troubled bank, which said it would take an additional $8 billion to $11 billion write-down. The stock hit a four-year low.
Robert E. Rubin, named chairman of Citigroup, will seek to revive the troubled bank, which said it would take an additional $8 billion to $11 billion write-down.
A skit on “Saturday Night Live” lampooned all the Democratic presidential candidates except Barack Obama, who portrayed himself.
Here’s how the post-Iraq Franco-American lovefest may unfold at the White House.
One big reason the Democrats are having trouble finding their voice is the influence of big money.
Paula Radcliffe of England reached the finish line farther ahead of her Ethiopian challenger, Gete Wami, than at any other point in the race.
When members of the House Financial Services Committee meet to put the finishing touches on a bill to curb abusive mortgage lending, they need focus only on how to make a good bill better.
New York City’s efforts to improve foster care for blacks and Latinos are as much a story of trouble as of triumph.

An article on Oct. 17 about a meeting of the Caspian Sea nations described incorrectly the agreements Iran and the Soviet Union once had on sharing the sea and its resources. They did not share everything 50-50.

MURPHY--Anthony John, on November 2, 2007. Born April 20, 1961 in Lima, Peru. Husband of Susan Strothmann and adored dad of Nicolas John. Beloved son of Lucia Anwandter and John Murphy. Loving brother of Peter, Kathleen, Clare and Ana. His wit and good company will be sorely missed by his extended family and many friends. Family will receive visitors at Frank E. Campbell, Madison at 81st Street. Monday, November 5, 1-3pm and 6-9pm Mass of the Resurrection, Tuesday, November 6th, 10:30am, Church of St. Thomas More, Manhattan. In lieu of flowers, please make a memorial gift to the American Liver Foundation. www.liverfoundation.org/do nate.

Cincinnati had a scare when receiver Chad Johnson was immobilized after being sandwiched by two Bills defenders. He later flew home with teammates after test results came back normal, the team said. The Broncos lost two starters when quarterback Jay Cutler left with a lower leg injury and running back Travis Henry injured his left knee against the Lions. The Chiefs' Larry Johnson injured his ankle against the Packers. Tarvaris Jackson left the Vikings' game against the Chargers with a neck injury. ...Texans cornerback Dunta Robinson will miss the season after hurting his right knee against the Raiders. Oakland lost its top cover cornerback, Nnamdi Asomugha, with a left knee injury.

SCHNEIDER--Monroe, M.D., of Brooklyn, NY and Wading River, NY died peacefully on October 27, 2007 at the age of 90 in Brooklyn. Monroe was the loving husband of Sylvia (deceased) and father of Jonathan Schneider, M.D. of Cheshire, CT and father-inlaw of Lissa Guerrieri, also of Cheshire and father of Jennifer Schneider of Brooklyn. He is survived by his sister, Helen Matlin of Harrisburg, Pennsylvania and his brother, Lawrence Schneider, M.D. and sister-in-law Thelma Schneider of New York. He was predeceased by his sister Beverly Weissman of Westbury, NY. He is also survived by his former daughter-inlaw Tedra Schneider of Orange, Connecticut. He was the adored grandfather of Greg and Doreet Schneider of San Mateo, California, Andrew and Reni Schneider of Brookline, Massachusetts, and Hilary Schneider of Pikesville, Maryland. He also leaves two great-granchildren: Brett Schneider of Brookline and Matan Schneider of San Mateo. At the time of his death, Monroe worked as a volunteer physician in the orthopedic department at the Kings County Hospital Center. In 1957 he established the first Department of Orthopedic Surgery at Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn and remained Chairman until his retirement from full time practice in 1990. He remained active in medical practice by working part-time in the orthopedic departments at Queens Hospital Center and Elmhurst Medical Center. He served in the US Army Medical Corps from 1943 to 1946 and achieved the rank of Captain. A memorial service will be held at 4:00pm, December 1, 2007, at New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64 Street, New York, NY 10023. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Hospital of St. Raphael Foundation, 1450 Chapel Street, New Haven, CT 06511.

BERLE--Peter A. A., died November 1, 2007 in the Berkshires. He was an environmentalist, public servant, lawyer and farmer. He served as a NYC Assemblyman, Commissioner of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation, and as President of the National Audubon Society. He also founded the nations first environmental law firm, Berle, Butzel and Kass. He is survived by his wife of 47 years Lila, his children Dolf, Mary, Beatrice and Robert, and 13 grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations are encouraged to the Stockbridge Land Trust and the National Audubon Society. Donations may be sent to Kelly Funeral Home, 3 Main St., Lee, MA 01238. Phone: 413-243-0204. A Memorial Service will be held at St. Paul's Church in Stockbridge, MA on Saturday, November 10 at 11am.

The Ravens outscored the Steelers by 58-7 in two games last season, and they will need to produce another unforgiving effort -- and maybe even a few points -- to pull even in the American Football Conference North race. The Steelers will send out a more efficient Ben Roethlisberger (15 touchdowns, 6 interceptions) and the league's No. 2 rusher, Willie Parker. If those players fail, Pittsburgh has history on its side. The Steelers have not lost a Monday night home game since 1991, and they will have members of their 75th anniversary team -- a group that includes 10 Hall of Famers -- on hand watching over them. Ravens Coach Brian Billick said it was as if a college team were trying to arrange a favorable setting. ''We look at it as we have been scheduled for their homecoming,'' he told reporters last week. FIDLER--Jay W., 85, a longtime resident of Rye Brook, died October 31, 2007 in White Plains of complications from a fall. A scholar-athlete at Brown University from 193943, Fidler was a first-team AllNew England tackle and Honorable Mention All-American who started for the North in the Christmas 1942 BlueGray game. He also lettered in baseball and was inducted into the university's Hall of Fame in 1992. As a trustee of Brown from 1969 to 1974, Fidler championed a first-ofits-kind relationship between Brown and Tougaloo College in Jackson, Mississippi. That program, which continues today, exemplifies his lifelong commitment to social justice. Active in the civil rights struggles of the 1960s, Fidler launched a Social Action Committee at Community Synagogue in Rye, worked with the Carver Center in Port Chester to expand the horizons of young kids at risk and with the Democratic Party to encourage black candidates to run for office in local and Westchester County races. Mr. Fidler was President and Chief Executive Officer of Hercules Chemical Company, manufacturer of a broad line of products for the plumbing and heating trade, until his retirement in 2000. The company's products, with creative brand names like ''Clobber,'' ''Wham,'' and ''Iron Ike,'' earned Hercules industry-wide recognition and the ''Top Brass'' Award from the American Supply Association in 1995. A Brooklyn native, Mr. Fidler is survived by his wife of 63 years, Rhoda Wander Fidler, whom he met at age 14 at James Madison High School. She shared his lifelong passion for social justice, which earned her the Westchester Ethical Culture Society's inaugural Ethics in Action Award, and induction in 2006 to the Westchester County Senior Citizen Hall of Fame. He is also survived by his brother Roy of San Rafael, California, three children, Josh of Baltimore, Maryland, Meg of New York City, and Shelley of Washington, D.C.; and five grandchildren, Alexandra, Drew, Aaron, Mica, and Jake. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to the Petra Foundation, 315 Duke Ellington Blvd., Apt. 16C, New York, NY 10025 or to the Jay W. Fidler Scholarship Fund at Brown University, c/o Gift Cashier, P.O. Box 1877, Providence, RI 02912.

In another losing locker room, the Jets slumped against their lockers. They did not scream. They did not vent. When they spoke, they spoke softly, with hardly a trace of anger or frustration. They appeared resigned to what has become a weekly routine: film followed by practice followed by a loss on Sunday. That pattern started Sept. 30, when the Jets lost to the Bills in Buffalo, and it continued for the sixth consecutive week Sunday.

A front-page article on Tuesday about changes in gay enclaves like the Castro district in San Francisco referred incorrectly to the time frame of the AIDS epidemic, which took a heavy toll on the Castro neighborhood. The first cases of AIDS in the United States came to light in the early 1980s; the epidemic did not begin in 1990 and end in 1995. Because of an editing error, the article also referred imprecisely to an area in which 33 percent of residents identified themselves as gay or lesbian. It was District 8 of San Francisco's Board of Supervisors -- not the Eighth Congressional District, which includes the Castro.

The headline with an article on Saturday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's campaign and the issue of treating women and men equally in presidential politics overstated Senator Clinton's response to suggestions that she had been using her gender as a shield against criticism from her male opponents. Mrs. Clinton said her rivals were ''picking on'' her because she was winning, not because she was a woman. She then went on to say: ''I anticipate it's going to get even hotter -- and if you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen. And I'm very much at home in the kitchen.'' Mrs. Clinton did not ''retreat'' on issues of men versus women.

The former press baron Conrad Black and three of his associates, convicted in July of fraud at their company, Hollinger International, lost their request Monday for a new trial.
The new South Oxford Park with its whimsical central fountain was quickly converted from a derelict facility into a magnificent public space.

American Financial Realty Trust, which aimed to become the preferred landlord of leading banks and other financial institutions, announced Monday that it was being bought for $1.1 billion in cash and stock by Gramercy Capital, a New York commercial real estate finance company.
A Boston private equity house, HarbourVest Partners, said Monday it plans to raise up to $400 million in a listing of one of its funds on the NYSE Euronext exchange in Amsterdam.

A former advertising executive for Wal-Mart Stores has decided to drop her breach-of-contract lawsuit against the retailer, saying that the lawsuit had become financially draining and more complex than she had expected.

A friend (who asked me not to use her name for reasons that will soon become obvious) recently told me that she had interviewed for a job but didn't get it. She said she thought it might have to do with the psychological evaluation she had to undergo as part of the interview process. Of course, she'll never know. But it was gnawing at her. It was the first time she had to submit to that kind of test for an interview, and she couldn't help wondering if she made a misstep somewhere.
A Brooklyn bar has been busted for illicit lime insertion into bottles of Corona. Quoting from the rap sheet against the bar, Michael Wilson describes the crime as:
Properties on the market in South Carolina, Missouri and California.

* Stop me if you've heard this before: a Carolina Panthers quarterback got hurt Sunday. It was David Carr, again. Carr, who has been battling a bad back for weeks, sustained a concussion Sunday against Tennessee. This is not entirely surprising because he was sacked seven times. UPDATE: The Charlotte Observer reports that Drew Olson is likely to sign with Carolina so there is someone to take reps in practice.
Richard Maxwell’s new musical is bleak, droll and strangely beautiful.
Astronomers reported Tuesday that there were at least five planets circling a star in the constellation Cancer, making it the most extensive planetary system yet found outside our own.

A Matisse painting depicting one of the artist’s favorite models fetched $33.6 million tonight at Christie’s, breaking the previous auction record for the artist in a lively kickoff to the fall auction season.
If the Senate passes the bill by a similar margin as expected, this will be the first of President Bush’s five vetoes during his two terms to be overridden.
Facebook now will give advertisers the ability to create their own profile pages on its system that will let users identify themselves as fans of a product.
House and Senate negotiators approved a $459 billion military spending bill, but rejected a Republican bid to provide $70 billion more.
Richard Stuckey, who helped dismantle Long-Term Capital Management in 1998,  will head a group devoted to managing $43 billion of Citi’s ailing mortgage-backed securities.
The French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, arrives in Washington today for his first official visit to the White House since becoming president.
It was the first official meeting between the Pope and so prominent a Muslim leader from the Middle East.
Shares of  China’s biggest e-commerce company soared in the opening day of trading in Hong Kong, creating one of the world’s wealthiest technology companies.
The end game of Charles O. Prince III’s career at Citigroup probably began with a flight to Saudi Arabia last week by the firm’s former chairman, Sanford I. Weill.
The Chinese web company’s public offering is expected to raise nearly $2 billion in Hong Kong, making its debut offering as large as Google’s 2004 I.P.O. in the United States.

Gene Haas, the 54-year-old owner of Haas Automation and Nascar’s Haas CNC Racing, was sentenced to two years in federal prison after he pleaded guilty to defrauding the government of more than $34 million in taxes. As part of his plea agreement, Haas paid a $5 million fine, and more than $70 million in back taxes and interest. He pleaded guilty in August to a felony conspiracy charge for orchestrating a plan to list bogus expenses that could be written off as business costs and save Haas Automation millions in taxes. The company makes computerized machine tools.
Investigators removed part of a door frame from the Fifth Avenue apartment where a celebrity real estate broker was bludgeoned to death last week, a law enforcement official said.
The end game of Charles O. Prince III ’s career at Citigroup probably began with a flight to Saudi Arabia last week by the firm’s former chairman, Sanford I. Weill.
Goalie Henrik Lundqvist registered his fourth shutout of the season as the Rangers extended their winning streak to four games.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the professional successes of Maria Bartiromo, a business journalist for CNBC, misstated the surname of Citigroup’s senior vice chairman, with whom she recently conducted a prominent interview. He is William R. Rhodes — not Rose. The article also misspelled the name of a sovereign investment fund that Ms. Bartiromo said she found exciting. It is Qatar Associates — not Cutter.

An article on Oct. 14 about Angola’s persistent poverty despite its financial windfall from rising oil prices misstated, in some editions, the country’s daily oil production. It is 1.5 million barrels, not 2 billion.
MSNBC executives acknowledged that they were talking to Rosie O’Donnell about a prime-time show.

The Champ Car World Series added Spain to its schedule for 2008, putting 8 of its 14 races outside the United States. The June 8 race will be held on the 2.752-mile Circuito de Jerez, a permanent course in southern Spain also used in testing by Formula One. Champ Car will run three races in Europe, the others in Zolder, Belgium, on June 1 and Assen, the Netherlands, on Sept. 14. The schedule also includes three races in Canada, one in Mexico and one in Australia.

The Naval Academy canceled classes yesterday to give the 4,400 midshipmen another day to celebrate the football team’s first victory over Notre Dame in 44 tries. Navy beat Notre Dame, 46-44, in triple overtime Saturday when Reggie Campbell caught a 25-yard touchdown pass and a 2-point conversion throw from Kaipo-Noa Kaheaku-Enhada. On the next drive, the Fighting Irish scored on Travis Thomas’s 5-yard touchdown run, but two Navy players tackled him on the 2-point conversion attempt.“We are all part of history because of this victory,” Vice Admiral Jeffrey Fowler, the academy’s superintendent, said in an e-mail to The Capital of Annapolis, Md.Notre Dame’s winning streak began in 1964, the year after Roger Staubach led the Midshipmen to a 35-14 victory.

The ruler of Dubai paid $10.5 million to buy Playful Act at Keeneland’s Breeding Stock Sale, a world-record auction price for a broodmare. The bidding was another showdown between two titans of the breeding industry, Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al Maktoum’s Darley Stud and Coolmore Stud. Playful Act, by the French champion Sadler’s Wells and out of Magnificent Style, had mated with Kingmambo but the foal was aborted. John Sikura, who sold the horse for Hill ’n’ Dale Bloodstock, said he expected a price topping $5 million and was surprised the bidding went so high.

Two bull riders died in separate incidents this weekend. Joshua J. Brunner, 21, who was known as Cody, died Saturday night after he was stepped on by a bull in a United Rodeo Association event in Topeka, Kan., the police said. Brunner had completed his eight-second ride and was injured as he dismounted the bull. Zackary Clinton, 17, died Saturday after being injured at a rodeo in Arkansas, authorities said. The police said the bull threw Clinton to the ground before stepping on his chest.
Sidney Crosby scored twice and Dany Sabourin made 20 saves to record his first shutout as the visiting Pittsburgh Penguins defeated the Devils last night, 5-0.

Tyler Zeller, a 7-foot senior at Washington (Ind.) High School, said he would play at North Carolina. He chose the Tar Heels over Indiana, Purdue and Notre Dame, where his 6-foot-10 brother, Luke, the 2005 Indiana high school Mr. Basketball, is a junior. Tyler Zeller cannot sign a letter of intent until Nov. 14, the first day of the N.C.A.A. fall signing period. Zeller averaged 18.3 points and 9.5 rebounds in leading the Hatchets to a 20-4 record last season.

Marcus Johnson, a junior forward at Connecticut, plans to transfer and has asked for permission to talk to other programs, the university announced. Johnson played in 51 games in his first two seasons with the Huskies and averaged 4.9 points. A small forward from Los Angeles, Johnson reached double figures seven times and led the Huskies in steals in eight games.

The freshman Derrick Rose had 17 points, 6 rebounds and 5 assists in his collegiate debut and No. 3 Memphis beat visiting Tennessee-Martin, 102-71, in the 2K Sports College Hoops Classic.Chris Douglas Roberts tied his career high with 28 points and had 8 rebounds for Memphis (1-0). Lester Hudson scored 35 points for Tennessee-Martin.

A man accused of killing his estranged wife and shooting the judge handling their divorce reached a plea deal, bringing an abrupt end to his trial. The man, Darren R. Mack, 46, pleaded guilty to first-degree murder in the stabbing death of his wife, Charla, at his Reno townhouse in 2006. The authorities said that after the killing, Mr. Mack drove to a parking garage and shot Judge Chuck Weller through the third-floor window of his chambers.

Gov. Donald L. Carcieri has vetoed a bill pushing the state’s presidential primary up a month to Feb. 5, a surprise move that comes just days after he signaled that he would not object to the measure. Lawmakers in the Democratic-led General Assembly argued that the state would become irrelevant in presidential politics unless it joined some two dozen others that have set their presidential primaries or caucuses for Feb. 5. In a veto message, Mr. Carcieri, a Republican, said changing the date so late could create havoc for election officials.

A paroled sex offender suspected of killing several women in Lansing over several weeks this summer was ordered to stand trial on murder charges in two of the deaths. Judge Patrick Cherry bound the suspect, Matthew E. Macon, left, over for trial after a preliminary hearing in which a Michigan State Police forensic expert testified that genetic evidence found at the two crime scenes either matched Mr. Macon’s DNA profile or did not rule him out as a suspect. Mr. Macon, 28, who had been in prison off and on since 2001, was paroled in late June.

The controller of a nationwide janitorial service entered a guilty plea in Federal District Court to conspiracy to defraud the federal government and to harboring illegal immigrants, said Hagen W. Frank, an assistant United States attorney. The controller, Christina A. Flocken, 59, of Longwood, Fla., is accused of hiring out cleaning crews staffed with illegal immigrants to a Michigan resort. The government’s investigation of the service, Rosenbaum-Cunningham International Inc., based in Florida, led to the arrests in February of more than 200 immigrants, mostly Mexican citizens.

An adviser quit former Senator Fred D. Thompson’s Republican presidential campaign, a day after a report about his decades-old criminal record for drug dealing. “The focus of this campaign should be on Fred Thompson’s positions on the issues and his outstanding leadership ability, not on mistakes I made some 24 years ago,” the adviser, Philip Martin, said in a statement. Mr. Thompson said that he had been unaware of Mr. Martin’s criminal past until Saturday, but that he would not “throw my friend under the bus” for old indiscretions.

The Mexican drug lord Francisco Javier Arellano Félix, 37, left, was sentenced to life in prison without parole for running the notoriously violent cartel that bears his family’s name, which Judge Larry A. Burns of Federal District Court said would “live in infamy.” The Arellano Félix cartel emerged as a trafficking powerhouse in the 1980s in Tijuana, Mexico.

The Texas land commissioner, Jerry Patterson, said he hoped to award a state-owned wildlife preserve near Big Bend National Park to one of two private bidders today, but give the National Park Service 90 days to meet or exceed the winning bid. The ideas of selling the preserve, the Christmas Mountains Ranch, to a private buyer and allowing hunting on it have drawn controversy. Both bids would allow hunting, and the National Park Service can seek Congressional authority to allow guns on the land, Mr. Patterson said. The 9,270-acre tract was given to the state in 1991.
DALLAS, Nov. 5 (AP) — Jason Terry came off the bench to score 31 points Monday and fueled a late 14-4 run that carried the Dallas Mavericks past the Houston Rockets, 107-98.
The company continued to benefit from its corporate restructuring and improved gross margins, but investors were hoping for a bigger start to the fiscal year.

The China National Chemical Corporation, backed by the Blackstone Group, agreed to pay 3 billion Australian dollars ($2.8 billion) in cash for Nufarm of Australia to form the world’s largest supplier of generic farm chemicals. The offer by China National values Nufarm at 17.55 Australian dollars a share, 27 percent higher than its closing price on Oct. 30, Nufarm said. The price includes the payment of a 30-cents-a-share dividend by Nufarm, it said. Buying Nufarm gives China National entry to the $36 billion global market for herbicides and pesticides as a worldwide agricultural boom spurs acquisitions.
The announcement proved to be a fresh blow to investor confidence in the company, as shares slid nearly 4 percent in Paris trading.
A woman whose estranged husband was killed on a Queens playground last month testified about her broken marriage and the custody battle she and her spouse were waging over their  daughter.

Microsoft and Reliance Communications of India announced a partnership to send Internet-based television services to Indian homes. Reliance will pay Microsoft about $500 million in license fees to use its software for Internet protocol television service, which delivers high-quality video over phone lines to home television sets. Reliance plans to introduce the service in March.

Getinge, the world’s largest maker of surgical workstations, agreed to buy two Boston Scientific Corporation units for $750 million to expand its tools for heart operations. The two divisions are a heart unit, which employs about 450 people at its headquarters in San Jose, Calif., and a factory in Dorado, Puerto Rico, and a vascular surgery unit, which employs 250 people in Wayne, N.J. Getinge, based in Stockholm, said it was cutting expenses and making purchases to become more profitable. Boston Scientific, based in Natick, Mass., said it was selling the units to reduce debt and focus on businesses with more growth potential.

A Qatari investment fund, Delta Two, withdrew its £10.6 billion ($22 billion) bid to take control of the British supermarket chain J Sainsbury as a result of escalating borrowing costs, Delta Two said. The fund will still have a 25 percent stake in the British retailer, and the fund manager, Three Delta, expressed confidence in Sainsbury’s management, a sign it apparently intended to hold onto its stake. “The transaction would not be in the best interest of stakeholders,” Paul Taylor, a principal of Three Delta, said in a statement.

The EnCana Corporation, a Canadian natural gas producer, agreed to buy out its partner in an East Texas gas field for $2.55 billion, its largest acquisition in three years, to increase its presence in one of the fastest-growing sources of the fuel in the United States. EnCana said it had acquired the stake in the field, located about 80 miles northwest of Houston, from Leor Energy, which is privately held. EnCana, which is based in Calgary, said it planned to accelerate drilling there next year by adding three rigs to the seven now in service.
The floral decals on the hoods, tops and trunks of cabs are part of a $5 million public art program to mark the centennial of the metered taxi in New York.
Gete Wami and Robert Cheruiyot were each presented with a $500,000 check Sunday for winning the first two-year cycle of the World Marathon Majors.
John Edwards is trying to recast the Democratic race, asserting that only he can assure a victory in November.
While Gen. Pervez Musharraf justified his emergency rule decree as helping him combat terrorism, it could end up weakening his ability and generating instability.
Andy Pettitte declined his $16 million option with the Yankees, but was still uncertain if he wanted to pitch next season.
Joe Torre sounded eager Monday to shift from his former life in the Bronx to his new managerial job with the Dodgers, who finished 82-80 last season.
For years, the idea of grooming a successor was a job requirement of a chief executive and a priority for a company’s board. But that is no longer the case.
Former Jets receiver Wayne Chrebet knows concussions, which is why he urged receiver Laveranues Coles not to play in Sunday’s game against the Redskins.
Hollywood writers took to the sidewalks, if not quite the streets, on Monday, as last-ditch bargaining failed to avert the first industrywide strike in more than 19 years.

Hall of Famers lined the Pittsburgh Steelers’ sideline last night, with Terry Bradshaw, Mean Joe Greene, Jack Ham, Mel Blount and Franco Harris out front. The Baltimore Ravens probably thought they were playing all of them — and the current Steelers, too.
A man from Worthville, Pa., has paid for a memorial to Jimmy Slagle, the baseball player who is easily the most famous person to ever come out of the speck of a town.
The Yazoo Pumps may well be the most daft in a long line of environmentally destructive schemes undertaken by the Army Corps of Engineers at Congress’s request.
The schools that failed in a blunt new rating system were so dismal that their 29,000 students would be allowed to transfer elsewhere, said Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.
President Bush pressed the Pakistani president to hold elections and give up his army post but also praised him as a “strong fighter against extremists and radicals.”
Mr. Viertel plumbed his relationships with the aristocracy of Hollywood and literary lions like Hemingway to produce provocative works of fiction and memoir.
At age 64, Phyllis Shipman, a retired elementary school principal, represented the sport of archery at the annual gathering of Olympic stakeholders and has her sights on China in 2008.
After months of speculation, Time Warner said that Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the chief operating officer, will succeed Richard D. Parsons as chief executive at the end of the year.
Michael R. Bloomberg retreated from previous remarks that a detective who died after working at ground zero was not a hero, but the controversy does not seem quite over.
The magazine will close after the abrupt departure of its publisher and years of losses for its parent, Condé Nast Publications.
The United States and Turkey have already shared significant amounts of intelligence about Kurdish rebels, and President Bush plans to continue the collaboration.
The city should try to help usher in more peaceful labor-management relations with the transit workers union.
To the list of life’s great mysteries, I would add one more: how long should an angler wait to cast again to an Atlantic salmon that has come up for, but not taken, your fly?
Former Yankees Manager Buck Showalter said preparation defined how he lives his life, something that is also true of new Yankees Manager Joe Girardi.
At least 31 people died Sunday in a fire at a nursing home in the Tula region south of Moscow.
An investigation has been ordered into accusations that a member of Parliament served opium-laced drinks at a party last week.
Prime Minister Jaroslaw Kaczynski offered up his government’s resignation after a bruising electoral defeat last month.
Prime Minister Romano Prodi defended the expulsions of Romanians considered “dangerous” after a fatal assault last week, but he warned against “criminalizing” an entire people.
Two Cairo police officers were convicted of torturing a 22-year-old man in their custody after a cellphone video of the man being sodomized with a stick appeared on the Internet.
U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers allowed thousands of travelers into the country who should have been barred from entry, the Government Accountability Office reported.
The former transport and public works minister went on trial, accused of taking $100 million in kickbacks from developers.
Local officials say the federal process used to pay for repairs to schools, sewers and police stations seems to value perfect paperwork over speedy resolutions.
Mr. Kelleher founded the the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s first full-fledged gift shop and oversaw the creation of countless artful and educational tchotchkes.
The former commander, Gen. Raúl Isaías Baduel, had been one of Mr. Chávez’s closest allies after helping to reinstall him in office during a brief coup in 2002.
A federal jury on Monday convicted a former military contractor of 13 felonies related to the bribery of former Representative Randy Cunningham.
Questionable practices among mortgage lenders are coming to light in bankruptcy courts across the nation.
Mitt Romney’s campaign announced an endorsement from the man some consider the father of the religious right, Paul M. Weyrich.
A case with the potential to unsettle the municipal bond market produced a lively Supreme Court argument on Monday.
The N.F.L. cleared the Colts on Monday of charges made by the Patriots that the Colts had pumped artificial crowd noise into the RCA Dome during Sunday’s game.
A proposed amendment to the Mortgage Reform and Antipredatory Lending Act of 2007 will make the weakest part of the bill even weaker.
Can women voters be heard above the macho din?
The move is aimed at bolstering Barry Diller’s company’s lagging share price and simplify its convoluted corporate structure, among other things.
Burger King Holdings reported a higher-than-expected profit yesterday, but its stock fell after it said private equity firms that own more than half of its shares plan to reduce their stakes.
Ilya Shurov, 21, agreed to serve 17 1/2 years in prison for manslaughter and attempted robbery as hate crimes.
PepsiCo Inc. said  it was combining operations in the Americas and dividing its food and beverage businesses in the region.
Her plans for a new brothel stymied, Heidi Fleiss is making due by overseeing a small coin-operated laundry some 60 miles west of Las Vegas.

A former advertising executive for Wal-Mart Stores has decided to drop her breach-of-contract lawsuit against the retailer, saying that the lawsuit had become financially draining and more complex than she had expected.
Investors and analysts say the large write-downs of mortgage securities by Citigroup and Merrill Lynch have unnerved the debt markets.
The No Child Left Behind Act, President Bush’s signature domestic achievement, faces an uncertain future.
Even as Ford’s hourly workers prepare to vote on their new contract, the automaker said it may have to adjust its corporate restructuring plan if industry sales continue to slide.
Former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said that the crime-fighting successes of the disgraced former New York City police commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik, outweighed his legal problems.
The owner of Salander-O’Reilly Galleries, who had been facing a barrage of fraud lawsuits, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy.
The Giants are one of the hottest teams in the N.F.L., having won six consecutive games. They are also one of the most rested, having not played since defeating Miami eight days ago.
A concert on Saturday celebrated the 104th birthday of Alice Herz-Sommer, a survivor of a concentration camp where Jewish musicians were used for Nazi propaganda.
On Monday, a group of Ron Paul supporters helped raise more than $4.07 million in one day with a fund-raising gimmick based on Guy Fawkes.
The court-martial is likely to highlight a classified Pentagon program in which snipers placed fake weapons as “bait” to attract and kill enemy fighters.
H&R Block, the largest United States tax preparer, said yesterday that its chief financial officer, William L. Trubeck, had stepped down, effective immediately.
The Chicago Fire is the hottest team in Major League Soccer, Coach Juan Carlos Osorio is the maestro of the month, and Cuauhtémoc Blanco is the spider spinning an unavoidable web.
The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would use an Idaho murder case to decide how appellate courts are to evaluate claims of ineffective assistance of counsel in plea negotiations.
Mary Lillian Ellison’s flying head scissors and hair-pulling “flying mare” body slams brought her renown as the professional wrestler the Fabulous Moolah.
The circulation declines of American newspapers continued over the spring and summer, according to figures released Monday.

Six to eight men forced their way into a basement apartment on Glover Street early yesterday, attacked the two occupants and left them tied up after stealing an undetermined amount of cash, the police said. One occupant, 18, managed to free himself and called the police. When officers arrived, they found the other occupant, Antonio Castillo, 44, unconscious. He was taken to Westchester Square Medical Center, where he was pronounced dead, the police said.

New York State officials asked the federal government yesterday to reverse its decision declaring a large swath of the state as an energy transmission corridor. The declaration of such a corridor would make it easier to construct large power lines in the area. Gov. Eliot Spitzer asked for a rehearing, arguing that the state could handle the issue itself. Supporters of the decision have said the corridor is necessary to prevent future blackouts. The Department of Energy has 30 days to reach a decision; if it does not, the request is considered rejected.

A teenager has been charged with fatally shooting a security guard who confronted a group throwing eggs outside the building where he worked, the Mount Vernon police said yesterday. The teenager, Nyanda Charley, 18, was arrested Saturday night and faces charges of second-degree murder and weapons possession, said Police Commissioner David Chong. The police said that Mr. Charley shot the guard, Neville Webb, 52, of North White Plains, on Wednesday night. Mr. Webb, who was shot in the head and chest, died the next day.

A Queens man accused of killing his 13-month-old daughter pleaded not guilty at his arraignment yesterday in Queens Criminal Court. The man, Peter O’Keeffe, 35, who is charged with second-degree murder, was ordered held without bail. Judge Alex J. Zigman also ordered that Mr. O’Keeffe be placed in protective custody and on suicide watch. Prosecutors said that Mr. O’Keeffe beat the girl, Jessica, while baby-sitting on Saturday afternoon because she would not stop crying, and then ran from his house on 117th Street in South Ozone Park and fled to Philadelphia. The baby’s mother found her when she returned home, prosecutors said. Mr. O’Keeffe returned and surrendered to the authorities. His lawyer, Michael V. Cibella, said Mr. O’Keeffe worked as an accountant and bookkeeper for a printing company.

The State Supreme Court yesterday denied a motion to postpone today’s mayoral election in Bridgeport. But the matter might still not be settled. According to court documents, the justices will hear an appeal on Nov. 30 from State Representative Christopher Caruso, the mayoral candidate who sought the delay because of what he said were voting irregularities in the Democratic primary. Mr. Caruso lost to State Senator Bill Finch by 270 votes out of about 9,000 cast. The justices can order a new primary if they believe it is warranted. Mr. Caruso’s appeal has been assigned a docket number, but John King, a Hartford lawyer representing Bridgeport, said that nothing should be read into that fact.

Firefighters removed residents from a section of the Richmond Terrace Houses yesterday after three City Housing Authority workers were overcome by fumes from a cleaning chemical just after 1 p.m., the police said. The Fire Department said that 16 people, including five firefighters, were treated at Richmond University Medical Center in the afternoon. One person was in critical condition, two were in serious condition and the rest were treated for minor injuries. The Fire Department said the workers had used hydrated lime, a cleaning chemical, in an enclosed space.

The New York City Central Labor Council plans to begin a campaign today to educate construction workers, truck drivers and other workers in the city to make sure they are not classified as independent contractors instead of as employees. Misclassification often saves employers money while depriving workers of unemployment insurance and workers’ compensation protections, the labor council said. The council plans to have dozens of union members distribute leaflets. Gov. Eliot Spitzer has asked state agencies to crack down on misclassification.

Two fire commissioners in Little Egg Harbor Township accused of stealing vehicles owned by the Fire Department pleaded guilty yesterday to related charges in State Superior Court. One, Edward A. Kluver, 48, a former chief of the Mystic Island Volunteer Fire Company, pleaded guilty to official misconduct. The second, Leroy Kaufman, 66, pleaded guilty to third-degree theft. Prosecutors charged that the men used their official positions to take a pickup truck and a sport utility vehicle by signing the titles over to each other.
Pressured by regulators, Bayer AG said it will withdraw the controversial heart surgery drug Trasylol after a Canadian study suggested that it increased death rates.
A team of American experts arrived at North Korea’s sole functioning nuclear reactor on Monday and began the work of disabling the facilities.

PLAYER In Asia, Aleksandar Duric, a 37-year-old striker born in Bosnia, has been called to Singapore’s national team for its World Cup qualifying match against Tajikistan on Friday. Duric, a naturalized citizen, is the leading scorer in Singapore’s top league with 37 goals this season.
The Bush administration will propose on Tuesday to expand the authority of the federal drug and consumer product safety agencies to inspect and certify imports.
Shares of financial companies stumbled Monday in the aftermath of the shake-up at Citigroup, sending the stock markets down and leaving investors on edge.
The hot-button issues that have attracted the focus of ballot measures in the past have been replaced by concerns like health care financing, road projects and land-use regulations.
Every time a bartender in New York City puts a lime slice in that Corona with bare hands, he or she is breaking the law.
A proposal by Gov. Deval L. Patrick and legislative leaders would require all home heating oil and diesel fuel to contain at least 5 percent biofuel by 2013.
After the last sips of beer had been consumed on Saturday, the Gowanus Yacht Club closed the doors on its fifth season, to become a Christmas tree farm.

THE WORST YEAR Domestic airline performance through September of this year ranked as the worst for any comparable period in at least 12 years, the Transportation Department’s Bureau of Transportation Statistics reported yesterday. Through September, 73.18 percent of flights arrived on time this year, compared with 76.14 percent in the same period last year and the 12-year high, 82.82 percent in 2003. The worst 3 of the top 32 major airports through September of this year were all in the New York area: Newark Liberty (59.60 percent on time) LaGuardia (59.85 percent) and Kennedy (60.86 percent). The best three were Salt Lake City (80.31 percent), and Oakland (80.22 percent) and San Diego (78.95 percent) in California.

NEW YORK Polls in New York City and throughout the state are open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. The New York Public Interest Research Group and Common Cause New York are running a nonpartisan voter help line. Voters can call (212) 868-3692 to locate a polling site, get advice on voting rights or report problems at the polls. Voters can also call the New York City Board of Elections toll-free at 1-866-VOTENYC (1-866-868-3692).
Since 1998, Martin Nesbitt and Mark Wildman have been trying to turn the typically grubby parking garage into a familiar and popular brand.
Life-threatening blood clots and flying have been linked for more than 50 years, but a new study confirms the risk, particularly for those who take long flights.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,837 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:.
Most of the shows affected by the strike are half-hour comedies that are taped in front of a studio audience.

As frequent international business travelers can attest, mobile phones have shrunk the distance between land masses, making it like prehistoric times when all the continents touched. Only, now there’s a better signal.
The deal comes as the company is attempting to stage a corporate turnaround and reclaim ground lost to more nimble competitors.
I am voting to support Michael B. Mukasey for attorney general for one critical reason: the Department of Justice is in desperate need of a strong leader.
In New Orleans, a city known for its eclectic housing styles, a posthurricane vernacular is now emerging.
Bruce Arena was dismissed as coach Monday after he failed to take the Red Bulls beyond the first round of the Major League Soccer playoffs.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
Thousands of protesters demonstrated yesterday in Athens to prevent the demolition of an Art Deco building near a new museum on the Acropolis.

Duane Chapman, the embattled star of the hit A&E series “Dog the Bounty Hunter,” will appear on the Fox News Channel program “Hannity and Colmes” tonight to talk about the racially charged comments he made in a private phone conversation.
Daniel Radcliffe is coming to Broadway in “Equus,” and Andre De Shields will star in “Black Nativity.”
The League of American Theaters and Producers released its 2006-7 demographic report.
A fictional autobiography of Zelda Fitzgerald, wife of F. Scott Fitzgerald, has won France’s highest literary award, the Prix Goncourt.
The 12th edition of “The Amazing Race” got under way to solid ratings on Sunday.
A former dormitory matron accused of abusing students at Oprah Winfrey’s Leadership Academy for Girls in South Africa was freed on $458 bail.
Portrait of the Broadway theatergoer,  Zelda Fitzgerald novel wins Goncourt prize, Athens rally defends Art Deco building and more culture news.
Nuts-and-bolts concerns surrounding health care funding, road projects and land use regulations fill local and state tickets this year.
The new musical by Stephen Flaherty and Lynn Ahrens is a sweet but strange hybrid, both joyfully naughty and totally innocuous.
A lagoon of human waste is a sort of metaphor for Gaza, coping with makeshift answers to long-term problems.
A visit made by the Spanish king and queen to two territories on the coast of North Africa last week prompted Morocco to recall its ambassador to Spain.
Dr. Rafael Espada, long the heart surgeon to Guatemala’s political elite, is the country’s newly elected vice president.
Readers respond to articles in Science Times with thoughts on the Manhattan Project, ending therapy, dieting and more.

KITTAY--William R., 84, died October 9th from a stroke. KITTAY, Rhoda Siegelman, 78, died October 31 from a tragic fall in September. For 56 years, they were two halves of a whole. Both were loved and adored by their family and friends -Bill for his kind heart and wry sense of humor; Rhoda for her generosity and vivaciousness. They were the devoted and proud parents of David R. Kittay and daughter-in-law Jan Kittay and Debby KittayParker and son-in-law Josh Parker. They are also survived by their wonderful grandchildren, Leigh and Bear Kittay and Jessie, Jonah and Julia Parker, and their granddog Yoshi. While we will miss them both terribly, we know that they were meant to be together in this world and beyond. A memorial service was held on Sunday November 4 at Congregation Sons of Israel, 1666 Pleasantville Road, Briarcliff Manor, New York. Donations in their memory may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 785 Mamaroneck Avenue, White Plains, NY 10605-2523, or the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, 100 Raoul Wallenberg Place, SW, Washington, DC 20024-2126.

D'ANGELO--Joseph. The Executive Committee, Officers and Members of the New York Electrical Contractors' Association, Inc., extend their condolences to Olga and all the family of Joseph D'Angelo. Having served as the Executive Secretary-Manager of NYECA from 1986 to 2006, and immediately prior thereto as Chairman of the Joint Industry Board of the Electrical Industry, his contributions to our industry have been immeasurable. Joe was a good friend and advisor to all of us, and will be sorely missed.

An article in Business Day yesterday about the professional successes of Maria Bartiromo, a business journalist for CNBC, misstated the surname of Citigroup's senior vice chairman, with whom she recently conducted a prominent interview. He is William R. Rhodes -- not Rose. The article also misspelled the name of a sovereign investment fund that Ms. Bartiromo said she found exciting. It is Qatar Associates -- not Cutter.

An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts to persuade union members at Ford to accept a new labor contract misspelled the surname of a worker who commented that workers' sacrifices would not save the company. She is Judy W. Wraight, not Wright.

A theater review and headlines yesterday about ''Rock 'n' Roll,'' at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theater, misstated the year the play begins. It is 1968, not 1967. (The review made the same error about the year Soviet tanks occupied Prague, where some of the play takes place.) The review also misidentified the author of the poem that characters are translating in the concluding scene. It is Plutarch, not Sappho.

KELLEHER--Bradford. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Brad Kelleher, who for the past 58 years has been a stalwart, inventive, inspirational, and brilliant member of the Museum's staff, pioneering and then cultivating to its broad level of success the field of museum merchandising. At a pivotal moment in 1950, as a young sales manager, he opened the Met's first art and book shop -little more than a rack of postcards at first -at the main information desk. Under his leadership the popularity of the publishing and reproduction business grew, soon to include not only books and other printed materials but jewelry and decorative objects based on works in the collection. Always innovative and also determined to bring art reproduction at a high level of excellence to a broad audience, he created and expanded areas including a reproduction studio, the mail-order catalogue, the carefully designed shops within the building, and satellite sales shops that are now located both around the U.S. and abroad. First as Publisher (1972-78) and then as Vice President and Publisher (1978-86), he extended the Museum's program of producing scholarly as well as general-interest publications about art. His fine work in these areas became a model for museums worldwide. As a consultant since 1986, he has continued to innovate and inspire, always open to exploring new techniques and technologies that might bring about broader exposure and enjoyment of the Metropolitan's encyclopedic and world-renowned collections. His colleagues throughout the art world will remember him with great respect and affection, for his skills as a businessman, his eye as a lover of art, his generosity and expertise as a manager, and his gentle and caring friendship. We will miss him greatly, and extend condolences to his wife Mary and the entire family. James R. Houghton, Chrmn. Philippe de Montebello, Dir. Emily K. Rafferty, President

The television writers' strike could affect the presidential campaign in one way. It promises to wipe out the part of the echo chamber that is late night comedy. For the time being, all the late night shows will be in reruns. That means that today's gaffe will not become tonight's punch line on ''The Tonight Show'' or ''The Daily Show,'' the interim step before the YouTube-political blog-mainstream media grinder.

An article on Oct. 14 about Angola's persistent poverty despite its financial windfall from rising oil prices misstated, in some editions, the country's daily oil production. It is 1.5 million barrels, not 2 billion.

A picture yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about the challenges facing Citigroup's new leadership was published in error. The person shown with Citigroup's new chairman, the former Treasury secretary Robert E. Rubin, was Manfred Bischoff, supervisory board chairman of Daimler -- not Winfried F. W. Bischoff, the head of Citigroup Europe, who will become Citigroup's interim chief executive.

The Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner is a Democratic tradition throughout the nation. But rarely is it as celebrated as it is in Iowa in the year before a presidential election. The dinner honors Thomas Jefferson and Andrew Jackson and helps raise money for state and local Democratic Parties. In Iowa, it showcases the candidates in advance of the first caucuses, on Jan. 3. The dinner, on Saturday, may be Iowa's grandest. More than 9,000 people are expected at the Polk County Convention Complex in Des Moines, and polls show the Iowa race as fluid and close. The biggest dinner was in 2003, when Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton was M.C. and 7,500 attended.

They say there is no place like home, but it is beginning to look as if there is a place sort of like home 41 light-years from here in the constellation Cancer. Astronomers reported Tuesday that there were at least five planets circling a star there known as 55 Cancri, where only four had been known before, making it the most extensive planetary system yet found outside our own. It is also the one that most resembles our solar system, with a giant planet orbiting far out from the star and four smaller ones circling closer in.

ZOHN--Edythe, passed away on November 3, 2007. Widow of Irving, mother of Matthew and Edward (Patricia), grandmother of Ian, Ainsley and Owen. Edythe passed peacefully and is deeply mourned by her family. Graveside service today, 11:30am at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

FIDLER--Jay W., 85, A longtime resident of Rye Brook, died October 31, 2007 in White Plains of complications from a fall. A scholarathlete at Brown University from 1939-43, Fidler was a first-team All-New England tackle and Honorable Mention All-American who started for the North in the Christmas 1942 Blue-Gray game. He also lettered in baseball and was inducted into the university's Hall of Fame in 1992. As a trustee of Brown from 1969 to 1974, Fidler championed a first-of-its-kind relationship between Brown and Tougaloo College in Jackson, Mississippi. That program, which continues today, exemplifies his lifelong commitment to social justice. Active in the civil rights struggles of the 1960s, Fidler launched a Social Action Committee at Community Synagogue in Rye, worked with the Carver Center in Port Chester to expand the horizons of young kids at risk and with the Democratic Party to encourage black candidates to run for office in local and Westchester County races. Mr. Fidler was President and Chief Executive Officer of Hercules Chemical Company, manufacturer of a broad line of products for the plumbing and heating trade, until his retirement in 2000. The company's products, with creative brand names like ''Clobber,'' ''Wham,'' and ''Iron Ike,'' earned Hercules industry-wide recognition and the ''Top Brass'' Award from the American Supply Association in 1995. A Brooklyn native, Mr. Fidler is survived by his wife of 63 years, Rhoda Wander Fidler, whom he met at age 14 at James Madison High School. She shared his lifelong passion for social justice, which earned her the Westchester Ethical Culture Society's inaugural Ethics in Action Award, and induction in 2006 to the Westchester County Senior Citizen Hall of Fame. He is also survived by his brother Roy of San Rafael, California, three children, Josh of Baltimore, Maryland, Meg of New York City, and Shelley of Washington, D.C.; and five grandchildren, Alexandra, Drew, Aaron, Mica, and Jake. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his name may be made to the Petra Foundation, 315 Duke Ellington Blvd., Apt. 16C, New York, NY 10025 or to the Jay W. Fidler Scholarship Fund at Brown University, c/o Gift Cashier, P.O. Box 1877, Providence, RI 02912.

FEDERICO--Lina, owner of the jewelry store La Campanina in Capri, Italy, passed away on November 4, 2007 at her home in Capri. Lina is survived by her husband of 57 years, Alberto, her children, Marioli and Filippo, and four grandchildren: Marcello, Roberta, Michela, and Giulia. Lina was dear to many hearts. Many of her best customers were her closest friends. She opened La Campanina 50 years ago and managed her store until recently when her health forced her to spend time at home. Lina will be remembered as someone who always put her family and friends above all else. The funeral took place on November 5, 2007 in Capri.

9 P.M. (22), 10 P.M. (26) EXTRAORDINARY RENDITION As members of a C.I.A. ''snatch team'' face trial in Italy, ''Frontline/World'' investigates the United States government's practice of delivering terror suspects to other countries for interrogation, including some where torture is common. Stephen Grey, among the first journalists to track the secret ''rendition'' flights, reports from Europe, Africa and Washington on the controversial program and ''ghost prisoners,'' including the Egyptian cleric Abu Omar, above left, and Bisher al-Rawi, a longtime resident of Britain, tell about their own abductions and disappearances. 8 P.M. (ABC) CAVEMEN Joel (Bill English) joins his new neighbor, Jake (Jim Pirri), in a motivational networking program and decides that Jake is a ''shaver'' -- a caveman who shaves his body hair in order to pass as a Homo sapiens.

Senator Barack Obama's cameo on ''Saturday Night Live,'' jesting at Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's expense, raised the question of who is winning the Lorne Michaels primary. Neither Democrat, finance reports show. Mr. Michaels, the show's executive producer, contributed $2,300 to Senator John McCain, whose daughter Meghan was an intern on the program, the filings show. Mr. Michaels gave twice as much to Senator Christopher J. Dodd. Still, Mr. Dodd was portrayed on Saturday as a dour figure who arrived at a Halloween party in the same Sponge Bob Squarepants costume as Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., lamenting, ''We really cancel each other out.''

A group of paramedics and emergency medical technicians employed by private hospitals who responded to the Sept. 11 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center will receive roughly the same benefits as public employees injured or killed in the attacks, labor leaders said yesterday. In a statement, George Gresham, above, president of 1199 S.E.I.U. United Healthcare Workers East, called the change ''a truly heartfelt victory.'' Five medical workers hurt or sickened in the attack will receive disability and workers' compensation benefits similar to those received by emergency medical workers employed by the Fire Department, said Leah Gonzalez, a spokeswoman for the union. The families of four workers who were killed will receive similar benefits, she said. The new benefits were awarded through a law signed last week by Gov. Eliot Spitzer, Ms. Gonzalez said.

Ever been to Le Mars, Iowa? Senators Joseph R. Biden Jr., John McCain and Barack Obama have, as have John Edwards, Mike Huckabee and Mitt Romney. Le Mars, population 9,200, is the self-proclaimed Ice Cream Capital of the World. It is also one of the most frequently visited small towns so far -- nine visits -- in a presidential race that has included more than more than 3,000 candidates' rallies, speeches, fund-raisers and news conferences around the country.

BOALT--James Anthony, of Palm Beach died on November 3, 2007. He was 79 years old. Mr. Boalt was born on March 2, 1928, to Eben Boalt and Bernice Sweatt in Wayzata, Minnesota. Mr. Boalt's grandfather, William R. Sweatt, was the founder of Honeywell. After moving to Palm Beach, Mr. Boalt attended the Palm Beach Day School and later Choate. Mr. Boalt was a graduate of Yale University and Columbia University where he received his Master's degree in Finance. Mr. Boalt established his own brokerage firm, Boalt Properties, Inc., in 1989, in Palm Beach after being an investment counselor representing Inverness Management Co. in Palm Beach. Mr. Boalt was a Governor and Director at the Everglades Club, a Governor of the Seminole Club and a member of the Sailfish Club, Bath & Tennis Club, Brook Club (NYC), Maidstone Club (East Hampton) and Lyford Key Club (Nassau). Mr. Boalt was a loving father to his children and is survived by his daughter, Lisa Boalt Jeffery and her husband Jeremy; a son, Adam Rousseau Boalt; a daughter, Amanda Strong Boalt; a son, Christian Anthony Boalt; grandchildren Wynn Prentiss Jeffery, Daisy Meek Jeffery and Rosalie Boalt Jeffery. He is also survived by his sister, Diane Potter Saunders of Wiltshire, England and his brother, Ralph Boalt of Delray Beach, Florida. A memorial service will be held at The Episcopal Church Bethesda-by-the-Sea on Wednesday, November 7, 2007 at 2:30pm, with the Rev. Lynne E. Jones, officiating. A reception will follow at the Everglades Club at 3:30pm. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to The Preservation Foundation of Palm Beach, 311 Peruvian Avenue, Palm Beach, Florida 33480. Quattlebaum Funeral & Cremation Services, West Palm Beach, FL. (561) 832-5171

BALDERSTON--Frederick E. Born August 15, 1923 in Philadelphia, PA. Died October 18, 2007 at home in Berkeley, CA, after a long battle with emphysema. A retired longtime UC Berkeley professor in the Haas School of Business with a lifetime of service to the university, to state government, to promoting international understanding and environmental conservation. He was California savings and loan commissioner during the 1960s, and later wrote extensively on the savings and loan crisis of the 1980s. Graduate of Deep Springs College. A Quaker, he volunteered as an ambulance driver with the American Field Service, serving with the British Eighth Army in Italy during World War II, later helping start the AFS student exchange program. He earned his BA at Cornell University and his Ph.D. in economics at Princeton University. He joined the UC Berkeley faculty in 1953; in addition to dedication to teaching, he served the university in many roles, including system-wide Vice President and Associate Dean of the Business School. Awarded the Berkeley Citation. After retirement, he was Executive Director of the Osher Foundation and was instrumental in establishing four-year UC scholarship programs for low-income students. He served on boards of Nature Conservancy (California and National) and Bernard Osher Foundation and was a Life Trustee of AFS Intercultural Programs. He married Judith Braude in 1949, who died of cancer in 1993. In 2001, he married Elizabeth Mackay Ratcliff. He is survived by his wife Elizabeth; his children, Daniel of Iowa City, Iowa, Sara of Columbus, Ohio; Thomas of Ardmore, PA, and Jonathan of Berkeley; five grandchildren; and a brother, Robert W. Balderston of Baker City, OR. A memorial service will be held at 2pm, November 11, at the UC Berkeley Faculty Club. The family asks that donations be made in his name to the Feather River Land Trust, P.O. Box 1826, Quincy, CA 95971, or to American Field Service International, 71 W. 23rd St., New York, NY 10010.
MARGOLIS--Rhea. August 25, 1912 -November 6, 1982. You are missed everyday. Keep leaving the dimes. I love you, Eila

Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Friday about the arrest of a Manhattan doctor on charges of insurance fraud paraphrased incorrectly in some copies a comment by a prosecutor, Hope Korenstein. The Media Equation column in Business Day on Oct. 15, about the business dealings of the Weinstein Company, the independent film studio founded two years ago by the former Miramax producers Harvey and Bob Weinstein, misstated the extent to which it has financed its recent acquisitions. It has co-financed 3 of its last 24 acquisitions -- not ''many.'' The column also misstated the company's involvement with the film ''Penelope.'' As part of an arrangement with IFC Films that is no longer in force, the Weinstein Company had the DVD distribution rights to the film; it did not own or sell the rights to the film.

BECK--A. Robert, M.D. Son of the late Francis and A. George Beck. Devoted husband to Marcia. Beloved father of David and Adrienne; father-in-law to Jennifer and Keith. Passed away quietly on November 4, 2007. Family to gather on Wednesday, 12:15pm at Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Graveside services, 1:30pm at Mt. Hebron Cemetery. BECK--A. Robert, MD. The Department of Surgery at The Mount Sinai Hospital and Mount Sinai School of Medicine mourns the passing of our distinguished colleague and dear friend. As an esteemed and highly regarded Professor and surgeon, Dr. Beck served the department and the hospital for over 40 years. He was recognized as a leader in the field of Pediatric Surgery. His contributions to the education of his students and care of his patients were extraordinary. We extend our sincere condolences to his entire family. Michael L. Marin, M.D., Chairman Department of Surgery Mount Sinai School of Medicine

KAPLAN--Madge. Commissioner of Community Services and Political Activist, 73. Madge Kaplan was a tireless advocate for social justice. Growing up in the Bay Ridge Section of Brooklyn during the 40's she became part of the charged political atmosphere of the times. She would often be found cutting high school classes to attend political speeches in Columbus Circle. Kaplan marched for civil rights along side Martin Luther King and spearheaded political campaigns for social justice and human rights. She was the backbone of many political campaigns for progressive causes and was a mentor for young people entering the political arena. ''If there was a progressive cause or battle, Madge was there to help lead the charge,'' said State Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli, a long time neighbor and colleague. She served as a committee person for the Democratic Party and Democratic Zone leader. After she was Democratic Zone Leader, she was First Vice Chair of the Nassau Democratic County Committee and President of the Nassau Library System board of Trustee. During 1979 and 1980 she was President of the Reform Democratic Association. She is a founding member of the Working Families Party. As Commissioner of Community Services for the town of North Hempstead, Kaplan served with dedication and distinction since 2004. She spearheaded an effort to revitalized the department and developed a number of new programs addressing a wide range of social issues from gang violence, to the environment and senior care. The most recognized of the programs is ''Project Independence'', a revolutionary empowerment program that allow seniors to remain in their homes. Madge Kaplan was a resident of Great Neck, NY for the last 50 years. Her home was always opened to people who had fallen on hard times. Kaplan believed that everyone had a story to tell and everyone was of equal value. Her daughter says that in her home growing up businessmen and the homeless sat side by side at the dinner table each sharing their stories. She had a truly unique ability to see needs and gaps in services and to mobilize others to help meet those needs. A brilliant student, she graduated high school and went to the University of Colorado at age 15, where she completed a graduate degree in psychology. After graduating she worked for Barton's Chocolate as a consultant and helped in the re-organization plan for the New York Central Railroad. She went on to work as a management consultant for the Joynt Group. She than worked for the Communication Workers of America as a political consultant. She worked as coordinator for the Nassau Employment Initiative and Housing Program for FEGS Health and Human Services System in Hempstead. Kaplan, a founder and member of the Working Families Party, left a lasting impression on Jon Kaiman, Supervisor of North Hempstead. ''She had an extraordinary way about her'' he said. ''She never sacrificed substance and she always stood for her principles.'' Kaplan was a member of the NY Civil Liberties Union, Amnesty International NARAL and other organizations fighting for the preservation of civil liberties. She was voted Women of the Year by the Eleanor Roosevelt Chapter of the American Jewish Congress. She is a recipient of the Martin Luther King Political Empowerment Award by the Economic Opportunity Council of Nassau County, The Allard Lowenstein award from the American Jewish Congress and the Community Service Award from the Community Organization for Parents and Youth. Madge Kaplan's life-long devotion to social justice and human rights ended on October 31, when she died in her home after a long illness. She was 73. A Celebration of her life will be held on November 17 from 10:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. at Clinton G. Martin Park, 1601 Marcus Ave, New Hyde Park. In lieu of flowers, her family requests that donations be made to the Great Neck Student Aid Fund, Inc, at P.O. Box 1067, Great Neck, NY 11023. She is survived by her daughter Nancy Kaplan of Redmond, WA, Kenneth Kaplan of Escondido, CA and Steven Kaplan of Port Washington, NY. Other survivors include 11 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

Well before you get to the twilight of "War and Peace," it dawns on you: what is often acclaimed (rightly in my view) as one of the greatest novels ever written is really about which of two previously married male aristocrats will get the young aristocratic girl. In the end, Count Bezukhov, otherwise known as Pierre, a bastard, obese, weak, wins the hand of Natasha, the self-centered "little princess," while Prince Andrei Bolkonsky, her other suitor, perishes from war wounds.
