Dogged by political scandal in his first term, Gov. Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky, a Republican, lost to Steve Beshear, a Democrat. In Mississippi, Gov. Haley Barbour, a Republican, won re-election.
Shares of Nortel Networks rose almost 18 percent on the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday despite lower revenue as the company reported its best operating margin since 2004.
Microsoft said Tuesday that it had fired its chief information officer, Stuart L. Scott, for violations of company policies, but a spokesman declined to give the exact reason for the dismissal.

Lawyers for the CSX Transportation Corporation, which is fighting costly asbestos claims, say they have been unable to find a crucial witness in a case, a doctor whom they accuse of fabricating scores of medical evaluations.
IndyMac Bancorp, hurt by mounting delinquencies and a collapse in demand to buy its home loans, posted a quarterly loss on Tuesday that was more than five times what it had projected.

The Texas School Land Board did not choose to award a state-owned wildlife preserve in West Texas to a private bidder or require that a winning bid allow public hunting, as the state’s land commissioner, Jerry Patterson, had insisted. Instead, the three-member board, which includes Mr. Patterson, chose to keep the two current bids open while giving the National Park Service 90 days to present an acquisition proposal on the 9,270-acre tract, the Christmas Mountains Ranch.

A Homeland Security Department employee has been placed on leave for wearing a Halloween costume that drew complaints from other workers as being racially insensitive, even as it won “most original” honors from managers at an agency party. An inquiry is under way to determine proper sanctions in the incident, said Michael Chertoff, the homeland security secretary. The unidentified employee’s costume of dreadlocks, dark makeup and prison stripes was deemed by Julie L. Myers, assistant secretary of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement division, and two other managers to be the most original at the party.

Sheriff Michael S. Carona of Orange County said he would take a 60-day leave of absence while he fought federal corruption charges accusing him and others of taking nearly $700,000 in bribes and kickbacks. Sheriff Carona said that the leave would take effect Friday. The sheriff, who is 52, could face up to 105 years in prison if convicted on all counts. He is free on $20,000 bail.

A federal judge ordered a Jesuit priest accused of molesting a boy he traveled with on an overseas trip released on $50,000 bail. Magistrate Judge Arlander Keys ordered the Rev. Donald J. McGuire, already free on bond while appealing a Wisconsin conviction on charges of molesting two boys in the 1960s, confined to his Oak Lawn home until his federal trial. The judge said he had a letter from the Jesuit order indicating that Mr. McGuire was being terminated as a priest.
Regulators would get more authority over drugs sold without a prescription under a bill by three Democrats.
Congressional appropriations committees agreed to add $3 billion to the $7.5 billion federally financed program to rebuild hurricane-damaged houses in Louisiana.

A federal judge allowed a lawsuit to proceed against a private military company, CACI International, whose interrogators are accused of abusing detainees at the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq. A similar civil suit against a second contracting company, the Titan Corporation, was dismissed under the order by Judge James Robertson. He said Titan interrogators were generally supervised and under the control of military officials, thereby freeing the company of blame. But he found that “a reasonable trier of fact could conclude that CACI retained significant authority to manage its employees.”.

A picture in the Today in Business column in Business Day yesterday with a brief report about an executive change at Time Warner was published in error. The picture was of Charles O. Prince III, the departing chief executive of Citigroup — not Jeffrey L. Bewkes, the newly chosen chief executive of Time Warner.

An article yesterday about the intentions of Prime Minister Agim Ceku of Kosovo to declare the country’s independence if agreement on its future is not reached with Serbia misstated Mr. Ceku’s age. He is 47, not 57.

An article on Thursday about a lawsuit alleging that a former lawyer for the New York State court system was fired for accusing her superiors of unethical conduct misstated the jurisdiction of the First Department of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court. It covers the Bronx and Manhattan, not “most of New York City and Westchester.”.

A profile in Science Times yesterday about Col. John Holcomb, a trauma surgeon who heads the Army’s Institute of Surgical Research, misspelled the surname of a former military physician who is the associate director of critical care medicine at Washington Hospital Center. He is Dr. Andrew F. Shorr, not Schorr.

An article in Business Day yesterday about circulation declines in the newspaper industry misstated the overall decline in Sunday circulation. The decline was 3.5 percent, not 4.6 percent. (Sunday circulation dropped 4.6 percent for the top 25 newspapers by circulation; the 3.5 percent figure was for more than 600 newspapers for which numbers were available.).

Because of an editing error, an article and picture caption in some editions on Saturday about a deadly collision on Interstate 95 in Connecticut involving a tanker truck and five other vehicles misidentified the location of the accident. It was near Exit 75, not Exit 47.

A map with a sports article on Monday about a hockey fan’s 30-day journey to attend a game at every National Hockey League arena misidentified the hometown of the Minnesota Wild. It is St. Paul, not Minneapolis.
A novel — and contentious — effort aims to commercialize the removal of heat-trapping carbon dioxide from the atmosphere using blooms of plankton.

Chris Phillips and Patrick Eaves scored 47 seconds apart in the opening minutes last night and the Ottawa Senators set a team record with their eighth straight win, a 5-1 victory over the visiting Toronto Maple Leafs.

Leandro Barbosa, Raja Bell and Shawn Marion led eight players in double figures with 16 points apiece as the visiting Phoenix Suns continued their dominance of the Eastern Conference with a 115-83 win over the Charlotte Bobcats last night.

The former strongman Alberto K. Fujimori is painting landscapes in prison as he awaits the start of his trial this month on human rights and corruption charges, an aide said, adding that he “has not ruled out holding a gallery show.”.

Twenty suspected Islamic militants were arrested around Europe in an operation led by the Italian police to break up what it said was a cell recruiting suicide bombers for Iraq and Afghanistan. Among arrests in Britain, France and Portugal, the Italian authorities said they had arrested 11 men in northern Italy, most of them Tunisians. While the authorities said the group did not appear to be planning attacks inside Italy, they said they confiscated Al Qaeda manuals for making explosives, remote detonators, poisons and instructions on guerrilla techniques. Last month, Spain arrested six North Africans suspected of recruiting bombers to go to Iraq and Afghanistan.
The independent Kenya National Commission on Human Rights has implicated the Kenyan police in the execution-style deaths of nearly 500 people between June and October.

Delegates at a congress of the Liberal Democratic Party voted unanimously to nominate President Islam A. Karimov to run in the Dec. 23 presidential election, the Interfax news agency reported. He is constitutionally barred from seeking a third seven-year term, and election officials have not yet explained the legal mechanism justifying his nomination.

In his most explicit statement to date on an article in Turkey’s penal code that has seen writers, journalists, academics and intellectuals prosecuted for insulting “Turkishness,” the European Union’s enlargement commissioner, Olli Rehn, left, said it was “simply not acceptable in a European democracy” and that it “must be repealed or amended without delay” if Turkey hoped for European Union membership. “The ball is in Turkey’s court,” he added. Hours later, Turkish television stations quoted Justice Minister Mehmet Ali Sahin as saying the government would change the controversial law and that a bill would be put before Parliament in the coming days. He gave no details of how the law would be changed.

Chile returned 3,778 books taken from Peru’s national library in Lima when Chilean soldiers pillaged it in 1881. The volumes, in Greek, Latin, French and Spanish, some with full-page colonial-era maps, dated from the 16th to 19th centuries.

Officials said that floods had killed at least 67 people in the central part of the country over the last week and that 160,000 others were being evacuated as coastal areas braced for another tropical storm.

Belgium broke its own record for the longest period without a government as tensions continued among the country’s leaders, divided by language. Almost five months since national elections on June 10, Belgium marked 149 days without a government, beating a previous record set in 1988. As the deadlock continues, speculation is mounting that political divisions between the Flemish, who speak a form of Dutch and make up two-thirds of the population, and the Walloons, who speak French, could lead to Belgium’s splitting up.

Portugal eliminated the United States yesterday, 6-5, and clinched a spot in the quarterfinals of the 16-team Beach Soccer World Cup in Rio de Janeiro.Portugal advanced from Group B; Spain was the group winner despite a 5-4 loss to Iran. The top two teams in each of the four groups advance.Brazil, the defending champion, defeated Russia, 5-4, on penalties to remain unbeaten and win Group A.Mexico, a 6-3 winner over the Solomon Islands, also advanced, as did Nigeria and Senegal. Italy, Uruguay, Japan, Argentina and France are vying for the last two spots.

Liverpool captured the biggest victory in Champions League history yesterday, defeating the visiting Turkish club Besiktas, 8-0. Liverpool, the five-time European champion, needed a victory after gaining only a point from its first three Group A matches. Yossi Benayoun, a midfielder from Israel, scored three goals. The margin of victory was the largest since 7-0 wins by Juventus in 2003 and by Arsenal two weeks ago.The defending champion A.C. Milan; Rosenborg of Norway; Porto; Lazio; and Glasgow Celtic were also winners. Real Madrid’s match at Olympiakos and Chelsea’s match at Schalke ended in scoreless draws.

Tommy Tuberville, coach of No. 18 Auburn, would not discuss reports that his name was high on the list of candidates if Texas A&M were to fire Coach Dennis Franchione. “As I told our players, that’s the least of our worries or anybody’s worries,” Tuberville, a former Texas A&M defensive coordinator, said.Meanwhile, Franchione denied reports that he was negotiating a contract buyout. Texas A&M said Monday that Athletic Director Bill Byrne would wait until the season ended before evaluating Franchione.

The jockey Garrett Gomez can match Jerry Bailey’s record of 70 stakes wins in a year with a victory today in the $65,000-added War Chant Stakes on the opening day of Hollywood Park’s 32-day Autumn Meet in Inglewood, Calif.Gomez will ride Karazi in the one-mile race for 3-year-olds. Bailey set the record four years ago.

The Vegas Grand Prix will not return in 2008 for the Champ Car World Series. Race officials said they were unable to find a new promoter to replace DDB Ventures, which ran the inaugural race in April. DDB Ventures also canceled a race in Phoenix in December, then closed its race promotions business.

Joe Crawford scored 20 points last night and 20th-ranked Kentucky began the Billy Gillispie era with a 67-40 victory over visiting Central Arkansas in the opening round of the 2K Sports College Hoops Classic.The Wildcats (1-0) advanced to the second round tonight against Gardner-Webb, which defeated Alabama A&M, 69-55.Gillispie led Texas A&M to the Round of 16 at last season’s N.C.A.A. tournament before replacing Tubby Smith.Crawford, a senior guard who was a starter last season, did not take to the court until 13 minutes in. He soon took over the offense, shooting 7 of 11 from the field, including two dunks.The sophomore forward Mark Coury accounted for 10 of Kentucky’s first 12 points. He finished with 13 points and 10 rebounds.The Bears missed their first nine shots and did not score until the junior center Landrell Brewer hit two free throws more than five minutes in. Durrell Nevels led Central Arkansas (0-1) with 10 points.
Some of the 38,676 people who completed the New York City Marathon on Sunday were given incorrect finishing times, possibly affecting their attempts to qualify for the Boston Marathon.
The city’s new glass-walled bus shelters have received their baptism by acid.
The French president backslapped and hugged his way through Washington, and proclaimed his determination to be a reliable partner of the United States.
The prospect of triple-digit oil prices has redrawn the economic and political map of the world.
Robert E. Rubin, who was named Citigroup’s chairman after the departure of Charles O. Prince III, has moved quickly to deal with the turmoil that has engulfed the banking giant.
A proposal to give the federal government sweeping authority over imports won plaudits as a step toward restoring public confidence in product safety.
Google’s plan to develop a new open software standard for mobile phones could result in a more richly and fully integrated universe of mobile devices.
Congress can help reduce recidivism by passing the Second Chance Act, which would aid former prisoners to find a place in society.
Congressional Democrats should vote for the Peruvian deal, which would give American businesses greater access to Peru’s markets.
The Department of Education will examine whether federal money was inappropriately used to buy educational products from a company owned by Neil Bush, the president’s brother.
Disappointment turned to fury after Gen. Pervez Musharraf scrapped the Supreme Court and the Constitution.
Congress needs to pass a strong new chemical plant law — one that puts more weight on the safety of the public and less on industry’s bottom line.
The social networking site now sells ads that display people’s profile photos next to commercial messages that are shown to their friends about items they purchased or registered an opinion about.
A majority of House Republicans joined Democrats on Tuesday in confronting President Bush over federal spending.
Campaigns venturing into the unruly territory of Web advertising risk losing what they crave most: control.
Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey may soon need to hang a help-wanted sign outside the treasurer’s office.
A retired AT&T technician is fighting back against the Bush administration’s plan to grant companies legal immunity for their secret cooperation in eavesdropping  programs.
Parents across the city are discussing the city’s new report card for its schools, the results of which surprised many.
With the help of Republicans aiming to embarrass Democratic Congressional leaders, Representative Dennis Kucinich nearly succeeded in securing an hour of debate on his bill Tuesday.

Laurence D. Fink, the leading candidate to become the head of Merrill Lynch, has met with the executive search firm responsible for filling the position, according to a person briefed on the discussions.
If approved, the pact could revive the administration’s faltering trade deals with Panama, Colombia and South Korea, all of which are awaiting Congressional approval.
Parents of about two dozen students who took part in a protest against the Iraq war at a suburban high school  demanded that their children be allowed to return to classes.

It was clear as the Pittsburgh Steelers dismantled the vaunted Baltimore Ravens pass defense Monday night that Steelers quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, below right, was having a special game, but it was not obvious just how unusual it was.
House and Senate negotiators approved a $459 billion military spending bill, but rejected a Republican bid to provide $70 billion more to the war in Iraq.
An art gallery that has filed for bankruptcy amid a cascade of lawsuits had a complicated relationship with the artists it represented.
Wall Street bonuses are expected to be flat to down 15 percent, making them the latest victim of the subprime mortgage collapse and the tight credit market.
St. Lawrence University is one of several New York institutions that use Adirondack Park for classes.
Tuesday marked the first official meeting between a pope and a Saudi monarch. They met for half an hour, speaking through interpreters.
A year ago, there were 15 billionaires in China. Now, there are more than 100, according to the widely watched Hurun Report.
Speaking softly and a little nervously, Judith Giuliani returned to the campaign spotlight.
Reeling from its exposure to assets backed by subprime mortgages, Citigroup has appointed a triage team led by Richard A. Stuckey Jr., one of Wall Street’s best-known fix-it men.
A booming car industry and high pollution levels are exposing the capital’s residents to heightened risks of a range of respiratory diseases.
The London newspapers have been reporting that Paul McCartney is having a romantic relationship with Nancy Shevell, who is on the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
A diagnostic test intended to identify patients who should receive heart defibrillators did not produce conclusive data, according to initial results from a clinical trial.
The San Francisco Chronicle reported that Mariners outfielder José Guillén and two retired players — Matt Williams and Ismael Valdez — received human growth hormone and steroids.

ORLANDO, Fla., Nov. 6 — With a 25-5 vote, general managers took the first step Tuesday to add instant replay to baseball games. The vote was a significant departure from previous votes at general managers meetings, where the issue had the support of, at best, half of those present.
On Staten Island, a boggy green break in one of the city’s most industrialized stretches of waterfront is being preserved.
Seeing low fees for family doctors as a weak link in the nation’s health care system, some big employers and health insurers are seeking new ways to pay doctors to reward high-quality medical care.
As the acting head of the Office of Legal Counsel at the Justice Department, Daniel Levin asked to undergo waterboarding to bring reality to bear on his deliberations on the torture question.
Shares bounded higher Tuesday as investors still mindful of widening credit problems nonetheless went in search of bargains in the stock market.
The Senate Judiciary Committee voted Tuesday to approve the nomination of Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general.
A federal judge has thrown out a main contention by Johnson & Johnson in a lawsuit against the American Red Cross over use of the red cross symbol.
F.C. Bayern Munich, Germany’s most decorated club, is trying to lead the country’s top soccer league back to greatness.
The Archer Daniels Midland Company, a major agricultural processor, reported higher-than-expected quarterly profit Tuesday.
An inquiry focuses on whether six prominent evangelistic ministries have illegally used donations to finance opulent lifestyles.
Some prominent show runners — the writer-producers who fill multiple roles at the helm of television programs — said they will not perform any duties while the writers’ strike continued.
Unless curbed, the two countries’ surging fuel consumption will strain global oil trade, push up prices and lead to substantially higher carbon dioxide emissions, according to a new report.

A bead toy that just won an Australian Toy of the Year award was recalled by its manufacturer on Tuesday after media reports that a chemical in it turns into a powerful date-rape drug, GHB, when eaten.

HARTFORD, Nov. 6 — A six-member bipartisan Senate committee investigating the conduct of the former Republican minority leader voted on Tuesday to ask the full Senate for subpoena power in considering whether to expel him for asking a trash hauler with alleged mob ties to threaten his granddaughter’s husband.

Mr. Viola was best known for sponsoring what was considered one of the most prestigious races of the year, the Frank Viola Invitational, a 400-mile contest in which the birds are released in Ohio and fly back to New York.
For gay Muslims, change may come via the reassessment of sacred texts used to condemn homosexuality.
For decades, Japan pursued economic development at all costs, but in an effort to protect the environment it is aiming to reverse destruction along the Kushiro River.
Unless Alex Rodriguez surprises the Yankees by taking a below-market deal to return, the Yankees are committed to looking elsewhere, and the Florida Marlins are dangling Miguel Cabrera.
Yahoo officials ran into withering criticism from United States lawmakers for their company’s role in the jailing of a Chinese journalist.
A kayak trip reveals the undeveloped land and the wildlife of Vieques, which was once home to a U.S. Navy bombing range.
A securities analyst at Fox-Pitt Kelton downgraded Morgan Stanley, forecasting that the firm could suffer losses of $6 billion related to the reduced value of credit investments.
The escalating confrontation with President Bush over federal spending is being fueled in part by 2008 political considerations.
The Department of Defense has identified 3,838 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Monday:.
Fred D. Thompson uses his ability to convey sincerity to underscore his conservative bona fides and his religious conviction in a new ad.

When Mario Biaggi, the revered Bronx congressman, was about to be sentenced in a racketeering case in 1988, he declared in court that the hostile testimony and unflattering publicity were punishment enough.
Jets tight end Joe Kowalewski scored more style points than actual points with his first N.F.L. touchdown and the ensuing celebration.
N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell informed Titans cornerback Pacman Jones Tuesday that he would serve out his entire suspension for the 2007 season.
Mr. Sundman’s innovative mail-order marketing, using everything from comic books to matchbook covers, introduced millions to the once exclusive worlds of philately and numismatics.

Judge Richard A. Damiani of State Superior Court imposed an order of silence yesterday that bars prosecutors and defense lawyers from talking to news organizations about the case against two men accused of killing a woman and her two daughters during a home invasion in Cheshire on July 23. The judge rejected arguments that other measures were available to ensure a fair trial for the suspects, Joshua Komisarjevsky, 27, of Cheshire, and Steven Hayes, 44, of Winsted.

Lawyers for Sharpe James, the former Newark mayor, have asked that a federal indictment on corruption charges be dismissed because the government has failed to prove a crime. In motions filed in Federal District Court late Monday, the lawyers also said that Mr. James would have an “exceptionally difficult, if not impossible” time getting a fair trial in Newark, but they stopped short of asking for a change of venue. They also asked for a delay in the start of the trial, set for early next year, to allow them to review about 240,000 documents.

The police are seeking a man suspected of 17 bank robberies in Manhattan and the Bronx since May 2006. On Monday, the man entered the Sovereign Bank at 169 Seventh Avenue in Manhattan about 5:20 p.m. and gave a note to a teller demanding cash. He is described as black, with a mustache and goatee, 40 to 45 years old, about 5-foot-3 to 5-foot-5. The police ask anyone with information to call 800-577-TIPS (800-577-8477).

A search for a suspected killer in the Bronx early yesterday turned into a six-hour hostage situation and ended with the arrest of Marlon Sanders, 31, of Queens, on charges of second-degree murder, the police said. Shortly after 3 a.m., detectives went to a home at 4445 Williamsbridge Road in Morris Park in search of Mr. Sanders, who was suspected of fatally shooting Jamal Leavy, 37, of Queens, on Monday, the police said. When they arrived at the home, Mr. Sanders had a woman and her two children captive, but they were removed unharmed about 9 a.m., the police said.

A subway operator received minor injuries yesterday when his train hit a wooden barrier at the end of a track, transit officials said. The southbound M train had just made its final stop and was not carrying any passengers, the officials said. The train crashed shortly before 11 a.m. in a tunnel just south of the Chambers Street station. The driver, who was not identified, was able to walk unassisted, and was taken to St. Vincent’s Hospital Manhattan, fire officials said.

A Queens man was arrested yesterday after having struck and killed a pedestrian in Brooklyn about 5 a.m., the police said. The man, David Aldarondo, 59, of Ozone Park, was charged with criminally negligent homicide, speeding and running a red light, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney said. The police said that Mr. Aldarondo, westbound on Atlantic Avenue, struck a pedestrian, Lillian Mustapha, 63, of East New York, at the Crescent Street intersection. She was pronounced dead at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, the police said.
Mr. Biagi’s criticism of Silvio Berlusconi during the 2001 election campaign got him ousted from state television when Mr. Berlusconi became prime minister.
Overweight people have a lower death rate because they are less likely to die from certain diseases, a report says.
Mr. Osmond was the father of the singing family act the Osmond Brothers and the performers Donny and Marie Osmond.
Shortly after completing the New York City Marathon on Sunday, Dr. Matthew P. Hardy, a research scientist, returned to his Manhattan apartment and died from cardiac arrest.
Analysts said the step reflected the likelihood that the company would not earn significant profits on its automotive or its finance operations in the near future.
Fiji Water plans to become carbon negative — that is, to more than make up for the greenhouse gases released in the creation, transportation and sales of its product.
There were more than 100,000 fewer deaths among the overweight in 2004 than would have been expected if those people had been of normal weight, a new study indicates.
The age discrimination case that was argued before the Supreme Court on Tuesday turned on a hyper-technical issue that only an employment lawyer could love.
Faced with increasing demands to give up his position as military chief, Gen. Pervez Musharraf decided to topple President Musharraf.
The moment has come for the Western democracies to show in their actions, and not just in their rhetoric, which side they are on.
Ringing cellphones and Web surfing students are only part of the exasperation of countless teachers and professors in the computer era.
As the number of sidewalk cafes increases and the size of bus shelters and newsstands grow, the city’s sidewalks are more crowded than they have ever been, according to a design watchdog group.
Making its first major foray into the Manhattan office market, the Kushner Companies bought 666 Fifth Avenue for $1.8 billion, a breathtaking price even by Midtown Manhattan standards.
The five authors say that the parent company of Regnery Publishing deprives its writers of royalties by giving steep discounts to book clubs and other organizations owned by the same parent company.
Five authors charged that Regnery Publishing deprives its writers of royalties by selling their books at a steep discount to organizations owned by the same parent company.
The Paper Mill Playhouse announced that it has appointed a new executive director, Mark W. Jones.
To the Editor:.
Soon, at a nearby theater, opera from La Scala, more Met Opera transmissions in more sites, the mystery finger and more culture news.
The singer Rosanne Cash, 52, the daughter of Johnny Cash, announced yesterday that she is to undergo brain surgery.

The first 34 chapters of the continuing online comic book devoted to NBC’s “Heroes,” a series about ordinary people dealing with extraordinary abilities, will be released today as a hardcover collection.
Italian officials, trumpeting another victory in their drive against the illegal traffic in antiquities, yesterday displayed eight Etruscan or Roman statues.
In a new venture, opera from Teatro alla Scala in Milan and two other renowned Italian houses will be shown at more than 60 theaters from coast to coast.
The second season of “Metropolitan Opera: Live in High Definition” will begin on Dec. 15 .
The finger has been identified. The digit that the guitarist Jimmy Page fractured, forcing a two-week postponement of Led Zeppelin’s reunion concert, was his left pinky.
While many viewers may consider that potential consequence of the writers’ strike a cause for seasonal celebration, it’s not as merry a prospect as one might think.
A proposal in Congress to put a price tag on greenhouse-gas emissions could overturn the economics of energy.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
To the Editor:.
One couple’s passion for art and architecture underlies everything they have done on their property in Greece.
Bands in large, modern, nondenominational churches — some would say megachurches — now provide one of the major ways that Americans hear live music.
Call it Phase 3 of the greening of corporate America. Companies are looking at their supply chain as the next frontier for combating climate change.
Bliss Broyard, author of “One Drop,” reconnects with her New Orleans kin while on book tour.
The tale told in Adrienne Kennedy’s short, sharp, quietly hypnotic play leaves a lasting chill in the bones.
“Political Idol” does to the presidential primaries what “Forbidden Broadway” does to theater; “Things Are Going to Change, I Can Feel It”  is done in by its own earnestness.
Prosecutors opened a formal investigation into charges that the chairman of the South Korean conglomerate masterminded a broad scheme of bribery and illegal transactions.
The United States is the fastest-growing market in the world for wind power. Despite a patchwork of laws and regulations, many European energy companies would like to plant their windmills here.
Even to the untrained eye, the manuscript of the Russian composer Alfred Schnittke’s Symphony No. 9 would speak volumes.
More than a half century after the opening of the first commercial reactor, there is still no permanent disposal site for highly radioactive waste.
For Recall Records, a Paris independent that celebrated its 10th anniversary at the Blender Theater at Gramercy on Monday, the philosophy of difference has mostly been a good thing.
After leaving behind a wife, a ruined restaurant empire and a welter of debt, an underground restaurateur returns.
“The Brothers Size” is an absorbing and emotionally resonant drama set in the bayou country of Louisiana.
A breeder in Kansas is on a mission to save rare heritage turkeys and the culture of raising them.
In an blunt interview, the head of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said he would not back more rate cuts unless the economy slowed further than current estimates.

The ability to manipulate matter on a tiny scale could lead to environmental breakthroughs. Billions of dollars are being spent, but the most exciting green nanoproducts are still on the drawing boards.
Dennis Russell Davies and Maki Namekawa played Alexander Zemlinsky’s four-hand version of Beethoven’s “Fidelio” in extroverted and very public fashion on Monday.
These sobering dispatches shed a dismal light on American efforts to improve the lot of ordinary Afghans.
By THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Mermaid Inn opens a branch on the Upper West Side, Momofuku expands, Bistro Desaret, Casaville, Jodie’s Friends and Ruthie Mae’s are now open.
Long Island Celebration.
Ancient Traditions.
As energy consumption by data centers climbs, energy efficiency becomes a priority.
The concept of an easement is clear when it comes to land. But who owns the water, or the fish, or the right to fish?
Respect for law, safety and public health still lag far behind the Kremlin’s restored sense of self.
Sound environmental policy has emerged as a central organizing principle of the city’s economic growth.

A listing in the Off the Menu column last Wednesday about Elementi, a restaurant in Brooklyn, misidentified the owner and the restaurant where the chef previously worked, and misspelled the chef’s given name. Elementi is owned by Roy and Mallory Rutledge — not by the chef, Camillo (not Camilo) Bassani. Mr. Bassani previously worked at the restaurant Esca, not Cipriani.

An article on Oct. 17, about a public health group that received money from the fishing industry and then recommended that women of childbearing age eat more fish despite fears of mercury contamination, referred imprecisely to the position of a Web site, realmercuryfacts.com, that also received money from the fishing industry. Although the Web site raises questions about studies that focus on the dangers of mercury in seafood, it does not directly dispute government warnings about mercury in seafood.

A recipe for pork grillades and grits with an article last Wednesday about the New Orleans chef John Besh omitted the amount of butter that should be folded into the grits. One pound of butter should be used. A corrected recipe is at www.nytimes.com/dining.

Because of an editing error, the Pairing column last Wednesday, about a Portuguese dish that inspired a recipe for a pork stew, referred incorrectly to Mealhada, the town that specializes in the dish. It is not at the mouth of the Douro River.
What’s greener than HFCs for refrigeration? Carbon dioxide. Thus the public relations problem.
Companies are giving up control of their electrical systems, and they are being paid to do it. The goal? To better manage the nation’s burdened power grid.
Authorities raised concerns about escalating health problems and looting following the five days of heavy rains last week.
Six American soldiers were killed in three separate attacks Monday, bringing the number of deaths this year to 852.
The suicide bombing, which killed a leading opposition figure, appeared to represent an effort by the Taliban to extend its reach to the north of the country.
Protests continued today as the ousted chief justice urged lawyers to continue to defy Gen. Pervez Musharraf’s state of emergency.
Frying a pizza results in one that is ultracrisp, with the wonderful flavor of olive oil permeating the dough.
Iraqi Kurdistan is a robust export market for Turkish farmers and factory owners, who would suffer if that trade were curtailed.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has started to chip away at nepotism and displayed a renewed vigor in launching projects not seen in decades.
In 2005, New York’s child welfare commissioner faced a delicate challenge in evaluating minority-run agencies.
On the outskirts of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., lies Sprout Creek Farm, where raw-milk cheese is made on 200 pastoral acres.
The automaker reported a $39-billion loss after it took a huge noncash charge to write down deferred tax credits.
Emmanuel Thingue, a landscape architect for the Parks and Recreation Department, is one of the people who make up the strong, hidden muscles of city life.
When Noel Isiais was a toddler, doctors learned that he had Duchenne muscular dystrophy, a condition that causes muscle weakness and wasting.
A study of car mechanics comes to a depressing conclusion about situations where the expert who diagnoses a problem is the one who will be paid to fix it.
Any agent with a player like Alex Rodriguez for a client would want the Yankees to drive up the bidding. The question now is if there is anyone else to drive up the bidding.
A 1910 Victorian house in Aiken, S.C., a lakefront log-style house in Galena, Mo., and an alcove studio in San Francisco.
It was the first phone conversation between President Bush and the Pakistani president since General Musharraf seized emergency powers on Saturday.
Democrats declared Tuesday that Gov. Eliot Spitzer’s plan to give driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants had not proved to be the electoral boon Republicans had hoped for in local elections

The Jewish Federation of Central New Jersey deeply mourns the passing of Alfred Gelfond, Past President and Campaign Chairman, and distinguished leader of the Jewish community. Alf, along with his wife Sandy, have been enthusiastic supporters of the Jewish community. Their passion and love of the State of Israel and the vibrancy of our community has inspired others for half a century. His passing is a tremendous loss for the entire community. Our sincere condolences to his beloved wife Sandy, his children Beth, Judy, Steve and his grandchildren Jonah and Jesse and his entire family. They say there is no place like home, but it is beginning to look as if there is a place sort of like home 41 light-years from here in the constellation Cancer. Astronomers reported yesterday that there were at least five planets circling a star there known as 55 Cancri, where only four had been known before, making it the most extensive planetary system yet found outside our own. It is also the one that most resembles our solar system, with a giant planet orbiting far out from the star and four smaller ones closer in.

ALBERT--Leo, noted Philanthropist, died on November 3, 2007, in Palm Beach, FL. Leo was born on October 9, 1920, to the late Felix and Azilda Michaud Albert of St. Agathe, Maine. He enlisted in the U.S. Marine Corps and served in the Pacific Theatre. After being discharged in 1946 Leo joined Prentice Hall as a stock boy and retired in 1985 as Chairman of the Board, Prentice Hall International Publishers. In 1992 Leo and his late wife, Anne Ross Albert, became residents of Palm Beach, FL, where they were known for their philanthropy. Leo was a member of St. Edward Catholic Church, The Beach Club, The Everglades Club, Old Guard Society of Palm Beach, Yacht Club, and the Knickerbocker Country Club of Tenafly, NJ. Leo is survived by his brothers, Jean Albert and wife, Yvette, of Farmington, CT; Philip Albert and his wife, Jeanine, of Farmington, CT; Roger Albert of Toms River, NJ; his sisters, Juliette Tardis of Southington, CT; Theresa Albert of Tampa, FL; Fran Sirois and husband, Valere, of Madawaska, ME; and Marguerite Lupine of West Hartford, CT, as well as numerous nephews, nieces, grandnephews and grandnieces as well as a great-grandniece. Visitation will be at the Quattlebaum Funeral Home, West Palm Beach, FL, on Thursday, November 8, 6-8pm. The funeral mass will be at St. Edward Catholic Church, Palm Beach, FL, on Friday, November 9. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a charity in Leo's name.

Leftover Chinese takeout can be refrigerated in its container. But not a slice of pizza. Now, instead of reaching for the aluminum foil, pizza-lovers with extra slices can slip them into sealable plastic bags. Mama Fresco's Pizza Saver is triangular, so a slice fits into it nicely for storage in the refrigerator or freezer.

General Motors said Tuesday that it would take a $39 billion noncash charge in the third quarter to remove net deferred tax assets from its books. G.M. said the charge, which affects the automaker's businesses in the United States, Germany and Canada, would have no impact on operations and would not interfere with efforts to restructure.

The Palm Court in the Plaza, above, a magnet for afternoon tea and Sunday brunch since the hotel opened 100 years ago, will have Didier Virot as its chef when the refurbished room opens by the end of the year. Mr. Virot, who has worked with Jean-Georges Vongerichten, was formerly the chef at FR.OG in SoHo. His breakfast, lunch, dinner, tea and brunch menus will blend classical and modern French. He will also create food for a new Champagne Bar in the lobby, and for the Rose Club, a lounge overlooking it on a new mezzanine.

PEDERSEN--Lucy K. S., a long-time resident of Rye, New York and Ocean Reef, Key Largo, Florida, died Monday, November 5, 2007 at her home in Rye. Lucy was born December 14, 1928 at New York Hospital to the late Rudolph Jay and Lucia Moran Schaefer Jr. Lucy attended Sacred Heart Convent in Maplehurst, NY, Convent of the Sacred Heart in Noroton, CT, and was a graduate of The Barmore School, in the Bronx, NY. An avid outdoors person, and all-around athlete, Lucy devoted much of her adult life to working within the Rye community including for many years joyfully and tireless caring for the disabled and the handicapped. She was President of The Rye Association for the Handicapped from 1986 to her retirement in 2006, when she was named President Emeritus of the organization. For her service and efforts she was awarded The City of Rye Commission on Human Rights Award in 1994, and The Rye YMCA Community Service Recognition Award in 2005. Lucy was loving mother to her four children, Peer Terrill (Jr.), Donna Fenech, Lyn Elizabeth, and Lucy Hazard; and a loving grandmother to her eight grandchildren Peer III, Paige, Madeline, Samantha, and Margaret Pedersen, and Nathan, Lorraine, and Kerri Fenech. She is also survived by her late father's wife, Janet Schaefer, by her siblings Edmee Schaefer Combs, Rudolph J. Schaefer, and Gwen T. Schaefer, and their large and loving families; and by her son-in-laws Craig Fenech and Scott Hazard, former daughter-in-law Mary Quick Pedersen, and former husband Peer T. Pedersen. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY on Wednesday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at Resurrection Church on Thursday at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Lucy to The Rye Association For The Handicapped, Inc., P.O. Box 16, Rye, NY 10580-0016.

All the news isn't bad for Duane (Dog) Chapman, whose use of a racial slur cost him his popular A & E reality show, ''Dog the Bounty Hunter.'' A magistrate in Honolulu dismissed a government attempt on Monday to extradite Mr. Chapman to Mexico to face a pending appeal of kidnapping charges, The Associated Press reported. United States Magistrate Barry Kurren decided that because a Mexican judge had dismissed the kidnapping charges in July, Mr. Chapman, 54, his son Leland and a third man were no longer charged with any offenses. Mr. Chapman was arrested in 2003 after seizing Andrew Luster, heir to the Max Factor cosmetics fortune, on a street in Puerto Vallarta to take him back to the United States to serve a 124-year jail sentence for drugging and raping three women. Mr. Luster was flown to California shortly after the capture and is now in jail.

A sports article yesterday about Phyllis Shipman, a 64-year-old retired elementary school principal who is competing for an Olympic berth in archery, misidentified the location of the 2004 Summer Games, for which Ms. Shipman failed to qualify. It was Athens -- not Sydney, Australia, the host city in 2000.

GUMBS--Robert Darvin, 57, departed this life on Wednesday, October 31, 2007, after a brief illness. Robert graduated from Columbia University with a master's degree in public health. He also attended St. Francis College, where he obtained a Bachelor of Arts degree in psychology. He was a fellow of the New York Academy of Medicine and executive director of the Community Health Alliance of Harlem and Northern Manhattan. He was on the board of directors of the following organizations: One Hundred Black Men, the National Black Leadership Commission on AIDS, the National Association of Child Advocates and the Ebony Ecumenical Ensemble, and served on several other organizations. Robert, an activist, advocate and health care industry strategist, worked tirelessly to improve access to quality health care for all Americans. He began his professional career in health care in 1974. As a systems analyst and strategic planner, he quickly made his mark on the industry serving as an influential resource shaping public policy decisions. Robert designed and implemented innovative and inclusive strategies and published numerous reports that helped remove systemic barriers to quality health care services for underserved populations. In a career that spanned over thirty years, he was executive director of the New York City Health Systems Agency, senior vice president for network development at St. Barnabas Hospital and, ultimately, founder and president of Strategic Resources, Inc., a consulting firm serving health and human services organizations. An active member and elected lay leader at the Riverside Church in New York City, and motivated by his passion for justice, Bob was active in the HIV AIDS Global Ministry, the Social Justice Commission and the Budget and Planning and Public Health Committee, to name a few. On August 21, 1982, Robert married the former Gerri (Sandy) Bryant. The union was blessed with twenty-five years of marriage. Robert also leaves to cherish his memory: his mother, Mildred Morrison Gumbs; a twin brother, Richard Allen Gumbs; a sister, Charlene Coleman; a brother-in-law, Charles Coleman; and his beloved nieces, nephews, godchildren and friends. Viewing will be held on Wednesday from 8am to 9:45am at the Christ Chapel of Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, New York, NY. A service will follow, from 10am to 12 noon. Interment is at the Ewing Cemetery, Trenton, New Jersey, at 3 pm. The Family of Robert Darvin Gumbs

There is much more to a steer than steaks, regardless of whether the animal was fed corn, or raised on grass, or like wagyu cattle in Japan, massaged and served beer. The wagyu cattle raised here are also pampered, and cuts from them other than steaks also have a particular succulence. There's the brisket, for example. This cut has no finer destiny than pastrami or corned beef. When made with lavishly marbled wagyu, these cured meats acquire a delectable lushness. The pastrami, held by Juan Garcia, below, delivers a nice peppery, smoky edge; the silky corned beef's salt is modest.

An obituary yesterday about the writer Peter Viertel misstated the relationship of his first wife, the former Virginia Ray Schulberg, to the writer Budd Schulberg. She is Mr. Schulberg's former wife, not his daughter.

HARDY--Matthew, M.D. We are deeply saddened by the sudden death of our dear friend and colleague, Dr. Matthew Hardy. Adjunct Professor of Reproductive Biology in Urology at Weill Cornell Medical College, Dr. Hardy was one of the world's leading researchers in the study of Leydig cells, the hormoneproducing component of the testes. The former co-editor of the Journal of Andrology, he was honored by the American Society of Andrology, receiving a Young Andrologist Award, and was recently selected for their Distinguished Service Award. Possessed with a unique ability to bridge clinical problems to basic laboratory work, Dr. Hardy was greatly admired by his colleagues and students at Weill Cornell. He will be much missed. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Diane. Peter N. Schlegel, M.D., Chairman of Urology Weill Cornell Medical College

An article on Oct. 17, about a public health group that received money from the fishing industry and then recommended that women of childbearing age eat more fish despite fears of mercury contamination, referred imprecisely to the position of a Web site, realmercuryfacts.com, that also received money from the fishing industry. Although the Web site raises questions about studies that focus on the dangers of mercury in seafood, it does not directly dispute government warnings about mercury in seafood.

THE WORLD OVER A BARREL The prospect of triple-digit oil prices (the price of a barrel reached $96.70 yesterday) has redrawn the economic and political map of the world. Oil-rich nations are enjoying historic gains, while major importers -- including China and India -- confront rising economic and social costs. Surging fuel consumption in China and India threatens to strain global oil trade, push up prices and lead to substantially higher carbon dioxide emissions in coming decades, according to the International Energy Agency. [C3.]

Robert E. Rubin, Treasury secretary in the Clinton administration and new chairman of Citigroup, has overcome early misgivings about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential candidacy and will support her publicly in the fight for the Democratic nomination, The New York Times reported.

If you ask most New Yorkers about GAAP-balanced budgets, four-year financial plans and the city’s emergency financial control board, you are likely to get only a blank stare. But any city resident who lived through the pain and tumult of the mid-1970s can attest to the anxiety caused by tens of thousands of layoffs, the disruption of city services and the looming fear of municipal bankruptcy.The city’s Independent Budget Office and the Center for New York City Affairs at the New School organized a gathering of the city’s leading experts in municipal finance — including Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s budget director, Mark Page — this morning for a discussion, moderated by Joyce Purnick of The Times. The issue is not a theoretical one, because next year will bring a major change — the first since 1975 — in how the city’s budget works.

Federal prosecutors will ask a grand jury today to indict Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York police commissioner, on charges that include tax fraud, corruption and conspiracy counts, William K. Rashbaum and Russ Buettner explain in a front-page article.

I can't guarantee Steve Smith will dance in the end zone this week, but you have to wonder if he is dancing somewhere right now: it looks like he'll get a break from David Carr on Sunday. Not that Smith was pleased when Carr sustained a concussion last week; it's just that he and Carr have had little chemistry this season, and while Carolina (8-8) has been able to tread water through injuries to Jake Delhomme and Vinny Testaverde, Smith's numbers have been in a nosedive with Carr at the controls.

I met my son Des for the first time in October of 2003. Well, it wasn't a real meeting - just a video tape meeting. A dear friend who had adopted a child from Ethiopia wanted me to consider an adoption from that country and told me that I could see some nice waiting children on a video if I contacted the agency she used. I had no intention of doing such a thing and that was that. I did not call the agency.

Will Okun is a Chicago school teacher who traveled with Nick Kristof in June to central Africa, on the win-a-trip contest. He blogged and vlogged as he went, and you can see his reports at www.nytimes.com/twofortheroad. He teaches English and photography in a Chicago school with many students from low-income and minority homes.

The interim Oklahoma State system chief executive officer and president Marlene Strathe announced late today that the embattled sophomore linebacker Chris Collins would not play in any of the Cowboys' remaining games this season.
Child bullfighting has become popular in Mexico, where there are no age limits for matadors. (This film contains footage that may be disturbing.)

Last year New York Times columnist and author Tom Friedman hoped that $100-a-barrel oil would induce the U.S. to finally curb its energy use excesses and jump into alternative energy. "The sooner we go to $100 a barrel, the sooner we're going to have everyone in America driving a plug-in hybrid car fueled by corn and ethanol," he said.

Updated | 7:40 p.m.Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, after prodding from a rival campaign, has issued positions on several trade deals currently before Congress, including her support for an agreement with Peru that is dividing her party.

Calling the Hollywood writers' strike "just a shame," Robert A. Iger, the chief executive of the Walt Disney Company, told analysts today in a quarterly conference call that ABC will feel the impacts of a walkout after four weeks of picketing. "It will definitely have an impact on ABC's schedule" if a strike stretches into next month, he said.

One of the more pleasant outcomes of the slowly growing trend toward highly involved fatherhood has been, I've found, the ability to plainly see that total ninnyishness is not a uniquely female thing.
Cartoon found here.
Oh my God. Well, strictly speaking, Sonny Perdue's God.
From NewsBiscuit across the pond:
I won't say this often, but Dan Froomkin is wrong here. I blame Bush for a lot of things, but the declining dollar isn't one of them.

With the prospect of a prolonged strike, "the broadcast networks are hard at work developing alternative programming to fill in the scheduling gaps," Shari Anne Brill, a senior vice president at the media buying agency Carat USA, wrote in a report to clients yesterday.
Pretty good review in the daily Times. But has Peter Beinart been assigned permanent status as reviewer of all my books?

The last time this blog commented on "Cavemen," the Tuesday night comedy on ABC that was inspired by Geico commercials, more than 100 readers responded. Half of the comments called the show a brilliant look at race relations, and the other half deemed it an utter waste of half an hour.

Robert Toll, the chief executive of Toll Brothers, longs for a day when the newspapers will stop saying such nasty things about housing. That day will not come as long as he keeps talking the way he is.
One day, three countries rippling with political instability, three leaders promising substantial changes. The Lede will follow whether they keep them in the coming days, weeks and months.

"NBC ran a rerun of "Late Night with Conan O'Brien" on Wednesday night during the ongoing writers' strike, but it was still possible for a select few to see the host do an original monologue," Jacques Steinberg reports.

Erick Erickson at RedState had few words to say about evangelical broadcaster Pat Robertson's support for Rudolph W. Giuliani's presidential bid, but his short sentiment echoed the bewilderment of most of the bloggerati.

ALBIA, Iowa - Campaigning in western Iowa, former President Bill Clinton said he should receive more blame than his wife for the failed attempt to reform the health care system more than a decade ago.

It's all about Ohio State this week for our road-tripping friends Matt Meyers and Mike Ogle of CSTV.com. In their eighth installment from the road, this crazy duo tells us why the Buckeyes are able to field such a powerful team year in and year out. In a word: facilities. The Ohio State facilities certainly impressed Mr. Meyers and Mr. Ogle. And we're sure Mr. Meyers's Elvis costume impressed everyone in Columbus. So settle into the passenger seat. It's time to hit the road.
The gang at Pollster.com has crunched the numbers from the major opinion polls ove the last 10 months, and one big change seems to be in the air.
Left: Ray Romano, the star of "Everybody Loves Raymond," joins striking writers on the picket lines outside Paramount Studios.

President Bush likes to sell his tax cuts for the rich by citing the standard Republican economic delusion that cutting tax rates leads to higher tax revenues. His aims, however, have always been darker: to bring the government to its knees by starving it of revenue.

Yesterday's article about servers' strange locutions elicited an unusually large number of e-mails apart from the many comments in response to a coordinated blog post yesterday that invited readers to weigh in.
I thought tomorrow's column should be about the market turmoil -- but I kept coming up blank on what to say, except "Eeeeekkkk!" So the column is about something else.
Updated
Anybody near a computer today has seen or read about the N.P.R. story about how Senator Hillary Clinton of New York stiffed an Iowa waitress and her co-workers on a $157 bill.
