From DealBook colleague Jenny Anderson:
By Matthew Driskill

The 41st Annual Country Music Association Awards show attracted 16 million viewers on Wednesday, matching its performance a year ago, according to Nieslen's estimates. The large audience put ABC on top of the ratings during every hour of prime time.
Fox said yesterday that under its revised schedule, the Sunday night animated comedies "all will continue with original episodes" in the spring.
Most locals think of P. T. Barnum only when the circus comes to town. But for almost 60 years, he was one of the most celebrated figures in the city.

Rumors of a BHP Billiton-Rio Tinto mining megamerger were percolating for months before BHP said Thursday it had made a formal approach. But after looking at the recent trading in Rio Tinto's stock options, one analyst speculated that someone may have had advance notice that an offer was coming.
The Times's political reporters and editors answered reader questions this week on the 2008 election.
Seagull catching makes lying on the beach a test of reflexes:

Out of all the news about pirates last week, the most intriguing tidbit featured an unlikely combination of nations: In Somali waters, the United States Navy came to the aid of a North Korean vessel (and then airlifted the wounded to Yemen, the site of the 2000 terror attack on the destroyer U.S.S. Cole.)
From DealBook colleague Jenny Anderson:

I got an e-mail yesterday that alerted me to a hugely interesting column in the Detroit Free Press, where I once worked for five years. I think the column is worth looking at, and talking about, because it touches on an issue that no doubt affects most restaurants in this city (and country) and that inspires disagreement among diners.
Welcome to the upside-down world of Morgan Stanley.
My husband and I will be spending time in Paris, and we'd like to take a day trip to Luxembourg. Can this be done, and if so, can you recommend an itinerary?
I'm speaking on a Geek Cruise to the Panama Canal-tough job, but somebody's got to do it-so I'll be taking two weeks off from my column, blog and videos.

The most exciting thing that happened on vacation was the mouse that came back to life. This happens to a lot of designers we know. A bad season, and then, presto, born again. I tried to do as little as possible during my holiday, which essentially entailed the odd flirtatious dance with the vacuum cleaner. Everything was too much and nothing was too little, if you know what I mean. My son brought home Terry Richardson's book of his father Bob Richardson's photographs and we especially liked Bob's stories and his straight-forward opinions about other photographers, mainly Avedon and Meisel. I think Terry did a great job with the book; it's a valuable resource for young photographers, and a week or so later, when I saw Terry's recent pictures in Vogue Hommes International, particularly of James Franco, I sensed again the son's desire to be contemporary. Like his dad. (Vogue Hommes also has a pretty good interview with Calvin Klein; especially interesting was what he had to say about Mark Wahlberg, then and now.)
Readers respond to some of life’s little questions that don’t seem to have good answers.

In the orderly manifesto of Pekka-Eric Auvinen, the Finnish teenager who killed seven people yesterday before killing himself, there's a section called Collective Deindividualization: Totalitarianism & Delusions Of Democracy.
Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

From today's press briefing by White House press secretary Dana Perino, after the Pakistani military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, announced that elections scheduled for Jan. 15 will be delayed for no more than a month, which means they might now be held by Feb. 15:

"Kobe Bryant might be traded, and he might not," writes Will Leitch in this week's Play newsletter. "He'll tell reporters he wants to be traded, then he'll back off, then he'll post a message to his Web site, then he'll recant it hours later. None of it means anything. Currently in Google, 'Kobe Bryant Championship' brings up 702,000 hits; 'Kobe Bryant trade' brings up 926,000. This will be his legacy, and ours."
There were many glorious highlights at the Orange Bowl, but these made our short list:

Earlier this week, baseball's general managers recommended for the first time that the league allow instant replay. The proposal is limited to instant replay on possible home run balls -- whether they are fair or foul, for instance -- and faces several more layers of approval. Is this a move in the right direction for baseball, or a bad precedent?

When Miami plays hosts to Virginia on Saturday it will be the Hurricanes' last game in the Orange Bowl before moving to Dolphin Stadium next season. The cost to renovate the stadium was too high and the appeal of more modern facilities was too great. As a result, the Hurricanes' 70th season in the Orange Bowl will be their last.

Bill Beeny, who has run the Elvis Is Alive Museum in Wright City, Mo., for 17 years, is selling the museum's contents on eBay. Along with books, newspapers clippings and a Cadillac is, he says, convincing evidence that Elvis Presley did not die in 1977:
By Katrin Bennhold

The Red Sox signing Curt Schilling the other day is a signal that, for a relatively reasonable amount of money ($8 million plus incentives), the team didn't see anybody out there on the free agent market that was very attractive. Boston could have explored trades, but instead they locked up Schilling before he could get away.

Well, well, well. The same place that may have hosted the best college football game of the year also hosted the first huge college basketball upset of the season. We interrupt this football blog for a basketball shocker: The 20th-ranked Kentucky hoops team lost to Gardner-Webb last night. Andy Katz does a nice job here with the late wrap up.

Two environmental groups have put out a fresh call to the United States to strengthen the Shark Finning Prohibition Act, a 2000 law aimed at blunting the illegal trade in shark fins that biologists say has devastated shark populations worldwide in the last decade or so.

It's hardly a done deal, but if BHP Billiton succeeds in acquiring its rival mining giant Rio Tinto, it would be a tie-up for the record books. Deal price tags have not been this high since 2000, a banner year for megamergers that brought us the union of America Online and Time Warner.
From a reader comment on an article today questioning the need for regular deodorant use:
The British writers and booksellers Russell Ash and Brian Lake have compiled a small but toothsome anthology called "Bizarre Books: A Compendium of Classic Oddities."
The Museum of the Moving Image Gala Honoring Tom Cruise Melena Ryzik attends, makes a flip book.
O.K., quick quiz: Which world leader said the following?
Tommy Haas's severe case of food poisoning at the Davis Cup would be a rather tame addition to the annals of Russian poisoning accusations.

The unlikely alliance of Rudolph W. Giuliani and evangelical broadcaster Pat Robertson yesterday brought mixed reaction from Republicans. Some conservative Christians worry whether the thrice-married Giuliani shares their values, and other G.O.P. members wonder if Mr. Giuliani's alliance with a controversial televangelist will turn off moderate voters.

BHP Billiton said Thursday that it had approached Rio Tinto about a potential takeover that would create a global mining giant worth about $360 billion. Rio rejected its offer, but BHP added that it would continue to press for a deal, which would rank among the largest mergers in history.

Merrill Lynch disclosed on Wednesday that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an inquiry into its mortgage-related holdings. It also said that its total exposure to mortgage-related securities is $27.2 billion, or $6.3 billion more than what it said last month.
From The Onion:
[UPDATE 11/11: See below for Republican lawmakers' point of view on this fight.]

AQR Capital Management, the hedge-fund firm run by a former trader at Goldman Sachs, Cliff Asness, has been forced to shelve plans for an initial public offering after poor performance caused several large investors to pull their cash from the firm's $38 billion fund, The New York Post reported.
With all the misery surrounding investment banks of late, is a spate of industry mergers on the horizon? The answer, one analyst told Reuters, is a resounding yes.
The Financial Times' John Gapper has a bone to pick with Merrill Lynch and Citigroup over the semantics used to describe the departures of the banks' chief executives.
AOL said it would buy Quigo, a seller of small, sponsored links that run next to articles, marking its fourth advertising acquisition this year. The price was reported to be about $340 million.

Shares of the Lenovo Group, the computer maker, fell 6.4 percent Wednesday in Hong Kong as three private equity firms sold part of their holdings to cash in 2.9 billion Hong Kong dollars ($372 million) after the stock hit a seven-year high.
A few hitherto unknown analysts have made names for themselves recently with their headline-grabbing calls on investment banking writedowns, Breakingviews says.

The Chinese Internet search firm Baidu.com is pondering acquisitions and possibly a Hong Kong share listing to fuel an expansion into the country's consumer Internet market, taking on Alibaba.com in the world's second-largest Web market.

Digg, a popular news site where readers rank stories, was the subject of renewed takeover rumors on Wednesday, as the Valleywag blog, citing anonymous sources, said a "major media player" was close to acquiring it for $300 million to $400 million. Digg's chief executive declined to comment to CNET News.com on the rumor.

Morgan Stanley said it would take a $3.7 billion charge for nonperforming assets tied to subprime mortgages, underscoring how much the tight credit market was affecting even peripheral players in the mortgage market.
The Close Brothers Group, a 129-year-old British investment bank, rejected a 1.4 billion pound ($2.9 billion) cash offer from Cenkos Securities and a partner, Landsbanki Islands.
MerchantCircle, a pioneer in online local advertising, raised $10 million in a Series B financing round, sticking with its faithful early-stage investors and adding a pair of key strategic partners.

American Public Education increased the expected price range of its initial public offering to $18 to $19 a share, setting up the company's two venture capital owners for a richer-than-expected payday.
Bankrupt Delphi has revealed the lending group that has agreed to provide close to $7 billion to help the insolvent auto parts maker emerge from court protection.

Cheyne Capital, the British hedge fund manager whose $6.7 billion structured investment vehicle Cheyne Finance went into bankruptcy last month, has paid a 3.2 million pound ($6.7 million) tax settlement to British authorities.
Kraft Foods on Wednesday struck a deal with the activist investor Nelson Peltz, adding two board members nominated by his Trian Partners and avoiding a potential proxy battle.

KKR Financial Holdings, a specialty finance unit of the buyout shop Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, shed its mortgage business and closed a series of collateralized loan obligations as the firm swung to a third-quarter loss after taking an expected hit from the credit crunch.
Midmarket buyout firm KRG Capital Partners said it closed its fourth private equity fund at $1.96 billion, beating its $1.25 billion target by 57 percent.

The Japanese brewer Kirin Holdings will buy an Australian dairy and juice producer, National Foods for $1 billion from a Philippine partner San Miguel as it seeks growth away from stagnating beer sales.
The Nasdaq Stock Market confirmed Wednesday that it would acquire the Philadelphia Stock Exchange for $652 million to expand its presence in the fast-growing equity options business.
Hallie Stephens and Holly Pakfar made a one-bedroom apartment in Stuyvesant Town more livable by dividing the living room.
Brian Regan of Comedy Central on greeting cards:
We're far from reader averse, so here's some reader verse. "Eat, Drink & Make Crazy," sent in by Leon Freilich of Park Slope, Brooklyn:

Looking beyond the glittery towers, Barclays Buying Abroad has launched a new service program for Dubai, targeting buyers looking to live and work in the Emirates. With workers flooding into the country and an estimated 300,000 apartments set to come onto the market in the next four years, Barclays believes the market is shifting away from people looking for luxury holiday or retirement homes.
The 41st annual Country Music Awards took place in Nashville.
The Ohio-born tenor saxophonist Albert Ayler probably would have gotten a kick out of Kasper Collin’s documentary about his life.
The 53 to 40 vote came despite Democratic criticism that he failed to take an unequivocal stance against torture.
At least two major television studios, 20th Century Fox and CBS Paramount, have sent breach-of-contract letters to show runners who have joined the strike.
The man who says O. J. Simpson stole $100,000 in sports memorabilia from him described a six-minute “military-invasion-fashion” raid in a Las Vegas hotel room.
NBC ran a rerun of “Late Night with Conan O’Brien” on Wednesday night, but it was still possible for a select few to see the host do an original monologue.
A man who was convicted of fatally shooting a police officer in Flatbush two years ago was sentenced today to life in prison without the chance of parole.
Hopes for a market rebound dimmed today as shares stayed in the red, extending yesterday’s 360-point swoon, with technology shares falling hardest of all.
The Senate voted today for a popular $23 billion water projects measure,  handing President Bush his first defeat in a veto showdown.
The European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 4 percent today but also signaled its displeasure with the euro’s rushed rise against the dollar.
Defying appeals from foes of free-trade, nearly half the Democrats in the House voted today to approve the deal.
Ben S. Bernanke cited the housing meltdown, tighter credit and rising oil prices, but he gave no signal that the central bank would cut rates again.
The nation’s big retail chains reported a second month of weak sales growth this morning, blaming economic clouds that show no signs of lifting before the end of the year.
The automaker said that it lost $380 million in the quarter, a better-than-expected result, but it lost $1 billion in North America as it carries out a restructuring plan.
Stocks in Europe and Asia declined today on worries about an economic slowdown in the U.S., but American shares were poised to rise.
Two days after NBC acknowledged that it was talking to Rosie O’Donnell about a possible show on MSNBC, the conversations have stalled.

The 19-year-old son of Mayor Dannel P. Malloy was arrested yesterday on drug charges by the Greenwich police. Ben Malloy was released on a $2,500 bond after his arrest, his lawyer, Robert Bello, said. The nature of the charges and details of the arrest were not immediately known. The mayor and his wife released a statement calling it a matter of immense concern and asking the community to keep them in their thoughts as they work through it as a family.
A priest from Boston has been charged with stalking and harassing the talk show host Conan O’Brien.

Gardner-Webb limited Kentucky to 35.5 percent field-goal shooting last night and built a 38-27 halftime lead in trouncing the Wildcats on their home court, 84-68, in a Coaches vs. Cancer game. Gardner-Webb advanced to the semifinals Nov. 15 at Madison Square Garden Garden. Grayson Flittner led Gardner-Webb with 22 points and Thomas Sanders had 21. Ramel Bradley led Kentucky with 24.
Rosie O’Donnell announced on her blog Wednesday that talks to give her a prime-time show on MSNBC had fallen apart.
Birth control pills taken by about 100 million women worldwide may clog arteries when taken more than 10 years, according to a study.

Prosecutors have appealed a judge’s decision to dismiss an immigration fraud case against Luis Posada Carriles, an anti-Castro militant and former C.I.A. operative. Mr. Posada, 79, is wanted in Venezuela on charges that he plotted the deadly 1976 bombing of a Cuban jetliner from Caracas. Prosecutors filed the appeal Monday with the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, in New Orleans. The case against Mr. Posada was dismissed in May after the judge, Kathleen Cardone of Federal District Court in El Paso, concluded that federal authorities used trickery, fraud and deceit in trying to pursue a case against Mr. Posada, who was accused of lying on an application and during an interview to become a naturalized citizen.

A boiler’s water tube exploded at a power station in Salem, fatally burning three workers with high-pressure steam, the authorities said. The men were repairing a fan Tuesday when a tube ruptured about 20 feet above and blew steam on them, said Dominion Virginia Power, based in Richmond, Va., which owns the plant, Salem Harbor Power Station. The boiler tubes contain high-pressure hot water and steam that turn the turbine-generator, which spins to produce electricity. There were no indications of problems before the rupture, the company said, and the 35-foot tall boiler passed its annual inspection in April.

Several District of Columbia tax office employees are accused by federal authorities of taking part in an embezzlement scheme involving phony property tax refunds, an alleged plot that may have netted them more than $16 million. Two employees of the tax office, along with other city workers, are charged with offenses including mail fraud and money laundering. An F.B.I. search warrant affidavit filed in Federal District Court states that the workers generated more than 40 fraudulent refund checks averaging $388,000.

Nearly two dozen illegal immigrants were arrested, accused of using fake security badges to work in critical areas of O’Hare International Airport in Chicago, the authorities said. The 23 workers were employed by Ideal Staffing Solutions Inc., whose corporate secretary and office manager were also arrested after an eight-month investigation that involved federal, state and Chicago authorities. The company contracted work for carriers including United Airlines, KLM and Qantas, said Elissa A. Brown, an Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent. The workers are from Mexico and Guatemala.
At the Country Music Awards, the awards presentations are minimized, to make room for performances by old favorites and new ones.
The Louisiana attorney general is accusing the state’s largest property insurance companies of conspiring to limit payments to policyholders after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita.
For Brian Leetch, being honored Wednesday with the Lester Patrick Award for contributions to American hockey was one of a series of events that followed his retirement this year.
Nigeria sued three tobacco companies seeking 5.3 trillion naira ($44 billion) in damages for public health costs for treating smoking-related diseases.
German industrial output unexpectedly increased in September, led by the construction and energy sectors.
The Danish brewer Carlsberg posted a 29 percent increase in third-quarter earnings on strong sales.

The Kushiro Journal article yesterday, about efforts in Japan to restore the original curves to rivers that had been straightened in the course of economic development projects misspelled, in some editions, the given name of a farmer who criticized the plan to restore the curves. He is Kazuaki Saito, not Kazukaki.

Josh Smith scored 22 points last night, the rookie Al Horford led a dominant performance on the boards and the Atlanta Hawks beat another 60-victory team from last season, holding off Steve Nash and the visiting Phoenix Suns, 105-96.

Atilla Selek, a 22-year-old German with Turkish parents sought in connection with a reported plot to bomb German and American facilities in Germany, has been arrested in Turkey. Turkish officials said he was detained Tuesday in Konya, his family’s hometown. Three other men, two Germans and a Turkish resident of Germany, are already in custody. German authorities said the plot was in an advanced stage when they uncovered it in September and seized large quantities of potentially explosive chemicals. German officials said Mr. Selek may have helped obtain detonators. In an interview in September, he denied having any links to the plot or to terrorism.
A 15-year-old French boy testified for two and a half hours in the trial of two Emirati men accused of raping him at knife point in July.
Parliament’s lower house to suspend participation in a treaty limiting conventional forces in Europe.
Lech Walesa, Poland’s first president after Communism, said he would have a heart transplant in Houston.
Prosecutors dropped charges against an American activist arrested in September while doing research for a documentary film about the troubled, oil-rich Niger Delta.
Fighting intensified in the war-wracked north as the government asked Parliament for a 20 percent increase in military spending.

New York City Transit will expand the express service on the Staten Island Railway next week. On Wednesday, the railway will add five express trains for the evening rush, for a total of 13. The expanded service will be timed to serve passengers on the Staten Island Ferry leaving Manhattan between 4 p.m. and 7:20 p.m. Morning service will expand on Dec. 5 with the addition of three express trains, for a total of nine. The trains will arrive at the Staten Island terminal in time for riders to board ferries from 7 a.m. to 9 a.m. The evening express trains run nonstop from St. George to Great Kills and then make local stops to Tottenville. The morning express trains make all stops between Tottenville and New Dorp and then run nonstop to St. George.

A state appellate panel yesterday unanimously upheld traffic convictions against Garry F. McCarthy, the Newark police director, and his wife, Regina, finding substantial evidence of misconduct. The convictions stemmed from an altercation between the McCarthys and police officers on the Palisades Interstate Parkway in February 2005 after one of the couple’s daughters received a ticket at a highway rest stop for parking in a spot for the handicapped. Mr. McCarthy was convicted of obstructing traffic and his wife for making unreasonable noise. The Appellate Division of State Superior Court, in a 3-to-0 decision, upheld that ruling.

A jazz bassist and martial arts expert from the Bronx who pleaded guilty this year to terrorism charges was sentenced yesterday in Federal District Court to 15 years in prison. In April, the defendant, Tarik Shah, 44, admitted taking part in a plot to teach would-be Qaeda operatives to wage jihad with hand-to-hand combat. An undercover F.B.I. informant recorded Mr. Shah making incriminating statements.

A computer software glitch caused election returns in Atlantic County to be delayed until early morning yesterday, election officials said. John Mooney, the Atlantic County elections superintendent, said his office was working with the manufacturer of the voting machines, Sequoia Voting Systems, to determine what caused the problem. The number of votes on each of the machines was properly recorded and tallied. But there was a problem in transferring that data from individual machines to a central database that tallied all the votes, he said.

Lawyers for Michael C. Skakel, convicted of murder for killing a teenage neighbor in 1975, have filed a petition in federal court seeking a new trial. The petition comes less than two weeks after Mr. Skakel, 47, was denied a new trial in state court on his claim that new evidence had been discovered. The petition, known as a writ of habeas corpus, claims that Mr. Skakel is being held unlawfully. Mr. Skakel, a cousin of the Kennedys by marriage, was convicted in June 2002 of killing his neighbor, Martha Moxley, when they were 15 and living in Greenwich. He was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison.

The Brooklyn Navy Yard will become home to a historic center as part of its expansion and redevelopment, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn said yesterday. The center, scheduled to open in early 2010 in the Marine Corps commandant’s residence, is to use multimedia exhibits, including oral history projects, to tell the story of the Navy Yard and provide meeting space and offices for the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. The City Council has promised $10 million of the $15 million needed to renovate and expand the building, which was erected in 1857.

Any Given Saturday, winner of the Grade I Haskell Invitational over Hard Spun and Curlin, will stand at stud at Darley at Jonabell in Lexington, Ky. The stud fee will be $40,000, the stable announced.

The ownership of the Breeders’ Cup Classic winner Curlin had another shakeup. Jess Jackson’s Stonestreet Stables and the investment banker George Bolton bought out the interest held by Satish Sanan’s Padua Stables in a private sale, according a Stonestreet lawyer. Earlier this year, the three owners purchased an 80 percent interest in Curlin for a reported $3.5 million from the original owner, Midnight Cry Stables, which bought the colt for $57,000 in 2005. Two of Midnight Cry’s owners, Shirley Cunningham Jr. and William Gallion, are in jail awaiting trial on federal wire-fraud charges related to a $200 million legal settlement over the diet drug fen-phen. Last week, a state judge ordered Cunningham’s and Gallion’s assets, including Midnight Cry Stables, turned over to the 418 plaintiffs to satisfy a $42 million judgment stemming from a lawsuit against Gallion and Cunningham over their handling of the settlement.

A senior executive with the National Basketball Association has been selected to return to his former job as chief executive of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority. The naming of the executive, Dennis R. Robinson, above, was approved yesterday by the authority’s board. Mr. Robinson, who is to succeed George R. Zoffinger on Nov. 30, has been serving as senior vice president for business and league operations with the N.B.A. since 1999. Before that, Mr. Robinson, 50, worked at the sports authority for nine years, becoming chief executive in 1998. He will be paid $250,000 a year by the authority, which operates the Meadowlands Sports Complex.

The International Tennis Federation is investigating allegations that Tommy Haas was poisoned before Germany’s Davis Cup match against Russia. Haas was forced out of his match against Mikhail Youzhny with a suspected stomach virus. Alexander Waske, Haas’s teammate, said he was told by a Russian who managed athletes that it was poisoning, although Waske did not identify the manager. Russia won both reverse singles matches Sept. 23 to win the semifinal series, 3-2, and reach the Davis Cup final.

Serena Williams retired with a left knee injury after one set and Justine Henin advanced to the semifinals at the Sony Ericsson Championships in Madrid. Henin beat Jelena Jankovic, 6-2, 6-2, at the season-ending tournament. Williams retired after losing the first set by 6-4 to the seventh-ranked Anna Chakvetadze.

All 16 Big East Conference members will play in its postseason men’s and women’s tournaments beginning in 2009. Four members have been left out since the league expanded in 2005-6. A day will be added to the tournaments. Teams seeded 9 through 16 will meet on the first day. The winners will advance to play seeds 5 through 8. The four highest-seeded teams will still receive a bye to the quarterfinals, where they will meet the winners of the second day’s games.

At least 14 towns in Connecticut will conduct recounts of Tuesday’s election results in the coming days, the office of the secretary of the state office said yesterday. In the town of Bethlehem, for example, only four votes separate the two candidates for first selectman. State law requires recounts when the margin of victory is one-half of 1 percent, or 20 votes or fewer. Hand recounts must be finished within five business days after the election, and a representative of each political party must be present.
Stock markets plummeted and the dollar fell as investors grew skittish over oil prices and the prospect of an economic slowdown.

The Fire Department announced yesterday that it was changing the way it inspects buildings under construction or being torn down, to avoid the confusion that contributed to the deaths of two firefighters in a blaze at the former Deutsche Bank building at ground zero last summer.
Morgan Stanley said Wednesday that it would take a $3.7 billion charge for nonperforming assets tied to subprime mortgages.
The House and Senate are poised to vote on a vitally important tax bill that will test whether Democrats have courage and convictions.
Iraq’s interior minister said he would authorize raids on Western security firms to ensure they were complying with stricter licensing requirements on guns and other weaponry.
The automaker reported a $39-billion loss after it took a huge noncash charge to write down deferred tax credits.
Masked gunmen shot into a group of students returning from a march protesting changes to the Constitution on Wednesday at Venezuela’s most prestigious university.
The defeat of an Oregon referendum in Tuesday’s election is a testament to the shamelessness of the nation’s big tobacco companies.
Under difficult conditions on an unusually busy and lengthy mission, NASA’s astronauts accomplished their tasks impressively.
Washington must make it clear to Pakistan’s dictator, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, that a blood bath against protesters would be intolerable.
The settlement comes nearly three years after the Supreme Court ruled that Visa and MasterCard had violated antitrust rules.
Charter school advocates across the country are watching the crackdown, fearful that the backlash could spread.
A biochemical geneticist’s story demonstrates how recalls come about, in a time when they are becoming routine.
The Mets had a meeting Wednesday with Scott Boras, the agent for third baseman Alex Rodriguez, staying on the fringes of negotiations for the marquee free agent of the off-season.
The 2,300 runners who were affected by a technical problem with the timing system at the New York City Marathon were asked by race organizers to submit their time according to their own measurement.
Farron Barksdale died in a hospital in Montgomery, Ala., on Aug. 20, shortly after being imprisoned for killing two police officers.

State utilities regulators hit Con Edison with an $18 million penalty yesterday for its service disruptions last year, which included a nine-day blackout in western Queens and other power failures in Westchester County.

The world’s largest insurance company said that it wrote down nearly $2 billion due to mortgage investments in the third quarter and expected to write down an additional $550 million in the next quarter.

Standard 41, a new furniture showroom in Red Hook, Brooklyn, is run by Andrew Raible, a designer and woodworker, above left, and his father, John, an architect. The pair work out of a loft at the 1860s Red Hook Stores warehouse overlooking Pier 41 (the origin of the showroom's name), where they sell chairs, tables, desks and other furniture made to order in materials like walnut, maple and cherry. The younger Raible, who was a partner in 3 Square Design, a furniture manufacturing company, and the Brooklyn shop Refinery, said that his work, like the Lounge Chair ($3,000), top right, is ''more square'' than his father's but that it has subtle details like beveled armrests that reveal the end grain. Since they started working together, he said, his father's furniture is ''getting cleaner'' and his is ''getting funkier.'' John Raible's pieces include, from left, Stork Table 1 ($3,400), Slap Happy ($3,400) and Walking Small ($1,600). For information or an appointment: (917) 805-0835 or standard41.com. LIZ ARNOLD

HERSKOWITZ--Jamie. We mourn the loss of our colleague, mentor and friend, Jamie Herskowitz. Jamie began working for Centerplate at Yankee Stadium at the age of 15, becoming General Manager in 1986, Vice President of Operations in 1988, Regional Vice President in 2002 and Senior Vice President in 2006. He was a true master of our business and held two Yankees World Series rings, a testament to his contributions to the Yankee organization. He won Centerplate's GM of the Year Award in 1996 and the John Dee Award in 2004. All of us who were present in 2004 cheered mightily when his name was announced, for Jamie truly deserved to be the first recipient of this prestigious award. We will surely miss his deep understanding of his job, the tremendous mentoring he provided to so many of us on a daily basis and his ability to anticipate exactly what would make a difference in our lives. To his wife Debra, his mother Jean, his sister Nanci, his niece Lauren, and the rest of their family, our whole company shares in your loss. We will always miss his tremendous generosity and spirit but we will definitely carry it forward, inspired by who he was and what he achieved. With fondness from all of us at Centerplate. HERSKOWITZ--Jamie Mark, beloved husband, son, brother, uncle, friend and mentor to so many people, passed away on Tuesday, November 6 at the New York Presbyterian Columbia University Medical Center. Jamie is survived by his wife Debra, his mother Jean, his sister Nanci and his niece Lauren, whom he doted on and adored. Jamie leaves all of us with wonderful memories of joy and laughter and extraordinary generosity. Jamie spent his entire 41-year career with Centerplate, the food and merchandise provider at Yankee Stadium. He was born in Brooklyn, New York in 1951 and grew up in Queens as a Yankee fan. At 15, he obtained a job at Yankee Stadium which was a dream come true. He continued to work at the Stadium as he earned an Associates Degree in Hotel and Restaurant Management at New York Community College in 1973 and a B.S. in Food Service and Management from the Pratt Institute in 1977. Over the years Jamie worked for Centerplate as General Manager, Vice President of Operations, Regional Vice President and Senior Vice President, all at Yankee Stadium. He liked to tell people that at one time or another he had held every job that Centerplate offered at the Stadium. Jamie truly understood the hospitality business. One of his proudest moments was receiving a 1996 World Series ring from George Steinbrenner. This was a testament not only to his contributions to Centerplate and New York Yankees fans but also to the entire Yankee organization. Jamie was a generous mentor and longtime friend to many people. His pride in what he did, good heart and straightforward approach inspired all of those who knew him. He touched and changed so many lives for the better. Jamie left a distinct impression on everyone he met. Until his last day Jamie maintained the love and loyalty he felt for his family, his co-workers and his friends. We will all cherish and miss him. Funeral services will be at 1:00pm on Thursday, November 8, 2007 at Schwartz Brothers, Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 11403 Queens Boulevard, Flushing, NY 11375, 718 263-7600.

Timorous Beasties, a Scottish company known for its quietly subversive take on textiles, has arrived stateside, with its first product designed for an American company. Liquid Floral, above, a wallpaper produced for Anthropologie, comes in two neo-Victorian motifs with black flocking on a gray background. The central elements of the two patterns line up, so they can be mixed and matched. ''We have long wanted to experiment with flocking,'' said Alistair McAuley, a cofounder of Timorous Beasties, adding that the company also wanted to make an affordable wallcovering (its papers often sell for more than $1,000 a roll). Available for $168 a roll at anthropologie.com; information: (800) 309-2500. JULIE TARASKA

A brief art review in Weekend on Friday about an exhibition focusing on masquerades in Mozambique, at the Wallach Art Gallery at Columbia University, misidentified the event that took place in the country in 1964 that prompted a change in the social themes of masquerade performances. It was the beginning of the armed struggle for independence, not a socialist government's coming to power after independence. (Mozambique did not become independent until 1975.)

An obituary yesterday about F. Maynard Sundman, an innovative stamp and coin dealer, misstated his place of death, which is also the location of one of his companies, the Littleton Coin Company, and the hometown of several relatives. It is Littleton, N.H.; there is no Littleton in Connecticut.

On Aug. 7, we published a letter from Zachary Townsend, a student at Brown University and a columnist for the student newspaper, about Japan's role in sex slavery in World War II, and slavery in the world today. We have now learned that the letter included material taken without attribution from an article in the November/December 2006 issue of Foreign Affairs, ''The New Global Slave Trade,'' by Ethan B. Kapstein. The student newspaper, The Brown Daily Herald, said in an editors' note on Monday that it had discovered after a review that several of Mr. Townsend's columns had included material taken from other sources without attribution and that he had been dismissed as a columnist.

BROWN--Sophie Feuermann, died at the age of 99 in New York City. An accomplished Pianist, she was born in Kolomea, Poland and grew up in Vienna, Austria. She often concertized with her brother, the world famous cellist Emanuel Feuermann. In 1938 she and her husband Harry Brown fled to America to escape the Holocaust. Here she performed, gave piano lessons and coached musicians. She is survived by two daughters, four grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

A Spare Times listing in Weekend on Friday for the New York Botanical Garden, which has been designated the cultural organization of November by NYC & Company, misstated the days a discount on admission fees is available. Visitors can receive either $4 off an adult ticket or a free children's ticket with a full-priced adult one when they mention ''cultural organization of the month'' Tuesdays through Fridays, except Nov. 23; the discount is not offered every day.

One of the latest ideas on the design front is ''upcycling,'' taking something unwanted and turning it into something desirable. In one example, Christine Misiak, a British designer, is coating secondhand tea services with enamels in startling shades like kelly green and black. The Tea Set Noir, above, is about $230; other colors are available. Ms. Misiak, a recent graduate of Northumbria University in England, where she is now a designer in residence, also applies antique handles and spouts to new metal vessels to create her Old/New and New/Old tea services. Information: 011-44-7878-911-930 or www.christinemisiak.co.uk. MITCHELL OWENS

GORDON--Herman. Temple Beth Sholom, Roslyn Heights, NY, mourns the passing of our beloved member, Herman Gordon. Our heartfelt condolences to his family. Rabbi Alan B. Lucas President Susan Zelman GORDON--Herman of Albertson, NY on November 7, 2007. Loving father of Bruce and Mark. Cherished grandfather of David, Benjamin, Daniel, and Caroline. Father-in-law of Beth, and Lori. Proud veteran of WWII. Funeral services Thursday 1:30pm at Temple Beth Sholom of Roslyn.

An article in the Dining section yesterday about Michael Hebberoy, who runs public dinners in clandestine locations around Seattle and was a popular restaurateur in Portland, Ore., before his businesses went bankrupt last year, referred incorrectly to the decision by The Oregonian to name Mr. Hebberoy's restaurant Clarklewis the city's restaurant of the year in 2004. The Oregonian gave the restaurant top honors three months after it opened; the newspaper did not do so ''before it even opened.''

LEONARD--Dr. Harold A. Born March 4, 1924, Bronx, New York, son of Sol Abramson (Abramajtis) and Anna Cohen (Powiatowski) of Suwalki, Poland. World War II Army veteran of the ChinaBurma-India Theater. Graduate of City College of New York (BA), New York University (MA), and Ohio State (Ph.D). Gifted math teacher and mentor to thousands of students in the public high schools of New York City and Smithtown, New York, and the New York State University College at Oneonta over a teaching career spanning three decades. Cherished and beloved husband of Jean Moverman Leonard, his wife of almost sixty years, loving father of Arthur, Raymond and David, grandfather of Benjamin, Daniel, Anya, Denver, Austin, Caroline and Dusty, and brother of Joan, who all survive him. Pioneer of modern mathematics education as a member of the School Mathematics Study Group. Enthusiast for baseball, classical music, astronomy, chess, contract bridge, reading, the stock markets, and most of all his family.

A chart in some editions on Tuesday with an article about a new system of giving New York City schools grades of A through F misstated the name of a school that received an A. It is P.S. 40 Augustus Saint-Gaudens, not Augustus Street Gardens.

HIKERS going off-trail can thank technology and market forces for keeping them on track. In the last 18 months, hand-held global positioning systems have become half as expensive while offering better functionality and more features. Besides basic navigational tools -- like satellite coverage, directional readings, topography maps and altimeters -- they come with extras like aerial photography, MP3 players, walkie-talkies and even satellite radios. These rugged and waterproof devices, with improved battery life and software, go easily from trail to boat or kayak.

JACOB--Albert. The Yeshiva University Family is saddened by the passing of a long-time supporter of our institution who, with his wife, Doreen, was a YU Guardian and provided scholarships for undergraduate and graduate students at the Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies (BRGS). Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Doreen, to his children: Simon (and Barrie) Jacob, Michael (and Batya) Jacob, Philip (and Lynn) Jacob, and Sally (and Steven) Malech; to his brother Abraham (and Trixie) Jacob, and to his many grandchildren and great - grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Min Hashamayim Tenuhamu. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry Weiss, Chairman, YU Board of Trustees Mordecai D. Katz, Chairman, BRGS Board of Directors David Eshaghian, Chairman, Sephardic Council of Overseers

A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about a Web site that used Guy Fawkes Day as a vehicle to raise money for Ron Paul, a Republican presidential candidate, referred imprecisely to the organizers of the effort. They were supporters of Mr. Paul, who has mentioned the British rebel Guy Fawkes in speeches; Mr. Paul's campaign was not involved.

SACKSTEDER--Richard Carl, November 4, 2007. Distinguished mathematician and beloved husband of Martha, father of Liz and Katie, brother of Nancy, and grandfather of Annie, Johnny, Rivkah, and Ephraim. His family mourns the loss of his keen mind, quick wit, and loving heart.

JIMENEZ--Jason, on November 6, 2007 of East Meadow, NY. Beloved son of Elizabeth (Liz) Barbera and Robert Jimenez. Beloved Stepson of Aldo Scivoli. Dear brother of Eric Jimenez and his wife Vanessa. Also survived by many loving aunts, uncles and cousins. A Marine Corps Sgt. Honorably discharged in 2003 and then serving in the reserves until 2007. Graduated Suma Cum Laudi from Nassau County Community College (4.0 GPA), Received the Chancellor's Award for Academic Excellence. Recently worked as a Physics Tutor for N.C.C.C. Participated in Columbia University's program at Adelphi University. Visiting N.F. Walker, Inc. 2039 Merrick Ave. Merrick, NY, Thursday 7-9pm and Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at Cure of Ars R.C. Church 2323 Merrick Ave. in Merrick Saturday November 10, 2007 at 11am. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury, NY. In lieu of flowers donations to: National Multiple Sclerosis Society, New York City Chapter for Primary Progressive Research, 733 Third Avenue, Third Floor, New York, NY 10017 or to St. Jude's Children's Research Hospital, Memorial and Honor Program, St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 501 St. Jude Place, Memphis, TN 38105 Appreciated.
An obituary on Oct. 30 about the country singer Porter Wagoner misstated the year he was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame. It was 2002, not 1992.

8 P.M. (ABC) UGLY BETTY Wilhelmina (Vanessa Williams) finds her blood boiling when she realizes that her maid of honor, Victoria Beckham (guest starring as herself, above left with Ms. Williams, center), is getting all the attention. And Betty (America Ferrera) is consumed with guilt about her pact with Wilhelmina not to tell Daniel (Eric Mabius) that his soon-to-be-stepmother is getting physical with her bodyguard (Rick Fox). 8 P.M. (NBC) MY NAME IS EARL The warden (Craig T. Nelson) asks Earl (Jason Lee) to create a skit called ''Scared Straight'' that will frighten children enough to keep them out of jail. The warden's wife, the governor, requests that the skit also incorporate an environmentally friendly message.

KATZ--Melvin, 72, of NYC, passed away on October 29, 2007. He is survived by his wife Ann Katz and daughter Rhoda Katz Yhee and four grandchildren. He was the President and founder of Triarc International, also he was President of Triach Catalystgroup, LLC, with offices in NYC, Stamford, Connecticut, and Celebration, Florida. He was a real estate developer, specializing in hotel development and construction.

BARRETT--Herbert. The staff of Herbert Barrett Management mourns the passing of Herbert Barrett, chairman, former president and founder. He died November 5 at age 97. His love of music and the artists who performed it remains an inspiration to us all. John A. Anderson, Pres. Mary Lynn Fixler, V.P. Alexandra Bacon, Mgr. Vocalists Stuart Wolferman, Publ. Dir. Michael Cudney, Office Mgr.

Margaret Elman, the owner of Chair Couture, is going green. Like her original collection of salvaged French period furniture, all of the pieces in her new collection are vintage. But Ms. Elman has reupholstered the furniture in recycled polyester or organic cotton decorated with her own nature-inspired designs, in prints made from photographs. The chaise longue Constance, below, upholstered in a pattern that recalls water, is $15,000. A bergère called David, redone in a textile with grass imagery, is $7,000, and Marianne, a 1930s queen-size bed frame covered in a dandelion fabric, is $13,000. Information: (646) 486-0841 or chaircouture.com. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

The Bebe Incense Burner ($59), above, is part of the latest collection by DFC Casa, a Mexican company known for marrying modern design with traditional craftsmanship. The collection also includes a portable barware set called the Science Series Bullet ($455), below. The six hand-blown shot glasses, housed in an ordnance-shaped case, were inspired by the silver or copper cups that men once attached to their belts and used for drinking at parties or picnics. The set was created in collaboration with Yoko Devereaux, a Brooklyn clothing company, for its 2007-2008 fall-winter collection. Available at the Future Perfect, 115 North Sixth Street (Berry Street), Brooklyn, (718) 599-6278. STEPHEN TREFFINGER

ATKINSON--Ralph Hopkins, of Stamford, CT, died peacefully at Nathaniel Witherell Nursing Home on October 26, 2007. He was 85 years old. Ralph was born on October 4, 1922 to the late Hattie and Earl Atkinson in Bowling Green, Missouri. He was a Sergeant in the United States Army during WWII, where he fought in the Battle of the Bulge and helped liberate two concentration camps. After the war he worked at the Louis J. Solomon Furniture Importing Company in New York City where he later became part-owner. Ralph was an Elder and a Deacon in the Presbyterian Church. He was a District Deputy Grand Master of the Third Masonic District of Manhattan; a member of the SAR; The National Arts Club; and an active volunteer in many organizations as well as an avid golfer. Ralph will be remembered as a true gentleman -kind, generous and always appreciative. Ralph is survived by his sister, Iva Atkinson and many nieces and nephews. He is predeceased by his brother, Norman Atkinson; his nephew, Bruce Atkinson; and his wives, Edith Atkinson and Ruth Atkinson. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 on Saturday, November 10, at the First Presbyterian Church, 1101 Bedford Street in Stamford, CT. Interment will be at Woodlawn Cemetery in Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America, 322 Eighth Avenue, New York, NY 10001.
GUEST--Lucy Cochrane. Dear Mummy, kiss Goosie and Mickie for me, I miss you. xoxo Cornelia

LIBLIT--Jerome, 78, of New Milford, NJ passed away on November 5th. He is survived by his wife of 40 years Roberta, daughter Deborah and son Benjamin. A political scientist educated at City College and Columbia University, he served as Associate Dean of the New School for 20 years and as adjunct professor at Baruch College and Bronx Community College. Prior to his academic career he was involved in non-profit and cooperative housing development, both domestically and in Central and South America for the U.S. Agency for International Development. His lifetime of civic service included board membership with Settlement Housing Foundation, Citizens Union, Parodneck Foundation, and the 6th Avenue Credit Union. Jerry was an elected member of the New Milford Board of Education for 19 years receiving the county wide Archie Hay Award in 2001 for his dedicated service.

DOLLAR SINKS; SHARES FOLLOW Stock markets plummeted and the dollar sank to a record low against the euro as investors worldwide grew skittish over rising oil prices and the prospect of a substantial economic slowdown in the United States. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 360 points and the broader stock market dropped nearly 3 percent. HOME EQUITY ECONOMY SLOWS The American pastime of using homes as an artery of cash -- through sales, home equity loans and refinancing -- has begun to wane, deepening worries that the economy is headed for a slowdown. [A1.]

The city’s new school ranking system, which has already created an uproar among many parents and teachers, finds yet another critic in Leon Botstein, the president of Bard College. The Bard High School Early College, associated with the college, earned a tentative grade of C on a draft copy of the report card, Mr. Botstein said. Its grade and those of 22 other schools were reported as “under review” by the department. Now city officials have agreed to meet with Mr. Botstein, who wants them to reconsider.

Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who needs to shore up support among Latino lawmakers after his shift on the driver’s license issue, appeared at the Somos el Futuro conference this morning — an annual gathering of the state’s Assembly’s Puerto Rican/Hispanic Task Force in San Juan, P.R.

Updated, 3:15 p.m. | Carol A. Gotbaum, the Manhattan woman whose body was found in a police holding cell in Phoenix on Sept. 28, died accidentally of asphyxiation, but alcohol and prescription drug intoxication contributed to her death, according to an autopsy released today.

Updated, 4:10 p.m. | The relationships between bosses and their personal assistants can be emotionally intense, to say the least. So we’re sure a hot topic in many an office today is the arrest of the 26-year-old personal assistant to Linda Stein, the well-connected real estate agent who was bludgeoned to death on Oct. 30 in her Fifth Avenue apartment. According to the police, the assistant, Natavia Lowery, said Ms. Stein had yelled at her, waved an exercise stick at her and blown marijuana smoke into her face.

If you’re a taxi, livery cab or commuter van driver licensed by the city’s Taxi and Limousine Commission and you’re charged with breaking the rules, and if you want to contest that charge, you have to go to a hearing in a place like 32-02 Queens Boulevard. One of the first things you notice –- one of the first things I noticed, anyway –- is that the building, a big former factory, is pink.It’s an odd touch next to the elevated No. 7 train, and felt incongruously festive considering the nonsmiles on the faces of the security guards working the metal detectors. Inside, the hearing rooms are on the third floor, past signs warning that bribery is illegal and that you have to be in your hearing room when the presiding administrative law judge calls your case, or they’ll conduct an inquest without you.
What we are reading elsewhere…

Updated, 4:53 p.m. | Michael J. Garcia has been the United States attorney for the Southern District of New York since 2003, but has generally kept a far lower profile than, say, one of his predecessors, Rudolph W. Giuliani, who held the same job in the 1980s. But today Mr. Garcia stood in front of the television cameras for a major indictment: that of Bernard B. Kerik, the former New York City police commissioner, on charges of conspiracy, tax evasion and making false statements.

Do you think this will be a good year for holiday sales? Don't bet on it.
A Soviet sculpture park in Lithuania stirs old fears of an increasingly hostile neighbor.
As Russia rises, pervasive fears spread across Baltic countries.

The credit market troubles that swamped financial stocks this week have given rise to all sorts of speculation. Among them was a report by The New York Post that AQR Capital Management, a hedge fund known for its quantitative trading strategies, had shelved its plans for an initial public offering after poor performance.
Fred D. Thompson today rolled out his 401(k)-style proposal to the nation's looming Social Security problem, becoming the first Republican candidate to detail such an overhaul.

After the FIA summons yesterday of the Renault team to answer charges of possessing McLaren data and breaking Article 151c of the International Sporting Code, Renault today responded in a team statement. The statement goes into very welcome detail about precisely what happened, and I am going to do the same by simply pasting in the full statement below. It's worth asking just how much this scenario differs from that of the McLaren/Ferrari spy scandal, and I expect that will fuel many a debate until the FIA World Council meeting on Dec. 6....

LOS ANGELES -- Several thousand striking writers and their supporters turned out Friday morning for a rally near the Fox Studio in Los Angeles, the largest gathering yet in the five-day-old strike by the Writers Guild of America against television and film producers.
Here they are -- from your friendly neighborhood "Fantasy Fanboy Looser [sic]," which is what one poster on a sports journalism message board called me recently -- your weekly Gems and Gimps.

It's time for another round of picks from our fearless prognosticators. As our colleague Fred Bierman said when running down this weekend's matchups, on paper it doesn't look as if Saturday has too many games that will be of tremendous interest. We've made the mistake of thinking that before. This season's been wacky and it will only get wackier. So, on to the picks:
In terms of campaign '08, this week has been the week of the great religious-right fallout.

The opinion editors and writers of The Wichita Eagle have chosen a novel format -- Web video -- to strike back at the coal company and utility that paid for ads in The Eagle and other Kansas newspapers this week attacking Gov. Kathleen Sebelius for denying permits for two coal-burning power plants.

Comedy Central has scheduled three weeks of "theme week" repeats for "The Daily Show with Jon Stewart" and "The Colbert Report" with Stephen Colbert, as the writers for both shows conclude their first week on the picket lines.
From Iowa, where the caucuses are only 55 days away, Jeff Zeleny writes in his Web column today that for many Democratic voters, a single question is starting to replace all others: Why you?

Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has a new television ad offering the bare outlines of her energy plan, which she promises would create millions of new jobs and reduce the United States' dependence on foreign oil.
Many thanks for all of the comments about the kitchen, and especially to Susan Serra, who was kind enough to draw several alternative plans.

The Writers Guild of America is demanding an increase in pay for movies and television shows released on DVD. Perhaps ironically, a long strike could benefit DVD retailers like Blockbuster and Netflix, as television viewers choose to watch past seasons of scripted shows.
A presidential candidate with big dreams, but slim chances of winning, bases his campaign on a radical platform of health care reform -- Sound familiar?

ESPN's College Gameday will be at Williams-Amherst this weekend, probably because on paper this seems like a light weekend with Georgia-Auburn as the only matchup featuring two ranked teams. Still, some games have the markings of upset specials. Is Ohio State going to get knocked off by Illinois? Will Kansas sustain its first loss to Oklahoma State? Will Fresno State keep Hawaii out of a B.C.S. game? Will anyone stay up late to find out? Mark my words, something ridiculous is going to happen this weekend if only because it seems like nothing interesting will.

Thursday's crossover stunt linking popular crime procedurals "CSI" and "Without a Trace" proved to be a ratings windfall for CBS. According to Nielsen's estimates, 21.9 million viewers tuned in to "CSI" at 9 p.m., the show's largest audience since its September premiere. Likewise, following it, "Without a Trace" (21.4 million) delivered CBS's best ratings in the 10 p.m. time slot in almost two years.

Representative H. James Saxton, a 12-term New Jersey Republican, announced today that he would retire after next year rather than seek re-election. Mr. Saxton, who has been under attack by Democrats in recent weeks because of his opposition to the expansion of a children's health insurance program, is the 14th Republican this year to announce retirement from the House.
For Alexis Louise Luongo and Scott David Litman, the third attempt at their relationship proved to be charmed.
Amid the steady drumbeat of investment banks' announcements of incremental losses, investors are struggling to understand just how serious the subprime mortgage meltdown really is.

This week, prosecutors in Italy celebrated a key moment in their struggle against the Sicilian mafia, also known as Cosa Nostra: By arresting Salvatore Lo Piccolo, who was set to be the next "boss of bosses," they effectively decapitated the group. Alas, there is another mafia left to fight in the country, and it can't be defeated that way, according to an Italian prosecutor interviewed last year by Britain's Guardian:

Over the last four years, the chef Laurent Tourondel seems to have tapped into the restaurant zeitgeist as well as any New York chef. His BLT restaurants --- BLT Steak, BLT Fish, BLT Prime, BLT Burger, BLT Market --- are gobbling up the city, and they're being exported to D.C., to Las Vegas, probably in due time to Mars.

"The Web has given angry and vitriolic people more of a voice in public discourse," former top Bush aide Karl Rove told an audience yesterday, according to The Washington Times's Fishwrap blog. Rove observes: "People in the past who have been on the nutty fringe of political life, who were more or less voiceless, have now been given an inexpensive and easily accessible soapbox, a blog."

Today Cadillac announced the 2008 Escalade will offer a hybrid version that manages about 25 percent better fuel economy than the non-hybrid 'Slade, which means that by next summer we can expect to see MTV Cribs episodes with the following dialogue: "Welcome to my crib... Here in the garage we have my Escalade. I've got the 34-inch cubic zirconium rims, a fireplace in the back, and instead of a hood ornament, I've got a projector that puts a life-size hologram of me dressed like Superman up there on the hood. I've got some ostrich-skin seats on order, but they're not in yet because it takes a long time to get them the right shade of purple so they don't clash with the chandelier. Oh, and this is a hybrid, too, because I find conspicuous consumption vulgar."

Art investments are risky business, if what happened this week at Sotheby's in New York is any indication. On Wednesday, an art auction crashed and burned when five of 26 lots went unsold and another 10 sold at prices below the minimum bids that Sotheby's had set. In the wake of that debacle, Sotheby's stock took a record 35 percent plunge.

Readers of my academic work on economic geography may know that the carpet industry of northern Georgia is famous among geographers as a classic example of how regional clusters arise: a teenage girl made a tufted bedspread as a wedding gift in 1895, and through a series of linkages this led to Dalton, GA becoming the center of the US carpet industry.
