From last December:

Guy Morriss is reportedly out as Baylor's coach, according to both the Houston Chronicle and the Dallas Morning News, and the former Baylor linebacker and N.F.L. Hall of Famer Mike Singletary is considered a front-runner for the job.

Yesterday, European meteorologists saw bad trouble coming: Strong storm winds would soon be blowing southeastward down the North Sea at a time of peak high tides, and could shove enough seawater into the narrow end of a natural funnel of shorelines to cause serious flooding in low-lying areas of Britain and the Netherlands.

Rio Tinto's rejection of a $140 billion all-share offer from BHP Billiton is likely to trigger rival bids from resource companies awash with cash from record commodity and stock prices, analysts said.
Wall Street has been contemplating a successor to Charles O. Prince III almost since he took over as Citigroup's chief executive four years ago. Now the job is actually open.

Many new words and phrases have been added this year to the everyday lexicon of finance: subprime mortgages, collateralized debt obligations, structured investment vehicles and the ABX index. More recently, "Help Wanted: Wall Street C.E.O." has joined the list.

Wachovia, the fourth-largest U.S. bank, set aside as much as $600 million for loan losses in the fourth quarter and said the value of some debt securities fell by about $1.1 billion before tax in October.
As Citigroup searches for a new leader mid a series of staggering losses, many investors have clamored for another potential solution to the bank's woes. A breakup.
It's Friday, and that means it's time to share some of the places I've been wasting spending time online lately. Here are a few:
Restoration Hardware, the California-based home-furnishings chain, agreed to be acquired by buyout firm Catterton Partners for $267 million.

"Mr. Nice Guy" Mike Huckabee is the man du jour on the pages of The Times and the Los Angeles Times. Our Michael Luo reports that Mr. Huckabee's campaign recently has celebrated small milestones, like increased fund-raising, higher Web traffic and its first endorsement from a Christian leader, Rev. Donald E. Wildmon.

Update: Clear Channel confirmed in a public filing Friday that Providence is considering its options in the TV stations deal, including withdrawing from it altogether. Clear Channel reiterated that no development would affect its own buyout.
The former chief financial officer of the Safety-Kleen hazardous waste disposal company was sentenced Thursday to 5 years and 10 months in prison after admitting to securities and bank fraud charges.
Total write-downs of collateralized debt obligations at Wall Street investment banks will probably climb to $64 billion, according to research by the global markets unit of Citigroup.

Conrad Black denied reports that he would seek to serve his prison sentence in a British jail, which would likely let him out on parole earlier than a U.S. facility, The New York Post reported Friday.
Singapore Airlines and Temasek have signed a definitive deal to buy a 24 percent stake in China Eastern Airlines for 7.16 billion Hong Kong dollars ($921 million), China Eastern said on Friday.

Disk storage technology developer ExaGrid Systems raised $20 million in a Series C funding round, with new investor Lehman Brothers Venture Partners leading the deal alongside patient existing investors Sigma Partners and Highland Capital Partners, which had previously pumped $45 million into the five-year-old Westborough, Mass.-based company.
Julius Baer, Switzerland's third-largest private bank, plans to sell its U.S. fund unit early next year in an initial public offering, Bloomberg News reported.
Quest Energy Partners, an Oklahoma City-based oil and gas exploration company, raised $163.8 million on Thursday with an initial public offering that priced below expectations.

American Public Education raised $94 million on Thursday with an initial public offering that priced above expectations. The 4.7 million share-offering priced at $20 per share, compared with a forecast range of $18 to $19, which had been raised from $15 to $17, an underwriter told Reuters.
HSBC, the British bank, said it had stopped sales and trading of mortgage-backed securities in the United States after the collapse of the subprime market forced it to close two lending units.
Hours before a scheduled rally, police blocked access to the street of former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, where they fought off demonstrators.
Affiliated Managers Group, which already holds a significant stake in hedge fund AQR Capital Management, said Thursday it will invest in ValueAct Capital, another well-known hedge fund.
Like all chief executives on Wall Street, John J. Mack has grappled with the question of who will succeed him.

Clifford Chance has come out as the first British firm to hand out a one-off bonus of up to $50,000 to U.S. associates, as the New York pay war gathers steam. Clifford Chance said it will offer the firm's New York-based associates a special bonus ranging from $10,000 for first-years to $50,000 for senior associates.

China has announced the first strategic plans for its new $200 billion investment fund, saying two-thirds of its funds will be invested in Chinese state banks and it will avoid buying into foreign oil, airline or telephone companies.
Merrill Lynch has put its Merrill Lynch Capital lending unit on the block, and the second round of bids is dominated by private equity firms, The Deal.com reported.

Intel Capital, the venture capital arm of chip giant Intel, announced Thursday that it has injected $10 million into security company Iovation, which targets online fraud and abuse based on the identification and "reputation" of Net-enabled devices.

Valleywag reported Wednesday that Barry Diller's IAC/InterActiveCorp, in the midst of breaking up the company into five parts, was planning to take some time off that project to buy youth-oriented social-networking site MyYearbook.
A new survey on corporate board pay has come up with a surprising find: The median compensation for female directors is actually higher than that for male directors.

With buyers lined up to bid for its Land Rover and Jaguar brands, Ford Motor said Thursday that it had decided to keep Volvo, at least for now, and would make an effort to fix the money-losing Swedish carmaker.
Images from the library in North Carolina.
Fifty years from now, cars will want to be robots, at least according to the design challenge at this year’s Los Angeles auto show.
I love the reader interaction in blogs.
(We give this space over to one of our readers, who became a friend of the blog with his frequent comments last year. His bio is at the bottom)
Joe Torre, who is back in the publishing game, will play host to his annual "Safe At Home" Gala on Friday night at Chelsea Piers.
“War/Dance” is an honorable, sometimes inspiring exploration of the primal healing power of music and dance in an African tribal culture.
“Steal a Pencil for Me” recounts 93-year-old Holocaust survivor Jack Polak’s stint in Nazi camps.
The off-putting, sometimes dizzying visual style of “The Sacred Family” settles down enough to reveal elements of absorbing drama.
“Saawariya” is 2 hours 11 minutes  of wide-screen close-ups, fanciful sets, colorful costumes, bellybuttons, almost-kisses and 10 pumped-up, achingly sweet songs.
Swift and stealthy “P2” is a canny exploitation of one of the urban woman’s greatest fears: the after-hours parking garage.
Career Politicians, the Fourth Estate and Disaffected Youth all earn a stern knuckle rapping in “Lions for Lambs.”
There’s a riveting story lurking inside “Holly.” It’s just not the one the filmmakers want to tell.
“Fred Claus” is a tacky would-be comedy about family dysfunction that fronts some Scrooge attitude only to dissolve into slobbering sentimentality and canned uplift.
For formalists — those moviegoers sent into raptures by tight editing, nimble camera work and faultless sound design — “No Country for Old Men” is pure heaven.
“Cocalero,” Alejandro Landes’s documentary about the presidential campaign of Evo Morales in Bolivia, seems to mirror the campaign itself: ragged and bare-bones.
“Choking Man” is harsh and intermittently affecting but oppressively contrived and mostly pointless.
The new musical from Mel Brooks has a high density of talent, but feels less like a sustained book musical than an overblown burlesque revue.
Stagehands plan to strike against theater owners and producers, according to two people briefed on the decision.
Michael B. Mukasey took the oath at the Justice Department less than a day after winning confirmation.
Beyond the issues, for many Democratic voters, a single question is starting to replace all others.
The auction house owner who arranged a confrontation between O. J. Simpson and two memorabilia dealers said that Mr. Simpson may not have known two of the men with him had guns.
Wachovia said it planned to increase its reserves for loan losses in the fourth quarter, while Barclays of London denied speculation that it is facing a huge write-down.
The former police commissioner faces charges of tax fraud, obstruction of justice and lying to the White House.
Linda Stein’s assistant bludgeoned her because she swore at her and blew marijuana smoke at her face, police said.
Another large bank said it would write down the value of some of its assets, reigniting fears of a credit squeeze.
The settlement, one of the largest ever in civil litigation, affects 27,000 lawsuits over the pain medication.
Myanmar’s pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi met with members of her party for the first time in three years amid signs that a political deadlock may be easing.
The surprise announcement appeared to be an effort to alleviate the domestic unrest and international concern after police action in Tbilisi.
Merck has agreed to settle 27,000 lawsuits by people who claim they or their family members suffered injury or died after taking the pain medication.
Michael B. Mukasey was confirmed despite Democratic criticism of his position on interrogation methods.

Taylor Twellman’s acrobatic goal last night put the New England Revolution in the Major League Soccer championship game for the third consecutive year. Twellman, third among the league’s career goal scorers, converted a bicycle kick between two defenders in the 38th minute, giving the Revolution a 1-0 win over the Chicago Fire in the Eastern Conference title game. The Revolution advanced to the M.L.S. Cup on Nov. 18 in Washington against the winner of tomorrow night’s Western Conference final between the Houston Dynamo and the Kansas City Wizards.
China asked Iran on Thursday to “respond positively” to international pressures to limit its nuclear program, a possible sign that China is responding to American demands.

A woman who mistakenly drove her car onto the railroad tracks on Long Island last night was rescued from an oncoming train by a couple who plucked her from harm’s way with the crossing gates down, alarm bells ringing and red lights flashing, the police said.
The stagehands’ union received strike authorization from its parent union and appeared to be on the verge of a walkout.
Richard Jefferson scored 25 points, including two game-winning free throws with 24 seconds to play, to lead New Jersey.

Charges have been dropped against a couple at the center of the Albany County district attorney’s investigation into illegal steroid sales, the couple’s lawyers said yesterday. The two, Steven and Karen Lampert of Anti-Aging Centers in Nanuet, N.Y., were accused in March of submitting prescriptions to a Florida pharmacy for drugs totaling more than $50,000 for people without a medical need for them. Mr. Lampert’s lawyer, Jonathan Ripps, released a court document dated Oct. 26 indicating that a judge had signed off on the prosecution’s dismissal of the charges, “based on lack of jurisdiction.” The Albany district attorney’s office said the other 14 pending cases in the investigation were not threatened. Christopher Baynes, an assistant district attorney, said the Lampert case had been referred to prosecutors in Rockland County.

A driver who drunkenly mistook a bike path for the West Side Highway last December and fatally struck a cyclist pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree manslaughter in State Supreme Court. The man, Eugenio Cidron, 28, pleaded guilty in exchange for a sentence of 3 ½ to 10 ½ years in prison. If Mr. Cidron had been tried and convicted, he would have faced a sentence of 5 to 15 years. Sentencing is scheduled for Jan. 3. Mr. Cidron was allowed to remain free on $150,000 bail, secured by his mother-in-law’s home. Mr. Cidron hit Eric Ng on the night of Dec. 1, 2006, near the intersection of West and Clarkson Streets. Mr. Ng, 22, was pronounced dead at the scene.
Cephalon Inc., the maker of sleep and pain drugs, said that it would pay $425 million to settle a federal investigation into its sales and marketing practices.

California sued the Environmental Protection Agency to force it to decide immediately on the state’s application to impose strict limits on emissions of heat-trapping gases from cars and light trucks.
Two senators, motivated by a bus crash that killed five college baseball players, proposed requiring seat belts on long-haul buses.

A state appeals court ordered a new trial for a former Wisconsin Assembly speaker convicted of directing staff members to conduct campaign work on state time. The former speaker, Scott Jensen, left, was sentenced to 15 months in prison but has remained free on bail while he appeals. The Fourth District Court of Appeals ruled that the trial judge erroneously excluded Mr. Jensen’s testimony about his understanding of the use of state resources for campaigns by other legislators. The appeals court also found that a jury instruction was improper. Mr. Jensen, a 47-year-old Republican, was convicted of directing taxpayer-financed aides to campaign for Assembly Republicans on state time during the 1998 and 2000 election cycles.
A judge rejected a motion to dismiss juvenile charges against a teenager at the center of a civil rights controversy.
Juan Luis Guerra, a songwriter from the Dominican Republic, was the big winner at the eighth annual Latin Grammy Awards for “La Llave de Mi Corazón.”
Pat White scored on a 50-yard run with 1 minute 36 seconds remaining to lift No. 6 West Virginia to a 38-31 victory.
Commissioner David Stern warned Thursday that if the SuperSonics leave Seattle he sees no way the league would ever return to the city.
Rookie center Brandon Dubinsky scored his first N.H.L. goal and forward Sean Avery scored his first goal of the season to lead the Rangers.
The president of Bard College has joined the chorus of criticism over the City Department of Education’s blunt new A through F rating system for public schools.
Two London-based investment companies and their British owner have agreed to pay a total of about $1.8 million to settle a lawsuit that said they illegally covered short sales.

The Japanese brewer Kirin Holdings will buy an Australian dairy and juice producer, National Foods, for $1 billion from a Philippine partner, the San Miguel Corporation, in its latest move to battle stagnating beer sales.
Siemens posted its first quarterly loss since 2001 as it raised to 1.3 billion euros ($1.91 billion) the amount involved in questionable payments that have prompted several corruption investigations.
Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, an Italian bank, agreed to buy Banca Antonveneta from Banco Santander of Spain for 9 billion euros ($13.2 billion) to increase its branch network by 50 percent.
Enel, the Italian utility, said third-quarter profit rose 5.1 percent as international units sold more power.
Five American soldiers were killed and seven wounded after an Army Black Hawk helicopter crashed outside Treviso, Italy.

Insurgents dragged the bodies of dead Ethiopian soldiers through the streets of the capital Mogadishu after another flare-up of fighting that killed at least 21 people and sent thousands fleeing the volatile city.
Prosecutors charged Andrzej Lepper, a former deputy premier, with soliciting sex from two women in exchange for political jobs.
Tony Blair was paid $500,000 for a 20-minute speech during a three-hour trip to a luxury housing development in southern Dongguan on Tuesday, Chinese newspapers reported.
Paris Métro workers announced that they would join strikes on Wednesday protesting President Nicolas Sarkozy’s plans to cut special retirement benefits for some state workers.

Switzerland’s highest court ordered the immediate release of a Russian imprisoned since 2004 for killing an air-traffic controller he blamed for the deaths of his wife and two children in a midair collision over Germany in 2002.

Samina Malik, a 23-year-old British-born woman who prosecutors said posted her poems on Web sites under the screen name Lyrical Terrorist, became the first woman to be convicted under the Terrorism Act.
Eric Lindros, a 6-foot-4, 240-pound center, had 372 goals, 865 points and 1,398 penalty minutes in 760 games for Philadelphia, Toronto, the Rangers and Dallas.
How much has the Giants’ defense changed since it was exploited by the Dallas Cowboys in a 45-35 season-opening loss? It depends on whom you ask.
The Scarlet Knights open their season at home Friday, a game that will serve as the debut of freshman Corey Chandler, Rutgers’s first major recruit under coach Fred Hill.
Unlike past oil shocks caused by interruptions in exports, this time prices are being driven by growing demand.
One solution would be some form of universal health coverage for all Americans. Then uninsured veterans could get the care they need.
Regardless of the outcome of the Hollywood writers’ strike, we implore the networks not to let reality TV intrude further upon our free time.
The Senate should pass a bill to outlaw discrimination in employment based on sexual orientation, and President Bush should sign it into law.
Nearly half the Democrats in the House supported a trade deal with Peru, reopening a party fissure on trade policy.
Congress will need to flesh out the Bush administration’s vague plans with sufficient resources to protect the public from unsafe foods and products.
Staff Sgt. Michael A. Hensley was found guilty of wrongfully placing an AK-47 rifle with the remains of one of the three men and of showing disrespect for a superior officer.

Paula Creamer birdied the final seven holes for a share of the first-round lead with Meg Mallon in the Tournament of Champions in Mobile, Ala., ending Suzann Pettersen’s run at the top of the leader board at six rounds. Creamer and Mallon shot five-under 67s, leaving them two strokes ahead of Pettersen, Natalie Gulbis, Pat Hurst, Mi Hyun Kim and Seon Hwa Lee. Pettersen was coming off consecutive victories in South Korea and Thailand, and has won three of her last four starts.
With George Mitchell’s investigation into drug use looming over Major League Baseball, player agents were informed that up to 11 players who are now free agents could be named.

Bora Milutinovic, who coached five teams to the World Cup finals, was fired as coach and technical director by the Jamaica Football Federation. The federation informed the Serbian-born Milutinovic on Wednesday that it was firing him for breach of contract. A statement from the federation did not elaborate, and calls to the federation were not immediately returned.Milutinovic took over as the coach and the technical director of Jamaica’s program last November and led the team to the Lunar Cup title earlier this year. But Jamaica has not played since July and has fallen in the FIFA world rankings to 103.

Ruud Gullit, once one of the best players in the world, has been hired to coach the Los Angeles Galaxy. Gullit, a 45-year-old Dutchman, will succeed Frank Yallop, who quit as coach of the David Beckham-led Galaxy on Monday to return to San Jose for a second stint with the Earthquakes. Gullit, born in Amsterdam, was a star striker on the standout Dutch national team that won the 1988 European Championship. He has spent the past two years as a television analyst.

The University of Louisville has filed a lawsuit against Duke claiming breach of contract after the Blue Devils opted out of the final three games of a four-game series. The programs were to meet four times between 2002 and 2009. Louisville beat the Blue Devils, 40-3, in September 2002, but Duke opted out of the final three games that were to be played this season, 2008 and 2009.

Oklahoma State suspended linebacker Chris Collins Jr. for the rest of the season yesterday after he pleaded guilty to a felony aggravated sexual assault charge. A jury Wednesday in New Boston, Tex., recommended five years of probation for Collins, who pleaded guilty Tuesday to the aggravated sexual assault of a 12-year-old girl. He is to be sentenced Dec. 10.

Bayern Munich allowed a late goal yesterday and settled for a 2-2 tie with visiting Bolton in the UEFA Cup group stage. Other winners were Tottenham, Everton, Panathinaikos, Villareal, Fiorentina, Spartak Moscow, Sparta Prague, Bordeaux, Zenit St. Petersburg and Helsingborg. Red Star Belgrade, the 1991 European champion, lost to Aris of Greece, 3-0.
Civil rights groups say that a plan to create a map detailing the Muslim communities in Los Angeles is no better than racial profiling.
Ben S. Bernanke told Congress that the economy is going to get worse before it gets better, a message that got a chilly reception from both Wall Street and politicians.
There are signs that Mike Huckabee is working his way from a long shot to a possible contender in Iowa’s caucuses.

A headline yesterday with an article about discussions between Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates and South Korea’s minister of national defense, Kim Jang-soo, misattributed a comment about North Korea in some copies. It was Mr. Kim who said that North Korea remains a military threat — not Mr. Gates, who said that much work remained to make certain that North Korea had surrendered its nuclear weapons and its weapons development programs.

An article on Saturday about federal charges of sexual misconduct against a Jesuit priest, the Rev. Donald J. McGuire, referred incorrectly to the response of the Archbishop of Chicago, Cardinal Francis George, to allegations involving Father McGuire. Cardinal George reported the allegations, some of which were known to the church in 1979, to the authorities in 2003 and revoked Father McGuire’s priestly faculties; Cardinal George did not fail to report the allegations.
At baseball’s winter meeting next month, Johan Santana of the Minnesota Twins is expected to be dangled, and the Yankees will move aggressively to get him.
The violence in the Niger Delta that has been aimed largely at foreign oil companies has begun to turn inward.
Congress approved legislation that would require the federal government to lend billions of dollars to states to help pay for damage to homes and businesses caused by natural disasters.
The nation’s big retail chains reported the weakest October in 12 years, blaming economic clouds that show no signs of lifting before the end of the year.
Detroit is a surprising 6-2 this season, but some fans, accustomed to years of losing, are suspending judgment on the team’s prospects for success.
Nothing delights New York car owners more than a religious holiday, any religious holiday that liberates them from the city’s alternate-side parking rules.
Mets General Manager Omar Minaya left Orlando, Fla., with no more than he arrived with. But he said, “There have been some productive talks to follow up on.”
The Bush administration has cited accusations that rape was employed by soldiers and militia members as a tactic for intimidation and warfare, notably in Sudan and Myanmar.
ALBANY, Nov. 8 (AP) — Charges were dropped against two defendants in the Albany County district attorney’s multistate investigation into illegal steroid sales, their lawyers said on Thursday.
A South Korean container ship hit one of the stanchions of the Bay Bridge in a dense fog on Wednesday, spilling 58,000 gallons of bunker oil.
The chief executive of the luxury home builder Toll Brothers said he fears that the housing market will not get better until the newspapers stop saying how bad it is.
At least two major television studios have sent breach-of-contract letters to show runners who have stopped performing their production duties once they went on strike with other television writers.
A brother of an orthodontist who was shot dead on a Queens playground last month testified in Family Court yesterday that his family had been threatened by the mother of his brother’s estranged wife.

In New Jersey, supporters of a failed $450 million bond issue for stem cell research say that they were undone by spending too little time and money trying to defeat a coalition of well-organized opponents.
The president of Georgia, Mikheil Saakashvili, on Thursday called for a special presidential election on Jan. 5, saying he would test whether he retained a mandate.
The Senate dealt President Bush the first veto override of his presidency, with a resounding bipartisan vote to adopt a water bill.
Jean-Claude Trichet’s remarks reflect concerns that the euro’s ascent against the dollar is making life harder for European businesses.

ALBANY, Nov. 8 — Lawyers for Gov. Eliot Spitzer asked a state court on Thursday to quash subpoenas from the State Senate seeking information on efforts by the governor’s aides to discredit Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader. They did so claiming a constitutional privilege to shield the information from disclosure.
An installation involving 30 dead sheep, one dead shark and 300 sausages by the British artist Damien Hirst will be unveiled in the lobby of Lever House.
On the second day of his war crimes trial, Vojislav Seselj, a radical nationalist, lectured the court on Serbian linguistics and told his judges they were paid not to think.
The Bloomberg administration said that the termination of its contract with the developer hired to build a championship golf course in the east Bronx had prompted an additional $7 million payment.
Nipping at the heels of various companies using biological methods to develop fuels from plant matter is a new group of entrepreneurs who favor chemistry.

Gardner-Webb, a Baptist college in the heart of the Bible Belt, did its best Appalachian State impression when it upset No. 20 Kentucky Wednesday, thrusting itself into the college basketball spotlight.
Hopes for a market rebound dimmed today as shares stayed in the red, extending yesterday’s 360-point swoon, with technology shares falling hardest of all.
The Walt Disney Company reported a 12 percent rise in quarterly net income largely from strong gains at ESPN.
High levels of carcinogens and toxic substances have been found in fish, water and sediment downstream from Alberta’s huge oil sands projects.
Defense lawyers say that the tactics used by military  prosecutors in Guantánamo show that the cases are unfairly stacked against detainees.
Total write-downs of collateralized debt obligations at Wall Street investment banks will probably climb to $64 billion, according to research by Citigroup.
The C.E.O. of the Airbus parent warned that widening losses and the eroding value of the dollar could force it to cut an additional one billion euros in operating costs.
Ms. Dainton, born in southern England, in 1911, was too young to remember the night when the huge liner hit an iceberg and sank in the Atlantic on April 14 and 15.

A lawsuit charges that inadequate funding, poor oversight and lack of statewide standards deny New Yorkers accused of crimes their right to competent representation at all stages of the judicial process.
Amgen and Johnson & Johnson strengthened the label warnings for their anemia drugs, placing further emphasis on the risk of heart attacks, a worsening of cancer and death.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s proposal could create a standoff with a shopping center developer who said he had spent over $120 million buying 10 acres in the heart of Coney Island’s frayed amusement district.
Scientists say they now have evidence that ultrahigh-energy cosmic rays come from supermassive black holes that rumble at the hearts of many galaxies.
The Massachusetts legislature gave final approval Thursday to a bill that requires protesters to stand at least 35 feet from clinics that offer abortions.
Congressional Democrats offered $50 billion in interim spending for combat operations coupled to a goal of pulling out most troops from Iraq within a year.
Last changed in 1978, the standards cover everything from how thousands of city inmates are housed to what they wear and how their mail is delivered.
The Labor Department faced questioning from a Senate committee on Thursday about its efforts to help reservists who have been denied their civilian jobs when they returned from active duty.
Rio Tinto, the London- and Melbourne-based mining company, rejected a $140 billion bid Thursday from its rival, BHP Billiton — calling it too low.

A Manhattan judge scheduled a hearing for this afternoon that could determine whether Shawn Kovell, who was arrested on drug charges last month with Robert E. Chambers Jr., the “preppy killer,” will be released on bail. The judge acted yesterday, a day after Randy Credico, a comedian who advocates easing penalties for drug use, posted $25,000 cash bail for Ms. Kovell. Prosecutors demanded tax returns and other documents yesterday to determine the source of the money and to ensure that it was not derived from criminal activity. Mr. Credico said he would testify that the bail had come from the sale of land he owned upstate.
A senior Israeli legislator is lobbying the U.S. Senate to freeze $200 million in military aid to Egypt unless it does more to stop the smuggling of arms into the Gaza Strip.
The story of how a yellow submarine ended up marooned off the Brooklyn shoreline starts with an ambitious plan that was derailed in a matter of hours 37 years ago.
For the thousands of Americans who jumped into the raging housing market of the last decade, the crash happened fast.
The Federal Reserve Board has approved the application by the sixth-largest Chinese bank to open an office in New York, its first branch in the United States.
The Knicks are off to a good start this season, winning their first two games at home for the first time since 2001. And their tickets sales have been positive, too.
A documentary about the Falun Gong spiritual sect was withdrawn by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation after protests from Chinese diplomats in Canada.
Ford Motor said Thursday that it had decided to keep Volvo, at least for now, and would make an effort to fix the money-losing Swedish carmaker.
Qualcomm posted a higher quarterly profit as revenue rose, but a disappointing outlook sent its shares down 7 percent in after-hours trading.
HSBC said it had stopped sales and trading of mortgage-backed securities in the U.S. after the collapse of the subprime market forced it to close two lending units.

A state judge refused  to allow the Transport Workers Union to begin automatically collecting dues again from its members, saying he did believe the union leaders’ assertions that it would not strike again.
Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign introduced a Web site dedicated exclusively to the instantaneous rebuttal of charges or news reports.
The agreement with Syria, which is home to 1.2 million to 1.4 million Iraqi refugees, cleared a major obstacle to the Bush administration’s resettlement program.
Cablevision reported a wider net loss for the third quarter, but operating income rose 59 percent as high-speed Internet and digital phone services subscriptions grew.
Running back Larry Johnson’s injured right foot “has made significant improvement,” the Kansas City Chiefs said yesterday.
The former C.F.O. of the Safety-Kleen hazardous waste disposal firm was sentenced to nearly 6 years in prison after admitting to securities and bank fraud charges.
Le Meridien, the hotel chain, would like to be viewed as a haven for hipsters and other creative types, rather than as a faceless stopover for European business travelers.
Ms. Cooper’s work explored women’s struggle to maintain meaningful artistic lives in postwar America — or in fact in the America of any era.
Mr. Kernochan was a leading professor of copyright law and the founder of the Kernochan Center for Law, Media and the Arts at Columbia University.
House Republicans have begun to push bills opposing the plan of Gov. Eliot Spitzer of New York to grant driver’s licenses to illegal immigrants, seeking to step up pressure on Democrats.
The settlement is one of the largest individual awards made by a Catholic diocese to a victim of sexual abuse by clergy members.
Allan Cameron was sentenced Thursday to life in prison with no chance of parole for murdering a police officer during a car chase in 2005 in Flatbush.
Mr. Lerner was the first director of the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, the repository that includes works by Picasso, Rodin, Matisse and Mondrian.
Shares of Sotheby’s fell 28 percent Thursday, a day after sales figures painted a lackluster picture that prompted fears of a slowdown in the art market.
Elaine S. Charnov is the maestro behind the estimable Margaret Mead Video and Film Festival at the Museum of Natural History.
Pedestrians are demanding their rights be recognized in Athens, which has the highest per capita car ownership in the European Union.
The Republican Party said it would deprive the states of half their delegates to the national convention because they planned to hold their nominating contests earlier than the party’s rules allow.
A new advertisement for Representative Ron Paul, Republican of Texas, is part of his first major television campaign, at a total cost of $1.1 million.

The state’s labor commissioner, M. Patricia Smith, announced yesterday that she was suspending the certificates of 129 crane operators after learning that licenses were issued to individuals who had failed the crane operators’ exam. She said that the state inspector general, Kristine Hamann, had recently notified the department that the operators’ certificates had been improperly issued from 1972 to 2000. “This is a public safety issue,” Ms. Smith said, adding that the Labor Department was urging the crane operators to retake the practical exam or have their licenses revoked. The Labor Department is checking 3,000 crane operators in the state to determine if their certifications were based on a passing score.

A man arrested after a police chase in Hempstead on Oct. 16 intends to file a lawsuit against the Nassau County police, claiming officers beat him and used racial epithets, his lawyer said yesterday. The man, William Byrd, 36, of Hempstead, was arrested after the police spotted him driving a car that had been reported stolen. When officers approached, the police said, Mr. Byrd drove off, dragging one officer about 10 feet. Mr. Byrd, who has been charged with assault and grand larceny, said police officers beat him after the arrest. The police said the department was investigating Mr. Byrd’s claims.

Republicans in the New Jersey Senate shuffled their leadership yesterday, replacing Leonard Lance, the minority leader of four years, with Thomas H. Kean Jr., one of the party’s youngest and most visible figures. The choice of Mr. Kean was said to be unanimous. Mr. Kean made an unsuccessful run for the United States Senate last year against Robert Menendez. The Democrats’ new Senate majority leader, Stephen M. Sweeney, said yesterday that he expected to work more closely with Republicans now that Mr. Kean was the minority leader. Compiled by John Sullivan.

A special prosecutor was appointed yesterday to pursue perjury charges against a witness whose testimony derailed the murder trial of a former F.B.I. supervisor. The prosecutor, Leslie Crocker Snyder, left, a former Court of Claims judge, was appointed by the administrative judge for State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, Neil Jon Firetog. The Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, requested the appointment to avoid “the appearance of impropriety.” His office had built its murder case against the F.B.I. supervisor, Roy Lindley DeVecchio, on the testimony of Linda Schiro, a gangster’s mistress, who testified that Mr. DeVecchio had ordered Mafia killings in the 1980s and early ’90s. Her testimony was abruptly halted last week when a Village Voice reporter revealed recorded interviews of Ms. Schiro from years ago that contradicted her recent account. The murder charges against Mr. DeVecchio were dismissed.

The police arrested a man yesterday who is suspected of robbing 18 banks in Manhattan and the Bronx over the past year and a half. They identified the man as Farid Abdul-Ali, 52, of the Bronx. The police said they tracked him down based on a tip given to the Crimestoppers hot line. Mr. Abdul-Ali was awaiting arraignment in Criminal Court in Manhattan yesterday afternoon.

Police officers using bomb-sniffing dogs to search an airplane at La Guardia Airport after a bomb alert yesterday found no bomb. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said that the plane, American Airlines Flight 382 from Chicago, landed safely and that 117 passengers and 5 crew members were taken off the plane before the search. The Police Department was alerted by a caller who said he had seen information on the Internet indicating there was a bomb on the flight.

The only survivor of a fiery collision that killed two people on the Bronx River Parkway on Wednesday afternoon was charged yesterday with driving while impaired by drugs, the police said. The man, Justin Martinez, 19, was arrested because he failed a sobriety test at the scene, said Kieran O’Leary, a spokesman for the Westchester County police. The cause of the crash was still under investigation yesterday, Mr. O’Leary said. The crash between Mr. Martinez’s Honda and a Cadillac sent the Cadillac off the parkway and into a tree, where it burst into flames. A man and woman in the Cadillac were killed. The police were trying to identify them yesterday.

Nine people were arrested and more than $10,000 in cash was seized in gambling raids in Suffolk County on Wednesday night, prosecutors said. The raids, at eight locations, followed a robbery at an illegal poker game in Lindenhurst in September, said Thomas J. Spota, the Suffolk County district attorney. In a statement, Mr. Spota said the robbery, by two men carrying shotguns, demonstrated the potential danger of high-stakes poker games. He said that the games attracted violence, and that “law enforcement is concerned about the safety of the innocent people in the neighborhoods.”.
In six years at Wake Forest, coach Skip Prosser posted a 126-68 record, among other things. But months after his death, such success is not the only thing for which he will be remembered.

Because of Diwali, the Hindu festival of lights, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.
